headline: YUGOSLAVS CLOSE REGIONAL COLLEGE
abstract: The government of Yugoslavia's troubled Kosovo Province closed the provincial university and other schools of higher learning today after a demonstration by 1,000 students, who demanded that the province become a republic and unite with neighboring Albania, the press agency Tanyug said.   About 77 percent of Kosovo's population is ethnic Albanian and the province is autonomous within the Republic of Serbia.

headline: TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Administration proposed easing or eliminating 35 auto regulations governing air quality or safety in an effort to help the U.S. auto industry compete with Japanese imports. A Cabinet-level auto task force had considered tax and import relief as well but took no specific actions because of disagreements. The industry immediately hailed the regulatory changes. (Page A1.)   House Democrats proposed a $713.5 billion budget for fiscal year 1982, $4 billion less than President Reagan had requested. They also endorsed a smaller tax cut than proposed by the President, urged that the Administration's proposed $50.5 billion deficit be slashed to $24.6 billion and projected a balanced budget by fiscal 1983. (A1.)

headline: NABISCO MERGER CALLED KEY TO GROWTH
abstract: When Robert M. Schaeberle accounced the marriage last week of his company, Nabisco Inc., and Standard Brands Inc., he termed it ''a merger in every sense of the word.''   But, without elaboration, Nabisco's chairman and chief executive officer then added that both companies ''will maintain their separate identities,'' a notion that F. Ross Johnson, his counterpart at Standard Brands, seconded. Both organizations ''will remain intact,'' Mr. Johnson said.   That left management specialists wondering what Mr. Schaeberle and Mr. Johnson had in mind for Nabisco Brands Inc., the new successor company. Many, however, say that the intention is evident: to fashion a more efficient and streamined organization than either could build alone.

headline: Argentine Bank Sale
abstract: The Bank of America, the nation's largest, said the Argentine Government had given final approval to its purchase of the Banco Internacional S.A. of Argentina for $145 million. Bank of America said that Banco Internacional is Argentina's 16th-largest bank, having deposits of $337 million and 60 branches, most of them in the metropolitan Buenos Aires area.

headline: Company News; NEW HEAD OF T.V.A. IS NAMED
abstract: President Reagan today chose a Knoxville, Tenn., municipal utility executive to be chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a major and enduring artifact of the New Deal and the nation's largest generator of electricity.   Charles H. Dean Jr., 55 years old, general manager of the Knoxville Utilities Board, will replace S. David freeman, who will remain a member of the three-man T.V.A. board, which has its headquarters in Knoxville. It is the first time in the 48-year history of T.V.A. that a chairman has been demoted.

headline: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Careers; Business Training In a Hurry
abstract: FOR liberal arts graduates who need a quick grasp of business knowledge to get or hold a job, the Graduate School of Management at Rutgers University, in Newark, plans to offer three courses, each requiring three consecutive days of intensive study.   Edward W. Smykay, director of the management development program for Rutgers, described the purpose of the new program, which starts next fall. ''We're trying to develop business capability in the shortest possible time,'' he said.   The three-day duration of the noncredit courses ''is no magic number,'' Dr. Smykay added, and it might be changed to four days or more if experience proves more time is worthwhile. ''We are trying to train, not educate,'' he said.

headline: WANTED: NEW ENGINEERS
abstract: As the college commencements play out the spring season, fresh evidence of what a degree is worth on today's job market is coming out. As in past years, new graduates with degrees in technical fields get more pay than those who majored in the liberal arts.

headline: Turkish Diplomat Is Wounded
abstract: Turkish diplomats said early today that one of their colleagues, whom they declined to identify, was shot and wounded last night at his home here by a group calling itself Justice for the Armenian People.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Corporation, Morris Township, N.J., has elected Nicholas A. Cameron a vice president.   * American Express Company, has appointed Stathis Andris vice president, investments.

headline: READER'S DIGEST AFTER WALLACE
abstract: The Reader's Digest, which has made a name for independence in the publishing business, says it has no intention of departing from that tradition following the death of its founder, DeWitt Wallace.   According to Edward T. Thompson, its editor in chief, while Mr.  Wallace was alive, the Digest periodically received overtures from would-be purchasers, but the Digest was never for sale. It is not now, either, Mr. Thompson said in response to a press query.

headline: HAIG FAVORS STAND AGAINST VIOLATIONS OF RIGHTS ABROAD
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that the United States should oppose human rights violations ''by ally or adversary.'' But, he said, it should be more critical of ''totalitarian'' regimes than of ''authoritarian'' ones.   ''The collapse of a bulwark against aggression, and the replacement of an au- Excerpts from the speech, page A6. thoritarian regime with a totalitarian one'' could produce ''the ultimate failure,'' Mr. Haig warned.

headline: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AIDE HINTS AT REAGAN TAX SHIFT
abstract: President Reagan, concerned by the unsettled condition of the financial markets, is prepared to accept less than the full amount of his proposed tax cut but wants the Democrats in Congress to make the first move toward compromise, a senior White House official said today.   In an interview, the official said Administration planners had become increasingly worried that the behavior of the markets would cause members of Congress to have second thoughts about voting for Mr. Reagan's tax program, despite the momentum created by the President's recent victories.   The official also said that recent disarray in the markets had shown some Reagan aides that Wall Street was afraid that tax cuts would widen the budget deficit, contributing to the fear of inflation. As a result, he said, the Administration was more willing to compromise on the size of the tax cut.   The Administration was also taking steps to make additional spending cuts this year as a way of convincing the markets that President Reagan was adamant about controlling deficits, he said. The decision to announce a series of Social Security cutbacks this week, he said, was in part spurred by the need to counter problems in the markets.

headline: WEINBERGER EXHORTS ALLIES TO SHARE BURDEN OF DEFENSE
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger turned a routine meeting today with Western Europe's Defense Ministers into a strong advertisement for the Reagan Administration's military policy, and he made it clear that the Europeans were expected to do their full share.   Senior American officials said Mr. Weinberger gave the Defense Ministers a graphic and detailed intelligence briefing on the Soviet military buildup in and around Poland and presented a sweeping analysis of the steady growth in Soviet nuclear and conventional arms.   On his first trip to Europe in his new position, the Secretary described a new mood among Americans on national defense and outlined the Administration's plans for rearming America, the official said.  Finally, he laid out his message for the Europeans.

headline: DELAWARE COURTING COMPANIES FOR JOBS
abstract: Among the loneliest people in this diminutive coastal state are its consumer activists, people like Ted Keller, who seems to feel at times as if he were trying to hold back a tidal wave.   ''Sometimes I'm out there all by myself,'' Mr. Keller, who heads the Citizens Coalition for Tax Reform, an organization based in his home here, complained the other day.   He had some help recently when other witnesses testified at Dover, the state capital, against legislation intended to lure financial institutions from New York and elsewhere. Provisions of the bill eliminating usury curbs would hurt consumers, farmers and small businesses, they said, but legislators swept their objections aside and quickly enacted the measure.

headline: Patents; Inventor, 90, Develops Energy-Saving Lighting
abstract: A 90-year-old inventor was granted a patent this week for an energy-saving light dispersion system.

headline: Business Forum; END THE MORTGAGE GIMMICKRY...
abstract: O VER the years, the nation's savings institutions have provided the mortgage financing necessary to the development of cities and suburbs around the country. Without them, our real estate developers would have been faced with a void. Without them, apartment houses, onefamily houses, shopping centers, office buildings and industrial parks would never have been built. In the past several years, however, encouraged by Washington, savings and loan associations have embarked on all kinds of go-go activities and mortgage varietals that fly in the face of their much-needed functions. Moreover, their depositors are being mistreated by that very same Government. These depositors should be exempt from income taxes, at least to an amount of $40,000 of deposits. The reasons are obvious.

headline: DISCORD AMONG ARGENTINE JEWS OVER REGIME FLARES ANEW IN U.S.
abstract: Long-standing differences among Argentine Jews about the nature of anti-Semitic violence in their country and how to respond to it emerged again yesterday at a meeting in Manhattan.   Mario Gorenstein, the president of the Delegation of Jewish Associations of Argentina, delivered an informal report on the situation for the Spanish-language press at a conference at the offices of the American Jewish Committee.   Mr. Gorenstein, a Buenos Aires lawyer visiting the United States to participate in the American Jewish Committee's 75th anniversary celebrations, said that while anti-Semitism was an ''endemic sickness'' of his country he did not believe that its many recent manifestations were Government-sponsored.

headline: AMERICAN ICON
abstract: The Empire State Building was already the eighth wonder of the world when King Kong swung from the top, Fay Wray struggling in his arms. The building, which turns 50 this week, has become one of the most famous shapes in American iconography.

headline: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Earnings; VW'S NET DROPS 66.4% IN QUARTER
abstract: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's leading car manufacturer, reported yesterday from its headquarters in Wolfsburg that depressed economic conditions in the European automobile industry caused its net income in the first quarter to plunge 66.4 percent, to $18 million, from $53.5 million in the same period last year.   Sales in the period ended March 31, 1981, rose 9.2 percent, to $3.88 billion, from $3.55 billion. The figures were based on one German mark equaling 41.8 cents, Thursday's closing rate. Per-share figures were not available.

headline: Bank Meeting in Spain
abstract: Bankers, finance ministers and economists from Latin America and major Western industrialized nations have gathered here for tomorrow's opening of the Inter-American Development Bank's annual meeting. The bank, established in 1959 by the United States and 19 Latin American countries, now has 43 members, including Japan and most of Western Europe, whose contributions support development in Latin America and the Caribbean. Debt in that region stands at about $200 billion, according to the bank, which said it plans to lend between $2.4 billion and $2.5 billion this year, a record sum.

headline: Around The World; French Communist Leader Asks for Representation
abstract: Georges Marchais, the leader of France's Communist Party, met today with President Francois Mitterrand and asked for representation in the Government after next month's parliamentary elections.   It was Mr. Marchais's first meeting with Mr. Mitterrand since the Socialist leader's election on May 10.

headline: Warranty Ruling
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission ordered Montgomery Ward & Company to offer warranty information to its store customers in binders ''in a prominent location,'' a ruling that lessened the impact of a previous F.T.C. decision about keeping buyers informed. The company said the latest ruling was still unacceptable, and that it would contest it. The case is the first to receive a final F.T.C. decision under its pre-sale warranty regulation, which says all warranties offered on products costing more than $15 must be available to customers before their purchase.

headline: U.S. Hears Police Version Of 23 Salvadoran Killings
abstract: Salvadoran officials have told the State Department that 23 people killed earlier this week in a San Salvador suburb died in an hourlong firefight between leftist guerrillas and the Government police, a department official said today.   The official said that Salvadoran Treasury police had denied reports from witnesses that Government soldiers and policemen shot and killed 30 unarmed civilians either in their homes or after having dragged them into the street.

headline: MACY, R H, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Synthetic Fuels Contract Delay
abstract: The award of the Federal Government's first major synthetic fuels contract, which had been scheduled to go to the Union Oil Company today, was delayed at the last minute because of a dispute between a Congressional subcommittee and the Department of Energy.   The contract is to compensate Union Oil for developing and operating a plant in Garfield County, Colo., to convert shale oil to usable petroleum products.

headline: Business People; GRAND UNION PRESIDENT
abstract: James J. McCaig, 36, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Grand Union Company, an 855-unit chain of supermarkets based in Elmwood Park, N.J. As president, he succeeds Patrick A. Deo, 50. Mr. Deo, who has been appointed chairman, will continue as chief executive officer of the company, a unit of Cavenham Ltd. of Britain.    ''We're seeing somewhat of a polarization in the industry,'' Mr.  McCaig said yesterday.

headline: DROP EXPECTED IN BOND YIELDS
abstract: Long-term Treasury bonds are yielding more than 13 percent, up from about 12.1 percent when President Reagan was inaugurated, even though the Reagan Administration is still moving toward the tax and spending cuts that are supposed to encourage lower inflation and lower interest rates.   ''The markets are saying that they do not believe these programs,'' said Norman Robertson, senior vice president and economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.   Mr. Robertson says that the Reagan Administration's proposals to increase economic growth while reducing inflation are disputed by many, but ''nobody really knows, because nobody has ever really tried these policies.'' With some effort, Mr. Robertson can suppress his doubts enough to see reasons why long-term interest rates might fall on balance for the rest of the year, even if the economy is growing.

headline: U.S. Technology
abstract: To the Business Editor: As a material-handling engineer and someone familiar with new developments in the textile industry, I can attest that the story of the re-industrialization of the American textile industry (''Textile Industry Shakes Itself Up,'' May 10) can be told without apology for the role played by American technological know-how.   The investment in foreign-made, sophisticated production equipment, such as you describe in Burlington's new North Carolina plant, is obviously paying productivity dividends.

headline: VOLKER'S HOPES FOR U.S. POLICY
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed optimism today about the direction of American fiscal policy, just one day after President Reagan endorsed a new plan to reduce taxes.   ''On the fiscal policy side, I think there's room for some encouragement,'' Mr. Volcker said.''I do think there is some room for tax reduction within the framework of a responsible program.''   Mr. Volcker's comments came at a news conference following a panel discussion among central bankers at the morning session of the International Monetary Conference here. The session was dominated by talk of the high American interest rates and their effect in strengthening the dollar and weakening other European currencies.

headline: LESLIE FAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REPRESSION IN GUATEMALA INCREASES AS U.S. IS SEEKING TO IMPROVE TIES
abstract: Violent Government repression of leftist and moderate groups in Guatemala is increasing at the very time that Reagan Administration officials are looking for a way to repair relations with the military regime of Maj. Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.   On the night Ronald Reagan was elected President, fireworks filled the skies of this capital city of 1.3 million people and marimba bands played in front of the United States Embassy.   The nation's leaders expected the Reagan Administration to resume military assistance suspended since 1977 and otherwise deal more sympathetically with them.   United States law prohibits arms aid to countries guilt of continuous violations of human rights. In Guatemala, there have been more than 5,000 killings of people in opinion-making positions since 1978, decimating university faculties, moderate and left-of-center political organizations and other groups. There have been no arrests or investigations.

headline: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; Chin-Steering Mechanism For Motorized Wheelchair
abstract: The handicapped occupant of a motorized wheelchair can steer it and control its speed by chin movements, using a system that was patented this week by two staff members at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, Laurel, Md. John H. Loveless and Woodrow Seamone, who were granted patent 4,260,035, have arranged for quadriplegics to operate half a dozen prototypes.

headline: Israel Repeats Its Opposition To Awacs Sale to the Saudis
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet repeated its opposition today to the proposed United States sale of radar reconnaissance planes to Saudi Arabia, but stopped short of authorizing measures to try to block the deal.   Israel regards Washington's plan to sell five Awacs planes to the Saudis as a threat to its security.

headline: OPEC Freeze Until '83 Urged
abstract: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, called today for an oil price freeze by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries until the end of 1982.   ''We need some time to think quietly whether $36 to $41 is very close to a reasonable price for a barrel of oil and whether we should take it easy from now on,'' Sheik Otaiba said at a conference on energy supplies organized by The Financial Times newspaper.

headline: Market Place; HOLLY SUGAR AND DISSIDENTS; Â¸ THE future direction of the Holly Sugar Corporation may be decided at the annual meeting a week from tomorrow at Colorado Springs, the company's headquarters.
abstract: For a year and a half, a dissident group led by Michael S.  Buchsbaum has been critical of management. The group, Arcanum One, owns 80,000 Holly shares, or 5.05 percent of the total outstanding.  It recently mounted a proxy contest whereby it hopes to seat its own board of directors.   Mr. Buchsbaum felt so strongly about Holly's future that he gave up his position at Ladenberg, Thalmann & Company to pursue his plans.

headline: U.S. CRASH IN EGYPT LAID TO TECHNICAL FAULT
abstract: The crash of a United States Air Force C-141 transport near here during the night, killing all 13 Americans aboard, was attributed today to ''technical reasons'' by a spokesman of the Egyptian Defense Ministry.   The spokesman, Maj. Gen. Mohsen Hamdi, said that an investigation was under way into the crash, which occurred as the plane was making its approach to the Cairo-West air base shortly after midnight. (The bodies were flown tonight to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, according to The Associated Press.)   In operations of this kind it is ''normal and acceptable'' that losses occur, the Egyptian general said.  He dismissed suggestions that the American pilot's lack of familiarity with the local terrain might have been the cause.  The plane was taking part in a two-day airlift in which 1,400 members of the Rapid Deployment Force and their equipment have been ferried to Egypt's largest air base from Fort Benning, Ga. The airlift was completed this morning a few hours after the crash.

headline: Threat Grounds Israel-Bound Jet
abstract: A Tel Aviv-bound Rumanian airliner with 155 passengers and crew aboard made an emergency landing today at a military airfield in central Turkey because of a bomb threat, the police said.

headline: Company News; Italian Bank Offer Accepted by Litco
abstract: The Litco Bancorporation of New York said it had signed an agreement in principle to be acquired by Banca Commerciale Italiana after Litco's board approved the proposal.   Litco, the largest domestically owned bank on Long Island, said it was still negotiating a definitive agreement.

headline: Auto Regulation
abstract: To the Business Editor: Concerning Leon S. Robertson's ''Regulating the Auto'' (March 29): It would seem that Mr. Robertson is totally enamored with air bags, but he makes some statements that are erroneous.   In the mid 1970's, General Motors offered ''inflatable restraints'' (air bags), at a price of $225, which was well below actual cost.

headline: G.I. Kills 4 Americans At Base in South Korea
abstract: An American soldier opened fire on other United States soldiers at rifle practice today, killing four and seriously wounding a fifth.

headline: GRAHAM GREENE DOUBTS HOLLIS WAS SOVIET AGENT
abstract: Graham Greene said today that he believed the world's secret services were riddled with traitors, but he discounted allegations that the late Sir Richard Hollis, Britain's counterintelligence chief, was a Soviet agent.   The 76-year-old author and former intelligence officer told reporters that spies ''begin to feel a game rather than a cause and begin to play the game both sides.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: There is a brief time, between the promises of the campaign and the long haul of trying to make a mark on reality, when a new Government has a moment to present itself. This is done through its appointments, its first measures, usually symbolic, and its first words. These, in different ways, are all signs. Through them the Government says what it would like to be, as opposed to its campaign version of what it thinks the voters would like it to be or what reality will compel it to be in the future.   The most conspicuous thing, a week after Francois Mitterrand became the first Socialist President of the Fifth Republic, is cheerful confusion and unsettled dust. The Minister of Environment cannot find a place for his offices, and there seem to be two, or possibly three, official presidential press representatives and a host of unofficial ones. Newly important people are unexpectedly free for lunch, not because they have nothing to do but because they have so much that it is stuck on its way up to them.

headline: No Headline
abstract: IRAQ VOWS TO PUSH NUCLEAR PLANS DESPITE ISRAELI THREAT   BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (UPI) - The Iraqi Government vowed today to press ahead with its nuclear program despite the threat by Israel's Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, to order a new attack if the nuclear reactor raided last Sunday was rebuilt.   'Iraq will not be deterred by enemy plots,'' Information Minister Latif Nusayyef Jassem wrote in an article printed today in the state-run Baghdad newspaper Al Jumhuriya. He said that Iraq was ''capable of establishing new and better nuclear installations.''

headline: The Economy
abstract: Bank regulators, seeking to aid savings and loan associations and other financial institutions, are drafting legislation to facilitate mergers and provide needed capital. John G. Heimann, Comptroller of the Currency, said a program was being devised to protect the institutions against a ''disaster scenario.'' (Page D1.)   Sales of the Big Three auto makers fell 11.9 percent in the first 10 days of April because of a 22.9 percent drop by G.M. and the end of cash rebate programs. Chrysler reported a 32.8 percent gain and Ford a 4.8 percent rise. Analysts forecast a return to pre-rebate sales weaknesses. (D1.)

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Amax Inc. said a molybdenum mine in British Columbia had been given tentative clearance by a Canadian Government-appointed scientific panel, despite strong opposition from environmentalists.   * Bunnington Corp. said it had acquired Universal Silicon Inc. of Trenton for an undisclosed amount of stock.   * Control Data Corp. is holding joint-venture discussions with International Computer Ltd. of Britain, but said it was not interested in acquiring the troubled computer maker.

headline: Business Conditions; SOME GIVE IN COLLECTIBLES
abstract: According to the fifth annual survey of 15 different types of tangible and financial assets, a very odd couple -Chinese ceramics and American equities - appreciated the most in value last year.  However, for the first time since Robert S. Salomon, general partner and director of stock research at Salomon Brothers, investment bankers, started to track the performance of these items, certain commodities and collectibles actually declined in value from a year earlier.

headline: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW CLIMBS BY 5.40 IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: The stock market finished moderately higher yesterday in heavier trading with the glamour, blue chips and airlines issues posting the largest gains.   Analysts attributed the market's upswing to an increasing belief among investors that interest rates may have peaked and that the Polish crisis is easing. Stock prices generally rise when interest rates decline.   However, they cautioned that if the Federal Reserve Board reports a sharp rise in the latest money supply after the market closes today, it would probably spark further credit tightening by the Federal Reserve Board and another rise in interest rates.

headline: INA to Lift Stake In Paine Webber
abstract: The INA Corporation, a major insurance company that currently owns 21 percent of Paine Webber Inc., will soon have 25 percent under a tentative agreement announced yesterday.   Paine Webber, the parent company of the nation's fifth-largest brokerage house, said that it had reached tentative terms with INA to exchange $11.2 million of its debentures for 112,000 shares of a new convertible preferred stock.

headline: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARGENTINA CALLED ESPECIALLY CRUEL TO ARRESTED JEWS
abstract: The leaders of an Argentine human rights group, Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, say the Argentine Government singles out Jewish political dissidents for especially cruel forms of torture and abuse.    In New York to accept a $10,000 Truth and Freedom Award from the Rothko Chapel of Houston, the two representatives said that many relatives of Jews detained by the police had told them of interrogation sessions far more violent and prolonged than those experienced by other arrested dissidents.   ''Many times, when the police find out that the family is Jewish, they treat them much more cruelly,'' Hebe Pastor de Bonafini, president of the human rights group, said. She said they had obtained the information from mothers and grandmothers of people taken away by the Government and never returned.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Enhancing Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 3 P.M.

headline: 13.75% Mortgages Sell Out in an Hour
abstract: Connecticut home buyers yesterday exhausted an offering of $40 million of 13.75 percent mortgages within an hour after they were made available through a new state program.

headline: Quake Jolts Southern Japan City
abstract: A fairly strong earthquake shook this southern Japanese city today with an intensity of four on the Japanese scale of seven. The police said there were no reports of casualties or damage.

headline: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INVENTORY CONTROL BY COMPUTER
abstract: A study of 1,480 manufacturers in the United States, Western Europe and Japan covering 1970 through 1978 suggests that computerized techniques for materials handling and sophisticated management of such materials are key competitive weapons.   Booz-Allen & Hamilton Inc. found that the most successful American companies had used effective computerized inventory control and information systems to double inventory turnover, while the average company's turnover increased just 20 percent.

headline: SAVINGS BOND YIELDS INCREASED BY 1 POINT
abstract: The Treasury Department announced today that it was raising by one percentage point the interest rates it pays on $70 billion of United States Savings Bonds held by 23 million households.   The rate on new and outstanding Series EE bonds will rise to 9 percent from 8 percent, effective with bonds bought Friday, the Treasury said. The rate on Series HH Bonds, which pay interest by check semiannually and are popular with older persons, will rise to 8.5 percent from 7.5 percent.   The Treasury also announced that it would offer next week three new securities, including a 30-year bond, to professional investors.  However, because of the unsettled state of the long-term bond market, the Treasury trimmed its offering of the 30-year bonds to $2 billion, about $250 million less than expected on the basis of past performance. The Treasury will also offer $3 billion of 3-year notes and $1.75 billion of 10-year notes.

headline: Economic Scene; Specter of Crisis In Global Debt
abstract: THE shock wave from the attempt on the life of President Reagan spread through the world financial system within minutes. Panic was forestalled by the quick closing of the New York Stock Exchange and by the news that, following surgery to remove the bullet from his lung, the President was not in danger.   Nevertheless, anxieties stirred by the assassination attempt will not quickly vanish.  Some threats to world financial stability come not from individual assassins or bands of terrorists but from governments themselves. A recent report by the heads of the four major foreign-policy research institutions of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany warns of three great dangers to the West:   First, in contrast to a decade ago when the prospects were for detente and successful arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, the period now beginning ''is marked by increased tensions between East and West and enhanced Soviet military threats both in Europe and in third-world regions.''

headline: Ulster School Bus Attacked
abstract: Gunmen in a speeding car sprayed automatic weapons fire on a school bus today, wounding the part-time soldier-driver, the police said. No children were aboard.

headline: PAKISTAN REPORTS U.S. HAS OFFERED 5-YEAR AID DEAL
abstract: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan said today that the Reagan Administration had offered his country a fiveyear economic and military assistance package to offset the Soviet threat from Afghanistan.   Speaking to reporters after two days of discussions here, including talks with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Mr. Shahi favorably contrasted the Reagan Administration with the Carter Administration. Last year, Pakistan had rejected as ''peanuts'' a Carter Administration offer of $400 million over two years.

headline: Houston Oil Suspended
abstract: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had suspended the common stock of the Houston Oil and Minerals Corporation from trading after shareholders of the company at the annual meeting last Friday approved an agreement that resulted in Houston Oil becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Tenneco Inc.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Beaumont State Bank, Dallas, has named Ronald L. Parrish chairman and chief executive officer. -Chemical New York Corp. and Chemical Bank have named Alan H. Fishman executive vice president-finance.

headline: ACF INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A MELLOW ROMAN EVENING SHATTERED BY SALVO, FOLLOWED BY WAIL OF SIRENS shooting
abstract: A joyful, cosmopolitan crowd of tens of thousands was filling St. Peter's Square this afternoon, cheering Pope John Paul II and holding up rosaries to be blessed by him. Suddenly a sharp salvo of what sounded like firecrackers was heard.   Those who were standing closest to the Pope, as he was being driven slowly around the square in an open, white cross-country car, saw him falter and raise a hand to his face. Then confusion broke out.

headline: FOR BRAZIL, ON EMBARRASSING TALE OF INTRIGUE
abstract: The Brazilian Government has been dragged into the controversy over Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor through a tale of intrigue involving the Israeli secret service, alleged clandestine shipments of uranium to Baghdad and an air chase over the African coast.   Brazilian officials have categorically denied all aspects of the narrative, but doubts persist because of the habit of Brazil's rulers of conducting the country's affairs in secret and the history of Brazil's acceding to pressure from Iraq, its principal oil supplier until the war with Iran cut the flow.   The episode has proved embarrassing to Brazil because its highly pragmatic foreign policy labors to keep the country out of superpower struggles or political entanglements that could impede pursuit of its own interests.   Brazil, a country eager to be considered stable and reliable, is also portrayed in the account as trying to dodge international nuclear safeguards.

headline: Japan Lifts Output Of Recorders
abstract: Japan's production target for home-use video cassette recorders this year has been revised upward to 8.4 million sets from an earlier estimate of 6.2 million, the Japanese Electronics Industries Association said today.   The increase reflects continued active demand mainly from overseas markets and compares with 4.4 million produced last year, it said.

headline: American Tobacco
abstract: The American Tobacco Company said it will close its Richmond plant, where cigarettes have been manufactured for 50 years, by Oct. 1, but said it plans to continue operating several other major facilities in the Richmond area. A company spokesman said the closing of the 600-employee factory, known as the Virginia Branch, should be completed within six months. The company blamed ''changes in cigarette manufacturing requirements'' and increased operating costs.

headline: SECOND I.R.A. HUNGER STRIKER IS BURIED NEAR BELFAST
abstract: The Irish Republican Army today buried Francis Hughes, the latest casualty of the prison hunger strike, with what it called the ''full military honors due a brave soldier.''   Like the ceremony last week for Robert Sands, the first I.R.A. man to die in the fast for political status in prison, the funeral procession this afternoon to a country churchyard in this peaceful little village 25 miles west of Belfast was accompanied by masked paramilitary commandos in battle dress.   Just outside the Hughes family home, which is two miles from the church, they fired three ceremonial volleys of rifle shots over the coffin, which was draped in the green, yellow and orange flag of the Irish republic.   The tense military mood - set not only by the hard-looking young men with their masks and guns but also by four British Army helicopters that clattered overhead - contrasted harshly with the peaceful, sun-soaked countryside, a picture-postcard land of ancient stone cottages with thatched roofs and gentle green meadows grazed by fat lazy sheep.

headline: KHOMEINI SUGGESTS BANI-SADR APOLOGY
abstract: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who said yesterday that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr could remain in office, appeared today to set a condition for allowing him to continue. The Ayatollah demanded that the President broadcast an apology to the Iranian people for calling on them last week to resist the clergy-dominated Government.   The President responded with one letter pledging loyalty to the revolutionary leader but complaining that he had been treated unfairly, then sent a second defending himself against charges that he had violated the Constitution by refusing to sign a bill empowering the Government to fill Cabinet vacancies and complaining that his first letter had not been broadcast.   It was not clear what the next step would be in the running battle between the dominant Islamic fundamentalists and the President, who has been stripped of virtually all power.

headline: High Iraqi Aide Flies to Moscow
abstract: An Iraqi delegation headed by First Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan flew to Moscow today on an official visit, the official Tass press agency reported. Iraqi sources said the mission was mainly economic but that political questions might be discussed. The Soviet Union has strongly condemned Israel for its June 7 raid on the Iraqi nuclear reactor center outside Beghdad.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: French Force In a Vital Area; Sole Ally That Is Ready For Indian Ocean Move; Military Analysis
abstract: The French military presence in the Indian Ocean and adjacent regions has assumed a new importance as American strategic planning turns increasingly toward Southwest Asia. Alone among America's allies,   France has substantial forces in the area.  French global strategic thinking agrees with that in the Pentagon on one important point: A Soviet attack on Western Europe is the most dangerous but at present least likely threat. The danger lies in proxy wars or limited Soviet interventions in the arc of land from Libya to Pakistan and in black Africa.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Fitzgerald Gardner Company has acquired Max Berking Advertising.

headline: Continental Air Takeover Fight
abstract: Texas International Airlines said today that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to block a plan by Continental Air Lines employees to buy control of Continental until the C.A.B. has ruled on the employee stock ownership plan.   Texas International, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, said that, to acquire control of Continental, the plan should be required to undergo the same scrutiny by the C.A.B. that Texas International had faced in its attempts to take over Los Angeles-based Continental.

headline: REAGAN VOICES REGRET TO ARABS, BUT ASSURES ISRAEL ON TIES
abstract: President Reagan told a group of Arab ambassadors today that he ''appreciated'' their concern about Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor. But he also assured Israel that his displeasure over the raid would not lead to any ''fundamental re-evaluation'' of the American-Israeli relationship.   In sessions this afternoon with five ambassadors from Arab countries and separately with the Israeli Ambassador, Ephraim Evron, Mr. Reagan also appealed to all sides not to let the Israeli bombing mission disrupt the Middle East peace process.   According to a senior Administration official, the President referred to the Israeli raid as ''this tragedy'' in the meeting with the ambassadors of Saudi Arabia, the Sudan, Bahrain, Morocco and Jordan, then observed that ''perhaps there were other options that could have been considered'' by Israel in its desire to prevent Iraq from acquiring nuclear weapons.

headline: XOIL ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; April 20, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 3 P.M.

headline: Argentina Complains On Timerman Debate
abstract: Foreign Minister Oscar Camilion called in the United States charge d'affaires Friday to complain about allegations made on a television program in the United States that there are concentration camps in Argentina.   Mr. Camilion later told reporters that the allegations made by Hector Timerman Wednesday night on a public television program called ''Human Rights and the Timerman Debate'' were ''intolerable'' and a ''complete lie.'' Mr. Timerman made the charges as a member of the studio audience, when the moderator, Bill Moyers, took questions from the audience.   Mr. Camilion's statements were the first to be made by the Argentine Government in response to a book published in the United States by Mr. Timerman's father, Jacobo Timerman, who says that he was tortured during his two-and-a-half-year imprisonment here.

headline: EDITORS TALK WITH HAIG ON UNESCO
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  told a group of newspaper editors and publishers today that he sympathized with their concern about threats to press freedom abroad, according to participants in the meeting.   Journalists at the off-the-record session in Mr. Haig's office were seeking an Administration commitment to resist Unesco proposals for the licensing of reporters and other steps that Western news organizations say would limit their freedom.

headline: MAY RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.2% AFTER BIG APRIL DROP
abstract: Sales by the nation's retailers rose by two-tenths of 1 percent last month following a 2.1 percent decline in April that was the biggest dip in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.   The newly revised April decline, originally reported at 1 percent, resulted mostly from an 11.2 percent drop in automobile sales as spring rebate programs ended.   In fact, the auto rebates have accounted for most of the recent changes in retail sales, the Commerce Department figures indicated.  Excluding automotive products, the value of retail sales has remained virtually flat for the past two months.

headline: Finance Briefs
abstract: * Capitol Air announced it had issued $4 million of 14 percent debentures convertible into common stock at $3.50 a share.   * Daig Corp., which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, reached an agreement with Northwestern National Bankwest, of Hopkins, Minn., allowing Daig to use cash or collateral generated from the sale or other disposition of inventory or the collection of accounts receivable subject to certain limitations.

headline: Patents; Apparatus to Teach Students Blow-Molding
abstract: In 1975, Howard Natter retired from Stuyvesant High School in New York as assistant principal for industrial arts. This week, he got a patent for a pedagogic molding apparatus that is used to teach students how to blow-mold plastic bottles, salt shakers and the like.

headline: BEIRUT TRIES ANEW TO SETTLE CONFLICT
abstract: The Lebanese Government resolved today to increase its efforts to obtain a negotiated settlement of the conflict between Syrian troops and Lebanese Christian militia forces.    But Government officials expressed fears privately that Israel's acknowledgment yesterday that it was aiding the Lebanese Christians in the Beirut area as well as the forces of Maj. Saad Haddad in the south would make it more difficult to get the Syrians into meaningful talks.   Lebanese Christian leaders, whose forces have been battered by the Syrian forces around the eastern Lebanese Christian town of Zahle in recent days, offered yesterday and today to begin discussions with the Syrians on ''an equal basis.'' But at the same time they reiterated their demand for the ouster from Lebanon of the Syrian soldiers, who are here as members of an Arab deterrent force assigned to enforce the cease-fire that ended the Lebanese civil war in 1976.

headline: RISE OF 10.27 LIFTS DOW TO 1,014.14
abstract: Heavy institutional buying pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 10.27 points yesterday, to 1,014.14, close to the eight-year high of 1,015.22 that was reached last Wednesday.   Lower interest rates and reports of continued improvement in President Reagan's condition following the assassination attempt on Monday aided the New York Stock Exchange rally, market participants said.   Big Board volume reached 54.9 million shares, up from 51 million the previous day. There were 932 advancing issues and 614 declining ones.

headline: CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RASHISH CONFIRMED AT STATE DEPT.
abstract: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Myer Rashish as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs today by a vote of 91 to 4.   His appointment was among those initially held up by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

headline: No Headline
abstract: PRESIDENTIAL FUNERAL IN ECUADOR: Oswaldo Hurtado Larrea, right, Ecuador's new President, bearing coffin of late President Jaime Roldos Aguilera at funeral in Quito. Mr. Roldos, his wife, and other Government officials were killed in plane crash. From left are Mrs.  Hurtado and Leon Roldos Aguilera, late President's brother.

headline: SCM Says Rockwell Will End Proxy Bid
abstract: The SCM Corporation said that it had reached an agreement with Willard F. Rockwell Jr., the retired former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, to end his second proxy fight for control of SCM, a major industrial complex with operations ranging from food to telecommunications equipment.   Under the agreement, Mr. Rockwell would be reimbursed $1.4 million for expenses in the proxy effort and be paid $3.9 million, or $30 a share, for his 130,000 shares of SCM stock.   Partners with Mr. Rockwell in the control battle, who retained 90,000 shares of SCM stock after the first proxy fight last year, are also to receive $30 a share, an amount only slightly more than the stock has been selling for on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: SOCCER VICTORY PERKS UP SPIRIT OF TORRID CAIRO
abstract: For days now Cairo has been in the sweltering grip of a hamsin, a furnace of still air from the desert that has had sweltering Egyptians cursing the premature arrival of summer.   Summer was informally declared Thursday when the city's beleaguered traffic cops switched from black uniforms to summer whites to stand on the blistering streets and perform their hopeless task of thwarting the fabled anarchy of the Egyptian driver.   Some relief from the torpor inflicted by desert air, which makes you taste sand when you lick your lips, came Wednesday night when a young Egyptian soccer team won the Africa Cup by beating Cameroon, 2-0. It was the first time in 20 years that Egypt had won the trophy. The victory restored the good spirits of thousand of Cairenes and prompted many motorists to engage in a binge of horn-blowing far in excess of the normal beeps that fill the air day and night.

headline: EXXON CONFIRMS GAS PRICE CUTS
abstract: The Exxon Corporation cut wholesale gasoline prices in several states today by one-half cent to two cents a gallon, joining the parade of major companies that have reduced prices as a result of slack demand.   The price was cut by a cent a gallon in Brooklyn, Queens, and Nassau and Suffolk counties in New York, and all of New Jersey.  Exxon did not announce the cuts publicly but in response to inquiries said that ''these changes reflect our assessment of competitive conditions in these markets.'' The company added that it could not speculate whether the cuts would be increased or extended elsewhere.

headline: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canadian Wheat for China
abstract: The Canadian Wheat Board said today that it had sold 1.4 million tons of wheat to China on a cash basis in Canadian dollars. Delivery is to be made between Aug.1 and Jan.31, 1982.

headline: KORVETTE'S CITES OFFER FOR 3 STORES
abstract: Joseph A. Ris, the chairman and chief executive officer of Korvettes Inc., announced his resignation yesterday after spending a year in closing down the once-successful discount chain and reported negotiations that might dispose of at least three Korvettes stores remaining in New York City.   He said that that a bid of $25 million had been received by Korvettes to sell the leasehold on its Herald Square store in Manhattan. Mr. Ris described the potential buyer as ''a Chinese company'' but said that he had been asked not to identify the company further.   He also said that Caldor Inc., one of the East's largest and most successful discounters, had been negotiating to take over the two sites on Bay Parkway in Brooklyn and one store on Staten Island. But Carl Bennett, chairman of Caldor, denied late yesterday that negotiations were being held.

headline: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INDIA AND CHINA ANNOUNCE TALKS ON BORDER ISSUE
abstract: India and China announced their intention today to hold early negotiations on their long-deadlocked border dispute.   Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Huang Hua, said after a 70-minute meeting that they had agreed on talks at an ''appropriate level'' to try to resolve the issue. Indian officials said that the talks would be held in September with a visit by an Indian delegation to Peking.   Mrs. Gandhi also said that she had accepted an invitation to visit China at a mutually convenient date.

headline: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LIBERTY NATIONAL INSURANCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REFINERS SHUN COSTLY CRUDE OIL
abstract: Oil companies have begun pressing petroleum producing countries to reduce prices substantially, with some companies refusing to accept oil they consider too high-priced, petroleum industry analysts and oil traders said yesterday. Such pressures have already provoked price reductions or elimination of special surcharges by Kuwait, Iraq and Egypt.   Companies discuss the accelerating moves in only the most guarded terms for fear of angering foreign suppliers. But they privately concede that the moves are prompted by the current glut of world oil, which in turn has led to painful losses by almost every refinery in the world. It is routine for companies to lose $3 or more on every barrel of oil processed in the present market, although many companies are still posting profits from their drilling operations..

headline: Brazil Oil Output Up 13.5%
abstract: Brazil's oil production rose 13.5 percent, to 19 million barrels, in the first quarter of 1981 from 1980's first quarter, a spokesman for Petrobras, the state oil company, said Friday.

headline: RULING SOUTH AFRICA PARTY HOLDS DOMINANCE IN SPITE OF DEFECTIONS
abstract: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's National Party was maintaining its overwhelming dominance in Parliament early today in the all-white general election despite significant defections by Afrikaner voters to extremist parties that accuse the National Party of endangering white rule.   With roughly 1.2 million voters setting the political course for this nation of 28 million, the governing party found its margins of victory narrowing in rural districts in the Transvaal and Cape provinces where it had not been seriously challenged in recent elections.   But its only loss of seats came in urban areas at the hands of the relatively liberal Progressive Federal Party, which took National Party seats in Capetown and Pietermaritzburg. The Capetown seat was lost by the Minister of Industries, Dawie de Villiers, the first Cabinet member to be defeated since the National Party came to power in 1948.

headline: OIL EXPORTS CONSIDER ARAB EMBARGO UNLIKELY
abstract: In the wake of Israel's attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor, oil industry officials and analysts yesterday discounted the possibility of an oil embargo against the United States by Arab petroleum producers.   This optimism, however, was tempered by a call by several deputies of Kuwait's National Assembly to impose another oil embargo against the United States, and suggestions by various Middle East experts that Saudi Arabia may have been angered by Israeli violation of its airspace during the flight to Iraq by the Israeli jets that carried out the attack..   ''I know for a fact that it's going to upset them,'' said David Toufic Mizrahi, editor of MidEast Report, which is published in New York.   The issue could be decided as early as Friday when Arab foreign ministers are scheduled to meet in Baghdad to discuss the situation.  ''We're still awful, awful vulnerable even though we think we're in good shape,'' said a top official of one of the world's biggest oil companies. Moreover, United States intelligence officials have not ruled out the possibility of an Arab oil embargo.

headline: Ship Fire Imperils Egyptian Port
abstract: A tanker in Alexandria harbor was engulfed by flames today, touching off eight tons of explosives in its cargo, the police reported. A state of emergency was declared and the area was evacuated. The tanker, carrying 3,000 tons of petrochemicals, was identified as the Eastfloat, of Panamanian registry.

headline: REAGAN TO NOMINATE NEVADA LAWYER TO I.C.C.
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Reese H. Taylor Jr., a lawyer in private practice, to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a seven-year term.   If Mr. Taylor is confirmed by the Senate, President Reagan intends to name him chairman of the I.C.C.  Mr. Taylor, who turns 53 years old on Wednesday, was chairman of the Public Service Commission of Nevada from 1967 to 1971 and was vice chairman of the Nevada Tax Commission.   A graduate of Stanford University and Cornell University Law School, he was previously associated with law firms in Las Vegas, Nev., and Los Angeles. He is now in private practice with Allison, Brunetti, MacKenzie & Taylor in Carson City, Nev.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. WARNS NATIONS ON USING STORED OIL
abstract: The United States warned today that it may not want to share oil with other members of the International Energy Agency during shortages, if they draw heavily on stockpiles now in order to save dollars by avoiding current purchases.   The warning came from Dr. James B. Edwards, the United States Secretary of Energy, who was in Paris for the semiannual meeting of the 21-nation International Energy Agency, representing energy consumer nations.   The agency now has a trigger that makes emergency oil-sharing mandatory when its members experience a 7 percent reduction in supplies. But it was suspended at the request of some major members during oil cutoffs brought on by the Iran-Iraq war last year.

headline: 23 BROKERS FIND A HOME IN JERSEY
abstract: Tucked inside a sleek, 15-story modern building here are the offices of 19 investment firms where brokers engaged in the trading of stocks, bonds and commodities have brought a corner of Wall Street to Montgomery Street.   Business taxes are comparatively low in New Jersey, which makes these firms quite happy. Sales and personal income taxes are also rather moderate, which makes their employees quite happy. Offices rent for far less than in Manhattan, and the harbor views, according to one broker, are ''spectacular.''

headline: ISRAEL ASKS U.S. FOR GIFT OF JETS, CITING SAUDI SALE
abstract: Israel has asked the United States for an outright gift of an additional 15 F-15 fighters as well as access to an American spy satellite to compensate for the Reagan Administration's planned sale of advanced military equipment to Saudi Arabia, Administration and Israeli sources said today.   With Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. leaving tonight on a nine-day trip to the Middle East and Europe, the American military relationship with Saudi Arabia and Israel has become complicated by a possible arms race that seems to have been inadvertently set off by an American desire to build up Saudi defenses against any Soviet threat.   Mr. Haig conferred with President Reagan at George Washington University Hospital this morning and received last-minute messages for the leaders he will meet on the trip.   Mr. Haig will spend one day each in Egypt, Israel, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. On Wednesday he will fly to Spain with a stop in Italy. On Thursday he will go to Britain, then stop in France and West Germany before flying back to Washington a week from tomorrow.

headline: INTERNATIONAL MOGUL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bass Seeks Up to 50% Of Blue Bell
abstract: Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-largest jeans maker, announced yesterday that Bass Brothers Enterprises, an oil-rich Texas family company, has filed statements with the Federal authorities that would allow it to buy up to 50 percent of Blue Bell's common stock.   Bass, which is owned privately by Perry R. Bass and his four sons and has extensive oil, gas and real estate interests, currently owns 9 percent of Blue Bell stock. By law, any investor planning to buy between 10 and 50 percent of a company must formally notify the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department.   Blue Bell, manufacturer of Wrangler jeans, reported sales of nearly $1.4 billion in the year ended last September and profits of $67.9 million, virtually unchanged from a year ago. The company, which has its headquarters in Greensboro, N.C., is less than half the size of Levi Strauss & Company, the leading jeans maker.

headline: Record Savings Outflow Noted
abstract: The nation's beleaguered savings and loan associations reported a record outflow of $4.63 billion last month, almost double the mark set only a month earlier, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.   The bank board's new report said that outflows - the difference between new deposits and withdrawals -traditionally rise substantially in April when many Americans are forced to tap their savings accounts to pay Federal or state income taxes.

headline: CHASE LOAN POLICIES DRAW FIRE
abstract: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, accused the Chase Manhattan Bank today of ''paying lip service only'' to Federal regulations requiring lending institutions to answer credit needs of their communities.   At a House hearing, Thomas J. Murray, a Chase vice president, defended the bank's loan strategy, citing Chase's role as a national bank.

headline: Conrail to Ask 6% Rate Rise
abstract: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced today that it would seek a 6 percent freight rate increase, to begin July 1. It would expand revenues about $240 million a year.

headline: BLACK CLERIC BACK IN SOUTH AFRICA BUT BOTHA IS FIRM OVER PASSPORT
abstract: Bishop Desmond Tutu returned here today from a 10-nation tour and declared, in a manner that was too ebullient to be described merely as unrepentant, that he regretted none of the remarks that provoked Prime Minister P.W. Botha to threaten to confiscate his passport.   ''Given the opportunity again, I will repeat precisely what I have said,'' the outspoken black cleric said. He then proceeded to do so at a news conference in which he said again that economic pressure from abroad was necessary if South Africa's racial conflicts were to be resolved by peaceful means. The Bishop, an Anglican, is General Secretary of the South African Council of Churches.

headline: ITALY'S CABINET QUITS AS MASONIC SCANDAL RUPTURES COALITION
abstract: The Cabinet of Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani resigned today as a result of the revelation that hundreds of highranking officials were members of a secret Masonic lodge.   The Government's fall became inevitable when the Socialists, the key partners of the Christian Democrats in the four-party coalition, refused to go along with Mr. Forlani's plans for a ''small Cabinet reshuffle.'' Mr. Forlani is a Christian Democrat.   The Socialists want a new Government. They have served notice that they will insist that their own leader, Bettino Craxi, be given a chance to become Prime Minister. If he succeeds, it would be the first time since the end of World War II that a Christian Democrat was not Prime Minister. Italy has had 40 Governments since the war.

headline: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Your Money; Buying Houses As Investments
abstract: ''DO you think we did the right thing?'' the nervous woman asked the supposed authority. She and her husband, already owners of a summer home in Southampton, L.I., had just contracted to buy a condominium there, purely as an investment. They had seen home prices in the Hamptons rise faster than the inflation rate in recent years - by 15 to 20 percent, according to brokers - and they felt they could expect the same with the condominium, part of a new development under construction since last fall.   But the couple knew the risks involved; hence, the nervousness. A house is a relatively illiquid investment. Even though prices may be rising, it may be difficult to find a buyer, if one wants or needs to sell, at a time when mortgage rates are high.

headline: East German Leader Returns From Visit to Japan
abstract: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, returned from his first state visit to Japan today and said that while the trip was a political success, he had been unable to conclude all the business deals he had hoped for.   The East German head of state and party leader had expected to buy high-quality equipment and installations from the Japanese valued at up to $1.5 billion during his six-day stay, but last-minute hitches over prices and credit terms delayed completion of some deals.

headline: SCA Services Names 2
abstract: Henry E. Russell, 64, has joined SCA Services Inc., the nation's third-largest waste disposal concern, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Thomas C. Viola, 53, who left the company, which is based in Boston. In addition, James J. Needham, former chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange and an SCA director since 1977, was elected vice chairman.

headline: British Seize 26 in Heroin Raids
abstract: The police arrested 26 people and seized five and a half pounds of heroin in a series of overnight drug raids in the London area, authorities said today. Two police officers were injured in a scuffle with suspects in one of the raids, the police reported.

headline: FLORIDA EAST COAST RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORAN BUSINESS IS NOT FOR THE TIMID
abstract: For the businessman bored with the daily routine, El Salvador presents some entrepreneurial challenges.  Warehouses and factories are favorite targets of guerrilla firebombings, trucks are regularly hijacked, stores are looted and workers are intimidated from showing up for the job. Extortion payments known as ''war taxes'' can be demanded by both sides, a curfew limits double-shift production, public utilities are erratic, credit and insurance no longer exist, customers demand cash in advance and owners and managers are subject to kidnapping, assassination or simply the unnerving threat of both.   The company run by one of the directors of the Salvadoran Association of Industrialists has had its executives held hostage, 17 of its trucks destroyed and one of its routemen held up 159 times in the past 15 months. Thirty-six well-armed security men patrol a plant near the old city airport.   Companies have taken to paying workers above-scale wages, selling them food and necessities in company dispensaries at cost, financing household purchases and providing medical care in order to maintain their loyalty.

headline: Coast Man to Purchase San Francisco Magazine
abstract: Another deal that never did come off was Knapp Communications' buying San Francisco magazine.

headline: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; April 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Enhancing the Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the World Dis- armament Conference - 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Block Cautions On U.S. Farms
abstract: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that the United States, with its huge capacity for food production, has ''one of the most valuable tools in foreign relations that it has ever held.''   Citing record exports of agricultural commodities, Mr. Block said they had provided a $30 billion annual edge over imports of such commodities.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Canada Energy Policies Assailed at U.S. Hearing   WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) - An American oil company executive testified in Congress today that, particularly in the energy field, the Canadian Government was following policies of ''nationalistic economic discrimination.''   ''Those policies have fostered an environment in which certain opportunistic Canadian companies - aided and abetted by Canadian banks - can fearlessly conduct raids on United States companies,'' said Philip W. Wood, executive vice president for finance and administration of the Cities Service Company.   Mr. Wood testified at a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing on the impact of Canada's proposed national energy policy on United States companies. 'On an Emergency Basis'   The Cities Service executive urged Congress to enact, ''on an emergency basis,'' legislation that would temporarily bar acquisitions by any Canadian interests of significant stock holdings in any United States energy company.

headline: American Medical Lifts Brookwood Bid
abstract: American Medical International Inc., locked in a bidding war with Humana Inc. over Brookwood Health Services Inc., yesterday raised its offer for the operator of hospitals and alcholism-care centers, based in Birmingham, Ala., by $10 a share.   The new offer, amounting to $50 worth of American Medical shares for each share of Brookwood, is valued at $150 million.

headline: MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Technology; New Elegance For Polaroid
abstract: THE new instant cameras Polaroid will market this summer may not justify the investment it took to develop them, some analysts say, but there is unanimous feeling that they are, in the words of one expert, ''technologically elegant.'' The key is sophisticated electronics.   Electronics is a technical boon to photography because electronic systems operate so fast and in such small spaces. Using electronics, the part of picture-taking that appears to be a single event to the average consumer becomes a series of steps that can be adjusted as they unfold to improve picture quality.

headline: Around the World; Leader of Peasant Party In Poland Forced to Quit
abstract: Stanislaw Gucwa, head of the pro-Communist Peasant Party, resigned today after party members had attacked him for opposing an independent farm union.   He has been replaced as party leader by Stefan Ignar, head of the Agricultural Policy Institute, according to the official Polish press agency. Mr. Ignar led the party from 1956 to 1962 and served as a Deputy Prime Minister under Wladyslaw Gomulka, the former Communist leader.

headline: XEROX'S SIMPLER COMPUTER
abstract: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced a product intended to overcome a major obstacle in the path toward the automated office - the reluctance of white-collar workers with no computer experience to use electronic terminals.   The 8010 Star Information System, a video display terminal, can be used without the need for code words and special commands common to other systems, Xerox said. The terminal can be used to create and edit documents, as is done on a word processor, to create graphs and charts, retrieve documents stored in electronic files and send and receive electronic messages.

headline: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The House approved President Reagan's proposed budget cuts that would trim $36 billion in fiscal 1982. By a vote of 217 to 211, the Republicans and 29 Democrats gave the President most of what he sought. The House-approved budget legislation included authorization for the President to sell 105.1 million troy ounces of silver from the nation's strategic stockpile. (Page 1.)   The Administration dropped its opposition to sugar price supports in return for backing by Democrats from Southern sugar-producing states. New farm bills would raise the price of raw cane to 19.6 cents a pound, almost four cents above the free market. (1.)

headline: Patents; Heat Collector Apparatus For Solar Energy Systems
abstract: Joseph R. Frissora, president and founder of the Sunmaster Corporation of Corning, N.Y., which manufactures solar energy systems, was granted a patent this week for a drainable collector apparatus used in Sunmaster equipment. Water in glass tubes collects the heat and can be protected from freezing without need of siphoning.

headline: BEGIN VOWS PEACEFUL EFFORT BUT SAYS SYRIA MOBILIZES
abstract: As the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, left for consultations in Washington, Prime Menachem Begin said today that Israel would support further efforts for a peaceful solution of the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon. But he charged that Syria had mobilized reserves and increased the deployment of missiles on its territory in apparent preparation for battle.   The Prime Minister's remarks, made after a final meeting with Mr.  Habib in Jerusalem, indicated that Israel would not interpret the envoy's departure as opening the way for an Israeli attack on Syrian antiaircraft missiles moved into eastern Lebanon since April 29.   Israel, citing an informal understanding prevailing since 1976 on the limits of Syrian military involvement in Lebanon, has demanded removal of the missiles. Syria has refused.

headline: CBS Challenges Newsweek TV Campaign
abstract: The folks at Newsweek and at its agency, Foote, Cone & Belding, never dreamed that anyone else would feel included when they took on Time magazine without naming it in a multimedia campaign with the theme ''We don't fit the mold.

headline: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CABLE TV CONCERNS FINDING 'REAL ESTATE' IN SPACE IS SCARCE
abstract: A severe shortage of transponder space on satellites used by cable television networks to beam programs across the country has vastly inflated prices for available slots, according to satellite specialists.   A transponder is a relay point on the satellite that bounces the signal to an ''earth station.'' ''The scarcity has resulted in multimillion-dollar bidding wars among companies vying for transponders,'' said Al Parinello, vice president of marketing for Satellite Communications Network, a broker of transponder space.

headline: Advertising; Chipwich Destined for Grocers
abstract: A QUALITY confection product sold by attractive and uniformed vendors from clean, well-tended carts? Why that sounds like the Good Humor of yesteryear. It also sounds like the new Chipwich Inc.   But unlike the old Good Humor, Richard E. LaMotta, the man behind Chipwich - its creator, its soul - does not intend his creation to be seasonal.   That's why he is doing business with Premium Products Sales, headed by James M. Stevens, the man who sold Perrier to America, and with Leber Katz Partners, the Fifth Avenue ad agency   Their job is to get the Chipwich into one of the city's most precious pieces of real estate, the ice cream freezers in neighborhood supermarkets.

headline: Conrail Cuts More Grain Rates
abstract: Conrail, the ailing, federally owned railroad, yesterday announced steep cuts, of 50 percent and more, in its intrastate grain-hauling rates.   The carrier said that the reductions, in effect June 20 through Sept. 26, are meant to win business away from trucking companies.

headline: Company News; OHIO HOME BUYERS GET REBATES
abstract: Home builders here, suffering from their longest and most severe postwar slump, have ripped a page from the auto industry's marketing manual and are offering home buyers a $2,000 rebate when they buy a new house.   The idea has generated a lot of interest among builders across the nation and some are hailing it as a bold step that could generate more demand for new houses and relieve the battered builders of unwanted inventories.   ''I think it's a great idea, especially if it shakes some people off the fence,'' said William Cheseroni, director of marketing for the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. ''There's lot of pent-up demand. People are afraid that they'll buy now and interest rates will go down. But they just keep going up.''

headline: SAUDI ASKS A FREEZE IN PRICE OF OIL
abstract: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said yesterday that the kingdom would ask OPEC to freeze prices at their current level through 1982. Sheik Yamani also said the kingdom would ask for moderate price increases thereafter by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   The Saudi official's remarks were the strongest indication yet of what Saudi Arabia would recommend to other OPEC nations when the 13 meet in Geneva on Monday. His comments seemed to represent a retreat from his earlier demands that other OPEC members cut prices, according to petroleum analysts and company officials.

headline: HANOI REPORTS FINDING THE REMAINS OF 3 U.S. AIRMEN
abstract: Vietnam announced today that it had found the remains of three United States airmen missing since the Vietnam War.   Vu Hoang, director of the Vietnamese office in charge of finding missing American servicemen, said the remains of the three airmen would be turned over to American officials as soon as forensic specialists had completed identification. ''The Vietnamese Government, prompted by good will and a humanitarian spirit, shall continue the search process,'' he said.

headline: COAST BANK GOING INTERSTATE
abstract: In early June, the Western Bancorporation will change its name to the First Interstate Bancorporation. And its 21 banks in 11 Western states will officially become units of the First Interstate Bank, part of a $32 billion financial organization with nearly 900 offices in 450 communities in the West.   If interstate banking is inevitable, as bankers seem to believe, then Western Bancorp intends to be the first. The largest of six multistate banking companies, Western Bancorp's banks, which had been part of the Bank of America, were allowed to remain as a unit after the 1956 Bank Holding Company Act blocked further interstate expansion. That law was apparently passed to prevent A.P. Giannini, founder of the Bank of America, from building a national bank empire.

headline: A.T.&.T PLANNING PUBLIC STOCK OFFER
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the most widely held company in the world, said yesterday that it plans to sell at least 15 million shares of common stock later this month, the company's first public offering of common stock in four years. If interest is strong, the company said, it would be willing to add another 1.5 million shares, bringing the total to 16.5 million shares.   At the stock's closing price yesterday of $56.50 a share, the sale of 15 million shares would amount to $847.5 million. A.T.& T. said the money would be used for general corporate purposes.

headline: Borg-Warner Seeks Ruling From F.T.C.
abstract: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission for an advisory opinion on whether its proposed acquisition of 4.5 million common shares, or about 22 percent, of the Echlin Manufacturing Company is covered by the F.T.C.'s 1975 consent order with Borg-Warner. Under the offer, Borg-Warner would transfer its automotive after-market division to Echlin.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   United Nations Development Pro- gram Governing Council - 10 A.M.  and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 3 P.M.

headline: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRANIANS FORCE SHIFT AT KRUPP
abstract: The supervisory board of Krupp Stahl has acceded to the demands of Iranian stockholders and has substantially revised its original plan to restructure the financially ailing steel company, which could have cost perhaps 5,000 jobs.   Instead, only 2,000 jobs will be eliminated, and those only through attrition, under a program finally approved this week at a meeting of the board that was attended by representatives of the Iranian Government, which owns 25 percent of Krupp Stahl's parent company.   ''It is our ideology,'' said Mahmoud Ahmadzadeh, Iran's Minister of Industry and its representative on Krupp's board, ''that the fate of ordinary people is more important than economic affairs.''

headline: SENATOR CONDEMNS I.R.A. AS MARXIST
abstract: Senator Jeremiah A. Denton said today that the Irish Republican Army was not a legitimate national liberation organization but a terrorist group that had been ''subverted and perverted'' and ''taken over'' by Marxists.   The freshman Alabama Republican said that, contrary to the belief of ''many well-meaning people in the United States,'' the provisional wing of the I.R.A. is ''not a little Irish group for freedom'' and is ''doing nothing but disturbing the tranquillity of government in the United Kingdom.''

headline: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RATES LEVEL IN QUIET TRADING
abstract: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday as investors and traders waited on the sidelines for clearer signs that the Federal Reserve would encourage a decline in short-term interest rates.
