The weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills, which averaged 13.91 percent and 13.62 percent, respectively, was the latest sign of the widely anticipated decline in short-term rates.  By accepting a lower yield for three-and six-month bills than could be earned in shorter-term money market instruments, investors and traders were showing that they did not expect the higher yields on the shorter maturities to last long.   Yesterday, for example, the institutional investor's return on new Treasury bills was well below the 18 5/8 percent that could have been earned on an overnight loan in the Federal funds market, and was also less than the 16 1/2 to 17 percent yield available on one-month issues of commercial paper or negotiable bank certificates of deposit.

headline: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MRS. THATCHER SAYS DEATH OF SANDS WON'T ALTER LONDON'S ULSTER POLICY
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher served notice in the House of Commons today that Britain would not change its policy on Northern Ireland despite the death of Robert Sands on the 66th day of his hunger strike and the street violence that followed.   In European nations and elsewhere, British attitudes came under sharp attack in the hours after the death of Mr. Sands, a 27-year-old member of the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Sands, who was elected to Parliament last month, died in Maze Prison near Belfast early today.   In Belfast, Roman Catholic youths battled the police in continuing protests over Mr. Sands's death, but the disturbances were scattered and less severe than those that followed the first announcement.  (Page A14.)

headline: Crowd in Manila Protests Vote on New Marcos Term
abstract: Hundreds of policemen and militiamen dispersed a crowd that gathered here tonight for a noisy protest of tomorrow's plebiscite on a new six-year term for President Ferdinand E. Marcos with no limit on re-election. The nation's 26 million voters are required under threat of arrest to cast ballots.   By midnight at least 30 protesters had been arrested, including former Senator Eva Estrada Kalaw and the family of former Senator Salvador Laurel.

headline: U.S. ENVOY ENDS TALKS WITH BOTHA ON THE INDEPENDENCE OF NAMIBIA
abstract: West Africa, June 11 - Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark ended talks with Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa today and prepared to head for this disputed territory where he is due to meet tomorrow with leaders of a score of political parties.   By this evening, there was no indication by either side that Mr.  Botha had embraced American proposals designed to end the impasse that has kept this territory under South African control, three years after agreement was supposedly reached on a plan for its independence under the name Namibia.   The Reagan Administration has taken an initiative for revising that plan - put forward originally by five Western nations, including the United States - in order to accommodate South African interests. It has forsworn sanctions as a weapon to pressure South Africa and promised not to impose deadlines, but has asked in return that South Africa commit itself to an unambiguous statement of its minimum conditions for relinquishing the territory.

headline: Company News;
abstract: The Timken Company, a major producer of tapered roller bearings, alloy steel and percussion rock bits, announced plans to spend $500 million over the next six years for construction of a steel plant.

headline: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.C.I. Profit Declines
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries announced yesterday that profits in the first quarter fell 90.8 percent, to $22 million, or 4 cents a share, from $240 million, or 41 cents a share, in the comparable 1980 period. Revenues slipped to $3.35 billion from $3.41 billion.

headline: 18 1 2% PRIME RATE PLANNED
abstract: Commerce Bancshares, a holding company of 38 Missouri banks, announced today that it would lower its prime interest rate to 18 1/2 percent from 20 percent, effective Monday. The prime rate at the nation's major banks remains at 20 percent. United Missouri Bancshares, a network of 21 United Missouri banks, has promoted a prime rate of 18 3/4 percent since June 12.

headline: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Credit Markets; TRADERS SPUR QUICK BOND RALLY
abstract: The credit markets were suprised yesterday afternoon by a quick rally. One trader called it a ''nervous spasm,'' but it was nevertheless strong enough to raise some long-term bond prices more than 2 1/2 points.   Most analysts attributed the rebound, which also reduced some Treasury bill rates by about a quarter of a percentage point, to technical factors, such as short covering by speculators. In the financial futures markets, where speculative positions can be taken with very little cash, the anticipation of a drop in rates from current high levels was great enough to lift prices sharply for Treasury bill and bond contracts.

headline: STRIKE AT BRITISH FORD IS SYMPTOMATIC
abstract: Even the participants might not have recognized it as such, but a classic example of one key aspect of the controversial economic policies known as Thatcherization was on display this week at the strike-bound Ford Motor Company plant on the outskirts of this worn industrial city.   In one sense, the striking workers hunched over barrels of burning wood scraps outside the factory entrance and the silent machinery inside constituted just another statistic in Britain's long history of acrimonious labor relations.   But on a broader level, the stoppage, a scene repeated countless times across Britain, was apparently a consequence of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's efforts to improve economic performance in Britain, until now a home of low productivity and high propensity to strike.   Her conservative economic philosophy has pressed companies like Ford to insist on more efficiency, and workers like these to acquiesce. Mrs. Thatcher's critics see broader results of her policies, particularly her tight control of the money supply: a neardepression that has left two and a half million Britons unemployed and left British companies virtually without profits.

headline: Shearson Takeover To Get U.S. Review
abstract: Either the Justice Department or the Federal Trade Commission will review the American Express Company's plan to acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the second-largest brokerage firm on Wall Street, to determine whether it might violate the antitrust laws, a Justice Department spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Mark T. Sheehan, said that there was ''nothing unusual'' about such a review. ''Any merger of any significance gets looked at by the antitrust division of the Justice Department or by the Bureau of Competition of the Federal Trade Commission.''

headline: F.C.C. Opposes A.T.& T. Rate
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission's staff disclosed today it had tentatively decided that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has failed to justify a 16 percent increase in interstate long-distance telephone rates.   In a letter from the common carrier bureau of the agency, the Bell System was told that 13 percent appears to be closer to a proper rate of increase for regular long-distance service than 16 percent because the higher rate indicates ''that A.T.& T. may have overestimated the extent to which use of domestic message telephone service would diminish under the carrier-proposed 16 percent.''

headline: New Head of Levi's Not in the Family
abstract: Robert T. Grohman, 56 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Levi Strauss & Company, the nation's largest apparel manufacturer, effective Nov. 29, the end of its current fiscal year. He will become the first person unrelated to the founding family to head Levi Strauss, which has annual sales of $2.8 billion.   Mr. Grohman will succeed Peter E. Haas, 62, who will become chairman. Mr. Haas, in turn, will succeed his brother, Walter A. Haas Jr., 65, who will retire after 41 years with the San Francisco-based company established 131 years ago by his great granduncle.

headline: BRITISH POLICE INVESTIGATING BLAST AT OIL PLANT DURING QUEEN'S VISIT
abstract: An explosion at a Scottish oil terminal during a visit by Queen Elizabeth II last Saturday was not caused by equipment failure as originally thought.   The British Petroleum Company, which operates the facility at Sullom Voe, near Inverness, said today that exhaustive investigations had shown no evidence of an equipment malfunction. The company said that this had been reported to the police, who are continuing their own investigations.

headline: HOUSE PANEL LINKS AID TO SALVADOR TO CURB ON 'INDISCRIMINATE' KILLING
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to impose restrictions on United States military aid to El Salvador that would require President Reagan to provide assurances that ''indiscriminate torture and murder'' by Salvadoran security forces is being brought under control.   By a vote of 26 to 7, the committee adopted an amendment to the foreign assistance bill that reflected deep concern over the violation of human rights in El Salvador. The bill contains a request for $25 million in military assistance to the Salvadoran civilianmilitary junta for fiscal 1982.   The amendment would require that President Reagan certify, in two semiannual reports to the Speaker of the House, that the Government of El Salvador is not engaged in a consistent pattern of violations of human rights and is achieving substantial control over all elements of its armed forces so as ''to bring to an end the indiscriminate torture and murder of Salvadoran citizens by these forces.''

headline: WESTERN NATURAL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; INVENTOR'S EXPOSITION SET IN MAY
abstract: WASHINGTON MORE than 175 American and foreign inventors will display and explain their creations at the Fifth Annual International Inventor's Exposition, to be held at the New York Statler Hilton Hotel from May 14 through May 17. The purpose of the exposition is to display inventions to businessmen for licensing and sale.

headline: DRIVE EXPECTED; Military Analysis
abstract: Iraq has reportedly assembled a large tank-backed force for a final push to take the Iranian oil refinery center of Abadan, which its troops have held under siege since shortly after the war began in September. American and British military analysts say they believe such a drive could begin in the next few weeks. British sources put the size of the Iraqi force at 60,000 men and 1,000 tanks. These figures, analysts say, may be inflated, but they report signs that Baghdad is stressing that Abadan must be taken.   The Iraqis hold large parts of Iran's oil-producing province of Khuzistan, with the occupied territory varying from 19 to 37 miles in depth. But analysts point out that the strategic objective of Iraq's drive into Iran - control over the Shatt al Arab - cannot be achieved as long as Iranian guns in Abadan can command the waterway, which separates the two countries at the head of the Persian Gulf.

headline: Around the World; Swedish Premier Facing Calls for New Elections
abstract: Prime Minister Thorbjorn Falldin today shuffled ministerial posts in his coalition Cabinet amid calls from the parliamentary opposition for new national elections.   Eight ministers of the conservative Moderate Party in the coalition of conservatives, Liberals and Centrists resigned on Monday in a dispute over changes in the income tax.

headline: Foreign Airlines Seek Fare Rises
abstract: Fifty-two international airlines, predominantly from Europe, Asia and Africa, agreed today to seek permission from their governments for 5 percent passenger fare increases on most international routes.   The airlines, convened here in an emergency session of the International Air Transport Association to discuss mounting losses, also decided to seek permission to raise freight rates, although the amount of increases being sought was not immediately known.

headline: 3 Gunmen Kill Ulster Militiaman And Flee Toward Irish Republic
abstract: Three gunmen killed a Protestant militiaman in County Fermanagh today, then fled in the dead man's delivery truck toward the Irish Republic 10 miles away.  The police said the gunmen shot a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment as he was delivering coal to a house near the village of Lisnaskea.   The Irish Republican Army announced today that an undisclosed number of imprisoned members would join four inmates taking part in hunger strikes, according to United Press International.

headline: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pollution Spending To Increase 9%
abstract: American business plans to spend $10 billion on pollution control equipment this year, a modest 9 percent increase over 1980, according to a survey released yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company.   After accounting for inflation, McGraw-Hill said, little if any spending increase by business on pollution controls is expected.

headline: Volkswagen's Orders Rise
abstract: Volkswagenwerk A.G. reported an increase of orders in the first two months of this year from declining levels in late 1980, but did not give any figures. Siegfried Ehlers, the auto company's chairman, told a meeting of workers in West Germany on Tuesday night that orders were especially high for diesel-powered models and that production was not keeping up with demand.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M.   Conference on the Law of the Sea - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 65 New Zayre Stores
abstract: The Zayre Corporation said that it intends to open about 65 new stores this year. Maurice Segall, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting in Boston that the new stores would include about 35 Hit or Miss units, which is Zayre's off-brand name women's apparel chain, and 18 to 20 T.J. Maxx Stores, the company's off-price family apparel chain. Mr. Segall also said Zayre plans to open 10 to 12 department stores and intends to close about 15 Hit and Miss stores this year. The company operates discount department and apparel stores.

headline: Manners
abstract: To the Business Editor: The timing was exquisite! Not 10 minutes before noticing and reading ''Why Nobody Calls You Back Anymore'' (May 24) by Robert K.  Otterbourg, I was remarking that I had fruitlessly tried to contact an executive through both his secretary and his wife. The purpose was to convey information of some value to him.

headline: BENN STARTS NEW LABOR PARTY FIGHT WITH A CHALLENGE FOR THE NO. 2 POST
abstract: The Labor Party was struck by a new round of bitter internal wrangling today with the announcement that Tony Benn, the hero of its radical left, had decided to seek the party's deputy leadership.   The party's No. 2 job is now held by Denis Healey, a leader of its right wing. Mr. Benn's challenge to Mr. Healey, a former Chancellor of the Exchequer, raised the prospect of a bruising battle between now and the voting in September, instead of the period of soothing reconciliation that many party members had hoped for.   Michael Foot, the party leader, made an unusual public appeal to Mr. Benn tonight to withdraw his candidacy in the interest of party unity.

headline: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES DEEP CUTS IN THE NAVY TO PAY FOR NEW TRIDENT SYSTEM
abstract: Britain unveiled a major defense restructuring today that would significantly reduce conventional naval forces to permit the money to be spent on development of the Trident missile system.   The plan provides for a smaller overall defense buildup than had been previously intended, although some of the cuts, particularly in the Royal Navy, were less substantial than had been rumored a few weeks ago.   Despite the reduction, the Government insisted that it was sticking by its commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to increase defense spending by 3 percent a year after adjustment for inflation. The Government added that it would maintain that policy for an additional two years, 1985 and 1986.

headline: British Firm on Terrorists Despite I.R.A. Man's Victory
abstract: A British Government spokesman in Northern Ireland said today that Thursday's election to Parliament of an imprisoned Irish Republican Army member would not move Britain to grant inmates convicted of terrorism the status of political prisoners.

headline: U.S. Predicts Wheat Price Drop
abstract: The Agriculture Department, following a crop report forecasting a record winter wheat crop of 2.08 billion bushels, predicted today that farmers' wheat prices would drop slightly this coming season.   The department predicted average prices would be within a range of $3.70 to $4.30 a bushel.

headline: MANHATTAN'S STRENGTH
abstract: Although New York City's economic health appears to be reviving, the recovery is overwhelmingly dominated by Manhattan. A recent analysis by Rona B. Stein, a regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, shows that activity remains low in the city's four other boroughs.

headline: Chicago Rail Service
abstract: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad Company said yesterday that it will seek approval on June 1 to suspend all commuter operations in the Chicago area a week later.

headline: TALKING BUSINESS
abstract: Talking Businesswith Hardy of McKinsey & Company Role of Inflation In U.S. Industry   An informal sampling of 200 executives in the last year by McKinsey & Company, the management consulting concern, puts the anticipated average annual inflation rate at about 10 percent for the 1980's.   Thomas G. Hardy and Robert A. Schmitz, principals at McKinsey, believe many executives in the United States are unaware of the ways inflation has altered the rules of business. Mr. Hardy, 36 years old, and Mr. Schmitz, 39, have discussed managing in an inflationary economy with the 200 executives in periodic seminars. Mr. Hardy was interviewed recently.   Q. How does inflation change fundamental business operations? A. It changes the way you make money. While profits from running the business remain critical, gains from appreciating assets and from the use of debt are important. You also need more cash to finance working capital and to replace working capital. There is also a risk of a cash squeeze.

headline: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to raise the price of its average equipped 1981-model car by 2.1 percent, or $178, effective Friday. The increase lifts the average price of a Ford car to $8,817, up $456 during the 1981 model year, a company spokesman said.

headline: Solomon Debt Plan Approved by Court
abstract: The Sam Solomon Company, a Charlestonbased retail chain that filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws in August 1980, said a plan of reorganization providing for 100 percent repayment of its debts had been approved by a Federal Bankruptcy Court.   The company, which operates 11 catalogue showroom stores in South Carolina, North Carolina, Georgia and Florida, said Judge J. Bratton Davis had confirmed the reorganization plan, which provides for 100 percent payment of debts plus 12 percent interest.

headline: GREIT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Harvester Reports Gain in Refinancing
abstract: The International Harvester Company said today that banks accounting for more than two-thirds of the funds involved in its refinancing program have approved in principle the terms for their participation.   The company also said that Roger E. Anderson, chairman of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, had resigned from its board ''to avoid any appearance of a conflict'' between his personal association with Harvester and his bank's leadership in the $4.7 billion debt restructuring program.

headline: JAPANESE ALUMINUM PLEA
abstract: Japanese trade unionists have received a polite but noncommittal hearing from the American aluminum industry and its workers to their request for voluntary restraints on United States exports of aluminum to Japan.   A delegation from the Japanese Aluminum Smelter Workers told American labor and industry representatives last week that a surge of American exports was leading to ''unacceptably high'' unemployment.   Despite the tradition of lifetime employment, they reported a quarter of the industry's work force of 80,000 four years ago has been laid off and blamed a surge of low-priced American imports for much of the difficulty..   Their visit here was likened to the trip to Tokyo last year by the United Automobile Workers president, Douglas A. Fraser, to urge Japanese auto makers to curtail their exports to the United States.

headline: Peking Police Break Up A Protest by Dissidents
abstract: Outlawed activists threw free-speech leaflets into the air today as more than 2,000 people paid homage to revolutionary heroes on the traditional Chinese day for mourning the dead.   One of the activists said they had planned to deliver a speech about freedom in Peking's Tian An Men Square. Their plans were thwarted by more than 100 soldiers, policemen and plainclothesmen who dispersed the crowd.

headline: REAGAN TO ATTEND FALL CONFERENCE ON THE THIRD WORLD, MEXICANS SAY
abstract: President Reagan has agreed to join the leaders of 21 industrialized and developing nations at a meeting in Mexico this fall to discuss the economic problems of the third world, Mexican officials said today.   President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico is to issue a formal invitation when he meets Mr. Reagan in Washington next week, but the American leader reportedly indicated privately some weeks ago that he would attend on condition that Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, was not present.   Although Mr. Castro is currently president of the movement of third world nations professing nonalignment and was eager to attend the meeting, he has since been informed by the Mexican Government that he will not be invited. ''He was not at all happy,'' a Mexican official said.

headline: ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO SELL BEER IN WEST GERMANY
abstract: It may sound like carrying coals to Newcastle, but this week Anheuser-Busch, America's biggest brewery, announced plans to sell beer in West Germany.   Together with Rudolf August Oetker, one of Germany's largest food companies, Anheuser-Busch will brew a light, American-style beer in West Berlin, where it will be test-marketed.   Brewers here say the new product may well jolt Germany's stagnating beer market, which is plagued by overcapacity, sagging profits and - most troublingly - shifting tastes that are shrinking consumption.   Using a recipe developed by Anheuser-Busch brewers in conformity with Germany's stringent purity laws, and employing barley imported from the United States, Oetker will brew the beer at the Berliner Kindl Brauerei, an Oetker subsidiary.

headline: CHRYSLER NAMES 2 TO JOBS AS IACOCCA'S CHIEF AIDES
abstract: Two younger executives were named to top positions at the Chrysler Corporation today just under Lee A.  Iacocca, the chairman, as the president and vice chairman of the company announced their retirements.   Gerald Greenwald, who is 45 years old, was named vice chairman and is clearly second in command and a likely successor to the 57-yearold chairman. Mr. Greenwald had been executive vice president for finance and is credited with handling the delicate negotiations with Chrysler's lenders.   Harold K. Sperlich, who is 51 years old, was named president for North American operations for Chrysler but was not made president of the corporation. A spokesman said that position had been eliminated.

headline: Prince Charles Rejoins Fiancee After Good-Will Visit to the U.S.
abstract: Charles, Prince of Wales and heir to the British throne, left the United States under tight security but unruffled today following a brush with hecklers that was the only incident during a good-will festival with the American people.   The Prince flew in a Royal Air Force plane to Scotland for a reunion with his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, after a month's separation.   There were only two signs of discord at places he visited during the trip - a sign hanging from a dormitory at the College of William and Mary saying ''Free Sands'' and a crowd outside the White House last night chanting ''Bobby Sands, Bobby Sands, Bobby Sands.'' Mr.  Sands is in the 64th day of a hunger strike at a prison outside Belfast, Northern Ireland, demanding status as a political prisoner.

headline: Sharp Rise Seen in Copper Price
abstract: Copper producers and analysts said today that prices for the metal could go much higher and possibly double in the next two years in anticipation of a strengthening of domestic and international economic activity.   David Waite, an analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said that copper prices could more than double, to $2 a pound, by 1983 with demand increasing at an average annual rate of 5 to 6 percent.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BASIC EARTH'S CUT IN RESERVES
abstract: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC., the public offering of which drew pension money from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Bankers Trust Company six months ago, has just made drastic reductions in the oil and gas reserves cited in its prospectus.   The shares traded at 6 last Friday, adjusted for a recent 2-for-1 stock split, but word of the reserve revisions on Monday sent them reeling to 3 1/2. They were 2 7/8 bid by midafternoon yesterday with sellers reportedly unloading the stock in volume late in the day.   Last Dec. 18, Basic offered through John Muir & Company one million units consisting of one common share and a warrant to buy another share at $15 each - unadjusted for the split. The shares themselves have since traded as high as 16 1/2 unadjusted - that is 8 1/4, allowing for last week's split.

headline: SOVIET SHOWS DETERMINATION TO KEEP PRESSING POLAND
abstract: The Soviet Union today demonstrated its determination to maintain pressure on Poland's Communists, giving prominent display to a letter sent to Polish leaders and focusing press attention on tough resolutions passed by the Central Committee in Warsaw.   The full text of the letter, which warned Polish leaders that their passivity had brought their nation to the brink of disaster, took up a fourth of Pravda's second page, which is reserved for Communist Party issues.   The official press agency Tass gave no indication of the power struggle that the Soviet letter touched off in Poland or that Stanislaw Kania, the first secretary, who was openly criticized in the letter, had survived a hard-liners' challenge to his leadership.

headline: ARGENTINA SAID TO BUY 57 TANKS FROM AN AUSTRIAN ARMS CONCERN
abstract: Argentina has signed a $180 million contract in Paris with an Austrian arms company to buy 57 tanks, according to sources close to the agreement.   The Austrian Government of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky announced yesterday that it had approved the agreement between Argentina and the Steyr-Daiml@er-Puch Company, apparently closing a sale that has become an issue here and in Austria.   Last week, while the agreement was still pending, Government spokesmen in Vienna denied reports that the sale was imminent. Some Austrian labor leaders, legislators and youth groups said, however, that they would seek to block it because of the human rights record of the Argentine military regime. The 57 tanks were originally part of an order of 100 tanks for Chile, but that order was canceled last year after similar objections were raised. The Argentine Government has been silent on the deal.

headline: LEVITZ IS FINDING SMALLER BETTER
abstract: In the early 1970's, the Levitz Furniture Corporation caught Wall Street's fancy. Its pioneering trend toward opening vast warehouses with showrooms and providing immediate delivery led to an earnings surge and a lightning rise in the price of its stock.   But Levitz's good fortunes soon came to an end. First there were problems of new competition and overexpansion. Then there was a stock trading scandal, a recession, family infighting and a takeover battle.

headline: U.N. Envoy Will Discuss Gulf War With Iranians
abstract: Olof Palme, the special United Nations envoy trying to bring an end to the Persian Gulf war, is to meet with Prime Minister Mohammad Ali Rajai and members of the Supreme Defense Council, Iran's official Pars news agency said today.    Mr. Palme, in his fourth visit to warring Iran and Iraq, arrived in Teheran yesterday, but the priority of his peace mission has been downgraded because of the Iranian Parliament's debate on the impeachment of the country's missing President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr.

headline: Market Place; The Appeal of Apple Computer
abstract: A SURPRISING number of people want a slice of the apple that's due to be dished out next month. The apple, in this case, is Apple Computer Inc., a three-year-old privately owned company based in Cupertino, Calif.   Last August Apple announced plans to go public, and it has generated all the earmarks of a hot new issue on Wall Street ever since. The excitement intensified last week after the company filed registration papers for an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares planned for early December. The tentative offering price was set at $14 to $17 a share.

headline: WHEN MA BELL'S LADY SPEAKS, WALL STREET LISTENS
abstract: I F Virginia Dwyer could have it her way, she probably would prefer not to be written about. But as treasurer of American Telephone & Telegraph Company, which raises more money every year than any entity except the United States Government, there is little she can do to escape the spotlight.   As Ma Bell's treasurer, Miss Dwyer is probably the most courted woman on Wall Street. While she is very much in the mold of the lowprofile corporate treasurer, big numbers, very big numbers, creep into her most mundane conversation.   ''Between the committee meeting and the presentation to the board of directors,'' she said, laconically ticking off the day's schedule, ''I have to go down and pick up a check for a billion dollars. I have never handled one before, but I am looking forward to it.''

headline: SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan's Premier in Italy
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for a three-day visit to Italy, the second of six nations on a West European tour. He arrived from West Germany and will also visit Belgium, Britain, the Netherlands and France.

headline: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
abstract: * Action Corporation has delayed until next week the offering of 700,000 common shares with warrants.   * Comtex Scientific Corporation registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial 700,000 common shares to be sold by underwriters headed by D.H. Blair & Company.   * Consumers Power Company announced the proposed offering by the Economic Development Corporation of a $43.5 million aggregate principal amount of Pollution Control Revenue Bonds, Series A, due June 1, 1991.

headline: PACIFIC TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Christian Democrat Backed As Mayor of West Berlin
abstract: After weeks of suspense, the impasse over the formation of a city government for West Berlin appears to have been overcome, with four rebels among the liberal delegates announcing that their choice for Mayor is Richard von Weizsacker, the 61-year-old Christian Democratic candidate.   Mr. von Weizsacker, if he is elected as expected next Thursday by the city parliament, will be the first Christian Democrat to run this city since 1954.

headline: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.P.U. Down 54%
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation reported a 54.4 percent drop in earnings for the first quarter.

headline: German Price Rise Slows
abstract: West Germany's wholesale price index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in May to 124.9, following an April advance of six-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.

headline: ICM REALTY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan Picks Chicago Financier As Next Ambassador to Canada
abstract: President Reagan today nominated Paul Robinson, a Chicago financier, to be ambassador to Canada, replacing Kenneth M. Curtis, who has resigned.   Mr. Robinson, 50 years old, is founder and president of Robinson Incorporated, which acts as broker and administrator for banks and professional institutions.

headline: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 33 Mexicans Die in Bus Crash
abstract: Thirty-three people were killed and 15 seriously injured when a bus and a truck collided in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, the police said today.

headline: SELLING THE CAPITAL'S SOCIAL SCENE--WITH CONNECTIONS Poston and Barbara Boggs
abstract: W ASHINGTON Whirl-Around, a conference planning firm with great connections, didn't exactly start out with a bang. In its first year, 1967, it made an underwhelming $400 for each of the three partners involved.   But those partners were Ellen Proxmire, wife of William Proxmire, the Democratic Senator from Wisconsin; Barbara Boggs, whose husband, Thomas H. Boggs Jr., is one of Washington's best-known lobbyists, and Gretchen Poston, married to Raymond Poston, a lawyer.   ''We were sitting around talking about, if you will pardon the expression, 'doing something' other than car pools and children,'' Mrs. Boggs said in a recent interview.   Weddings, they decided, were something they knew about. Putting up $150 apiece, they founded Wonderful Weddings. ''We were fortunate,'' Mrs. Proxmire said, ''in that none of us had to make any money.''

headline: ECONOMY UP ON EXPORTS
abstract: The size of the first-quarter increase in gross national product, which rose at an adjusted annual rate of 6.5 percent, took many economists by surprise. A partial explanation lies in the fact that exports, unexpectedly, surged.

headline: AFRICAN SCENES: 'GHOSTLY' RAIDS TO CHINESE AID
abstract: A dozen Angolan soldiers, AK-47 assault rifles at the ready, dogged every step taken last week by a group of reporters looking at a refugee camp in Angola's east central province of Moxico. The soldiers' presence belied an official myth.   According to Angola's Marxist regime, there is no organized internal opposition. Jonas Savimbi and his National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita, are ''phantoms.''

headline: SAUDIS CUT SOME OIL $2
abstract: Amid growing evidence of an oil glut, Saudi Arabia has intensified its campaign to lower world oil prices by cutting the price it charges for some of its oil exports by $2 a barrel.   The Saudis have reduced the price of their so-called war relief crude to $34 a barrel from $36, oil industry sources said yesterday.  The move closely followed a statement by Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, that his country wants the basic price of oil reduced to $32, the level where Saudi Arabia sells most of its own oil.

headline: MOUNT VERNON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING STEEL IMPORTS
abstract: The Government today announced a series of actions to enforce the trigger price mechanism, which regulates the flow of steel imports into this country, and said that in one such case a grand jury was considering fraud allegations against the Mitsui Company, one of the largest of Japan's trading companies.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the alleged fraud practices under investigation included double invoicing, false damage claims and the use of false terms of payments. He said that imports from 11 other countries were also under fraud investigation, but he declined to name the countries.   The cases are being pursued by the Customs Service and the Justice Department with assistance from the Commerce Department, which monitors import control procedures.

headline: JAPANESE SHIP SINKS IN COLLISION WITH U.S. ATOM SUB
abstract: A Japanese freighter and an American nuclear-powered submarine running just below the surface collided yesterday in the East China Sea. The cargo ship sank.   Thirteen of the freighter's crew members were rescued from rafts early today by Japanese destroyers, but the captain and his first officer were reported missing and presumed dead.

headline: Pope's Swiss Visit Postponed
abstract: The Conference of Switzerland's Roman Catholic Bishops formally confirmed today that the six-day visit that Pope John Paul II was to make to Switzerland beginning May 31 had been postponed.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Prospects dimmed for House adoption of the budget cuts sought by the White House. House Democratic leaders thwarted President Reagan by agreeing upon separate votes on the package's six parts. Outraged Republican leaders vowed a floor fight to enable the President's proposal to be voted upon as a single package. (Page A1.) The House Ways and Means Committee, as the Senate Finance Committee had done earlier, approved a tax-exempt savings certificate as a way to help savings and loan associations. (D14.)   President Reagan, embarking on a cross-country campaign for his tax and spending cuts, appealed to a roaring crowd of Jaycees in San Antonio to demand Congressional passage. (B14.)

headline: PAKISTANI SEES FLAWS IN U.S. AID OFFER
abstract: The proposed $500-million-a-year package of American military and economic aid for Pakistan falls short of matching Soviet military assistance to India, which, according to a senior Pakistani official, was what his Government wanted Washington to do.   ''We would have wanted the West to sell us military equipment on concessional terms similar to those given by the Soviet Union to India,'' said the Pakistani official, who took part in the aid talks in Washington.   Last fall the Russians agreed to sell arms to India that they valued at $1.6 billion. The terms of that sale reportedly provided for repayment in 15 years and an additional 10-year grace period with interest of 2 percent.

headline: RAIDERS UNDETECTED BY U.S. RADAR PLANE
abstract: The United States was unaware of the Israeli air strike into Iraq until four hours after it took place, despite the presence of American radar planes in Saudi Arabia and other intelligence resources in the region, a Pentagon spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Henry E. Catto Jr., said the Government saw no reason to be concerned that the intelligence services had not discovered that the raid was planned or in progress.   Mr. Catto reported new details of the raid, as reportedly passed on to the Pentagon early this morning by Israeli officers. He expressed grudging admiration for what he called the ''surgical precision'' of the bombing, but joined other Government spokesmen in condemning the action itself.

headline: Credit Markets; SHORT-TERM INTEREST RATES UP
abstract: Short-term interest rates rose yesterday in response to a the continued high level of the Federal funds rate.  The funds rate, which is the cost of money that banks lend to each other overnight, traded around 20 percent, as it had Wednesday.  Market analysts had expected the funds rate to ease with the start of the bank statement week yesterday, but the overnight cost of money remained high and pushed up all short-term rates.   One result of the strong short-term rates was that several big banks raised their loan rates to securities brokers by a full point, to 20 1/2 percent. The brokers, in turn, will pass along the increased cost to the clients to whom they lend funds for securities purchases.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Heublein Inc., Hartford, to UniWorld Group Inc. for its Rhum Saint James imported rum brand. * Town & Country magazine to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss. * International Paint Company, Union, N.J., to Bozell & Jacobs Inc.

headline: MAINE CENTRAL RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Girard Back Down to 20%
abstract: The Girard Bank of Philadelphia, which last Friday raised its prime rate to 21 percent, reduced it yesterday to the prevailing level of 20 percent.

headline: Tax Cut Called Spending Spur
abstract: A study of 441 major corporations, released today, says that the Reagan Administration's proposed business tax cuts could produce an estimated $14.7 billion in corporate spending for capital improvements.   The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, which conducted the study, described it as ''more detailed evidence than ever before available on the effects of taxes, regulations and inflation on the investment plans of corporate America.''

headline: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Indonesian Oil Contracts
abstract: A South Korean concern and two United States companies will spend nearly $315 million over the next six years under oil exploration contracts signed today with Indonesia's state-owned oil company.

headline: Assets Increase At Money Funds
abstract: After four weeks of decline, assets of the nation's 122 money market mutual funds rose $680.5 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $118.4 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   With market interest rates somewhat lower in the last two weeks, investors are apparently putting cash into the money market funds to benefit from their higher yields.

headline: DOLE CITES PANEL DOUBT ON TAX CUT
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that President Reagan now lacked majority support on the tax-writing committee for the Administration's proposed three-year, 30 percent tax cut.   About half of the 11 committee Republicans ''have serious reservations about 10-10-10,'' Mr. Dole said, referring to the proposed cuts of 10 percent a year for three years. Furthermore, he added, ''only one or two Democrats'' are for it.   He also indicated that the committee was unlikely to vote for as much tax relief as the $54 billion bill proposed by Mr. Reagan in February, including $44 billion for the first year of tax cuts for individuals and $10 billion for liberalized depreciation deductions for business, also in the first year.

headline: Japan Ex-Im Bank Signs Soviet Loans
abstract: The Export-Import Bank of Japan signed a contract today to provide the Soviet Union with bank loans totaling $949 million for two Siberian development projects.   The loans are based on agreements reached between the Governmentowned Export-Import Bank and the Soviet Foreign Trade Ministry in Moscow last December, Ex-Im Bank officials said.

headline: BUSINESS CHECKING, MONEY FUND LIMITED
abstract: The Bank of New York yesterday announced a cash management account plan enabling small and medium-sized businesses to invest their checking account balances in high-yielding money market funds.   The bank said its program was the first by a bank linking a regular business checking account to separate money market mutual funds, although several other banks have announced plans to invest consumer deposits in money fund instruments periodically.   Under the plan, the bank will automatically ''sweep'' checking accounts at the end of each business day and invest the surplus in a choice of 10 money market funds for which the bank is agent and processor.   The Bank of New York is the nation's 18th-largest bank and the largest agent and processor of money market mutual funds. Customers in the CheckInvest program may choose any one of three Dreyfus Corporation money market funds, the Shearson Daily Dividend Fund and Value Line Cash Fund, among others. The funds are now yielding around 16 percent annually.

headline: Air Canada Trims Boeing Purchase
abstract: Air Canada has scaled back its purchase plans for the new Boeing Company 767 wide-body jetliners in a decision that represents a potential revenue loss to the plane maker of nearly $300 million.   The Canadian Government-owned airline, the first major foreign airline to order the 767, said it had canceled options to buy six 767's but it was going ahead with orders for 12 of the twin-jet planes and options for 12 more.

headline: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW SLIPS BY 3.90 IN WEAK TURNOVER
abstract: Takeover fever, touched off by acquisition bids from Canada, gripped Wall Street yesterday and sent a handful of stocks briskly higher in a rumor-filled session. Elsewhere, lingering worries over interest rates produced a modest setback for the overall market.   The Dow Jones industrial average, recording its fourth decline for the week, slipped 3.90 points, to 992.87. The only Dow component changing as much as a point was Merck, down 2 1/4, to 97.

headline: TEXT OF IRAQI'S SPEECH TO COUNCIL
abstract: Following is the text of a speech by Foreign Minister Saadun Hamadi of Iraq to the Security Council today::   Mr. President, I should like to express to you our gratitude and appreciation for the manner in which you have conducted the deliberations of the Council. Your efforts as well as those of the other members of the Council to arrive at a decision on a matter of great importance to the international community have been appreciated by our Government. We are also deeply grateful to all the member states which have participated in the debate for their support. Our thanks go also to the Secretary General, Mr. Kurt Waldheim, for his efforts in achieving a unanimous resolution by the Council.   Now that the Security Council has adopted a resolution on the complaint by Iraq in connection with Israel's air raid of 7 June 1981 on Iraq's nuclear installations, it remains for us to evaluate this conclusion on the basis of all the events that have unfolded during the consultations.

headline: COKE BRINGS 'TASTY HAPPINESS' TO CHINA
abstract: Its name is rendered in Chinese as ''Ke Kou Ke Le'' and roughly translated it means ''tasty happiness.'' Some Chinese say it tastes more like carbonated medicine but they note that the aluminum cans it comes in can be split lengthwise to make a spiffy red and white mudguard for bicycle fenders.   Today, with more fanfare than attended the normalization of diplomatic relations more than two years ago, the Coca-Cola Company officially opened its first bottling plant on the China mainland since 1949.   Aretha Franklin, on a tape submitted in advance for official clearance, belted out the soul version of Coke's current theme song, ''Coke adds life, have a Coke and a smile,'' through the loudspeaker system at the Great Hall of the People as some 500 Chinese officials and Americans gathered tonight for a reception to celebrate this symbol, officials said, of Chinese-American friendship.

headline: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bond Prices Increase Slightly; 7-Year Notes Yield 13.34%
abstract: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday as dealers and speculators were encouraged by stability in overnight interest rates.  ''Wall Street's sigh of relief that the President's injury was not more serious carried prices higher,'' one government securities dealer commented. He added that ''outright investor buying of new issues remains light, though many firms are willing to accumulate some inventory.''   Bond prices opened higher than late Monday's close, analysts said, as some traders purchased securities to offset the sales they arranged Monday after the President was shot.

headline: Battles Said to Intensify In Iran's Khuzistan Area
abstract: Both Iraq and Iran reported today that fighting between their forces had intensified in the southern Iranian oil-producing province of Khuzistan.   They agreed only on the pace of the fighting, however.

headline: SHARP DROP IN MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
abstract: Machine tool orders in May showed a sharp drop from the alreadydepressed levels of a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. They declined 47 percent, compared with May 1980.   The industry group said that orders totaled $229.8 million in May, compared with $434 million the year earlier. The May order rate was also 24.7 percent lower than in April, when orders totaled $305 million.

headline: NADAR PARLEY AIRS LAW FEE COMPLAINTS
abstract: With hourly fees for senior partners soaring above $200 and annual salaries for 25-year-old fledgling lawyers rising above $40,000 at major Wall Street law firms, rumblings of discontent among corporate clients that must pay law firm bills are beginning to break into the open.   Cost-conscious executives who ''thought that they were being overcharged'' - sometimes for ''services that they didn't need'' - have begun to shed the traditionally gentlemanly relationships that they have maintained with their outside law firms, William G.Langston, the top lawyer for the Homestake Mining Company, told a conference here today.   The ''conference on excessive legal fees'' was sponsored by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate. Mr. Nader, who has done more than his share to keep corporate lawyers busy, cast himself in the improbable role of an ally of corporate cost-cutters, whom he urged to ''fight back against rising legal costs.'' Each Paid $150 to Attend   A modest turnout of about 60 corporate executives and legal officers and 20 other people paid $150 each to attend. They took notes diligently but turned shy when asked by a reporter who they were and what they hoped to learn from Mr. Nader, a nemesis of business.

headline: Southland Royalty
abstract: The Southland Royalty Company said Friday that its directors had authorized the purchase of up to 1.4 million of its common shares, or 3 percent of its 46.6 million shares outstanding. The company said the purchases would be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The oil and gas exploration and production company said that the amount and timing of the purchases would depend upon market conditions and other factors.

headline: SELAS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Leftists Protest in West Berlin
abstract: Hundreds of leftists, some hurling stones and paint, shouted antimilitary slogans today and carried banners demanding ''Americans Go Home!'' during the annual parade by American, French and British occupation troops. The police arrested 53 demonstrators. The groups urged disarmament and an end to the occupation, in effect since the end of World War II.

headline: Volkswagen Plans To Cut Dividend
abstract: Volkswagen, the West German auto maker, will cut its annual 1980 dividend to shareholders because of a slump in net earnings last year, the company said today. the supervisory board, the group that forms company policy, voted to recommend to a July 2 shareholders meeting to reduce the dividend to 8 marks, or $3.73, per $22.50 share. In 1979, the company paid 10 marks.

headline: People
abstract: * George Russo named senior vice president-media director at Creamer Inc., New York.   * E. MacFarlan Moore has been named vice president, advertising for Times-Mirror Magazines.

headline: U.S. PRIEST IS MISSING IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: The United States Embassy reported today that an American Roman Catholic priest working here as a television crew's interpreter has been missing since he left his hotel here yesterday to buy medicine.   An embassy spokesman said Salvadoran authorities were checking hospitals and pharmacies that were open yesterday for clues to the whereabouts of the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, a native of Lutcher, La., who now lives in Chicago.   The spokesman said the 42-year-old Father Bourgeois, a member of the Maryknoll Order, arrived in El Salvador Thursday to work as an interpreter for a Chicago-based CBS News television crew. The priest's work here apparently was not church-connected, he added.

headline: Canada's Real Estate Giant; A.E. LePage Is Focusing on Deals Abroad
abstract: Canada's largest real estate company, A.E.  LePage Ltd., has moved into international real estate management with an agreement to manage 10 luxury apartment buildings in Saudi Arabia.    LePage is also looking for joint-venture or acquisition opportunities in England and Australia, and it is expanding its development business in Florida. It recently entered Hawaii, where it is promoting time-sharing arrangements for vacationers at hotels and resorts.   LePage predicts that its international revenues will equal its Canadian revenues by 1990. The 67-year-old company, which handles almost one-third of all real estate business done in Canada, expects to report revenues of $185 million (Canadian) for this year on $300 billion in real estate transactions, according to its 52-year-old president, William Dimma.

headline: Around the World; 8 Czech Rights Activists Are Detained by Authorities
abstract: The Czechoslovak authorities have arrested Jiri Hajek, who was Foreign Minister during the short-lived 1968 liberalization period, and seven other rights activists, including the wife and brother of Vaclav Havel, a jailed playwright.   The charges were not made public, but the arrests yesterday coincided with a report by the official press agency that two foreigners charged with smuggling subversive material into the country had also carried money for people who conducted ''subversive activity.''

headline: Company News; KAISER GERMAN UNIT DEPENDS ON AIRBUS TO SUPPORT GROWTH
abstract: With orders for the A-310 European Airbus continuing to grow, suppliers to the European aircraft industry are gearing up for better times.   One company that hopes to ride the Airbus's good fortunes is the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. Its European unit plans to invest nearly $83 million in West Germany over the next four years to become one of the prime suppliers of the special heavy aluminum plate used to build the skin for the wide-bodied jet.   ''We're aiming at delivering about 10,000 tons a year to the aircraft industry,'' said Rolf Wiesinger, spokesman for the managing board of the Dusseldorf-based Kaiser Aluminum Europe Inc. ''That will cover about a third of demand.''

headline: BOLIVIA WINS DEFERRAL ON DEBT REPAYMENTS
abstract: Washington, May 1 - An international banking group led by the Bank of America has agreed to refinance $460 million in foriegn debt for Bolivia's military Government, which is at odds with the United States over drug smuggling and political repression.   The agreement rescheduled Boliva's Government-guaranteed debt falling due by March 1983 to terms of up to seven years, with four years' grace. The interest was set at 2 1/4 points over the London interbank offer rate, or Libor, which is about 16 1/2 percent.

headline: ALL AGOG OVER JIM AND SANDY
abstract: The conference room on the 40th floor of the American Express building is sweltering as the afternoon sun over the Hudson River streams into the the room, but Jim Robinson and Sandy Weill are grinning like the cat that ate the canary.   Small wonder. For after three weeks of secret and exhausting negotiations, the two chief executives, both in their 40's, set the financial world agog by announcing the proposed merger of American Express one of the premiere financial giants, with Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., one of the largest and most aggressive brokerage firms. The transaction, which is expected to be complete in July, is valued at more than $900 million.   The announcement followed by only a few weeks similar merger plan - Prudential Insurance's acquisition of the Bache Group. Still, the potential for the Amex-Shearson combination was powerful enough to shake bankers and brokers.  Sanford I. Weill, the self-made Wall Street entrepreneur from Brooklyn who heads Shearson, and James D.  Robinson 3d, the financial prodigy from an old-line Georgia banking family who heads American Express, obviously hit it off.

headline: Business People; BURNS ELECTS NEW CHIEF
abstract: James J. Cronin, the 54-year-old president and chief operating officer of Burns International Security Services, a leading private protection company, has been elected to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive officer. He will succeed George E.B.  King, 59, a grandson of William J. Burns, who founded the company in 1909.

headline: BASQUE HOME RULE BECOMING A REALITY
abstract: It was a typical day in the Basque provinces. In Lemona, in Vizcaya Province, two Civil Guards were killed when terrorists of the Basque separatist organization, E.T.A., detonated a land mine under their jeep. In Vizcaya and Guipuzcoa Provinces, a score of Basque radicals were accused under harsh antiterrorist legislation of helping E.T.A.   ''You know we've had two more today,'' Carlos Garaicoetxea, president of the regional government, said. He did not have to explain further.

headline: ISRAELI SHIPS SHELL PALESTINIAN BASE IN NORTH LEBANON
abstract: Israel struck again at Palestinian guerrilla positions in Lebanon today as its gunboats bombarded a camp in the far north more than 100 miles from the Israeli border.   The vessels opened fire on the Nahr al-Bared Palestinian camp north of Tripoli shortly after midnight, and Israeli officials said that they hit a guerrilla headquarters constructed on the ruins of a building that was the target of a raid in 1979. Wafa, the Palestinian press agency, said that today's raid was on a refugee camp and destroyed several houses but caused no casualties.

headline: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Real Estate; Eagerness For Sites in Manhattan
abstract: THIS man does not lose hope easily. For 50 years Stephen Merjanian and his family have lived in an apartment above a store at 452 Third Avenue, near 31st Street. His mother and sister live in another building next door.   He runs M. Merjanian Inc., a clothing store founded by his father.  Until Sept. 30, 1963, he owned his building. But on that date the Post Office Department took title to the entire block bounded by Third and Lexington Avenues and 31st and 32d Streets, intending to put a postal facility there.

headline: Company News; Morgan's Operating Net Up 12%
abstract: J.P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday a 12 percent increase in its first-quarter net operating earnings over the similar period of 1980. The company is the corporate parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest banking organization.

headline: PHILIPPINES PUTS STRESS ON IRRIGATION OF FARMS TO BRIDGE DRY SEASON
abstract: When the last of the monsoons subsided in November, the long dry season came to the Phillipines, except its southernmost islands. Now with the season almost spent in 98-degree temperatures, the land is parched and inhospitable to agriculture.   For most farmers, the land will become useful again only in July, weeks after the rains set in to soften the soil. They will then sow rice and corn and grow them while the rains last. In four months, they will harvest the only crop for the year.

headline: Natomas Sues Magma Power
abstract: The Natomas Company of San Francisco announced it had filed suit against the Magma Power Company and B.C. McCabe, who is Magma's chairman, chief executive officer and principal stockholder, to restrain them from making what it called false and misleading statements in connection with a Natomas $42-a-share cash tender offer for all of Magma's outstanding common. There are about 9.9 million Magma shares outstanding.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.4% IN APRIL
abstract: The Government index that is intended to forecast economic trends climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. The rise in the index of leading economic indicators was the second straight following three monthly declines.   The result, substantially in line with expectations, confirmed the views of many analysts that the economy would continue to push ahead into the summer but at a considerably slower rate than it did during the first quarter, when the nation's output of goods and services grew at an exceptionally robust annual rate of 8.4 percent.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: A little more than a month ago, a member of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government told a visitor that one of the Chancellor's concerns in trying to set up a weapons deal with Saudi Arabia was the effect the failure of such an effort might have on perceptions of his ability to make West Germany an influence in world affairs.   The problem, as seen by the associate of the Chancellor, who flew home Friday from talks in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, was that judgments would be made not only by Saudis and Israelis but also by Americans and Russians.   On Tuesday, when Mr. Schmidt announced in Riyadh that a weapons sale to Saudi Arabia was ''not feasible at this time,'' the associate was reminded of the earlier remark and asked what he thought the reaction would be in those places where West Germany wanted to maintain its influence.   The answer, in a sense, was a recognition of concern that Mr.  Schmidt might be seen as a man so weakened over the last six months that he could not do all he seemed capable of from 1977 until after his re-election last fall.

headline: Market Place; Two From One At Engelhard
abstract: SINCE Wall Street pays more for steady progress than erratic growth, Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation is planning to separate its precious metals and chemical businesses from its trading company.   Engelhard's plan involves a spinoff of Engelhard Industries, world leader in precious metals, along with its Minerals and Chemicals division, which mines and converts nonmetallic minerals for a variety of speciality products.   The two businesses would be organized as the Engelhard Corporation, while the present company's trading business, Philipp Brothers Division, would remain as the renamed Philbro Corporation.   If the plan is approved by shareholders at the May 20 annual meeting, each of them will receive 0.40 shares of the new company for each old share (record date May 20), and the company will seek a separate New York Stock Exchange listing for Philbro. The old company, Engelhard, will continue to trade on the Big Board.

headline: Republic's Mexico Service
abstract: Republic Airlines has been granted permission to serve six cities in western Mexico from Chicago, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

headline: Executive Movements In the Interpublic Group
abstract: James D. Kuras, 41, a senior vice president of the Interpublic Group of Companies, parent of McCann-Erickson, is moving over to be executive vice president and general manager of the New York office of McCann. He replaces Stephen W. Norcia, 40, who will move to Interpublic until he is assigned to another agency in the group.

headline: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. ANNOUNCES HAIG WILL GO TO CHINA IN LATE JUNE
abstract: The State Department said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will visit Peking at the end of June.  It would be the first high-level contact between the Reagan Administration and the Chinese leadership.

headline: Starrett Reports Loss of $504,000
abstract: The Starrett Housing Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had a loss of $504,000 in the first quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $39,000 for the corresponding 1980 period.   Starrett, which previously reported that it was discussing a restructuring proposal related to its bank debt and subordinated lenders, attributed the loss to high interest costs and a drop in volume at its Levitt division because of high interest rates on home mortgages.

headline: 5 YEARS A CAPTIVE, MRS. PERON IS STILL A RALLYING POINT
abstract: The high-walled compound sits, a foreboding presence, on the edge of this lushly foliaged town. The people of San Vicente, 25 miles outside Buenos Aires, have tried to inure themselves to it and its sole occupant.   ''She is incognito,'' said a gasoline station attendant. ''No one knows what goes on inside.'' But to Argentina, the compound and its prisoner are becoming an increasingly looming presence. Isabel Martinez de Peron, a captive of the military since her overthrow as President five years ago, is once again stirring the country.

headline: MILITARY SPENDING
abstract: To the Business Editor: From the end of the Korean war through 1979, this country spent $3.6 trillion at the Pentagon, not including veterans' benefits. We assume a 6 percent interest rate over that time span.

headline: FLAT RESULT EXPECTED FOR APRIL-JUNE G.N.P.
abstract: The gross national product will show no growth at all in the current April-June quarter, the Government projected today, after reporting that first-quarter G.N.P. had grown at a vigorous 8.6 percent annual rate.   On a more encouraging note, officials said inflation had eased in the first quarter to 9.8 percent, as measured by G.N.P.-connected figures. The department had put the inflation rate at 10 percent in an estimate last month. Inflation tends to decline as the economy slows, a process that many economists believe is now taking place.

headline: TROUBLED THRIFT UNIT MERGES WITH ANCHOR
abstract: Two Federal banking agencies, fearing a default at the New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association, forced it to merge with the Anchor Savings Bank yesterday.   The move was described in Washington as the seventh ''federally assisted'' merger of a thrift institution this year.  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation said their ''default prevention action'' allowed New York and Suburban's assets of $511 million to be absorbed by Anchor, which has $2.05 billion in assets. The four branches of New York and Suburban -two in Manhattan and two on Staten Island - were included in the takeover. The association's executive offices were in Scarsdale, N.Y.

headline: Texaco-Amoco Well
abstract: Texaco Inc. and the Amoco International Oil Company said on Friday that they had struck oil at a wildcat well they have been drilling in a remote part of northern Guatemala. They said they would drill two more wells at the site.

headline: EARNINGS MIXED FOR MAJOR COMPANIES
abstract: Major corporations showed mixed earnings results in the most recent quarter, according to a New York Times compilation of sales and earnings of 306 companies.   The industry-by-industry roundup shows that about 60 percent of the companies reported earnings increases or converted a loss into a profit. About 40 percent showed declines or reported a loss. The quarterly compilation is published today on page D6.

headline: Waldheim, in Moscow, Urges U.S.-Soviet Thaw
abstract: Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that an improvement in Soviet-American relations was important to enable a revival of negotiations on disarmament and other international problems.   Mr. Waldheim held a news conference at the end of a three-day official visit, during which he met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader and chief of state, and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

headline: Gas Found in Australia
abstract: Esperance Minerals said yesterday it had discovered a large natural gas deposit while drilling for oil shale at Nagoorin and Lowmead basins near Gladstone, Australia. However, drilling had to be abandoned for safety reasons. A blowout occurred during drilling, and natural gas has continued to flow unabated at rates over 500,000 cubic feet a day for over 39 days to date.

headline: Advertising; Doyle Dane Bernbach Has Cokin Creative Filter
abstract: In a switch of traffic flow from last week, Doyle Dane Bernbach got an account that had been at Bozell & Jacobs.

headline: I.M.F. Loans Set For Rumania
abstract: Rumania will get loans worth nearly $1.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund, it was announced today, and the Rumanian Government has promised to raise prices and hold down spending in an attempt to improve its international financial standing.   Rumania will have to repay its advances over three to seven years, with interest at annual rates varying from 6.25 percent to 13.5 percent or more.

headline: IDEAL TOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Careers; Is There A Machinist Shortage?
abstract: ''I T'S like asking for booze in the Prohibition era,'' said Oscar Rath, a faculty member of the New York City Technical College. ''At professional meetings they come up to me and whisper, 'Hey, Oscar, have you got a machinist for us?' ''   He was describing what he said was a shortage of good machinists and the secretive efforts of companies to find them. ''They don't want anyone else to know they are asking,'' he explained.   ''Why, yesterday, I had nine phone calls from major companies, and I can only fit them with two machinists,'' he added. Mr. Rath believes in fitting an individual's particular talent as a machinist to the particular skill a company requires.

headline: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PHONE RATE CHANGES APPROVED
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to begin applying a series of telephone rate increases, including a 16 percent increase for interstate long-distance calls.   Under a special F.C.C. order, A.T.& T. will be allowed to file notice tomorrow of rate increases to take effect at 12:01 A.M.  Sunday. An A.T.& T. spokesman confirmed that the company would do just that.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS EASED BRIBERY ACT
abstract: The Administration today proposed a significant relaxation of the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which was intended to prevent American companies from bribing foreign officials. The Administration argued that the existing legislation was making it difficult for the United States to compete in foreign markets.   The Administration's recommendations - which went beyond proposals already being considered in Congress to loosen the provisions of the 1977 act -would eliminate accounting regulations enforced by the Securities and Exchange Commission that require publicly owned corporations to keep accurate books and records on all transactions.  A narrower category of offenses would fall under the bribery section enforced by the Justice Department.

headline: COAL EXPORTERS ARE SEEN FACING PROBLEMS AT PORTS
abstract: The long-range problem in the coal export business may well turn out to be excess port capacity, rather than the inability of ports and other transportation companies to handle the expected boom, according to some rail and coal experts.   ''By 1985, I believe that we will have excess port capacity, even though a lot of the port expansion will never be completed,'' said John P. Fishwick, chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk & Western Railway.   An examination of the coal business and transportation problems surrounding its expansion was conducted at a workshop last week under the auspices of the Association of American Railroads, with participants that included executives from the railroads, coal producers and utilities.

headline: Oil Revenue Up 14% in Kuwait
abstract: Kuwait's revenue from crude oil exports reached $20.8 billion in 1980, a 14 percent increase over 1979, the Kuwait Chamber of Commerce and Industry said in its annual report released today.   The report said the increase took place despite the Government's decision to reduce production by 25 percent, to 1.5 million barrels a day from 2 million as of April 1, 1980.

headline: BRIGADIER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TELEPROMPTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: State Savings Association Near Agency Selection
abstract: It's not official yet, but it is understood that the agency selection committee of the Savings Banks Association of New York State will recommend to the organization today that it retain Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein for the estimated $2 million account.   The previous agency was Kenyon & Eckhardt and it has worked on the business for the last decade.

headline: RCA Officer Goes To TLK New York
abstract: David A. Heneberry, 50 years old and a real heavyweight on the direct marketing scene, is leaving RCA on May 1 to become general manager of TLK New York, the direct marketing subsidiary of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, with $15 million in billings.

headline: Schmidt Gets Backing of Coalition Partners for Stand on Missiles
abstract: Delegates to a party conference of the Free Democrats, the junior party in the Bonn coalition, voted 271 to 103 with 8 abtentions late last night to support the NATO decision to station additional nuclear missiles in Europe, provided arms limitation talks begin soon.   Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the party chairman, threatened to resign if the move was rejected.

headline: Ted Bates Name Change
abstract: Ted Bates & Company, 40-year-old consumer goods agency giant, is changing its name to Ted Bates Worldwide, joining the other agencies seeking a multinational image through a name change. Bates is entitled, however, since it does have 68 offices in 31 countries in its international group, as well as five big domestic subsidiaries.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Development Program, Governing Council - 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Conference on the Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 3 P.M.

headline: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mortgage Rate 14.5% at F.H.A.
abstract: The ceiling on interest rates for Government-backed, fixed-rate home loans will be raised to a record 14.5 percent on Monday, Federal officials said today.   The move will make home loans more costly for low-income and middle-income families served by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HIGH BONN OFFICIAL PRESSING U.S. TO SET DATE ON SOVIET ARMS TALK
abstract: A high West German Government official today listed Bonn's expectations in connection with the coming meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Rome, including the wish that the United States set a date for beginning arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union.   West Germany considers the Rome meeting, which begins Monday, of prime importance, the official said, since it will afford the Reagan Administration an occasion to trace the basic outlines of its foreign policy to its allies.   ''We feel a clear signal for the time frame for negotiations should be given at the meeting,'' said the high official, who declined to be identified.

headline: BANI-SADAR SAYS FOREIGN MINISTRY USURPS HIS POWER
abstract: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today accused the Iranian Foreign Ministry of usurping his powers and said that he would put the matter before a special commission set up to resolve disputes between Iranian leaders.   The President denounced the ministry for having described an Islamic peace envoy as pro-Iraqi and said that the ministry was both wrong and a meddler in an area that was his responsibility. The President is also Commander in Chief of the Iranian armed forces and in that capacity is responsible for any peace moves.

headline: STORE CHAIN PLANNED BY TECHNOCOLOR
abstract: Technicolor Inc., a major processor of professional motion-picture and consumer film, said yesterday in Los Angeles that it planned to enter the retail photographic finishing field with a new division, Technicolor One Hour Photo. The company said that it would spend $150 million to open about 1,000 stores by June 1986 that will develop and print film within one hour.   Normally, photo developing takes from a day to a week before delivery, although some stores offer four-hour delivery. Technicolor said that its One-Hour Photo stores would become a major new element in the processing of 110, 126 and 35-millimeter film.

headline: Real Estate; Designing Manhattan Retail Sites
abstract: SEVERAL midtown office towers under construction in Manhattan offer a variety of approaches to urban retail space, one of the more controversial issues in the proposed revision of midtown zoning and the proposed designation of an Upper East Side Historic District.   Whereas a decade or so ago many planners felt that downtown areas had to compete with their suburban counterparts - the regional shopping centers - and create enclosed malls to invite off-street strolling and capture something of the spirit of congregation, the planning pendulum is swinging again.   High-rise towers with gallerias, atria and arcades proliferated in recent years, but these ''covered pedestrian spaces,'' which gave developers a zoning bonus of more building bulk, were often not noticed and unsuccessful.   Many planners are now advocating the supremacy of the street and the need to reinforce its environment for pedestrians. The city's draft revision of midtown zoning proposes to eliminate many of the bonuses for certain ''public amenities'' and mandates, in many instances, street-level retail uses.

headline: THE GROWTH IN CONSUMER DEBT SLOWS
abstract: American consumers bought $2.33 billion more on installment credit than they paid off in April, a 25 percent decline from the expansion of credit in March but still one of the highest recent monthly totals, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   A big drop in new auto loans accounted for the decline from March.
