''Auto credit outstanding expanded a seasonally adjusted $428 million in April, compared with a $1.68 billion increase in March when newcar sales were boosted by rebate offers,'' the Fed report said.  The decline in the growth of credit for the month was the first since January.

headline: DROP FORESEEN IN ENERGY USE
abstract: The nation is expected to use slightly less energy this year than it did last, according to a report from the Department of Energy.

headline: DIXON, JOSEPH, CRUCIBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEAN WITTER INCOME GAINS
abstract: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. announced yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter ended May 31 increased 14.4 percent, to $12.7 million, or $1.15 a share, from $11.1 million, or $1.10 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased 23.8 percent, to $225.5 million, from $182.2 million.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY IRAQ HAD ABILITY TO MAKE NUCLEAR WEAPON IN 1981
abstract: State Department and intelligence officials said today they believed that Iraq had acquired enough enriched uranium and sensitive technology to make one nuclear weapon by the end of this year, and several bombs by the mid 1980's.   This conclusion, intelligence officials said, is based on Iraq's ambitious nuclear program, which they described as far exceeding either the Iraqis' power requirements or programs aimed at commercial use. But the conclusion is questioned by some Administration and Congressional quarters.   Concern about Iraq's nuclear capabilities has grown recently, the officials said, in light of intelligence reports that Baghdad has been negotiating with an Italian company to purchase a small reprocessing plant. In addition, the officials said that Italy had been training Iraqi technicians and scientists in reprocessing technology, which could be used to separate plutonium as a weapons material, a development that generated intense concern in Israel.

headline: U.N. UNCERTAIN ON LEBANON ROLE
abstract: High United Nations officials suggested today that an expansion of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon would offer the best prospect for restoring a measure of peace to that country. But they have concluded that there is virtually no chance such a plan would be accepted by Arab countries or the Soviet Union.   This assessment was made today as Brian Urquhart, a special United Nations representative, began attempts to ease the crisis. Mr.  Urquhart is to see key officials in Lebanon, Israel and Syria.

headline: U.S.-Japanese Coal Talks Set
abstract: Japanese coal importers and United States suppliers will hold their second set of annual talks in mid-July in California to pave the way for increasing exports to Japan. The announcement was made today by the Nippon Steel Corporation, which represents the Japanese side.

headline: Debt Service Rises in Seoul
abstract: South Korea's foreign debt servicing will require $25.8 billion during the five years starting this year, the Government's Economic Planning Board estimated in a study released today.   The estimate listed $3.6 billion in repayment of principal and interest for 1981, $4.2 billion for 1982, $5 billion for 1983, $6 billion for 1984 and $7 billion for 1985.

headline: BEGIN GREETS SADAT AT SINAI SETTLEMENT
abstract: Occupied Sinai, June 4 - President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt asked Prime Minister Menachem Begin today to halt Israeli attacks on Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanon and to place no deadline on diplomatic efforts toward a peaceful solution of the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon.   Mr. Begin immediately rejected the request on the guerrilla bases, arguing that pre-emptive attacks by land, sea and air were essential to Israel's security. But he agreed to give more time for Syria to withdraw the antiaircraft missiles it began moving into Lebanon April 29, the day after Israeli jets shot down two Syrian helicopters. Talks Held at a Strategic Site   The leaders outlined their positions at a news conference after a 90-minute meeting in this Sinai settlement overlooking the strategic Strait of Tiran leading into the Gulf of Aqaba. The settlement is scheduled to be returned to Egypt next April under the peace treaty signed by Egypt and Israel in 1979.

headline: Aetna Link to I.B.M.
abstract: Aetna Life and Casualty announced yesterday it had signed an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to market more than 1,000 mini-computers to independent agents throughout the country by 1985. The contract commits Aetna to buy as much as $70 million in specially tailored equipment from I.B.M. over the next four years.

headline: Saudi Budget Allocates $25 Billion for Security
abstract: Saudi Arabia, the world's major oil exporter, announced a $90 billion budget today with more than a quarter of the money for the military and the police.

headline: FIRST VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TREASURY AIDE CRITICAL OF FED
abstract: Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that, in trying to peg interest rates, the Federal Reserve System ''interferes'' with the steady slowing of money supply growth, which is one of the key economic policy objectives of the Reagan Administration.   Mr. Sprinkel, one of the country's leading monetarists, asserts that inflation is primarily caused by excessive money creation. He discussed in Congressional testimony what he called ''technical factors for consideration'' by the Fed to improve its monetary control.   ''We do not presume to dictate monetary policy procedures to the Federal Reserve,'' he told the monetary and fiscal subcommittee of the Joint Economic Committee. ''However, since the success of the economic recovery program is so dependent on achievement of monetary targets, we are vitally concerned that results match intent.''

headline: ALLIED MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 BANKS CUT PRIME TO 19 1/2 PERCENT
abstract: Citibank and the Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that they had lowered their prime rate to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent.  On Monday the Chemical Bank reduced its prime rate a full percentage point, to 19 percent, and last week the Marine Midland Bank was the first to drop to the 19 1/2 percent level.   At most other banks the prime rate remains 20 percent, but many analysts expect that within a few days the rate will settle at 19 1/2 percent or less.

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS COUNCIL BACKS HIGHER ARMS OUTLAY
abstract: A ''substantial increase'' in military outlays to support the United States ability to use force in unstable regions was urged yesterday in New York by a panel drawn largely from leading figures in four recent Administrations.   The report urged the sending of arms to Afghan insurgents, an ''improved capacity'' for covert action and aid and training for regimes friendly to the United States to preserve their ''internal security.''   These and other measures were recommended in a 23-page pamphlet published by the Council on Foreign Relations, an influential private organization.

headline: Magellan Holders Back Management
abstract: The Magellan Petroleum Corporation said that its management had won a proxy contest initiated by United Canso Oil and Gas Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, owner of some 74,800 shares of Magellan.   According to a Magellan spokesman, a preliminary count indicated that holders of 4 million shares voted in favor of the current management compared with 2.9 million favoring United Canso.   Magellan, which has its headquarters in Hartford, has long been dominated by the family of William F. Buckley Jr., the writer, and his brother James Buckley, a former United States Senator.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In November 1979, Andrei A. Gromyko, the first Soviet Foreign Minister to visit Madrid, reportedly made an extraordinary private offer to his Spanish counterpart at the time, Marcelino Oreja.   If Spain discontinued its plans to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Mr. Gromyko reportedly said, the Soviet Union would be prepared to help in combating Spain's most trying domestic problem, terrorism.   But, according to Spanish officials, Mr. Gromyko also implied that a decision to go forward with NATO membership might leave Spain's young democracy vulnerable to more terrorist actions. Soviet Aid to E.T.A. Hinted   Even before Mr. Gromyko issued this reported threat, some Spanish politicians and intelligence officials were convinced that Moscow was assisting the Basque terrorist group E.T.A., a Marxist-Leninist organization whose avowed aim is to create an independent, socialist Basque nation. Former Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, who resigned in January, was among the most convinced.

headline: TREASURY CHIEF SEES INTEREST RATES RISING MORE, CITES HARM TO BUDGET
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that interest rates would probably climb higher and stay high for ''several months.'' He added that rate increases since March had increased the Federal budget deficit for the 1981 fiscal year by $2 billion to $5 billion.   At a breakfast meeting with reporters, he termed this year's budget ''a disaster,'' and predicted that the Treasury's overall borrowing needs in the 12 months ending Sept. 30 would total $75 billion to $80 billion.   He said the 1981 deficit could reach $60 billion, with the balance of the total borrowing requirements stemming from programs, largely involving Government credit, that Congress had specifically excluded from regular budget accounting.

headline: Continental Target Of Texas Air's Suit
abstract: Texas International Airlines has filed suit against the management of Continental Air Lines and the newly formed Continental Employees Association, accusing them of conspiring to block a takeover bid by the Texas line.   The suit, filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles, contended that Continental; its president, A.L. Feldman; the airline's directors, and the employee group had violated Federal securities laws by seeking to entrench themselves and prevent Texas International from taking control of the airline.

headline: U.S. Spy Planes Going to Britain
abstract: The United States will station new spy planes in Britain beginning in 1983, Geoffrey Pattie, Britain's Under Secretary for Defense, said today.

headline: CAPITAL RALLY ASSAILS ARMS TO SALVADOR
abstract: At least 20,000 demonstrators marched on the Pentagon today to protest United States military aid to El Salvador, proposed increases in arms spending and budget cuts in social programs.   The rally, organized by a coalition of religious, student, labor and black activists, was the largest antiwar protest seen here since the demonstrations for peace in Vietnam in the early 1970's.   The marchers, carrying banners and posters, stretched at one point from the Lincoln Memorial, across the Memorial Bridge over the Potomac River, to the Pentagon's mall entrance, where speakers addressed the crowd from an elevated stand.   ''This is the first national act of resistance to Reagan's repression, racism and militarism,'' shouted Laurie Fierstein of the People's Anti-War Mobilization, which organized the rally.

headline: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.& W. Lifts Stake In Collins & Aikman
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. announced it had increased its stake in the Collins & Aikman Corporation and sold all of its holdings in the Salant Corporation, a diversified apparel manufacturer.

headline: ALLIES ANGERED AS U.S. SLASHES SCIENCE OUTLAYS
abstract: It was a determined and angry Vittorio Manno who stepped into the chill Paris morning and headed for Orly Airport on the Monday after President Reagan announced his budget revisions in February. He boarded a Concorde for New York, where he was met by two Americans - high officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration - in a private Air France lounge at Kennedy International Airport.   The message Dr. Manno brought from Paris, where he is deputy science director of the 11-nation European Space Agency, was filled with injured indignation.   His agency had already spent $100 million fulfilling its commitment under the International Solar Polar Mission, a joint venture to fly twin spacecraft - one European, one American - over opposite poles of the sun to make scientific observations. And now, as the Reagan Administration trimmed its budget, the United States was abruptly and unilaterally planning to kill its satellite.

headline: New American Library Switches to Marsteller
abstract: In another account switch, Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, has been named to do advertising for the New American Library, a subsidiary of the Times-Mirror Corporation.

headline: GEORGE GILDER'S HYMN TO GETTING RICH
abstract: It is well, nay, essential for the progress of the race, that the houses of some should be homes for all that is highest and best in literature and the arts, rather than that none should be so. Much better this great irregularity than universal squalor.   Andrew Carnegie, Wealth, 1889 PEOPLE magazine immortalized his Massachusetts homestead. Money is doing his finances. He has peered out of the pages of both Time and Newsweek, been profiled by the Washington Post, and cross-examined by both Bill Buckley and 60 Minutes. When the restless eye of the media decides to focus, there is no fooling around.   The object of all this publicity is a 41-year-old writer named George Gilder, an unlikely literary lion whose new book, ''Wealth and Poverty,'' has been embraced by Washington with a warmth not seen since the Kennedys adopted John Kenneth Galbraith.

headline: U.S. SENT TWO PATROLS INTO LAOS IN QUEST OF G.I.'S THOUGHT TO BE CAPTIVES
abstract: The Reagan Administration sent at least two long-range patrols into Laos in response to what a high-ranking official called ''tantalizing hints'' that American prisoners of war were still alive in that country, Administration officials said today.   The patrols of 20 to 30 men, mostly Laotians, did not bring back the evidence they sought, the officials said. No American military personnel were involved in the operation, the officials said, but civilians under the supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency helped to plan, finance and train the patrols.   Whether the Americans accompanied the patrols into Laos was not clear, and other details of the operation were sparse. But officials said that it was mounted with the approval of the State Department, with intelligence information from the Defense Intelligence Agency, and under the operational control of the C.I.A.

headline: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 16
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. IS WEIGHING AID TO CHINA IF RUSSIANS ACT AGAINST POLAND
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union was continuing to build up its forces in and around Poland and added that the response of the United States to intervention by Moscow could include trade sanctions and the sale of weapons to China.   ''There's still a lot of activity that we wish weren't going on,'' Mr. Weinberger said as he arrived here on his way to a longscheduled meeting in Bonn on Tuesday of defense ministers of the 15 North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries.   ''I suspect that the Poles wished it weren't going on, too,'' he said.  Mr. Weinberger said he believed that the Polish people would resist Soviet forces if they invade Poland. 'Concerted Action' Is Sought   The Secretary said that the United States and its allies in Europe had been discussing other political and economic responses in a ''concerted action'' if Soviet troops intervened in Poland. He declined to give details.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Open-Ended Working Group on the Drafting of International Conventions on Migrant Workers - 10:30 A.M.   Unicef executive board - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.  U.S. ENVOYS BONE UP ON TERROR TACTICS

headline: IRANIAN FORCES HUNT FOR BANI-SADR AS HE IS BLAMED FOR COUNTRY'S ILLS
abstract: Iranian security forces hunted for President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today as an aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini accused him of being responsible for whatever shortcomings Iran had.   Parliamentary sources said that although the President continued to be missing, impeachment proceedings were still scheduled to begin tomorrow, without him if necessary. They noted, however, that the Speaker, Ayatollah Hashemi Rafsanjani, could postpone the session.

headline: Delay in Merger Hurt Amax Socal
abstract: Shares of Amax Inc. continued to come under heavy selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as the prospects for a takeover of the huge mining company by the Standard Oil Company of California grew increasingly uncertain.   Socal paid $37.67 a share for 20 percent of Amax in 1975 and offered early in March to buy the rest for between $78.50 and $86.75 a share in cash and stock, or at least $4 billion.

headline: CBS WANTS TO STAR IN THE MOVIES--AS ONE OF THE MAJOR FILM PRODUCERS
abstract: W hile movies have been booming at the box office the past few weeks, all is not well in the movie business. The majors are said to be retrenching and the independents falling by the wayside. And the reasons are legion: the skyrocketing costs of talent, production, promotion and distribution; the percentage of profits consumed by the rising prime rate; the impending directors' strike; the attrition rate of quality motion pictures; and the difficulty of closing favorable distribution deals and of collecting the agreed-upon share of box office receipts.   Having considered all that, CBS Inc. wants in. It wants to be a star, a studio to rival the long-established Hollywood majors - even though it phased out its last feature-film venture at a loss. It wants to produce movies that, far from being film fodder, will succeed at the box office and sell year after year on video cassettes and videodisks.

headline: A Flood Cleanup in Mexico City
abstract: Residents of southern sections of this city swept, bailed and pumped water out of their homes today after flooding was touched off by a day of heavy rain.

headline: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EGYPT NOW SAYS 10 DIED IN MOSLEM-CHRISTIAN CLASHES
abstract: The Egyptian Minister of the Interior reported to Parliament today that 10 people were killed and 55 injured in rioting between Moslems and Christian Copts in Cairo this week.   The report by Mohammed Nabawi Ismail said that 113 people had been detained and 37 rifles and pistols seized as policemen searched the slum district where the clashes took place. He said the police were still searching for weapons.

headline: Advertising; Co-op Ads' New Look At Doner
abstract: WHEN a newspaper ad for a supermarket is full of individual nationally branded items, that's cooperative advertising. When a television commercial by a perfume manufacturer ends up with a fivesecond message giving the name of a store at which it is available, that's a co-op ad, too.   Cooperative advertising is advertising run by the retailer and partially paid for by the manufacturer, and it is one of the hardest areas to work in and administer in the advertising industry.   Advertisers worry about not having enough control. They worry about verifying that a retailer has indeed run the advertising as claimed.

headline: Company News; American Financial
abstract: The American Financial Corporation, a diversified financial holding company, said it had two options to buy a total of 304,165 shares, or 6.8 percent, of the common stock of Chi-Chi's Inc., a chain of Mexican-style restaurants.In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Financial said the options may be exercised between July 9 and Dec. 31. It said it viewed the options as an investment.

headline: NEW SURGERY REQUIRED
abstract: The medical information on the shooting of Pope John Paul II, although incomplete, showed that the most serious damage was done to the intestines.   Three sections of the bowel, or intestines, were removed in surgery, which was termed successful, at the Gemelli Hospital in Rome.   A second operation will be needed to reconnect portions of the bowel that were surgically severed in a procedure called a temporary exclusion colostomy, which allows removal of bodily wastes through an opening of the colon part of the bowel outside the body.   The Pope received about six pints of blood, the equivalent of about 60 percent of his total blood volume.  Surgical repair of the bowel is common in gunshot wounds to the abdomen, and a temporary colostomy is often necessary in such injuries. Recovery is often complete, provided complications do not develop.

headline: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has elected to its board John G. Linvill, professor of computer systems and director of the Center for Integrated Systems at Stanford University. Martin G. Landin was elected vice president of domestic sales.   * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, has elected Robert J. Lambrix corporate vice president and chief financial officer.

headline: Fred Meyer Offer
abstract: Fred Meyer Inc., the largest retailer in the Pacific Northwest, said yesterday in Portland, Ore., that its board has decided that ''it is not in the best interest of the company and shareholders'' to pursue further the proposal by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, to buy the company. The offer by the New York investment company involved participation by Meyer management at a price of $310 million.

headline: TEXT OF LETTER SENT BY LEFEVER
abstract: Following is the text of a letter sent to President Reagan today by Ernest W. Lefever asking that his name be withdrawn from consideration for the position of Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs: My Dear Mr. President:   I am blameless of the charges and innuendoes against my integrity and my compassion. I do not wish any longer to put up with the kind of suspicion and character assassination that some of my adversaries have used to besmirch my name.

headline: SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1981; International
abstract: The White House, Congressional leaders and domestic auto makers hailed Japan's plan to limit car shipments to the United States, saying the move should deflect moves in Congress toward import quotas. Others said it would push up prices of all cars. (Page 1.) Japanese auto industry officials responded to their Government's agreement with highly unusual statements of disapproval. (1.)   The United States will fulfill its financing commitments to the Asian Development Bank, Timothy McNamar, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, reassured representatives of the 14-year-old multilateral financial institution. (29.)

headline: Insider Reports; Insider Reports for Exchanges; Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. NEW YORK EXCHANGE   ALBERTO-CULVER COMPANY-W. Clement Stone, director, sold 25,500 shares leaving him directly with 145,584 shares and by wife, 225,940.  BIG THREE INDUSTRIES-Russell Kraig Smith, director, sold or disposed of 15,200 shares, including gifts of 200 shares, leaving him 175,894.

headline: Gulf Canada Plans Beaufort Drilling
abstract: Gulf Canada Ltd. said today that it would spend $674 million (Canadian) to build and operate a yearround drilling system for the frigid Beaufort Sea, estimated to hold reserves of some six billion barrels of oil.   Gulf Canada, a 60 percent owned subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said that it would build two offshore drilling platforms, two icebreakers and two supply vessels to begin a drilling program on 1.5 million acres of the sea in the summer of 1983.

headline: Allied Considers Sale Of 2 Canadian Units
abstract: The Allied Chemical Corporation, based in Morris Township, N.J., said it is considering the sale of two of its Canadian subsidiaries, the Uno-Tex Petroleum Corporation and Union Texas of Canada Ltd., for an undetermined price. Both companies are involved in oil and natural gas exploration in western Canada and had combined afterroyalties revenues of $39.8 million (Canadian) in 1980, Allied said.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAEL DERIDES SYRIAN PHOTOS
abstract: The Israeli military command today derided a Syrian contention that an Israeli plane was shot down yesterday by antiaircraft missiles.   Sources at command headquarters said the wreckage shown in Syrian photos might been that of a pilotless plane that crashed in Lebanon on a mission one and a half years ago. Israel said at the time that the drone had not returned to its base.

headline: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW ZEALAND QUESTIONS THE U.S. GOAL OF ISOLATING AND PUNISHING VIETNAM the Foreign Minister of New Zealand
abstract: One of America's closest allies in the Pacific questioned at a two-day conference that ended today whether the Reagan Administration's policy of seeking to isolate and punish Vietnam for its ties to the Soviet Union might be too harsh and result in pushing Hanoi even closer to Moscow.   According to participants at the 30th annual meeting of the Anzus Council, Foreign Minister Brian E. Talboys of New Zealand told Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that he was concerned that if the current diplomatic effort to persuade Vietnam to withdraw from Cambodia failed, the American approach of stepping up pressure on Vietnam might prove counterproductive.   Throughout his Asian trip, Mr. Haig has been attacking Vietnam at every opportunity. In Manila Saturday, he said that the United States would not normalize relations with Vietnam so long as its soldiers remained in Cambodia and was ''a source of trouble to the entire region.''

headline: Sears Foresees Improved Profits
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company expects a ''substantial'' improvement in the profit of its merchandising group this fiscal year after a ''poor'' performance last year, Richard Jones, its vice chairman, told security analysts in New York yesterday.   He said that the giant retailer expected all three operating divisions, which include the Allstate Insurance Group and a financial services and real-estate division, to post earnings gains in the fiscal year ending next January.   He also reported that March sales so far had been increasing at a double-digit rate over the year before.

headline: ARMS MAKERS SEEN GAINING POLITICALLY
abstract: The nation's largest defense contractors have enhanced their political power in recent years by investing heavily in campaign contributions and by billing the Government for major lobbying expenses in Washington, according to a report released today on the politics of defense contracting.   The report, prepared by the Council on Economic Priorities, an independent research organization based in New York, said that eight major defense contractors spent a total of more than $2 million on campaign contributions between 1976 and 1980.   Sixty percent of that amount was given to candidates for Federal office, mostly to key members of military and appropriations committees in Congress, according to Federal Election Commission statistics cited in the report. Eight Companies Scrutinized   The eight companies examined in the report were the Boeing Company, the General Dynamics Corporation, the Grumman Corporation, the Lockheed Corporation, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Northrop Corporation, the Rockwell International Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation.

headline: International
abstract: The West German recession raises doubts about Bonn's future as the economic engine of Europe. Economists fear that the downturn, which is expected to be temporary, has severely damaged West Germany's business structure. (Page D1.)

headline: Stock System's Volume at 1.8%
abstract: A pilot automated stock trading system operated by the Cincinnati Stock Exchange continues to account for only a small share of total trading volume during its third year of operation, a monitoring report by the Securities and Exchange Commission has found.   The system, called the National Securities Trading System, accounted for only 1.8 percent of composite share volume in the 49 stocks traded in the system in 1980, the S.E.C. said.

headline: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUBMARINE SAID TO HAVE LEFT CRASH AREA BECAUSE SKIPPER SAW NOTHING AMISS
abstract: Naval and diplomatic reports on the collision of an American submarine and a Japanese freighter two weeks ago show that the submarine left the scene shortly after the accident because the American captain saw nothing amiss, Pentagon officials said today.   These officials said that the submarine George Washington had surfaced immediately after striking the freighter Nissho Maru. The submarine's crew determined that the damage to their vessel was minor and they saw the Japanese ship steaming away apparently unharmed, the officials said.   The captain of the submarine, which carries nuclear ballistic missiles, then ordered his craft to submerge and to clear the area in accord with standard operating procedures intended to avoid detection by Soviet satellites, ships or aircraft.

headline: WEST ALLOWS POLES 4-YEAR DEBT DELAY
abstract: The United States and 14 other Western industrialized nations agreed today to let Poland postpone $2.6 billion in debt repayments due this year for four years to ease the pressure on its ailing economy.   The agreement - the first rescheduling of a Communist country's foreign debt - is intended to be the first step in a concerted and prolonged effort by all of Poland's foreign creditors to prevent the country from going bankrupt and to enable it to buy essential imports of food and other goods.   In return for this assistance, however, the Polish Government has undertaken to impose stringent austerity measures on its people with the intention of eventually repaying outstanding loans and eliminating its need to borrow abroad. It acknowledges, however, that the measures will cut living standards and increase unemployment.

headline: U.S. CALLS MANEUVERS WITH LIBERIA A MOVE TO STABILIZE ITS REGIME
abstract: The Reagan Administration has ordered a show of military support for the Government of President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia in an effort to maintain him in office and to fend off offers of military aid from Libya, a State Department official said yesterday.   The official said that sending 100 soldiers from the Special Forces, better known as the Green Berets, and a missile-firing destroyer was intended to persuade Master Sergeant Doe to take United States interest as genuine.   ''You're dealing with a sergeant,'' the spokesman said. ''He'll take us more seriously if there's a military dimension to our aid.'' While the United States has detected no one waiting to topple Sergeant Doe from power, the spokesman said, the Administration would be confronted with an unknown if he fell. Sergeant Doe came to power in a coup a year ago.

headline: Regan Holds Talks With Bonn Official
abstract: West Germany's Finance Minister, Hans Matthofer, troubled by high American interest rates, was cautioned today by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, at a meeting near Frankfurt, that American interest rates would recede only ''as monetary growth and inflationary expectations recede.''   But Mr. Regan reportedly told Mr. Matthofer that ''interest rates are at or near their peak and will be coming down in the next couple of months.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * All-Steel Inc., Aurora, Ill., has elected Mason D. Feisel president and chief executive officer.   * Batus Inc., Louisville, Ky., has appointed Dale N. Garth vice president and director of strategic planning for the Batus Retail division.

headline: 13.54 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,007.42
abstract: A growing conviction that interest rates have peaked touched off a rousing rally in stock prices yesterday in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 13.54 points, to close at 1,007.42, going above the 1,000 level for the first time since April 29.   The average pierced the 1,000 level six times previously this year but has failed to stay above it for more than a week or two at a time, usually being driven down by rising interest rates, especially in late April and May.   The Dow dropped 41 points in the first two weeks of May because of rising interest rates, reaching 963.44 on May 11, before beginning to climb again to its current level.

headline: Creamer Acquisition
abstract: Creamer Inc., which made a small agency acquisition in Chicago on Jan. 1, has reached an agreement to pick up another one out there. It is the Chicago office of Barkley & Evergreen of Overland Park, Kan., and its contribution of about $5 million will bring Creamer's C hicago size to about $13 million.

headline: British Car Sales Rise
abstract: British car sales in April rose nearly 19 percent from a year earlier, to 136,000 units, while imports fell to 55.3 percent of the market from 58.5 percent, according to figures released today by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

headline: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Currency Markets; DOLLAR UP SHARPLY IN EUROPE
abstract: The dollar surged in value against other currencies in European trading today following yesterday's one-point increase in the Federal Reserve's discount rate to a record 14 percent.   Although the dollar eased in later New York trading, the strong showing in Europe raised widespread fears among European bankers and monetary officials that other countries would also be forced to increase rates to defend their currencies against the dollar, further depressing Europe's recession-gripped economy and creating more unemployment.   Contributing to those fears, France's central bank today raised its discount rate for seven-day Treasury bills a full percentage point, to 13.5 percent, in an effort to bolster the sagging franc. The franc has been depressed by the fast-climbing dollar and fears that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing may lose next Sunday's Presidential election to his Socialist opponent, Francois Mitterrand.

headline: ROMAN CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CRISIS IN POLAND: SOVIET FORCES FORMIDABLE
abstract: Although there have been no Soviet military moves of substance during the last week, the consensus among United States and other NATO analysts is that Soviet ground and air strength in and around Poland would be sufficient to deal with Polish resistance even should it take the form of a national rising.   Discussions of possible military developments have increased in the last 48 hours because both diplomatic and military sources believe there has been a worsening of the situation. The Soviet Union, it is said, has reached the point where it cannot ignore further Polish defiance and where it must weigh the pros and cons of military action.   An important element in Soviet planning, an Atlantic alliance source said, must be the evaluation of the loyalties of the Polish Army and Air Force in the event of an intervention. The consensus among Western experts is that, with the exception of a small number of senior officers, the ground and air forces would resist Soviet military intervention.

headline: WYSZYNSKI FORTIFIED CHURCH UNDER COMMUNIST RULE
abstract: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw and Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, spent three decades in a struggle with secular authority and left the Polish church far more powerful than before.   Treading a thin line between resistance and compromise, he prevailed - through Stalinist incarceration and the persecution of the faithful, through the harassment that followed, through Communist efforts to legislate the church into submission, through the downfall of a succession of discredited party and Government chiefs.  In the end, an officially atheist regime had to turn to him and his bishops for rescue from a citizenry enraged by economic hardships as well as by official corruption and ineptitude.   In the labor unrest starting last year, Cardinal Wyszynski became the arbitrator between between the leaders of the independent labor movement and the Communist Party leadership. Right to Be a Catholic Nation   ''After 10 centuries of Catholicism,'' he had reminded Poland's political leaders long before, in 1966, ''we have the right to be a Catholic nation, and we do not resign that right.'' Responding to cheers from hundreds of thousands of pilgrims in Upper Silesia, he used that show of support to plead for co-existence between the Church and ''the authority of Caesar.''

headline: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TANNING PARLORS FADE FROM FRANCHISE SCENE
abstract: ''It was too much blue sky,'' said Fred Tippen, president of Wonder Tan, an Atlanta-based company, when asked what happened to all those tanning parlors. ''Everybody thought it was easy money.''   Or talk to Rick Stevenson, president of Supertan, based in Arkansas: ''This is personal,'' he said, ''but I think franchising is the biggest rip-off in the world.''   In 1978, when the idea of tanning booth franchises was first marketed with vigor, the enterprise looked like an entrepreneur's dream. In two minutes, for a few dollars a visit, the public would get brown. And seemingly, for a franchise fee of $7,000 to $30,000, a few strips of plywood, some goggles, some ultraviolet tanning bulbs and a supply of reflective paper, the entrepreneurs needed only to wait for the profits to roll in.

headline: ARMS SCANDAL IS CHARGED IN COSTA RICA
abstract: A congressional committee here has charged that some of the weapons that entered this country from Cuba in 1979 to help overthrow the Somoza regime in Nicaragua were subsequently sold illegally by Costa Rican officials for smuggling to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.   The three-man commission also accused the Government of President Rodrigo Carazo Odio of covering up its involvement in the regional arms traffic and of trying to block the 11-month-long congressional investigation.   The 73-page report, which was issued yesterday, has added to the widespread disenchantment with President Carazo, whose management of the economy and foreign policy has come under mounting criticism from both opposition parties and his former supporters.   Almost all Costa Ricans cheered on the Sandinist guerrillas in their struggle to overthrow Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle two years ago. They condoned the fact that Costa Rican territory was being used by the guerrillas as a propaganda base, for military training and as a conduit for weapons being supplied to them by the Governments of Panama, Venezuela and Cuba.

headline: Asarco Sets Accord On Sale of Stock
abstract: Asarco Inc. said it had signed formal agreements with institutional investors covering the previously announced issuance by the company of $140 million of preferred stock.

abstract: * Amerace Corporation has named David L. Nighbert a group vice president responsible for the Swan Hose division and the Anchor Coupling Company subsidiary.   * American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Theodore Deikel executive vice president.

headline: INVESCO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business People; Posner Critical of Image
abstract: Victor Posner, the 61-year-old controversial entrepreneur whose name has long been identified with corporate takeover efforts, says that this public image is inaccurate. ''We have positions in 40 or 50 companies,'' he asserted yesterday in a telephone interview.

headline: Trains Are Stoned in Yugoslavia
abstract: Trains and railroad equipment are being stoned in the troubled southern province of Kosovo, it was reported today. The Belgrade newspaper Politika Ekspres did not blame anyone for the attacks. It said they had become frequent since the rioting by ethnic Albanians in Kosovo last March and April.

headline: FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Consumer prices rose last month at an annual rate of 7.5 percent, the Labor Department reported. The increase was the smallest advance since July. The small advance reflected the slowing of energy price increases and an apparent imporovement in the inflation picture overall. (Page A1.)   Adjustable-rate home loans were approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in a move that will significantly change the structure of the nation's home mortgage market. The absence of a limit on rate changes was criticized by consumer groups. (A1.)

headline: KELSEY-HAYES CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ethiopian Rebels Report Gain
abstract: Guerrillas seeking autonomy for Ethiopia's northern province of Tigre said today that they had gained control of 80 percent of the province.

headline: LEISURE GROUP INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Forum; ...AND REFORM FUNDING
abstract: The most serious mistake made by the Carter Administration was to allow savings banks and savings and loan associations to sell sixmonth savings certificates. Before that move, these thrift institutions were attempting to sell savings certificates with maturities of up to 10 years. And they had begun to extend the average maturity of their deposits. Since the advent of the six-month certificates, the thrift institutions have sold close to $100 billion of them, but not without some troubling consequences. As a result of the large amounts of money flowing into the thrift institutions, this inflationary effect drove the national average price of a home up close to 100 percent, and as savers closed out passbook accounts and put the money into the new certificates, this more than doubled interest payments on deposits and put a tremendous squeeze on the thrifts' profits.

headline: SOONG CHING-LING IS EULOGIZED BY DENG
abstract: The man widely expected to be China's next Communist Party chairman, Hu Yaobang, presided over funeral services today for Soong Ching-ling before 10,000 mourners, including the present party chairman, Hua Guofeng.   Deng Xiaoping, who as the party's senior deputy chairman is China's nominal ruler, delivered a 25-minute eulogy for Miss Soong, who died Friday at the age of 90. She was the widow of Sun Yat-sen, who founded modern China in 1911.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Two phrases sum up the political battle that will be conducted over the next two weeks between President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Francois Mitterrand, the candidate of the French Socialist Party.   One phrase is the slogan on a Socialist poster: ''Change? Or 14 Years of Giscard?'' The other was heard all over town today; for instance, in a statement by Roger Chinaud, an aide to Mr. Giscard d'Estaing: ''If Mitterrand is elected he will need the presence of Communists in his government.''   The two phrases suggest why the May 10 runoff election between the two largest vote-getters yesterday offers a crucial test of the French Fifth Republic.   The institution erected by Charles de Gaulle - a presidency with a seven-year term and powers unequaled in any other democratic Western nation - was designed to give strong government to a France weakened by continual political crisis.

headline: Bomb Damages a NATO Depot
abstract: A bomb explosion at a halffinished North Atlantic Treaty Organization arms depot at Wahrendahl, 17 miles southwest of Hanover, caused damage estimated at $130,000 today. There were no injuries. The police said they suspected that antimilitary terrorists set the bomb.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied Corp. said that a preliminary count of the shares tendered in its offer for Bunker Ramo Corp. showed that the offer had been oversubscribed.   * Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. approved resumption of a previous attempt to acquire a total of 1,250,000 shares of its common stock, of which 500,000 shares were acquired during the three weeks ended March 22.   * Eletrobras, Brazil's national electric company, said it had signed a $300 million, eight-year loan agreement with 32 international banks led by Bank of America.

headline: EL SALVADOR TURNS DOWN A PLAN FOR OUTSIDE MEDIATION
abstract: A major international effort to bring El Salvador's warring factions to the bargaining table has failed with the refusal of the Salvadoran army high command to accept an offer of outside mediation.   Hopes for an early breakthrough toward a political settlement of the conflict were further dampened this week when the Reagan Administration showed little interest in the latest peace initiative.    The mediation proposal, which had been endorsed by the opposition Democratic Revolutionary Front, was made last month to the President of the Salvadoran junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte, by a special representative of the Socialist International, the worldwide organization of Social Democrats.

headline: Around the World; Japan Says It Won't Bar The Carrier Midway
abstract: The Japanese Government, under attack in Parliament for allowing nuclear-armed American ships to enter Japanese waters, today rejected a demand by the opposition that the aircraft carrier Midway be banned from returning to its home port here.

headline: RECORD U.S. WHEAT CROP FORECAST
abstract: The Agriculture Department today predicted a record American wheat crop for the second consecutive year, giving the United States greater flexibility in negotiating additional grain sales to the Soviet Union.   The department's latest crop report, which followed yesterday's offer to resume selling grain to the Russians, estimated that the 1981 winter wheat harvest would be 2.01 billion bushels, or 54.8 million metric tons. This would be 6 percent larger than last year's crop but 3 percent less than the department forecast in May.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Du Pont Company, Wilmington, Del., has elected to its board Edward Shapiro, co-founder and former chairman of the New England Nuclear Corporation.   * General Foods Corporation, White Plains, has appointed Ervin R.  Shames president of General Foods-Europe, succeeding James C.  Tappan, who becomes group vice president, corporate planning and information services.

headline: Pembroke Cracking Plans Wales Unit
abstract: Texaco Inc. and the Gulf Oil Corporation said a jointly owned affiliate had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of notes and debentures, proceeds of which will be used to finance a fluid catalytic cracking unit and related facilities at Milford Haven, Wales.   The facilities are designed to convert 65,000 barrels a day of heavy fuel oil into gasoline and other higher-grade products, the companies said.

headline: FIRST WISCONSIN MORTGAGE TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SMALL PARTY HEADS NEW ITALIAN CABINET
abstract: Italy's Christian Democrats lost the post of Prime Minister for the first time in 36 years today as Giovanni Spadolini, secretary of the small Republican Party, was sworn in at the head of a 27-member coalition by President Sandro Pertini.   Mr. Spadolini, the 56-year-old leader of a party that won only three percent of the seats in Parliament in elections in 1979, ended a monthlong Government crisis provoked by a scandal over a secret Masonic lodge by putting together a coalition that lacks only the Communist Party and the neo-Fascist Social Movement among major parties.   Mr. Spadolini said in an interview that this was ''the first secular Government in the history of the Republic,'' and said it was ''a historic event because it established for the first time the practice of rotation of the Prime Ministership between the secular and the Catholic forces in the country.'' Role for Communists Is Unlikely   He added that it was unlikely that the Communists would enter the Government during the five-year term of Parliament that will last until 1984 unless national elections have to be called early.

headline: Advertising; KELLOGG MAPS CAMPAIGN FOR ITS NUTRI-GRAIN CEREAL
abstract: Suddenly the Kellogg Company, the dominant force in the country's dry cereal business, has four new products, but that doesn't come as much of a surprise to the industry, which has been getting bits and pieces from the trade press since William E. LaMothe, chairman, slipped out a teaser line at the annual meeting six weeks ago.   The products, packaged altogether differently from the many others in the Kellogg's line (no red logo), are called Nutri-Grain and they come in barley, corn, rye and wheat.

headline: 19 Prisoners Killed in Nicaragua
abstract: Nicaraguan prison guards killed 19 inmates and wounded 28 after several guards were taken hostage in an escape attempt, the Interior Ministry said today. A statement said the prisoners, most of them former National Guardsmen loyal to the ousted dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, offered to exchange the guards for their freedom. Shooting broke out after several hours of negotiations, the statement added.

headline: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: F.D.A. RULE AND LENS CLEANERS
abstract: The introduction of the soft contact lens more than a decade ago proved a boon to the companies that made them. And like lots of other new products, the soft contact lens was a boon as well to ancillary industries - in this case, the business of helping wearers to clean their thin little shells of plastic.   One manufacturer, Burton, Parsons & Company of Seat Pleasant, Md., did especially well. The company produced a sterilized saline solution, the only such product approved by the Food and Drug Administration in l978. In that year, the F.D.A. banned less costly salt tablets that lens-wearers had mixed with water to make their own cleansing solutions. The F.D.A.'s concern was directed at users who might not have used the distilled water specified, causing harm to their eyes.

headline: Investment Up In Slurry Line
abstract: The five partners in the proposed 1,500-mile ETSI coal slurry pipeline said today that they had committed an additional $70 million to the project and planned to begin construction by early 1983. ETSI hopes to complete the line by 1985.

headline: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Burroughs Corporation, the office equipment manufacturer, has appointed William P. Conlin senior vice president in charge of corporate product managment.   * Chemical Bank, the nation's seventh-largest bank, has named Thomas G. Manuel head of the financial institutions group.

headline: Wurlitzer Chief Quits Suddenly
abstract: Wiliam N. Herleman, the 57-year-old chairman of the Wurlitzer Company, resigned suddenly yesterday. His resignation from three corporate posts - he is president and chief executive, as well as chairman - becomes effective today, according to a brief statement from the company's Dekalb, Ill., headquarters late yesterday afternoon.

headline: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BANGLADESH REPORTS DEATH OF PRESIDENT ZIAUR RAHMAN
abstract: President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh was killed today in the southern city of Chittagong, the Bangladesh radio reported. He was 45.   It was believed here that General Zia died in an accident, but there was no immediate confirmation.  The Press Trust of India, a news agency, reported from Dacca, the Bangladesh capital, that the announcement was made in a special broadcast, but the circumstances of the President's death were not given. According the radio, Vice President Abdus Sattar took over as acting President. Reports said a 40-day period of national mourning had been announced by the Bangladesh Government.

headline: COSTA RICA MOVING AGAINST FOREIGN POLIITICAL EXILES
abstract: The Costa Rican Government, after the explosion of two terrorist bombs in San Jose last month, has begun a campaign against foreign political exiles, who have traditionally sought refuge in this tiny Central American democracy.   Despite strong protests by liberal groups in Costa Rica, six Guatemalan opposition leaders were deported to neighboring Nicaragua last Wednesday after being held in jail for more than two weeks.   And since the two terrorist bombs exploded in San Jose last March 17, injuring three United States Marine guards and damaging the Honduran Embassy, a total of 36 foreign exiles, mainly Nicaraguans and Salvadorans but including some Argentines and Hondurans, have been expelled from Costa Rica.

headline: G.M. RAISING PRICES AVERAGE OF 3.5%
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing prices on its 1981 cars by an average of 3.5 percent, or $351, despite considerable weakness in the automobile market in the last 10 days of March.   The move follows the auto company's best sales month in almost two years, a result of substantial rebates given early in the month. And it comes after a half-year of relative price stability in the industry, during which some car prices were actually reduced.

headline: PROGRESS OF TAX BILL DISPUTED
abstract: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, asserted today that House Democrats ''may not want a tax cut in 1981.''   Senator Dole's opposite number, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, rejected that accusation. Dan Rostenkowski asserted that he had made ''a campaign commitment that we would have a tax cut this year.''   Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, charged in turn that President Reagan had agreed to additional tax relief for crude oil royalty owners and to larger estate tax exemptions to win the votes of conservative Democrats from Texas and other Southern states.

headline: TENTATIVE DRUG PACT WITH BONN
abstract: Tentative agreement has been reached between West Germany and five major American drug companies to end a sevenyear-old German antitrust suit alleging that the companies monopolized the worldwide antibiotic drug market, an attorney for the Bonn Government said today. But Paul C. Sprenger, a Minneapolis lawyer and registered agent for West Germany on the case, refused to disclose the terms.   Mr. Sprenger said that the two sides had reached an oral agreement as Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was visiting President Reagan and other officials in Washington, and that therefore he had asked the Chancellor not to bring up the matter during his official discussions.

headline: GAIN FOR DENG SEEN IN TALKS WITH HAIG
abstract: Long-delayed meetings of the Communist Party leadership were reliably reported to be under way today, and Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, is expected to tell them what Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said here yesterday: that Chinese-American relations are stronger than ever and continuing to improve.   Mr. Deng and his associates were also expected to tell party skeptics that the policy toward the United States had reaped benefits without China's having bartered away any of its principles. What was said and not said during Mr. Haig's visit will help Mr. Deng accentuate the positive, Western diplomats said.   In three days of talks and carefully worded public statements, Mr.  Haig demonstrated to the Chinese that the Reagan Administration could be sensitive to their internal political concerns. He gave support to Mr. Deng and, of equal significance, he gave Mr. Deng's critics no fresh ammunition for sniping at China's foreign policy in general and moves toward the United States in particular.

headline: Rome Police Capture Gunman
abstract: The police captured a man who fired at them with a shotgun in front of the international terminal at Rome's airport today, the police reported.

headline: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tribune Adds Cable
abstract: The Tribune Company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News in New York and newspapers in Florida, said it had completed its acquisition of the Douglas Communications Corporation, which owns and operates cable television systems serving communities in New York, Maryland, Tennessee and Louisiana. The cable firms all will be assigned to Tribune Company Cable Inc., a newly created subsidiary of the Chicago-based communications company.

headline: SOVIET SAYS ZIONISTS STRIVE TO UNDERMINE POLAND
abstract: The Soviet press, which has been accusing American labor unions, West Germans, Western radio stations and Western imperialism of interfering in Poland, today added Western Zionism to its list of subversive meddlers.   Literaturnaya Gazeta, the weekly of the Union of Soviet Writers, said Zionist organizations were engaging in a ''massive campaign to undermine the socialist foundations of Poland.''   The article, part of which was distributed in advance by Tass, the official press agency, cited a number of recent events in the United States to substantiate its allegations.

headline: Philipp Brothers Change
abstract: Hal H. Beretz, 45, who will become president and chief operating officer of the Philipp Brothers Corporation when the giant commodity trading and marketing company becomes an independent concern, anticipates that conditions in his field will improve before too long.   ''World recessionary influences obviously have an impact on our business,'' he said. ''But inventory levels of many consumers in the world have been kept at very low levels because of the high cost of money and as things pick up, this is going to reflect itself more rapidly than usual.''

headline: THE LID COMES OFF AT AMERICAN CAN
abstract: A spring rain pelted the American Can Company's headquarters one day last week, softening the harsh lines of its modernistic concrete and glass construction. The 10-year-old complex, tucked away in the gentle greening hills of southwestern Connecticut, exudes an aura of corporate stability sufficient to a company with annual sales approaching $5 billion.   Inside, the office staff and executives work amid appointments of unrelenting good taste, and the avant-garde art works hanging everywhere fail to shake the impression that this is an indestructible and self-assured fortress of an old-line American business.   But just right now, the lid is popping off at American Can. After years of comfortable profits, earnings plummeted 33 percent last year. And in a Brooklyn Federal court earlier this month, a jury found one of American Can's units, Sam Goody Inc., guilty of dealing in thousands of counterfeit tapes of popular music.

headline: WESTERN BEEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hyatt International Appoints Executives
abstract: Colgate A. Holmes, 45 years old, has been named president of the Hyatt International Corporation. He succeeds Jay A. Pritzker, the 58-year-old chairman of the Chicago-based company, who continues as chief executive officer.

headline: Around the World; Greece Protests to Turkey On Incident in Aegean
abstract: The Greek Government today delivered a formal protest to Turkey over alleged harassment of Greek warships by Turkish fighter planes in the eastern Aegean Sea in an area it said was just inside Greek territorial waters.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Bruce P. Andrews and Louis H. Beres have been elected to the board of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Abbott Laboratories named John G. Kringel president of the Sorenson Research Company.   Associates Corporation of North America, a financial service organization, appointed Keith W. Hughes executive vice president and a member of the board.

headline: YOUNG POLISH MODERATES EMERGE IN PARTY ELECTIONS
abstract: A major change in the ranks of the Polish Communist Party is taking place as the election of delegates to an extraordinary party congress one month from now reaches the halfway point.   Partial results indicate that more than half the delegates are new, meaning they have never attended a congress before.  At the same time, concurrent elections to party cells and to municipal and provincial party organizations are sweeping away the old guard in some areas and replacing it with a younger generation.   Party officials view this as a resurgence of strength and even a regeneration after months in which the party was shell-shocked by the worker rebellion and the emergence of the independent labor movement.

headline: No Headline
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that he was willing to hold talks with guerrilla leaders provided there were no preconditions.   However, he said that an offer by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front to hold talks if certain conditions were met was a political maneuver.

headline: Kennedy Attacks Plan For Arms Sales to Arabs
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, speaking in New York, sharply attacked the Reagan Administration yesterday for embarking on what he called ''the most extensive rearmament of the enemies of Israel in modern times.''   Speaking at the daylong American Assembly for Zionism and Israel, the Massachusetts Democrat especially criticized the Administration's decision to sell Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia.

headline: Japan Trade Surplus
abstract: Japan's customs-cleared trade posted a $312.4 million surplus in the first 10 days of May, in contrast to an $878.3 million deficit a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.  Exports rose 9.6 percent from the period a year earlier, to $3.22 billions. Imports, meanwhile, fell a sharp 23.8 percent from a year earlier, to $2.91 billion, the Finance Ministry said.

headline: NEW HIT ON BROADWAY: TELEVISION ADVERTISING TO PROMOTE THE SHOWS
abstract: The neon lights swirl around the jazzy set of ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and glow stubbornly behind the mist that spews from two portable black boxes to evoke a romantic scene. Nine dancers fitted in sequined topcoats and hats stand ready to strut into their number.    The theater crowd is still at home but the television cameras are ready to roll.  ''O.K., let's go,'' shouts Bob Giraldi, the director whose task it is to reduce the review of Duke Ellington's music from more than two hours into a 60-second television commercial that will make television addicts want to rise from their seats and head for the box office.   Since 1973, when a commercial for ''Pippin'' doubled the play's gross advance sales, television has come to rival print as Broadway's biggest promoter. Mr. Giraldi, a fast-talking, Robert De Niro look-alike, has filmed a variety of 60-second box office smashes, and three Broadway clips he has produced have won Clio awards.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 15, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Iraq. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   United Nations Development Pro- gram, Governing Council - 10 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Chemical, Citibank Raise Prime to 20%
abstract: The prime lending rate charged by the nation's major banks was unified yesterday at 20 percent as two large New York banks, Chemical Bank and Citibank, raised their rates.   Chemical had cut its rate to 19 percent a week ago.

headline: TITOISM WITHOUT TITO: LEGACY SEEMS BUOYANT
abstract: On a recent ordinary weekday, 12,000 people filed solemnly through the villa here where Marshal Tito lived and worked and through the garden pavilion where he is buried.   There were visitors from Czechoslovakia and China, but most of the visitors were Yugoslav factory workers, peasant women in black and young couples with babies in their arms - all paying homage to the President, who died May 4, 1980.   A year after his death, Tito continues to be a force for the Yugoslav people and for the nation's political leaders. The first year of the post-Tito period has passed more smoothly than most analysts had predicted, and the collective leadership that succeeded him appears determined to continue proving that Titoism will survive.

headline: U.S. DEFENDS REPORT ON SALVADOR ARMS
abstract: The State Department today issued a detailed rebuttal of criticisms of an official report on Communist arms shipments through Cuba and Nicaragua to El Salvador's guerrillas.   The State Department's response to articles in The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post questioning the accuracy of the report drew new critical comment from Representative Michael D.  Barnes, Democrat of Maryland, who is chairman of the House foreign affairs subcommittee on inter-American affairs.   The ''white paper'' on El Salvador, issued Feb. 23, formed part of a major diplomatic effort by the Reagan Administration accusing the Soviet Union and Cuba of supporting left-wing subversion in Central America and justifying United States military aid to the militarybacked civilian Government of El Salvador.   The State Department, reaffirming its findings of external Communist political and arms support, based on captured guerrilla documents and other intelligence information, said that a ''few points of misstated detail or ambiguous formulations'' in the report did not invalidate the conclusions about Communist intervention.

headline: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

headline: Youths Earn Too Little to Survive but Feel They Can't Return to Their Farming Villages
abstract: Hasan would like to go back to his village but cannot because it would bring dishonor to the family.   "life was better in the village, but once a boy comes to the city, he can't go home because that would mean failure," explained Hasan, who is 17 years old and came here to look for work four years ago.   Like 70 percent of the capial's two and a half inhabitants, Hasan lives in one of the bleak squatters' houses called gecekondus, or night houses, that have sprouted all over the hills around Ankara.   Hasan, who would rather not mention his last name, is from the village of Otaci, 45 miles west of Ankara, where his father has a small farm producing wheat, vegetables and a few cows.  The boy came to Ankara because he was "bored" with farm life and also because it is the tradition for village boys to go off to the city and seek a better life.

headline: Advertising; Highwire Magazine Aims at Top Students
abstract: Next month, National Community Service in Lowell, Mass., will be putting out a new publication called Highwire magazine, which they say will be aimed at the ''opinion leaders and achievers'' in the top half of the nation's 18 million high school students.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 23, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on Namibia at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Council for Namibia - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Economic Committee - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: IOWA BEEF REVOLUTIONIZED MEAT-PACKING INDUSTRY
abstract: In laying out some $800 million in stock to purchase Iowa Beef Processors, Occidental Petroleum is acquiring a company that did for the American meat-packing industry what Henry Ford did for automobile assembly.   In the process of revolutionizing the way meat is butchered and packaged, Iowa Beef forced the competition either to copy its methods or quit the business.   Analysts are nearly unanimous that Occidental could not have found a better partner through which to make a major entry into the food industry. The combination of Occidental's money and Iowa Beef's experience is expected to turn the meatpacker into a worldwide processor, not only of beef but of pork products as well.

headline: 500 Charged in Morocco Riots
abstract: About 500 people have been arrested and charged after food riots in Casablanca last weekend in which 66 people were killed and 110 injured, the Moroccan news agency reported.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Mayor of Soweto Is Unhurt In Assassination Attempt
abstract: The Mayor of the South African black township of Soweto escaped an assassination attempt last night when he drove off just before a hand grenade exploded under his car, the police said today.   Mayor David Thebehali leads the Soweto Community Council, which is shunned by radical blacks who see him as a puppet of the white government.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET SET MEETING ON MISSILES
abstract: Washington, June 5 - The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to begin talks in Washington in the next few weeks to prepare for nogotiations later in the year on limiting each side's mediumrange nuclear missiles in Europe, Administration officials said today.   According to the officials, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin worked out an arrangement last month for senior aides to meet regularly, starting this month and continuing through the summer, in advance of a meeting in late September between Mr. Haig and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.   Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, will conduct the discussions with Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the No. 2 diplomat at the Soviet Embassy.  Mr. Eagleburger will be assisted by Richard R. Burt, Director of Politico-Military affairs in the State Department, officials said.   The disclosure that the Russians have agreed to the arrangement is the first indication that Moscow has apparently accepted the Reagan Administration's timetable for talks, officials said.

headline: Chilean Guerrilla Killed in Raid
abstract: Unidentified guerrillas opened fire on a local police station from a passing car here last night, the police said. Policemen returned the fire, killing one of the attackers, identified as a 43-year-old woman, Orsa Busto Fierro. The police said the attackers were probably leftist guerrillas.

headline: U.S. AND PEKING JOIN IN TRACKING MISSILES IN SOVIET
abstract: The United States and China are jointly operating an electronic intelligence-gathering station in China to monitor Soviet missile tests, according to senior American officials.    The facility was opened last year in a remote, mountainous region of the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region in western China, near the Soviet border. Two key Soviet missile-testing bases are at Leninsk, near the Aral Sea, and at Sary-Shagan, near Lake Balkhash. Leninsk is 500 miles from the nearest point on the Chinese border, Sary-Shagan 300 miles.

headline: Canada Utility To Lift Exports
abstract: Ontario Hydro Ltd., a major Canadian electric utility, is expected to receive authorization from Canada's National Energy Board this week for a substantial increase of its electric power exports to the United States.   The company has asked for authorization to export up to 50 billion kilowatt-hours in any 12-month period from July 1 to Dec. 31, 1983, and as many as 25 billion kilowatt-hours in any subsequent 12-month period until June 30, 1991.

headline: RATES RISE WITH FEDERAL FUNDS
abstract: Short-term and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, with new Treasury bill rates rising above 14 percent, while new Bell System bonds, rated triple-A, were priced to yield a record 15.93 percent.   In the absence of a good flow of orders from investors, securities dealers said the credit markets were dominated by the increase in the Federal funds rate to 16 1/2 percent during the afternoon. ''The market seemed to focus on the higher funds rate and the large volume of Treasury securities to be sold next week,'' commented Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc. ''Everyone is ignoring signs that would encourage higher bond prices, such as a slowdown in the economy and less inflation.''   In the Treasury bill market the higher funds rate helped increase the average rate for new three-month and six-month bills to about 14.19 percent and 14.04 percent, respectively. Last week the average rates were 13.55 percent for three months and 13.62 percent for six months.

headline: GRENADA ACTS TO QUIET TOURISTS' FEARS ABOUT REVOLT
abstract: ST GEORGE'S, Grenada, April 25 (Reuters) - The tiny Caribbean island of Grenada, fearful of a major decline in tourism, is trying to counter adverse publicity about its leftist revolution.   Reports about the island's close relationship with Cuba have already contributed significantly to a decline in visitors, officials say.   Jane Belfon, director of tourism, said that some Western news organizations deliberately distorted the facts about the island's revolution, which brought the New Jewel Movement to power two years ago.

headline: Interest Rates Advance Slightly
abstract: Interest rates were slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday.  Yields on long-term securities remained very near their peaks, as shown by the bellwether 12 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2010, which closed at about 95 30/32 to yield 13.3 percent.   In the money markets, rates were little changed to slightly higher as the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market fluctuated around 15 5/8 percent. The Federal Reserve arranged $900 million of temporary purchases for a customer account, a move that analysts said showed only that the central bank was not trying to drain credit aggressively from the banking system.

headline: Harvester Trucks
abstract: The International Harvester Company said that its combined national market share for medium truck categories rose to a record 35.7 percent in April, or 2,986 units, from 13 percent a year ago. The categories include trucks of 19,501-26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight and trucks of 26,100 pounds and over. For the six months ended in April, Harvester, which manufactures trucks under 10 nameplates, said that its combined market share for the medium truck categories rose to 31 percent from 17.9 percent in the strike-affected period a year earlier.

headline: Company News; HORSES FLY FIRST CLASS ON TRANSAMERICA
abstract: If Cure the Blues finishes anything short of first in the 107th running of the Kentucky Derby tomorrow, it will not be because he received less than first-class transportation to the race.   Last week, the Virginia thoroughbred was loaded gingerly on Transamerica Airlines flight in New York for the two-hour flight to Louisville, Ky. Once on board, he received the same caliber of service that Transamerica has provided Secretariat, Seattle Slew, Affirmed and many other champions.   Transamerica Airlines, a subsidiary ofthe huge Transamerica Corporation, which reported 1980 revenues of $4.4 billion in movie production, financial services and manufacturing, is the country's largest carrier of horses. Last year, it transported 3,500 thoroughbreds to races, shows and equestrian events in this country and abroad.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Rudolf Skvortsov, a Soviet consul general in Poznan, died from self-inflicted gunshot wounds last night.

headline: CHANGES IN PEKING LEADERSHIP SEEN AS COMMUNISTS MARK ANNIVERSARY
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party celebrates its 60th anniversary this week with leadership changes expected to formally mark the end of more than a quarter century of social experimentation under the doctrines of Chairman Mao Zedong.   Since the death of Mao in 1976, the party has been trying to restore its prestige among a population of one billion people brutalized by radical policies in Communist engineering. So far it has had little success, and it has been forced to argue that despite ''serious mistakes'' in the past, it remains the only force in China powerful enough to prevent Balkanization and a return to feudalism.   In preparing for festivities on July 1, the party-controlled press has dwelt on the glories and victories of the struggle against foreign oppression in the period before it came to power in 1949. It has eulogized the early optimistic years of its rule and glossed over the era since 1957 in which China mostly stagnated behind a wall of propaganda that made many in the outside world think of it as a utopia.

headline: Halliburton Posts Gain
abstract: The Halliburton Company, a leading supplier of oil well services, announced yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 increased 25.4 percent, to $132 million, or $1.12 a share, from $105.3 million, or 89 cents a share, in the first three months of 1980. Revenues rose 16.5 percent, to $1.84 billion, from $1.58 billion.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Interest rates are likely to climb and stay high for several months, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. The deficit in fiscal 1981 could be as high as $60 billion, or $2 billion to $5 billion above earlier forecasts, as a result of rate increases since March, he said. Calling this year's budget experience ''a disaster,'' he put U.S. borrowing needs in fiscal 1981 at $75 billion to $80 billion. (Page A1.)   The U.S. merchandise trade deficit narrowed in the first quarter, to $3.7 billion on a balance-of-payments basis, from $6 billion in 1980's last quarter, the Commerce Department said, citing a sharp increase in exports of heavy machinery. (D2.)

headline: RECORD RATE ON 30-YEAR U.S. BONDS
abstract: The United States Treasury was forced yesterday to pay the highest price ever for 30-year financing of Government debt.  The Treasury auctioned $2 billion of new 13 7/8 percent, 30-year bonds at an average yield of 13.99 percent, up from 12.68 percent in February.   The bond sale marked the end of a very expensive week of financing for the Treasury, which earlier sold new 3-year and 10-year notes at record yields of 15.81 percent and 14.56 percent, respectively.  Analysts explained that already-high interest rates were pushed even higher over the past week when short-term interest rates rose sharply as a result of the Federal Reserve's efforts to reduce the growth of the nation's money supply.
