headline: Correction
abstract: Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc. are planning to merge. A reference to the proposal last Sunday inadvertantly misnamed Standard Brands.

headline: ROGEERS: HONOR THY CONTRACT
abstract: The following reply to Mr. Bakes' letter was invited by The Times.  Far from being an exemplary innovation, New York Air is an airborne ''runaway shop'' created with Texas International money, planes and management personnel. The four corporate entities headed by Francisco Lorenzo - Jet Capital, Texas Air, T.I. and New York Air - are one and the same.

headline: Noranda Leading For Bloedel Control
abstract: Only 1,174 shares of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd.  stock were tendered to the the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation, in an offer that expired at 9:30 A.M. on the floors of the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. As a result, Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto appeared to be heading for control of Canada's largest forest products company.

headline: U.S.-AFRICA TIES FACE TEST OVER SANCTIONS
abstract: The Reagan Administration's strained relations with Africa could undergo their harshest test so far when the Security Council is faced next week with a demand for a trade boycott against South Africa.   Led by Uganda, the Africans seek to punish Pretoria for delaying the independence of South-West Africa, or Namibia. A Council meeting is scheduled to begin Tuesday, and African diplomats predict that their resolution demanding sanctions will be voted on by the end of the week.   Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate, is virtually certain to veto the resolution, probably with Britain.  France may abstain. Four years ago all three countries voted against a similar Council call to break off trade, and both the Reagan Administration and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain are more sympathetic to South Africa than their predecessors.

headline: HIGH SOVIET AIDE ARRIVES IN SYRIA AS LEBANON CRISIS GROWS
abstract: A senior Soviet official arrived here this afternoon for consultations with the Syrian Government in what was seen by Western diplomats as an intensified effort to prevent a wider Middle East confrontation between Syria and Israel.   The official, First Deputy Foreign Minister Georgi M. Korniyenko, conferred with his Syrian counterpart, Nasser Khaddour, and was expected to meet tomorrow with President Hafez al-Assad.   Mr. Korniyenko is to be here three days.  A special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, left Washington today for London on the first leg of a mission to Jerusalem, Beirut and Damascus, also aimed at averting a conflict between Syria and Israel. Mr. Habib is expected here on Saturday after the Korniyenko visit has ended.

headline: Charter to Close Dayton Press Unit
abstract: The Charter Company, a diversified petroleum, broadcasting and insurance concern, said it would close Dayton Press Inc., its unprofitable printing unit, and take a one-time, pretax write-off of about $41 million in the second quarter.   Charter estimated the closing of the plant, one of the largest in the nation, would result in an after-tax charge of $23 million.

headline: UA-Columbia Gains Stockholder Pledges
abstract: Columbia Cablevision Inc. said that shareholders representing 1,256,000 of its 3.3 million common shares outstanding had signed agreements indicating that they would not tender their stock to United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc., and that agreements representing another 32,000 shares were expected shortly.   UA-Columbia sought the pledges to help speed the definitive agreement it entered last week for a joint venture of Dow Jones & Company and the Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. for a price of $80 a share.

headline: WORKERS CRITICIZE POLISH PARTY CHIEF
abstract: Polish workers sharply criticized the Communist Party leader and other officials today for a lack of leadership, information and food during a round of face-to-face factory meetings, the Polish press reported.   The Soviet Union, meanwhile, stepped up its criticism of both Solidarity, the independent labor union, and the Polish Communist Party. Warsaw Pact maneuvers continued in and around Poland.

headline: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Associated Press ANTI-GOVERNMENT DEMONSTRATION IN KOREA: Student demonstrators fleeing from police after breaking through roadblock on the Seoul National University cam-pus. It was the second day of their rock-throwing clashes with riot police. The students were demanding the resignation of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea.

headline: G.E. Is Shifting Some TV Output
abstract: The General Electric Company, citing stiff competition from imports of Taiwanese and South Korean television sets, announced that it will stop production of black and white sets by 1983 and shift production overseas.   G.E. is the last United States manufacturer to produce black and white television sets in this country, said Roger Keesee, general manager of manufacturing for the company's television business at the Suffolk, Va., plant, where the sets are produced.

headline: Mondale Is Received in Bonn
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher received former Vice President Walter F. Mondale for lunch today, the Foreign Ministry said. Mr. Mondale is on a private visit.

headline: IN FRANCE'S JOB-POOR POCKETS, MITTERRAND'S RUNNING HARD
abstract: Cheap wine once made Beziers rich; more recently it has impoverished it. A graceful, shabby southern town in need of paint and jobs, it is taking the general depression of the times particularly hard because its over-produced red is steadily losing out to cheaper wines from Italy and Spain.   The town is quiet on weekdays and dead on weekends, except for the young men bucking old motorcycles down the central promenade. Last Saturday the somnolence lifted, tentatively, for a bit of national politics.

headline: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSUMER DEBT SOARS $2 BILLION
abstract: Consumer borrowing surged by $2 billion in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.  It was the largest increase since February 1980, when a $2.9 billion rise contributed to President Carter's decision to impose credit controls throughout the economy. The annual rate of increase spurted to 8 percent in February from 3 percent in January and 1 percent for all of 1980.

headline: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BELGRADE SEES PERIL OF MINORITY UNREST
abstract: Yugoslav Government and Communist Party leaders have voiced apprehension that other national minorities may stage anti-Government demonstrations following the rioting by Albanian nationalists in Kosovo Province.   Kosovo Province, which is inhabited largely by ethnic Albanians, is still under a state of emergency after last week's rioting in which two demonstrators were killed and many people wounded. Movements and public gatherings were restricted and journalists were discouraged from visiting the province.

headline: Company News; German Steelmaker To Cut 5,000 Jobs
abstract: Krupp Stahl A.G., the steelmaking unit of the Fried. Krupp group of steel and heavy industrial companies, said that it plans to eliminate about 5,000 jobs by 1982 as a major part of its plans to restructure operations amid the current steel crisis.

headline: YANKEE OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Good News For Consumer
abstract: WORRYING about Congressional action on President Reagan's proposed three-year, 30 percent tax-cut program, Administration spokesmen have been playing down the surprisingly strong surge of the gross national product in this year's first quarter. ''Real'' G.N.P. - total national output adjusted for inflation - climbed at an annual rate of 6.5 percent.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, attributing much of the first quarter's strength to the ''momentum'' of the final quarter of 1980, assured reporters that the strong pace ''almost surely won't be sustained.'' Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, who had described the economy as ''soft'' and ''soggy'' just a few days earlier, conceded that the first-quarter rise had been ''nice'' but said it would not be duplicated.

headline: Shearson Loeb Net Up 41.2% in Period
abstract: Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., benefiting from its diversification, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter, ended March 31, rose 41.2 percent, to $27.4 milllion, or $1.75 a share, from $19.4 million, or $1.55 a share, in the similar 1980 period.

headline: Liberal Iranian Paper Reappears With a Pledge on Press Freedom
abstract: Mizan, Iran's leading liberal newspaper, was back on sale today after a two-week ban, and promised its readers to defend freedom of the press and independence of the courts.   In a front-page editorial, the newspaper said, ''We will defend the independence of the judicial system and safeguard the liberties provided in the Constitution and the freedom of the press.''

headline: RAMADA INNS PLANS 13-HOTEL EXPANSION
abstract: Ramada Inns Inc. will spend $425 million in the next two years to add 13 large hotels with at least 300 rooms each to its worldwide chain, a company official said today.   Juergen E. Bartels, president of the Ramada Hospitality Group, said in Atlanta that the company's long-term strategy was to become the ''best mid-priced hotel chain in the world.''

headline: Airline Talks On Losses Set
abstract: The world's major international airlines with the exception of United States carriers will convene in emergency session next week to discuss growing financial losses, it was announced today.   The International Air Transport Association, calling the meeting for next Tuesday and Wednesday at the airlines' request, said that ''urgent action is required in order to prevent 1981 results from being even worse than those of 1980.''

headline: VENEZUELA SUPORTS FREEZE IN OIL PRICE
abstract: Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's oil minister, is calling for a freeze in OPEC oil prices until 1983.  The statement, reported yesterday by The Associated Press from Geneva after a meeting of OPEC's Long-Term Strategy Committee, appeared to mark a major attempt within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restructure oil prices in the face of weakening worldwide oil demand.   To cope with what are perceived as new threats to OPEC's share in the world energy market, Mr. Calderon Berti said he was pushing for an agreement that would freeze the basic crude price set by OPEC for two to three years, starting Jan.1. For 12 of the 13 members, this price is $36 a barrel; Saudi Arabia's basic price is $32.

headline: Steel Output Increases 0.7%
abstract: Steel production rose to 2.6 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.58 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.   The industry's production amounted to 86.9 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 86.3 percent the previous week.

headline: Company News Briefs; BRIEFS
abstract: * Aminoil USA, a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said it had discovered an estimated 3.3 million cubic feet of gas a day and 168 barrels of condensate a day at a Dewey County, Okla, well.   * Canadian Javelin Ltd. said it had purchased 50,000 common shares of Jubilee Quebec Holdings Ltd. for $50,000.   * Christian Schmidt Brewing Co. negotiated a $10 million contract to sell beer to the Taiwan tobacco and wine monopoly.

headline: COUNCIL IN NAMIBIA FINDS WHITES' GRIP STILL STRONG
abstract: West Africa, June 13 - It may seem a trivial sidelight on a subject of intense diplomatic interest, but when a high-level United States State Department mission arrived here to discuss the ever-receding prospect of this country's transformation into the independent nation of Namibia, it landed at an airport still named after the last unabashed white supremacist to serve as South Africa's Prime Minister.   J.G. Strijdom, who died in 1958, would undoubtedly twirl in his grave if he could contemplate the degree to which the South African racial system has been set aside in a territory that he regarded as just another South African province. So would Hendrik F. Verwoerd, his successor, who is memorialized in a small park a few steps from the hotel at which the Americans stayed.   But the homage that is still paid to their memory is one of numerous signs - a military presence of roughly 20,000 troops is another - that South Africa remains the de facto colonial power in this vast, arid land that it took from Imperial Germany in World War I and later received, after the fact of conquest, as a mandate from the League of Nations.

headline: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Wienerwald Entrepreneur's Empire Grows
abstract: Friedrich Jahn, a 57-year-old Austrian who opened his first restaurant in 1955, built a worldwide chain of Wienerwald restaurants over the next 25 years. Now his empire is about to get bigger, following an agreement last week by his Wienerwald Holding, a private Swiss company, to acquire the IHOP Corporation, the publicly owned parent of the International House of Pancakes, for $2.60 a share.

headline: TIPS BY REAGAN'S TRUST MANAGER
abstract: For investment wisdom, Ronald Reagan's advisers sought out Raymond J. Armstrong of the Starwood Corporation in New York and placed the President's $740,000 blind trust in his hands for the next four years. Mr. Armstrong will not breathe a word about the President's money, but he will talk about the investment strategies that guide the managing of Starwood's $400 million of pension funds and large personal holdings.   Mr. Armstrong, not a large man but one who enjoys a large reputation on Wall Street, apparently impressed Justin W. Dart, chairman of Dart & Kraft's executive committee and a friend of Mr.  Reagan's, with a presentation before the company's pension committee. He doesn't speak as an adviser to small investors, rather, as a pension fund manager who buys and sells big blocks of stock, the kind of trading that has come to dominate Wall Street and, he admits, has added to its frustrating volatility.   ''We feel the stock market is in a very favorable position to grow over the next five years,'' the 55-year-old president of Starwood said in a lengthy interview. ''But that doesn't say much about the next five months. If you can take a lot of turbulence for several months, you can probably make a lot of money in stocks.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ROYAL FAMILY GETS A COURT INJUNCTION
abstract: Prince Charles was granted an injunction today to prevent the publication of purported transcripts of telephone calls he made from Australia to his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, and his mother, Queen Elizabeth II.   Illicit tape-recordings of the calls were allegedly made last month while the Prince was staying at the ranch of a friend, Sinclair Hill, 300 miles northwest of Sydney. The tapes were then transcribed and the transcripts were given to a British freelance journalist, Simon Regan, who had already upset the royal family with an unflattering biography called ''Charles, the Clown Prince.''

headline: FEDERATED CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE, 37
abstract: When Michael J. Boyle was appointed president of the Lazarus department store division of Federated Department Stores in Columbus, Ohio, about two years ago, a Wall Street retailing analyst said, ''At his age, in that job, you can look forward to hearing a lot more about him.''   Yesterday the retailing world heard about the 37-year-old Mr.  Boyle, who was named to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer of the 16-unit chain, effective Aug. 1. He will succeed Charles Y. Lazarus, 67, a scion of the founding family.

headline: Stocks Close Mixed; Rate Concerns Cited
abstract: The stock market, unsettled by growing investor concern that interest rates may move higher, closed mixed yesterday in slow trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, finished up 1.04 points to 996.19. However, losers on the New York Stock Exchange outscored winners by 814 to 707. The best performers were the energy-related issues.

headline: HERSHEY, SINGER UP
abstract: Norton Simon Inc., the parent of Avis Inc. and one of the nation's leading manufacturers of foods, cosmetics, distilled spirits and other consumers products, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 dropped 40.4 percent, while revenues advanced by 6.3 percent.   Norton Simon attributed its earnings decline to the significantly lower results at Avis.  Norton Simon said that net income in the latest fiscal three months shrank to $13.7 million, or 31 cents a share, from $23 million, or 47 cents a share, in the fiscal quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $748.7 million from $704.4 million.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

FLEXI-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

headline: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUSPECT SAID TO HAVE LIVED IN GERMANY
abstract: Reports circulated in West Germany's large Turkish community today that Mehmet Ali Agca, who is accused of trying to assassinate Pope John Paul II yesterday, spent long periods underground here after his escape from a Turkish prison in 1979.   The West German authorities said that searches for Mr. Agca had been made but had been unsuccessful.  According to Turkish newspapers and diplomats here, Mr. Agca lived with forged papers and under aliases in various cities, including West Berlin, where 250,000 Turks live, and Frankfurt. Other reports said that he had obtained a residence permit by marrying a German woman in Berlin or Frankfurt.

headline: A.T.& T. Offering Is 'Going Great'
abstract: The sale of 16.5 million common shares of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's stock, the largest equity financing in history, which began yesterday, is ''going great'' according to William Kneisel, a principal with Morgan Stanley & Company, the lead underwriter.   The stock is being sold at $57 a share, for a total of $940.5 million, through some 255 underwriters.

headline: MAKERS OF MATERIALS FOR SEMICONDUCTORS HURT BY SLOW SALES
abstract: High inventories and soft sales are squeezing the suppliers of materials used by the semiconductor industry.   These suppliers, which provide silicon wafers, test equipment, chemical-etching devices and other items, make up an industry that has seen rapid growth, with sales of more than $4.5 billion in 1980.   Their current problems are the result of declining sales among the semiconductor producers: The Intel Corporation, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and other major concerns reported reduced orders beginning in the fourth quarter of 1980, and analysts have predicted a 10 to 20 percent drop in worldwide semiconductor sales this year. Downturn Seems Modest   But in an industry subject to distinct cyclical trends, the current downturn is regarded as modest.

headline: Steifel/Raymond
abstract: The First Women's Bank has chosen Steifel/Raymond Advertising as its first agency. Asked why she had not chosen an agency run by a women, Judy Hendren Mello, president of the bank, said that after a careful screening of 30 agencies to fill the bank's advertising, public relations and marketing needs, she decided that Stiefel/ Raymond was the proper one for the bank. And it has assigned two woman executives to her account

headline: Company News; Air Florida Cites Rise in Air Traffic
abstract: Air Florida, which since airline deregulation has expanded its routes in the Northeast and added an overseas route, reported a sharp increase in air traffic for April. System revenue passenger miles, including scheduled and charter flights, totaled 253.5 million in April, more than double the 119 million in April,1980.

headline: FRENCH AIR TEAM IS FIRST TO LAND IN CANADA IN TRANS-ATLANTIC RACE
abstract: A twin-engine craft piloted by the French team of Helen Lacour and Nicole Duval became the first of more than 60 light airplanes to touch down on the North American continent in the Paris-New York-Paris trans-Atlantic air race, organizers said today.   The two women, aboard a Partenavia P-68, landed in Goose Bay, Canada, this morning, race officials said.

headline: UA-COLUMBIA CABLEVISION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chrysler Sees No Motor Fault
abstract: A spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation said today that ''there is nothing to indicate we have a problem'' with excessive oil consumption in the engines of its Plymouth Omni and Dodge Horizon cars, despite their similarity to the water-cooled Volkswagen engines cited yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission.   The F.T.C. yesterday charged that Volkswagen had failed to notify its customers of potential oil-use and repair problems with more than one million of its Volkswagen and Audi cars made for the 1974 through 1979 model years.

headline: S.&P. CUTS RATINGS ON NORTON SIMON
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its ratings of Norton Simon Inc. debt yesterday, citing continued weakness in the company's consumer products business and the impact of sluggishness in the airline industry on its automobile rental operations.   Another major ratings service, Moody's Investors Service, left its ratings unchanged for the company, whose major businesses include Hunt-Wesson foods, Avis vehicle rentals and Max Factor cosmetics.

headline: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Fiat Expects Loss on Cars
abstract: Fiat S.p.A. expects its automotive business to report a loss this year, although the group as a whole still expects to break even in 1981, Umberto Agnelli, vice chairman, said in an interview last Friday.   Fiat Auto lost 131 billion lire in 1980, including a 120 billion lire extraordinary loss.

headline: Turner Inc. Seeking $50 Million in Loans
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., parent of the all-news Cable News Network and the Atlanta Braves, said it was working to obtain $50 million in financing before its annual stockholders meeting next week without selling additional stock.

headline: BEGIN HAPPY WITH REAGAN, KOCH SAYS
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel met with some of his influential American friends yesterday and told them that he was looking forward to a Reagan administration.   On his first full day in New York at the start of a 10-day visit to this country, Mr. Begin held court in a suite at the Waldorf Towers.  Governor Carey and Mayor Koch dropped by to talk politics and diplomacy, making their presence known before a score of cameras and microphones. A few Jewish New Yorkers of influence and wealth went to the Waldorf, including George Klein, a real estate developer who was part of a national committee that worked for Ronald Reagan's election.

headline: Business People; J. ROTHSCHILD OFFICE SET UP IN NEW YORK
abstract: When the squabble between Jacob Rothschild and his cousin Evelyn de Rothschild, two prominent members of the British Rothschild banking family, ended last September, the Rothschild Investment Trust was renamed RIT, Ltd. Now this organization, a fast-growing investment company, with Jacob Rothschild as its chairman, has established an American entity - the J. Rothschild Management Corporation - and named Francois Mayer as its president.   Mr. Mayer, a 40-year-old French-born Swiss citizen, is also managing director of RIT. But he said yesterday that he intended to be in the new Rothschild New York offices frequently on company business.

headline: Business Conditions; EMPLOYEES OVERSEAS: EXPENSIVE
abstract: High taxes, rising inflation and a weak dollar have made the cost of maintaining American employees abroad an increasingly expensive proposition for United States companies. A sharp decline in the number of United States citizens employed overseas has ensued.   However, problems in compiling tax, salary and foreign allowance information for the countries where American companies send employees has always made accurate cost projections difficult to obtain. In order to help employers determine the total cost of American expatriates, Ernst & Whinney, the accounting firm, recently conducted a study covering conditions in 60 countries.

headline: I.M.F. REORGANIZES DRAWING RIGHTS
abstract: The International Monetary Fund today announced a series of actions designed to make the special drawing right, a near-currency used for settling accounts between governments, a more attractive asset for governments to hold in their reserve coffers along with gold and dollars.   The moves, which among other things involve increasing the interest rate that holders will receive, are part of an evolutionary process that international monetary managers are hoping in time will make the drawing right the centerpiece of the world monetary system as a kind of supermoney.   Some $25 billion worth of the drawing rights already exist, and governments are now negotiating a new allocation that could be used to supplement existing reserves and help countries pay their international bills.

headline: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROYAL DUTCH SHELL POSTS A 53.7% DROP IN EARNINGS
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that high crude oil costs, coupled with slumping prices for refined products, helped drive down net income 53.7 percent for the first quarter of 1981.   The British-Dutch conglomerate, the world's second-largest petroleum company after the Exxon Corporation, said net income fell to $744 million from $1.61 billion in the first quarter of 1980.

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1981; Markets
abstract: The credit markets were surpised by a quick rally that raised some long-term bond prices more than 2 1/2 points. Most analysts attributed the rebound to technical factors such as short covering by speculators. Some Treasury bill rates fell by about a quarter of a percentage point. (Page D1.)   The assets of money market funds have started to decline after 17 consecutive weeks of growth, according to figures reported by the Investment Company Institute. Their yields have lagged behind those on competing investments. (D1.)

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Administration and Congressional leaders offered compromise proposals for a bipartisan bill to cut income taxes. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and House Majority Leader Jim Wright said the Administration wanted a bill that mainstream Democrats could support. (Page A1.) President Reagan asked Congressional leaders to meet with Secretary of Health and Human Resources Richard S.  Schweiker ''to save Social Security.'' The Senate on Wednesday rejected two major parts of the Reagan plan to cut benefits. (A1.)   The Senate voted final approval of a $695.5 billion budget, completing the first stage in President Reagan's budget reorganization plan. (A16.) Interest rates will soon fall when the Administration's economic program is put into place, President Reagan assured Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. (A1.)

headline: DuPont Plans to Lift Plastic Film Output
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said that it planned to increase production capacity for Kapton polymide plastic film by about onethird at its Circleville, Ohio, plant. It said that it had doubled capacity for the film at the plant last year, but did not disclose any figures.

headline: ENGELHARD TO DIVIDE OPERATIONS
abstract: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation yesterday announced a plan for splitting up the two sides of its business - commodity trading and industrial operations - into two independent, publicly held companies.   According to the plan, the existing shares of the corporation would become the outstanding stock of the Phi@lipp Brothers Corporation, the new corporate entity that embraces the raw materials trading and marketing operations. Shareholders would receive fourtenths of a share of the new company, the Engelhard Corporation, for every share of existing Englehard Minerals and Chemicals they hold.

headline: MANY REPORTED HURT
abstract: Shells and rockets hit commercial and residential areas of the city today in the renewed fighting between Syrian and Christian forces.   President Elias Sarkis, who has been trying to arrange negotiations between the Syrians and the Christians, urged both sides to cease hostilities.   There was no official count of the casualties, but doctors at hospitals on both sides of the Green Line that divides Beirut into Moslem and Christian zones reported that many wounded were being treated. Unofficial reports said that at least four people had been killed in Moslem western Beirut and at least four had been killed in the Christian eastern side.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * American Express Co. announced a joint venture with Banco Bamerindus and Banco Economico, both of Brazil, to establish a new company to market an American Express Cruzeiro Card throughout Brazil. * A-T-O Inc. changed its name to Figgie International Inc.   * Chrysler Corp.'s four operating United States car and truck assembly plants will work overtime schedules next week for the fourth consecutive week.

headline: TAX BREAK ON SAVINGS: INITIAL VICTORY
abstract: In a skillful display of how to influence Congress, the savings and loan industry has produced a stunning first-round victory for its bill to create a new type of tax subsidy for savers and financial institutions.   The Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee voted overwhelmingly to include the new tax subsidy in the 1981 tax relief bill. The finance panel's vote was 20 to 0; in the Ways and Means Committee the tally was 29 to 3.   Yet, doubts about final committee approvals had persisted. One reason was that neither committee had held even one day of hearings on the proposal. A second was that, in the Ways and Means Committee, neither of the proposal's chief sponsors voted for it.

headline: ATOM ARMS SPREAD WORRIES PRESIDENT
abstract: The White House emphasized today that President Reagan was committed to preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, especially in the Middle East, and that the Administration had expressed its concern before this week to the countries supplying nuclear material to Iraq.   Larry Speakes, the acting White House spokesman, said that Administration aides were working to formulate a set of policies intended to prevent the spread of nuclear arms.   Specifically, he acknowledged for the first time that officials in the Administration had ''made known our concern'' about shipments of nuclear fuel and technology to the Governments of both Italy and France, the two major suppliers of equipment for the nuclear reactor in Iraq that Israeli planes bombed last Sunday.

headline: Thieves Steal Fine French Wine
abstract: DU-PAPE, France, April 11 (AP) - Thieves with a taste for fine red wine broke into the cellars of the Amouroux wine-growing estate and made off with 1,000 bottles of Chateauneuf-du-Pape ''Grand Cru,'' police sources said today. They estimated the loss at about $10,000 and said the bottles, which carried the highest classification for French wine, were stolen late Thursday or early yesterday.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUBAN SHOWCASE
abstract: Many of Havana's apartment houses and office buildings could use some sprucing up, but otherwise the city of two million people is well kept. Streets are swept and safe for pedestrians.  Service is courteous and crowds orderly.   The city's sandlots are busy with boys playing baseball. And tourists from Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, Canada and other parts of Latin America tour the old city, stopping at such sites as Bodeguita, one of Ernest Hemingway's favorite bars off Cathedral Square.

headline: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HUNTS' CASE APPEARS STRONGER
abstract: The Hunt brothers of Dallas, Nelson Bunker and William Herbert, have been complaining on philosophical grounds for years about Government interference in their multibillion-dollar business dealings.   Now, in a lawsuit against the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Hunts seem to have partially prevailed. The S.E.C. has acknowledged that it may have ''misinterpreted'' the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978 during a continuing investigation of the Hunts. And a source close to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has said that the Hunts are likely to emerge unscathed from a commission investigation into commodity price manipulation.   The Privacy Act requires Federal agencies to inform bank customers when their bank records are being subpoenaed.

headline: Link of Salvador Soldiers To Killing of 4 Reported
abstract: CBS News said tonight that evidence evaluated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation pointed to six members of the Salvadoran National Guard as the killers of four United States churchwomen in El Salvador last December. The F.B.I.  denied the report.

headline: Fox Films' TV Buy
abstract: The 20th Century-Fox Films operation is putting $10 million into advertising during the ABC-TV Network coverage of the 1984 Winter and Summer Olympic Games. It will be the exclusive film company advertiser and the network says it is the biggest TV buy ever made by a movie maker. The Entertainment division of J. Walter Thompson made the buy.

headline: German Steel Union Pact
abstract: The West German metalworkers' union and employers agreed on a 4.3 percent basic wage increase for 210,000 steelworkers, a union spokesman said today. The main components of the accord are a 4.3 percent wage rise in the nine months starting May 1 and payment of an extra 150 marks per worker, or about $66, for the three months starting Feb. 1 of this year.

headline: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; The New Chairman For A.A.F.
abstract: PATRICIA J. MARTIN, the first woman chairman of the American Advertising Federation, who takes office June 8, is arriving at a time when that grass roots organization is becoming more important to the advertising industry than it has ever been.   With the cutback of Federal regulation under the Reagan Administration, the A.A.F. now expects cities and states to fill the void in regulating and taxing advertising, thus enhancing the role that the federation will play, she said the other day.   And as important as they are in the industry, the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers are not in a position to monitor such activities. But the A.A.F., with some 25,000 members belonging to 203 clubs in all 50 states, will be able to hoist the early warning signals, catch early legislative activity before trends start and then mount counterattacks.

headline: BAKER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN NAMES 2 OVER OPPOSITION OF CONSERVATIVES
abstract: The White House nominated Thomas O. Enders today to be Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs over the opposition of Senator Jesse Helms.   Senator Helms, Republican of North Carolina, had told the White House he would oppose Mr. Enders, who is an economic specialist with no Latin American experience. Senator Helms, the Senate's foremost conservative, proposed Louis Tambs for the job. Mr. Tambs is a professor at Arizona State University and has worked as a contractor in Latin America. Rostow Also Nominated   The White House today also announced the nomination of Eugene V.  Rostow, a former diplomat who is a professor at Yale Law School, to be Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

headline: 2 FED OFFICIALS DEBATE CRITICS
abstract: Despite the misgivings of their chairman, Paul A. Volcker, two senior officials of the Federal Reserve System squared off today against leading critics of the way the central bank manages the nation's money.   As expected, nothing was resolved. But the debate was significant because for the first time, the Federal Reserve responded directly and publicly to its critics, the monetarists, whose power has been growing within the Reagan Administration.   A standing-room-only crowd filled the Hitchcock Hall auditorium at Ohio State University here. On one side stood Stephen H. Axilrod, director of monetary policy research of the Federal Reserve System, and Peter D. Sternlight, the manager of the system's open market account.

headline: Technology; Controlling Use Of Electricity
abstract: NEW power plants are so expensive and unpopular that more and more electric utilities want - or are being ordered by public utility commissions - to get by with what they have.   The key to their ability to do so is load management. Utility systems are designed to cover peak demand plus a safety margin. If the peak can be shaved, so can the total capacity of the system. Load management also minimizes the use of the units that generate the most expensive power, which saves consumers money.

headline: U.S. Will Withdraw Case In World Court Against Iran
abstract: The United States has authorized the withdrawal of its claim in the International Court of Justice for damages from Iran for its 444-day holding of the American hostages, sources close to the case said today.   The formal withdrawal of the claim next week will state, however, that the United States can reopen the case if Iran ''fails to live up to its commitments,'' the sources said.

headline: Asarco Completes Share Repurchase
abstract: Asarco Inc. said it had completed the purchase of all of its shares held by the Bendix Corporation by buying 1.78 million common shares for approximately $103 million.   Asarco, a leading producer of nonferrous metals, previously purchased 3.83 million of its shares from Bendix on Jan. 26 for about $211 million and 492,500 shares on April 20 for about $28 million.

headline: energywatch
abstract: MARCH 27 Crude oil imports fell, but supplies jumped to 391.1 million barrels.

headline: JAMAICAN LEADER URGES A DOUBLING OF CARIBBEAN AID
abstract: Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga of Jamaica said today that the goal of a proposed Caribbean and Central American development program should be to double the region's per capita income in 15 years.   Mr. Seaga told the council of the Organization of American States that to achieve that goal, official aid from donor countries, including the United States, should be raised to $3 billion a year.   The present annual level of official development aid to the 31 countries of the Caribbean and Central America, excluding Cuba, is $1.3 billion.

headline: CARMA DEVELOPERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DURSBLES ORDERS OFF 0.4% IN MAY
abstract: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods declined four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the latest in a lengthening list of indications that the national economy has been weakening since the first quarter's big expansion.   Increases in defense orders and in orders for commercial aircraft and parts in May were more than outweighed by declines in orders for steel, machinery and other items and materials.

headline: Italy's Premier-Designate Denies He Was a Mason
abstract: Prime Minister-designate Arnaldo Forlani, striving to stay clear of the scandal over a secret Masonic lodge that toppled this country's Government 10 days ago, denied today that he had ever been a Freemason.   Mr. Forlani said he would take legal action against a Rome newspaper that published an allegation that he had once belonged to a lodge in the central city of Ascoli Piceno.   In Rome, a 45-year-old lieutenant in the customs police, Luciano Rossi, killed himself today, a week after the police questioned him about documents found in the house of Licio Gelli, 62, grandmaster of the secret lodge. Mr. Gelli, who was facing charges of political espionage, fled before the scandal broke and was yesterday reported to be in Uruguay.

headline: DANES KEEP WARY EYE ON SOVIET-BLOC SHIPS IN BALTIC
abstract: Capt.  Erling H. Jensen peers across the misty Baltic Sea through a pair of battered gray binoculars, then quietly gives the orders in Danish.  The hunter has spotted his quarry.   An officer loads film into a two-handled camera with a gunsight on top. Two ensigns mount a pair of four-foot-long binoculars on a turret above the bridge. At the glowing radar screen, another officer, the second in command of this Danish patrol vessel, quickly chalks a yellow ring around pulsing dots of light.

headline: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SIGNODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Overseas Bank Sale Is Studied
abstract: The American Express Company confirmed yesterday that it was contemplating the sale of its international banking operation because of its inability to compete fully with other large international banking institutions.   The big financial services company first disclosed the possibility in proxy material prepared for a special stockholders meeting on June 29 that has been called to vote on its proposed acquisition of Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., the securities firm.

headline: NEW XEROX PERSONAL COMPUTER ALSO SERVES AS WORD PROCESSOR
abstract: The Xerox Corporation today will become the first major American office products company to enter the personal computer market, introducing a machine that can double as a word processor.   The move reflects the fact that personal computers are finding their largest use not in the home but in both small businesses and in the largest corporations, which are starting to order them in volume for their managers, analysts and engineers,   The Xerox 820, to be unveiled today, is to retail for $3,000, including a video screen displaying 24 lines of 80 characters on a line, two 5 1/4-inch diameter disk-storage devices and 64,000 bytes of internal memory - equivalent to more than 10,000 English words - according to one source. A letter-quality printer will sell for $2,900 and the program to enable the computer to be used as a word processor will sell for $500.   So far, the personal computer business has been dominated by consumer electronics companies, such as the Tandy Corporation and Texas Instruments, and by companies devoted almost exclusively to microcomputers, such as Apple Computer. But other office equipment and business computer companies, such as the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation are expected to quickly follow Xerox's announcement with products of their own, possibly by early this summer.

headline: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WHITE MOTOR WILL SELL TRUCK BUSINESS TO VOLVO
abstract: The financially troubled White Motor Corporation has agreed to sell its most important manufacturing operation - the heavy-truck business that made it famous - to AB Volvo, the Swedish car, bus and truck manufacturer, the two companies announced today.   The agreement makes Volvo the latest European company to establish a bridgehead in North American truck manufacturing. Others are Italy's Fiat, France's Renault and West Germany's Daimler-Benz, which reached an agreement last month to take over Consolidated Freightways' Freightliner truck-making operation.

headline: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT GAINS NARROW LEAD IN PRELIMINARY VOTE
abstract: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, emerged last night from the first round of the presidential election as neck-and-neck contenders in the runoff in two weeks.   With five-sixths of the returns in, the Minister of the Interior, Christian Bonnet, announced that Mr. Giscard d'Estaing was leading with about 28.2 percent of the vote and that Mr. Mitterrand's share stood at 26.2 percent.   Though the President's showing was not as bad as his supporters had feared, his slim lead confirmed his decline in the last few weeks.  Mr. Mitterrand, on the other hand, did unexpectedly well.   The vote, which eliminated eight other contenders, was too close to permit any predictions about the May 10 runoff between the two finalists. Setback for Communist Party   But the returns did produce one clear and dramatic result: a sharp and unexpected setback for the Communist Party. Georges Marchais, the party leader and its candidate, polled a little over 15 percent of the vote, a sharp drop from the 20 percent that the party has maintained in recent years.

headline: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GROMYKO PRESSES U.S. ON STARTING ARMS CONTROL TALKS
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today pressed Soviet demands for American action toward negotiating arms controls with a speech declaring that it was ''necessary and possible'' to contain the arms race.   ''What is needed is negotiations on the substance of problems and not on how to embark on negotiations,'' he said at a luncheon for the visiting Belgian Foreign Minister, Charles-Ferdinand Nothomb. ''It is an open secret that at present it has become a vogue in some capitals to talk endlessly about negotiations, without at the same time doing as much as moving a finger to embark on such negotiations.''

headline: South Africa Bank Rate
abstract: The South African Reserve Bank said today that it would raise its discount rate, known as the bank rate, to 10.5 percent tomorrow from 9.5 percent. As a result, commercial banks are expected to raise their prime lending, or overdraft, rate to a record 14 percent from the current 13 percent. Under terms of an agreement between the authorities and the banks, the prime rate may not rise more than 3.5 percentage points above the bank rate.

headline: WHITE HOUSE TAKES EXCEPTION TO VIEW OF HAIG ON POLAND
abstract: The White House, taking a different approach from that of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., emphasized today that a total trade embargo against the Soviet Union was ''one of many options'' President Reagan could choose if the Soviet Union invaded Poland.   On Saturday, Secretary Haig said that Mr. Reagan would impose a total embargo in the event of an invasion.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 5, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Zero Coupon Issue Is Sold by Penney
abstract: Strong investor demand for the first zero coupon bonds ever issued to the public enabled underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation to increase to $200 million from $100 million an issue of A/A+-rated J.C. Penney Company notes that were priced yesterday at 33.247 to yield 14.25 percent to maturity in 1989. The issue is to be offered today.

headline: DECISION TO END SOVIET GRAIN SALE CURB REPORTED NEAR
abstract: The Reagan Administration was reported tonight to be close to a decision to lift restrictions on grain sales to the Soviet Union in stages, according to White House officials.   Mr. Reagan, the officials said, has not completed his deliberations on the action, and several senior aides insisted that no decision had been made.   Others, however, said that there was a consensus that the curtailment should end and that the issue now was one of timing. One official said that the President had discussed the matter with his senior advisers and had agreed in principle to lift the restrictions as soon as possible.

headline: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.E. TO SELLA ROBOT FOR USE IN FACTORIES
abstract: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would manufacture and sell an industrial robot developed by an Italian company as part of its strategy to become a major supplier of equipment for factory automation.   The G.E. announcement said that a new group had been formed to develop and market robots and that the initial entry into the robot business would be followed by additional robots. G.E. will either design these itself or license them from others.   General Electric said its agreement, with DEA of Italy, gives it nonexclusive rights to manufacture and sell worldwide a DEA robot that can assemble small items such as automobile parts. In North America, G.E. has exclusive rights to the product unless DEA wants to sell its robots on its own, according to Julius A. Mirabal, general manager of G.E.'s new robot group.

headline: WEINBERGER SAYS INVASION IS STILL A 'REAL POSSIBLITY'
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger asserted today that a Soviet invasion of Poland ''is still a very real possibility'' despite what he described as a ''more conciliatory'' tone in Moscow's recent statements.   Since the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact forces ended their military maneuvers, Mr. Weinberger said, ''nothing has happened'' to lessen the threat of invasion. He said that the level of military activity was slightly less but that the forces had stayed in place.   In a conversation with reporters on his plane during the last leg of his European tour, Mr. Weinberger said that ''there's no question that the threat remains.''

headline: MISSILE CRISIS: SHIFT BY ISRAEL
abstract: Although it has not yet defused the missile crisis in Lebanon, the shuttle diplomacy of the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, has begun to produce a subtle change in Israel's assessment of the problem.   Since April 29, when Syria first moved batteries of antiaircraft missiles into Lebanon, Israel's stake in a political solution has grown, and the alternative of military action, which at first seemed such a decisive, conclusive answer, has developed serious liabilities. Military Force Is Not Ruled Out   The shift in perception is not absolute and does not rule out armed force should diplomatic efforts fail. But Mr. Habib's two weeks in the region have provided a cooling-off period, time for Syria to reinforce its defenses and a chance for the Israelis to analyze and define more sharply their security interests across their northern border.

headline: J. Walter Thompson In Cable TV Deal
abstract: Leaping right into the center of the cable TV maelstrom, J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. has got itself a deal with the Adams-Russell Company, which operates a 52-channel, two-way cable system in Peabody, Mass., with 8,000 subscribers.   The agency will be working on a service called the Cable Shop, an information and advertising service, from which viewers, by dialing, can request special-information programming, some of which will be advertiser-sponsored (''How to buy a car,'' from an auto maker, or menus, from a food company) and some, community information.

headline: PATENTS; Big Wind Fences Utilized To Produce Electricity
abstract: Wind fences that may be 500 feet high and five miles long have been invented to produce commercial electricity. Harry H. Bahrenburg, a principal field engineer for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, was awarded patent 4,265,086 this week.

headline: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; 2 REIT's Gain In Lease-Backs
abstract: IN the late 1960's, when long-term mortgage money was relatively dear, a number of shopping-center and garden-apartment developers welcomed the chance to sell and lease back land underlying their income-producing properties.   By doing so, they were able to recover a major portion of the capital they had invested in the land while leasing it at reasonably attractive long-term fixed rates.   They also contracted to pay the new landowner a portion of incremental rents over the years. When the contracts were initiated, this seemed like a good deal for all parties concerned.

headline: NEW CHAIRMAN OF CHINA PARTY
abstract: In 1941, a 26-year-old Communist political officer named Hu Yaobang was assigned to work in the 11th Army Group of the Red Army, operating in the arid Taihang Mountains in the northwestern part of China. There he was thrown together with another political commissar, 11 years his senior, named Deng Xiaoping.   It was the beginning of a long friendship between Mr. Hu and Mr.  Deng, now China's predominant leader.  From the early 1940's on, the career of Mr. Hu - his name is pronounced hoo yaow-bahng - has closely paralleled that of Mr. Deng.  They served together in the army for eight years. They marched south into Sichuan Province and worked in the local administration there at the outset of the People's Republic in 1949. They were transferred concurrently to Peking in 1952. And when Mr. Deng was purged in the Cultural Revolution as a ''capitalist roader,'' Mr. Hu was toppled along with him, attacked by Red Guards as a member of Mr. Deng's ''club.'' It was a pattern that was to be repeated in 1976 when Mr.  Deng was disgraced for a second time.

headline: Pirelli Plans to End Ties With Dunlop
abstract: Soci ete Internationale Pirelli S.A. of Basel, Switzerland, and Pirelli S.p.A. of Milan, Italy, announced the end of a 10-year union with Dunlop Holdings Ltd. of London. A spokesman for the Pirelli interests said that the end of the agreement would enable it to develop export markets more effectively without the limitations of the losses incurred by the ailing British company, a major tire maker.

headline: NEW TRADE IN GOLD FUTURES
abstract: THE powerful 104-year-old London Metal Exchange, in an apparent recognition of the role that futures contracts play in pricing gold, will begin trading futures in the metal for the first time on Sept.  7. Should the venture succeed, the exchange is expected to add a market in silver futures.   The exchange's belated move into the futures arena is seen by analysts as less significant than its impact on the global market in gold.   London is still considered the world's leading market in physical gold. The twice-daily price fixings by the top five dealers there have long exerted strong influences on worldwide prices. But there is a strong belief in the trade that the futures prices on New York's Commodity Exchange, the biggest metals futures market, are the real determinant of the price of gold.

headline: IN THE NEW YORK REGION, TEARS, PRAYERS AND CALLS FOR GUN CONTROL
abstract: Residents of the New York metropolitan area and their religious and political leaders responded to the shooting of Pope John Paul II in Rome yesterday with tears and outrage, expressions of incredulity and prayers for the Pontiff's recovery.   Amid renewed calls for gun control, the Connecticut Senate, citing the wounding of the Pope, reversed itself and gave final approval to a bill that prescribes a mandatory sentence of one year in jail for illegal possession of a handgun.   Gasps and cries of ''Oh, God!'' rose from crowds gathered for the noon mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral when the Rev. Charles Mahoney announced: ''I have some dreadful, tragic news to tell you. Pope John Paul II was shot just a few minutes ago.''   In streets, homes, offices and schools throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Catholics and non-Catholics alike stopped what they were doing to gather around radios or television sets and anxiously listen for news of what had happened and of the Pope's condition.

headline: E.E.C. Duties On U.S. Goods
abstract: The European Common Market, acting in advance of trade talks with the United States this week, announced two new measures today to counter alleged American dumping.   The Common Market Commission imposed a 38 percent temporary antidumping duty on American textured polyester cloth after a complaint from European concerns that United States undercharging was damaging their industry.

headline: TEXT OF ADDRESS BY MITTERRAND
abstract: Following is the text of President Francois Mitterrand's inaugural address, as translated by Reuters:   On this day when I take up my functions, I think of those millions and millions of women and men, the ferment of our people, who for two centuries, in peace and war, with their labor and their blood, have fashioned the history of France without ever having access to it other than by brief, glorious eruptions of our society.   It is in their name above all that I speak, faithful to the teaching of Jaures, at a time when, at the third stage of a long journey, after the Popular Front and the Liberation, the political majority of the French people, democratically expressed, has just identified itself with its social majority.   It is natural for a great nation to have great ambitions. In today's world, can there be a loftier duty for our country than to achieve a new alliance between Socialism and liberty, a more noble ambition than to offer it to tomorrow's world?

headline: Company News; Sun Banks Intends To Acquire Century
abstract: Sun Banks of Florida Inc. said that it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire Century Banks Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for a combination of cash and notes valued at about $111.2 million.  Combined assets of the two institutions total $4.6 billion.

headline: Frank C. Dougherty
abstract: PEACEKEEPERS IN LEBANON: Irish members of a United Nations battalion in southern Lebanon survey the fields below from a hilltop emplacement. Their outpost is a short distance from Haddata, a Christian enclave. Yesterday, Libya said that four of its soldiers died last week in Israeli raids while acting as ''volunteers'' in Lebanon.

headline: Police in Pakistan Clash With Supporters of Bhutto
abstract: Riot policemn using tear gas clashed today with about 4,000 supporters of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto on the second anniversary of his execution, the police reported.

headline: ALBERTA CUTS OIL OUTPUT AGAIN
abstract: The province of Alberta stepped up its pressure on the federal Government for higher oil prices today by cutting its oil production by a further 5 percent.   Despite new efforts to reach an agreement in the long and costly dispute between the federal Government and Canada's biggest energy producing province, Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta stuck to his program of progressive production cuts announced last November in retaliation for Ottawa's new National Energy Program.   The provincial governments, especially Alberta, have charged that the program interferes with their jurisdiction over energy resources. Alberta wants to raise its oil prices closer to world price levels at a pace faster than the federal Government is willing to permit. The wellhead price of domestic crude is now $17.75 (Canadian) a barrel, about half the world price. A Canadian dollar is worth about 83 cents in United States currency.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LONG-TERM YIELDS CLIMBING
abstract: Just a few months ago, as the Reagan Administration was moving in, some bond traders were eager to buy Treasury bonds yielding less than 12 1/2 percent because they expected yields to drop even further.  They may still be right, but they will have to wait a while longer.   Long-term interest rates are setting records almost daily. The yield on bellwether 30-year Treasury bonds has increased 1 3/8 percentage points in less than a month, reaching 13.45 percent by late Friday.

headline: Colombian Mining Town Raided
abstract: Leftist guerrillas attacked the Colombian gold mining town of Segovia today, wounding 10 people, including five policemen, according to radio news reports. The reports said guerrillas had escaped with more than $20,000 worth of gold. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by the authorities.

headline: Delinquent Mortgages Up
abstract: Mortgage loan delinquencies at the nation's savings and loan associations rose slightly last month but remained below 1 percent, according to the United States League of Savings Associations.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SYNTHETIC FUELS: PROGRAM LAGS
abstract: The Reagan Administration seems to have become almost casual about synthetic fuels in light of the current oversupply in world oil markets.   Never keenly interested in Government sponsorship of a synthetic fuels industry, the Administration has eliminated direct subsidies for synthetic fuels programs started by the Department of Energy, expressed no objection when a bill was introduced in the Senate under which money appropriated for the Synthetic Fuels Corporation could be tapped to finance the filling of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, cut the salaries of a half-dozen top corporation officials and delayed naming a new corporation board.   Meanwhile, a House subcommittee headed by Representative Toby Moffett, a Connecticut Democrat, has been peppering the corporation with procedural and other complaints about its operations since it came into being last October.   The result is growing concern at both the public corporation and among potential sponsors of synthetic fuels projects that the major national effort envisioned by Congress may not take place.

headline: Bell Argues Data Case
abstract: While representatives from much of the communications and computer industries waited to protest, an attorney for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company told a Federal judge today that a 25-year-old antitrust suit settlement should be reinterpreted to allow the huge company to enter the potentially lucrative computer market.   The A.T.& T. attorney, Harold S. Levy, told Federal District Judge Vincent P. Biunno that a Federal Communications Commission decision permits the company to enhance the services attached to its phone lines.

headline: GHANA'S LEADER ASKS U.S. AID FOR AILING ECONOMY
abstract: President Hilla Limann has appealed to the United States to help make Ghana ''a model and a showcase of pluralistic democracy.''   Ghana has experienced a long slide from what seemed to be a glittering promise of development and prosperity when Britain granted it independence in 1957.   There is no longer any attempt to veil the precipitous decline in production and trade in this potentially rich country or the corrosive spread of corruption, the only way things are kept limping along.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bendix Asks F.T.C.  About Divestiture
abstract: The Bendix Corporation asked the Federal Trade Commission for approval of its proposed divestiture of a subsidiary's rotating-toolholder business, the F.T.C. said.

headline: DISCLOSE DETAILS OF MEDICAL CARE
abstract: Doctors treating Pope John Paul II said today that he was out of danger and should recover fully from his gunshot wounds within 60 days.   The Pope's recuperation, described in a medical bulletin issued today, has come as a relief to the doctors who have been treating him since he was shot on May 13. In interviews, with the Vatican's approval, they agreed in recent days to clarify confusion that resulted from early reports after the shooting and to re-create the steps that they took to save the Pope's life.   At the time of the shooting, one of the chief surgeons of Gemelli Hospital, Dr. Giancarlo Castiglione, was at a medical meeting in Milan. He rushed back to Rome by air. In an interview he recalled how the first news reports had confused him.

headline: Quake Shakes Northern Japan
abstract: A strong earthquake hit northern Japan today, rattling windows and doors but causing no major damage or casualties, the Central Meteorological Agency said.

headline: Market Falls Again, Dow Dropping 6.67
abstract: Stock prices, continuing to react to surging interest rates and the Federal Reserve's move in tightening credit, dropped moderately yesterday, for the sixth consecutive session, as the trading pace quickened.   After the market closed Monday, the Fed increased the discount rate - its charge on loans to member banks - to 14 percent from 13 percent. The Fed also raised the penalty surcharge for frequent big borrowers to four percentage points from three.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session yesterday, fell 6.67 points, to 972.44. On Monday, the blue-chip barometer tumbled 16.48 points after a number of major banks increased their prime rates, the basis for loan charges to their most creditworthy corporate customers, to 19 percent from 18 percent. The cumulative decline in the Dow for the last six sessions is about 52 points.

headline: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
abstract: Questions appear on page 14.  1. A contest to design a national memorial to Vietnam War veterans.  2. That the British Government treat imprisoned members of the Irish Republican Army as political prisoners.  3.

headline: THE PARIS AIRSHOW: WINING, DINING AND DEALING FOR MILITARY MIGHT
abstract: LE BOURGET, France F OR the first time in many years, military aircraft flying at the 34th Paris Air Show are loaded with simulated weapons. Defense is in again. The American contractors and their competitors are flexing their muscles in export markets with new intensity.   The air show, which ends tomorrow, is by far the biggest shop window for the world's aerospace industry.  ''What we hear is that foreign military sales will be accelerated dramatically over the next few years,'' said Alan Benasuli, an analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert and president of the Society of Aerospace Analysts, whose members are here. ''Areas to be in are simple - foreign military sales, missiles, defense electronics, space aplications and navy. What not to be in is military aircraft not for export and not commercial aircraft.''   ''It's a concentrated time and place where you can see chiefs of air forces, ministers of defense and finance,'' said C. Robert Gates, international vice president at Northrop, which is touting its new F-5G Tigershark. ''I don't think we've ever sold a plane at an air show, but you make a lot of steps in that direction.''

headline: PRESIDENT PICKS ACTOR FOR MEXICO POST
abstract: President Reagan has selected the actor John Gavin to be Ambassador to Mexico, the White House announced today.   The nomination of the 49-year-old Mr. Gavin, whose films included ''Psycho'' and ''Imitation of Life,'' had been expected.

headline: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Belgian Government Is Sworn In by the King
abstract: King Baudouin today swore in a new Belgian Cabinet headed by Prime Minister Mark Eyskens.  The new Government, the fifth since 1979, is virtually identical with the coalition of Christian Democrats and Socialists headed by former Prime Minister Wilfried Martens that resigned last Tuesday over a proposal for a wage freeze. Mr. Eyskens was Finance Minister in the Martens Government.   Earlier today the new Prime Minister won approval for a package of economic measures from Flemish- and French-speaking Christian Democrats and Socialists who are split into four parties along ethnic lines.

headline: Andrus Joins United Solar
abstract: Cecil D. Andrus, former Secretary of the Interior, has joined the board of directors of United Solar Associates Inc., the company announced today. Mr. Andrus served in President Carter's Administration.

headline: Trade Gap Narrower For March
abstract: A sharp decline in imported oil, combined with a surge in American exports, shrank the nation's merchandise trade deficit to $451.4 million in March, the smallest in more than five years, the Commerce Department reported today.   Economists said the drop in oil imports - to about 5.5 million barrels a day from February's 7.5 million -probably will not be repeated in future months. But they also said imports were unlikely to soar again in the next few months.

headline: Split-Stock Prices: New Method Used
abstract: Beginning today, a new method is used in the stock market tables to show the historical range of prices of stocks that have been split within the last year. The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange tables are affected.

headline: YOUTHS PRAY FOR POPE AT ST. PATRICK'S
abstract: About 1,300 teen-agers, many of whom seranaded Pope John Paul II during his visit to the United States in 1979, gathered at St.  Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to pray for the Pope's recovery from gunshot wounds.   ''We are united with the suffering of our Holy Father,'' Terence Cardinal Cooke told the students from Cathedral High School at a mass.

headline: President of Dominicans Will Not Seek New Term
abstract: President Antonio Guzman Fernandez said today that he would not seek reelection next year.

headline: STANDARD ALLIANCE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Lost Missile Exploded in Air, West Germans Now Say
abstract: The police said today that an American-made Sidewinder missile that disappeared during a West German Air Force training flight exploded in the air and did not fall intact to the ground as feared.   Three residents of the area southwest of Straubing in northeast Bavaria told the police they heard a loud explosion and saw clouds of smoke Monday afternoon when the missile fell from the Phantom jet.  The police later said three other people looking for mushrooms in the woods around Gingkofen, a village southwest of Straubing, found parts of the missile, confirming it had gone off in the air.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Despite the unexpected agreement by President Reagan and Mexico's President Jose Lopez Portillo in their talks earlier this month to work out a joint economic aid package for the Caribbean basin, the initiative faces formidable political difficulties.   In reality, the much-vaunted assistance plan for the region is still at an embryonic stage, with the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, Venezuela and Canada eventually expected to join the United States and Mexico in financing and implementing it.   Yet questions are already being raised in the region about the viability of a plan that seeks to isolate economic problems from the sharp political differences that exist, not only within and between the countries of the area but also among potential aid donors.   ''If anyone thinks that economic aid can resolve the political crises in El Salvador and Guatemala, they're simply naive,'' a regional economist said, mentioning the two Central American countries polarized by extremist violence.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Aminoil USA Inc., a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries, made a second wildcat oil discovery in the Montana sector of the Williston Basin.   * Brascan Ltd. said in a filing with the S.E.C. that it had paid $236 million for the purchase of 8.7 million shares, or 20.5 percent, of the Scott Paper Co. Curtiss-Wright Corp. will redeem all outstanding class AA stock on June 10 at $40 a share.

headline: SCHICK INC reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AVOIDING MISTAKES OF THE PAST
abstract: - Will the much-talked-about new video technologies have an effect on the advertising creative product? John E. O'Toole, chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding, not only hopes so but has some specific ideas.   And as the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies came to a close today at the Boca Raton Hotel, he shared them with his fellow members.   What he is hoping is that the advertisers beginning to explore the new areas made accessible through the new technologies do not make the same mistakes they did in television and that the new formats will force advertising disciplines that will be beneficial to commercials in all of broadcast.   "If you look at it right," he said, "this next chapter in the development of electronic communication could be the opportunity to correct the three major mistakes we marketing people made in the last chapter.  We might get a second chance."

headline: CANADIANS HONOR 2 FROM MISSION IN IRAN
abstract: Starting in early November 1979, two wives of Canadian Embassy officials endured almost three months of constant tension in Teheran while they cared for six American diplomats who had escaped the seizure of the United States Embassy and had taken refuge in their homes. This week, almost 18 months after the successful rescue of the Americans, the wives were honored by the Canadian Government.   Patricia Taylor, wife of Kenneth Taylor, the Canadian Ambassador in Teheran at the time of the rescue and now Consul General in New York, and Zena Sheardown, wife of John Sheardown, the immigration officer at the embassy in Teheran, were both given the Order of Canada, the country's highest civilian award.   Mrs. Sheardown, who was born in Guyana, was given only honorary membership in the order because she is still a British subject, according to an announcement by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who stressed the ''unique'' circumstances of an award that is ordinarily reserved for citizens.

headline: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japanese Cassette Plants
abstract: BASF Japan Ltd. said today that its parent firm, BASF A.G. of West Germany, planned to build two plants in northern Japan to assemble magnetic tape cassettes at a monthly rate of about two million.

headline: THOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iranian Says Secret Agency Isn't Like Savak Under Shah
abstract: A senior Iranian official said today that Iran has a new intelligence agency but that it is not like the Shah's hated Savak secret police since it is run along Islamic lines.   Asked at a news conference to confirm the existence of a secret agency called Savama, a Government spokesman, Behzad Nabavi, said, ''Yes, we have an intelligence organization.''

headline: Greece Protests NATO's Stand Against Maneuvers on an Island
abstract: Greece has protested NATO's refusal to include the northeastern island of Lemnos in recent alliance military maneuvers because of a belief that the island should be demilitarized.   A Government spokesman said today that the stand by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had been interpreted as supporting Turkey's argument that the eastern Aegean islands should be demilitarized, which Greece refuses to do for fear of a Turkish attack.

headline: Teletype Chief Appointed
abstract: John J. Pappas, 48, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Teletype Corporation, a subsidiary of the Western Electric Company. He succeeds Lloyd C. Boswell, 63, who retired as head of the Skokie, Ill., manufacturer of data terminals.

headline: Honda Plan for Colombia
abstract: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would sign a technical assistance agreement with a Colombian bus-body maker to manufacture motorcycles in the South American country. The contract, scheduled to be concluded this month, will empower Fabrica Nacional de Autotartes Nanalca S.A. to produce Honda-designed motorcycles starting in the mid-1980's, company officials said.  Initially put at 16,000 units annually, the output of 100-cubiccentimeter motorcycles will be increased to 30,000 units later in the decade, the officials said.

headline: Hospital Corp. to Buy INA Health Unit
abstract: The INA Corporation, reversing its strides into the health-care field, yesterday announced plans to sell its hospital unit, Hospital Affiliates International, for $650 million in cash and stock to the Hospital Corporation of America.   The agreement, if approved by both boards of directors, would further consolidate H.C.A.'s position as the nation's leading owner of hospitals and biggest supplier of management services to nonprofit or independently owned hospitals. In turn, INA would acquire a 13 percent stock position in H.C.A., while adding $450 million in cash.

headline: POLICE CALL TERRORIST PLOT 'REMOTE'
abstract: Pope John Paul II was moved today from the intensive care unit at Gemelli Hospital to a four-room private suite.  The move, which came on the Pontiff's 61st birthday, was a sign of his steady recovery from serious abdominal wounds suffered in an assassination attempt five days ago.   In another positive development, his doctors today began issuing only one bulletin a day instead of two. Today's bulletin said his condition was stable, but hospital officials warned that the danger of infection had not entirely disappeared.   At the same time, Italian authorities resumed their questioning of Mehmet Ali Agca, the 23-year-old convicted murderer who is accused of firing two shots at the Pope last Wednesday. They appeared to be pulling back from the theory that Mr. Agca, a Turk, had acted with the support of an international terrorist ring.

headline: ALPHA PORTLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: B.P. CUTS NORTH SEA OIL OUTPUT
abstract: The world oil glut, coupled with the high official price for crude oil from the British sector of the North Sea, has forced the British Petroleum Company to reduce production from its Forties Field there by 17 percent during the second quarter of this year, the company said yesterday.   The production cutback, from 520,000 barrels a day in the first quarter to an average of 430,000 barrels a day in the current quarter, is thought to be the first in the North Sea unrelated to technical or weather problems. Industry sources described the cutback as an attempt to put pressure on the state-owned British National Oil Corporation to cut the price it pays for North Sea crude from the current $39.25 a barrel.

headline: MICKELBERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
