headline: No Headline
abstract: Around the World; Britain Moves to Bar Prisoners From Parliament   LONDON, June 22 (Reuters) - The British Government, fearing that another jailed Irish republican guerrilla may be elected to Parliament, introduced a bill today to prevent convicted prisoners from entering Parliamentary elections.   The bill would disqualify anyone serving a prison sentence of a year or more from being nominated for election.

headline: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Super-Accurate Clock
abstract: A clock described by the Guinness Book of World Records as the most accurate timekeeping device in the world -exact to within one second per 1.7 million years - has been turned over to the National Museum of American History in the Smithsonian Institution by the Naval Research Laboratory.

headline: U.S. MAY SELL SAUDIS RADAR, FUEL PLANES
abstract: The Reagan Administration was reported today to have tentatively decided on enlarging its program of arms sales to Saudi Arabia by including five Awacs electronic surveillance planes and seven KC-135 aerial tankers.   In addition, the Administration was said by officials and Congressional sources to be prepared to leave in Saudi Arabia four Air Force Awacs craft operating there, until five such planes to be sold to the Saudis can be delivered in 1985.   This tentative decision was made, officials said, at a National Security Council meeting yesterday. Vice President Bush presided at the meeting in the absence of President Reagan.

headline: Around the World; Arm of Solidarity Threatens Strike Over Police Beating
abstract: The Solidarity trade union movement said today that it was sending a delegation to the northeastern Polish city of Bialystok to investigate a report of alleged police brutality.   The Solidarity branch in Bialystok said that the police in the town of Kuznica beat up a disabled man on May 2 and left him lying in the street.

headline: Farm Prices Again Fall 0.4%
abstract: High interest rates and a slowdown in export sales of United States crops combined to depress farm prices by fourth-tenths of 1 percent in May, according to the Department of Agriculture.

headline: SAUDI OFFICIAL VOWS HIGH OUTPUT OF OIL UNTIL PRICES DROP
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that his country would not raise its oil prices or reduce its production until other petroleum-exporting nations reduced their prices significantly.   Sheik Yamani's comments represented Saudi Arabia's most pointed threat so far in its struggle with other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries over oil prices. His comments set the stage for an acrimonious meeting of the 13-member cartel in Geneva on May 25.   ''We think it went too far,'' said Sheik Yamani of the rise in oil prices. ''It's not in the interest of the international community, and therefore we want it to come down a little bit lower.''

headline: Multifoods Earnings Up
abstract: The International Multifoods Corporation said today that its net income rose 70 percent in the first quarter of the 1982 fiscal year, to $3.9 million, or 48 cents a share, from $2.3 million, or 28 cents, in the similar period a year ago. Sales in the quarter, which ended May 31, rose 18.8 percent, to $279.4 million from $235.1 million.

headline: Drop Continues In Fuel Demand
abstract: The American appetite for oil products continued to wane in the four weeks ending April 17, with refiners marketing an average of just 15.9 million barrels a day, the Energy Department said today.   The agency said the overall supply rate for refined products - a rough gauge of demand - was 13 percent below the average so far this year and 6.1 percent below the comparable period in 1980.

headline: Eisenhower Aide Picked As Ambassador to Italy
abstract: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Maxwell M. Rabb, secretary to the Eisenhower Cabinet, to be Ambassador to Italy.   Mr. Rabb, 70 years old, a New York lawyer who was active in fund raising for Mr. Reagan's campaign, is to succeed Richard Gardiner.  Mr. Reagan also announced that he was nominating Charles H. Price 2d as Ambassador to Belgium. Mr. Price, 50, chairman of the board of the American Bank and Trust Company of Kansas City, Mo., is to succeed Anne Cox Chambers.

headline: Economic Scene; Reagan Budget Versus Reality
abstract: FOR the time being, President Reagan has got what he wanted from Congress: a $695.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982. This represents a cut of $43.8 billion below the Carter Administration's proposed budget for that year. But the Reagan budget figures are clearly wrong, even before the first Congressional budget resolution has been printed. Virtually no informed person in Congress or the White House believes that spending in the fiscal year 1982 will be anywhere near that low.   Next month the appropriations committees of Congress will start to wrestle with producing agency totals that stay within the $695.5 billion ceiling - a task made impossible by prices and interest rates that are higher than the Administration or Congress had assumed.

headline: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LABOR PARTY LEADER SAYS LIKUD IS PROVOKING CAMPAIGN VIOLENCE
abstract: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's candidate for Prime Minister, accused Menachem Begin's party today of organizing violent disruptions of his party's campaign rallies.   A spokesman for Mr. Begin denied the allegation.  Mr. Peres spoke at a news conference called in the wake of a fistfighting and window-smashing incident at a campaign rally last night. About 8,000 Labor Party supporters had gathered in Petah Tiqva, a city several miles south of Tel Aviv, to hear Mr. Peres.  About 200 hecklers jeered Mr. Peres and threw tomatoes at him, shouting, ''Begin, Begin, king of Israel!'' The police made 23 arrests.

headline: REAGAN WRITES LETTER TO BREZHNEV ABOUT TALKS ON MISSILES FOR EUROPE
abstract: President Reagan has written to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to inform him that the United States is ready to begin talks this year on limiting middle-range nuclear missiles in Europe, the NATO allies were told today.   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., informed foreign ministers at the semiannual NATO meeting here about the President's letter, which was sent within the past few days.   According to conference sources, he told them that the discussions would take place within the same framework that was established for the suspended Soviet-American talks on limiting strategic arms. This meant, they said, that possible Soviet requests to include French and British nuclear missiles in the discussions would be rejected.

headline: Lord Kagan, Jailed as a Swindler, Is Stripped of British Knighthood
abstract: Lord Kagan, a textile magnate who was jailed last December as a swindler, was stripped today of the knighthood awarded to him by Queen Elizabeth in 1970.

headline: CHRYSLER CHANGES
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close its Detroit Universal division plant by the end of the year and transfer operations to an engine plant and a stamping plant, both in the Detroit area, and a machining plant in Toledo, Ohio.  It said that most of the unit's 300 workers would be offered jobs at the other plants.  The move reflects a rapid change-over to the output of front-wheel-drive cars from the rear-wheel-drive units, in which the Universal division plant specialized.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Exxon and Avondale Sign Tanker Deal
abstract: Exxon U.S.A. said it had signed a contract with Avondale Shipyards of New Orleans, a unit of the Ogden Corporation, to build three 43,000-deadweight-ton tankers at an estimated cost of about $100 million each.

headline: CHINESE PARTY PARLEY UNDER WAY
abstract: Central Committee meetings were reported to be continuing today amid conflicting accounts of harmony and discord over proposed leadership changes.   Chinese officials have told visitors that the party meetings, which began last weekend, were proceeding smoothly toward a plenum, or formal meeting, of the 174-member Central Committee this week.

headline: Sun Yat-sen's Widow Is Visited
abstract: Soong Ching-ling, the widow of Sun Yat-sen, was visited at her bedside by relatives from San Francisco and Hong Kong, the official New China News Agency said today. She is about 90 and has been in critical condition from worsening leukemia and heart disease, according to the news agency. Her husband led the 1911 revolution that overthrew the Manchu dynasty.

headline: Toshiba's British Output
abstract: Toshiba Consumer Products said today that it planned to restart full production of its range of Britishmade color television sets in Plymouth, England, on May 4.  Toshiba Consumer Products, a new company operating through Toshiba U.K., which is a subsidiary of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, takes over production following the closing on March 20 of Rank Toshiba, the former operators of the plant. Toshiba U.K. said the first year's production would be around 100,000 sets, with the majority destined for the British market.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S., BONN AND JAPAN END SYNTHETIC FUEL PLAN
abstract: The United States, West Germany and Japan agreed yesterday to abandon a cooperative $1.55 billion coal liquefaction project that less than a year ago was hailed by Department of Energy officials as a centerpiece of the nation's drive to reduce dependence on imported oil.   The synthetic fuel plant, which was to have been built in Morgantown, W.Va., was to have converted 6,000 tons of high-sulfur coal into 20,000 barrels of oil and gas daily using a process developed by the Gulf Oil Company.   Gulf joined with a Japanese consortium led by Mitsui and Ruhrkohle A.G. of West Germany to form SRC International Inc., a venture that was to have provided $100 million for the project and served as prime contractor. The Governments of West Germany and Japan each agreed to cover 25 percent of the costs, and the United States was to pay the remaining 50 percent.

headline: '21' NOW SERVING ELITE IN TEXAS
abstract: Two captains of industry, seated on a banquette, are pressed up against the restaurant's walls like a pair of pinstripe-suited icons. The powers that be in communications are seated at a table nearby.  Downstairs, Random House huddles with CBS; ABC dines alone.   ''These are the people who make New York happen,'' Sheldon Tannen, executive vice president and part-owner of the ''21'' Club, said recently, as he ushered a visitor across the crowded restaurant floor.

headline: Economic Scene; Game Theory On G.O.P. Plan
abstract: ONE of the greatest intellectual achievements of the 20th century is game theory, developed by the mathematician John von Neumann in 1928 and extended to economics by Dr. von Neumann and the economist Oskar Morgenstern in their classic, ''The Theory of Games and Economic Behavior'' (1944).   Game theory, a mathematical system for analyzing contests where opponents seek to outwit each other and design the best course of action under all circumstances, has had a steadily growing influence in fields as diverse as warfare, arms control, politics, business and the humanities.   The current contest between Republicans and Democrats in Congress over President Reagan's economic program poses a challenge for game theory. The Democrats have two basic strategies: (I) mainly support the Reagan program or (II) attack the Reagan program and present a tax and spending program of their own. The Republicans also must choose between two strategies: (A) fully defend the President's program or (B) compromise with the Democrats, who have a majority in the House (if they hang together).

headline: Monthly Housing Completions Up
abstract: Privately owned housing units were completed in February at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.4 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.   The rate is 10 percent above the revised January rate of 1.3 million, but 23 percent below the 1.8 million units completed in February 1980.   The monthly data on completions are largely influenced by shortterm weather performance, but also reflect in a delayed fashion the slumping construction industry.

headline: Careers
abstract: IN John P. Marquand's 1949 novel, ''Point of No Return,'' the hero and another assistant vice president stage a quietly desperate battle for a vice presidency of an important New York bank. One loses (not the hero) and apparently must resign. The president, expressing wonderment, says there was never a doubt in his mind that the hero would be chosen.   Today businesses are much bigger, and competition for top jobs has become even more fierce. The loser can sometimes keep working for the company but often gets eased out.

headline: ARAB LEAGUE URGES SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL FOR ATTACK ON IRAQ
abstract: Arab foreign ministers and officials of the Arab League called today on the United Nations to impose ''binding sanctions'' on Israel, and they urged the United States ''to work seriously'' to curb Israeli ''aggression and expansionism.''   Representatives of 20 Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization convened in emergency session here to condemn Israel's raid on Iraq's nuclear reactor center. The raid, carried out last Sunday, destroyed a reactor being built by French specialists. The reactor was nearing completion.

headline: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * A.L. Laboratories Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., appointed Kenneth V. Kolberg vice president for finance and treasurer.   * Centura Energy Corp., Houston, named John M. Moore chief executive officer and vice chairman, succeeding Rudy K. Steury, who resigned from those posts but remains treasurer.

headline: A FAST-FOOD CHAIN; Hampstead, a Literary Community, Is Upset by McDonald's Plan to Open Hamburger Spot
abstract: Residents of Hampstead, one of London's most fashionable neighborhoods, have banded together to combat what they see as a dangerous threat to the character of their pleasant little main street - a plan to open a McDonald's hamburger restaurant.   ''Mind you, I've nothing against hamburgers, or Americans either for that matter,'' explained Sybil Wilson, as she signed a petition against McDonald's this morning during a demonstration outside the empty Hampstead store that the chain hopes to occupy. ''But for people who like McDonald's, there are already two of their shops not far from here. Must we turn all of Britain into an American junk food emporium?''

headline: SYRIA, LONG ISOLATED, IS REGAINING ARABS' SUPPORT IN THE MISSILE CRISIS
abstract: Syria, long isolated in the Arab world, has won the backing of Saudi Arabia and other Arab League members in its confrontation with Israel over Syrian missiles in Lebanon. But the Saudis are widely believed to be trying to find a face-saving way out of the crisis.   As foreign ministers of Arab League member countries issued their declaration of support over the weekend at a meeting in Tunis, Col.  Rifat al-Assad, brother of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria began talks with the Saudis.

headline: Bristol Myers Settles Suits
abstract: The Bristol Myers Company said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary settlement of antitrust suits pending since 1970 regarding ampicillin, an antibiotic drug.   The company did not disclose the amount it agreed to pay, but said it would not have a material effect on the company's profits.

headline: U.S. TALKS TOO MUCH ABOUT POLAND, RUSSIAN INSISTS
abstract: American officials talk too much about Poland, according to Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations, who returned to New York recently after extensive consultations in Moscow.   In an interview at the Soviet Mission he declined to comment on a possible role for the United Nations in stemming international complications arising from the Polish labor crisis.   ''I'll say this much, though,'' he added. ''There's too much being said in this country about Poland, and there have been too many instructions from Washington. For instance, President Reagan instructed Poland not to take drastic steps to establish law and order. That's rather as though we had insisted that the National Guard not be called out to quell rioting in Miami.''

headline: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: energywatch
abstract: JUNE 12, 1981 Crude oil stocks held steady at 404 million barrels.

headline: BEGIN IS SAID TO TELL REAGAN THAT ISRAEL FACE PERIL AS IN '67
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was reported today to have told President Reagan last week that, although he was willing to allow additional time for American diplomacy to try to resolve the crisis over Lebanon, the situation was similar to the 1967 Arab-Israeli crisis.   In that crisis, diplomatic efforts failed and Israel acted militarily. American and Israeli officials familiar with behind-thescenes contacts said that Mr. Begin, in a letter delivered to Mr. Reagan on Tuesday, specifically raised the parallel of the 1967 war. That conflict erupted when diplomatic efforts were unsuccessful in settling a crisis aggravated by Egypt's ejection of United Nations troops from Sinai.

headline: HAIG, ON A VISIT TO SPAIN, ATTEMPTS TO ASSURE REGIME OF U.S. SUPPORT
abstract: After meeting with King Juan Carlos, Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo and other Spanish leaders, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today ended a one-day visit to Spain expressing support for its democratic institutions.   Both in private conversations and at a news conference, Mr. Haig's principal aim appeared to be to disabuse Spaniards of the impression, widespread here since the attempted military coup on Feb. 23, that the Reagan Administration was lukewarm in its support of Spanish democracy.   This impression had grown from an off-the-cuff remark the Secretary made shortly after Parliament was seized that what was occurring in Spain was ''an internal matter.'' Though the Reagan Administration sent messages of congratulation to the King and Mr. Calvo Sotelo after the coup collapsed, the Spanish press interpreted Mr. Haig's comment as a sign of indifference and, in some publications, as proof that Washington knew of the coup attempt in advance.

headline: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Company News; DEALERS SPLIT ON JAPAN QUOTA RAMIFICATIONS
abstract: To say that John Cronin, the sales manager of Free World Foreign Cars Inc., a Datsun franchise in Manhattan, is pleased about the voluntary export quotas on Japanese automobiles is perhaps an understatement.   ''I love it,'' he said, smiling mischievously and rubbing his thumb and forefingers together. ''It's the law of supply and demand.  It means more money.''

headline: American Motors And Chiat/Day End Tie
abstract: American Motors and Chiat/Day are ending their 14-year relationship.  The Los Angeles-based agency, through its subsidiary, Chiat/Day/ Hoefer in San Francisco and Detroit, has been handling the advertising for A.M.C.'s cars and Jeeps outside the United States and Canada.

headline: Business People; 14 Real Estate Brokers Going to Pearce, Urstadt
abstract: On July 1, Robert J. Mehlman, 47, will lead 13 other real estate brokers, his entire department, from Herbert Charles & Company to Pearce, Urstadt, Mayer & Greer, when he becomes president of its new commercial leasing division. The reason for the move from one New York real estate firm to the other: the Charles concern is leaving the field of commercial leasing and the Pearce company is going into it full steam.

headline: NEW AMERICAN FARE
abstract: American Airlines said it would introduce a systemwide "Amerifare" that limits the cost of round-trip travel on any of its domestic flights to $179 one way.  American's special summer fare, which cuts regular coach fares by 35 to 63 percent, matches similar $179 caps announced last week by Eastern and Trans World Airlines for domestic travel.  The Amerifare is effective June 1 to Sept. 15 in any market where the round-trip Super Saver fare would be greater than $358, or $179 each way.

headline: FRANCE SAYS IRAQIS COULDN'T HAVE BUILT A-BOMB UNDETECTED
abstract: The French Government has disclosed the existence of an agreement with Iraq that it said would have made it impossible for Baghdad to avoid detection if it had tried to make nuclear weapons at the reactor destroyed by Israel on June 7.   Under this unpublished agreement, France was to have kept scientists working at the French-built reactor outside of Baghdad until 1989. The scientists were authorized to watch all nuclear experiments that Iraq carried out at the reactor and to check afterward to insure that it was still functioning safely.   In Washington today, Under Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. said that although the Reagan Administration had been concerned about Iraq's nuclear program, it would not agree with Israel's assertion that the reactor destroyed near Baghdad was designed to produce nuclear weapons. (Page A18.)

headline: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business People; Sun Company Chooses Chief Operating Officer
abstract: Robert McClements Jr., 52, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Sun Company, the nation's 11th-largest petroleum corporation. He moves up from executive vice president, succeeding Theodore A. Burtis, 59, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, with headquarters in Radnor, Pa.

headline: IN BOOMING TAIWAN, FARMS SUFFER
abstract: Booming Taiwan is having trouble keeping 'em down on the farm now that they've seen the assembly line, and the Nationalist Chinese Government is advancing what it calls ''a second land reform'' to combat some of the success of its first program, undertaken soon after its retreat from the mainland in 1949.   The present campaign is an indicator of the economic success of this island of nearly 18 million inhabitants. The first program was undertaken to give its impoverished and largely landless farmers title to the land from which they eked scant livelihoods under the Japanese colonization and the early years after the island's return to China.

headline: EAST GERMANY, SWITCHING COURSE, RENEWS CRITICISM OF EVENTS IN POLAND
abstract: Just a few days after party leaders here signaled their confidence in Poland's ability to solve its own problems, the East Germans today renewed their attacks on counterrevolutionaries and said the situation in Poland had worsened again.   A report published in all East German newspapers said ''Marxist-Leninist forces'' were greatly upset at recent events in Poland that threatened to undermine the leading role of the Polish party and gave ''new scope to counterrevolutionary elements in the country.'' The attack indicated that the struggle in Poland was far from over.
