headline: Back at Burger King
abstract: J. Jeffrey Campbell, one-time Dancer Fitzgerald Sample man, who joined Burger King and worked in its advertising department before going into the field to actually run operations, has come back to the hamburger chain's headquarters in Miami, Fla., as executive vice president and director of marketing.

headline: Loan From World Bank To China Reported Near
abstract: The World Bank has completed negotiations with China on a $200 million loan application to improve science and engineering teaching at universities, bank sources say.

headline: Co-Founder Of Sony to Get Aspen Award
abstract: Masaru Ibuka, the 73-year-old co-founder and honorary chairman of the Sony Corporation of Japan, will receive the first humanism and technology award of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies. The award will be presented to Mr. Ibuka at a ceremony in Aspen, Colo., on July 3.

headline: Union Camp Plans South Carolina Mill
abstract: The Union Camp Corporation, a diversified paper, packaging and chemicals concern, announced it would build a $600 million bleached pulp and paper mill near Eastover, S.C. Construction is to start early next year with the mill scheduled for completion in mid-1984, the company said.   The mill, which would ultimately employ between 350 and 400 people, will produce about 600 tons a day of uncoated printing and writing papers, the company said. It will be on a 3,800-acre tract on the Wateree River, about 20 miles southeast of Columbia.

headline: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW GROWTH BUSINESS- ARMING CARS
abstract: Richard C. Medlin is a man with a light-hearted approach to a grim business.  The calling card of his Custom Armor Manufacturing Company carries three miniature holes above a diagram of spent cartridges, and his favorite parting shot for a client leaving his shop with one of his custom-made bulletproof vests is, ''If you have any trouble with that thing, you give me a call.''   It isn't that he's ghoulish. It's just that the growing need that edgy people abroad feel to protect themselves from terrorist attacks is making him rich.

headline: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Harvard Lampoon To Parody People
abstract: The droll, witty Harvard Lampoon staff, the prime joshers of the Ivy League, have selected People magazine for their next parody effort. And now that they've discovered that you can make money selling ad space in them, it's oh so much more fun.

headline: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHAPLAIN IS REVEALED AS AUTHOR OF BOOK ON VIETNAM
abstract: The name of the Reserve lieutenant colonel who used the pseudonym Cincinnatus when he wrote the book ''Self-Destruction: The Disintegration and Decay of the United States Army During the Vietnam Era'' has been revealed to be Dr. Cecil B. Currey, a professor of American military history at the University of South Florida in Tampa who never served in Vietnam.   Professor Currey, 48 years old, remains in the Army Reserve, attached to the Office of Chief of Chaplains.  Capt. Margaret Lamax, an Army spokesman, confirmed over the weekend that Professor Currey has had a Pentagon assignment since October 1979, but she said that no formal statement either about the disclosure of his authorship or about his future status could be made until higher-ranking officers discussed the matter this week. 'Failure of Military Mind'   The disclosure of the book's contents first appeared in The New York Times of Dec. 30. The author maintained that Vietnam was ''a failure of the American military mind.'' He blamed both the American generals in Saigon, particularly William C. Westmoreland, and the Pentagon officers who ''thought and fought like corporate executives.''

headline: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reserves Fall In Britain
abstract: Britain's reserves of foreign currency, gold and special drawing rights in the International Monetary Fund fell $1.5 billion last month because of early repayment of overseas loans, the Government announced today.   The money was repaid to a consortium of international banks on a loan of $2.4 billion made in 1974 when the Labor Government was in financial difficulties following the 1973 oil crisis, the Treasury said.

headline: THE SINGING TELEGRAM BUSINESS
abstract: It is midmorning in a refurbished San Francisco warehouse, the home of National Singing Telegrams Ltd., as Ed Eng leafed through the 65 pages of neatly-typed song lyrics that comprise his company's telegram repertoire.   Mother's Day, bar mitzvahs and birthdays are covered in separate, copyrighted songs. Courtship and job applications also have their own compositions. There is even a song, composed for an orthodontist, extolling the special joy of having braces removed from one's teeth.

headline: G.N.P. UP STRONGLY FOR FIRST QUARTER AT 6.5% YEARLY RATE
abstract: The nation's economy grew in the first quarter of 1981 at an annual rate of 6.5 percent, a figure that was higher than most economists had expected.   The economists divided over the impact of the figure, with some saying that the strong growth would damage chances for Congressional passage of the Administration's proposal to cut income taxes by 10 percent annually for three years. The tax cut is designed to stimulate economic growth.   The advance in the ''real'' gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services adjusted for inflation, was the biggest quarterly gain since the second quarter of 1978 and compared with an annual growth rate of just 3.8 percent in 1980's fourth quarter.

headline: LIBERTY FABRICS OF NEW YORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Parliament Elected, By Vietnamese Voters
abstract: Vietnamese voters elected a new Parliament today.  The 496-seat assembly will be the seventh since Ho Chi Minh declared Vietnam an independent country in September 1945, but it will be the first to be chosen in nationwide elections since the unification of North and South Vietnam in 1976.

headline: Joint Irish Venture For Foster Wheeler
abstract: The Foster Wheeler Corporation, designer and builder of processing and steam generating plants, said it would establish a joint venture in Galway, Ireland, to produce components for steam boilers.

headline: BELGRADE SENDS TANKS TO REBELLIOUS REGION
abstract: Yugoslav tanks and troops took up positions today in a province in the south to put down anti-Government riots by Albanian separatists.   The Interior Ministry imposed a curfew in Pristina, capital of the Autonomous Province of Kosovo, and in four other towns after a police order yesterday banning all public gatherings.   Under the curfew, citizens in five districts were ordered to stay in their homes from 8 P.M. to 5 A.M.  Dzavid Nimani, head of the local government, accused Albanian nationalists of seeking to ''destabilize, break up and endanger the territorial integrity and independence of our country.'' He called on Communists to unite to quell the demonstrations.

headline: Portuguese Fireworks Mark Seventh Year of Democracy
abstract: Fireworks and parades marked the seventh anniversary of Portugal's 1974 revolution today as the Government sent Parliament a bill to end military supervision of the country's democracy.

headline: Advertising; by Philip Dougherty; Modern Photography, In the Air and on Campus
abstract: ''Up in the Air . . .'' and ''On the Campus . . .'' - both followed by ''With the Editors of Modern Photography'' - are two inserts being planned over at ABC Leisure Magazines to run in airline magazines and campus newspapers.

headline: Ray-O-Vac to Stay
abstract: The Ray-O-Vac Corporation, which had earlier announced plans to move out of Lancaster, Ohio, has decided instead to build a new $13.2 million plant there.

headline: INSIDERS AND THE LAW
abstract: EVERYONE is looking for an edge.  In the stock market, the edge that is sought is called insider information.  Stanley S. Arkin, of of the law firm of Arkin & Arishon, knows a lot about this topic.  He defends individuals who have been accused of white collar crime.   In 1980 Mr. Arkin won a dismissal of charges against Vincent Chiarella of Greenwich Village.  Mr. Chiarella had purchased stock before an announcement of tender offers.  He learned about the offers while setting type at a financial printing firm.

headline: COMMUNIST-CHRISTIAN CONFLICT IN CUBA SEEMS TO EASE
abstract: At the narrow mouth of Havana Bay, a 70-foot white marble statue of Jesus, depicted as the risen Christ of Easter, looms over an embankment that drops sharply to the water.  Hastily erected by the tottering regime of Fulgencio Batista days before his overthrow in 1959, it is a symbol of the ambivalence with which religion exists under the Communist Government of Fidel Castro.    While the ''Christ of Havana,'' as it is known, has never been removed, it strikes an uncomfortable image standing over a harbor busy with Soviet ships loading and unloading cargo.   It is both a rebuke to the state's atheistic doctrine and something of an embarrassement to many Christians, who see it as a reminder of a bygone era and a cause of tension between Communists and Christians. During Holy Week the statue overlooks a city caught up in the remembrance of the Cuban victory at the Bay of Pigs 20 years ago. Religious events are scarcely evident.

headline: American Home Joins Sanofi Venture
abstract: The American Home Products Corporation and Sanofi of France said that they had agreed to form a joint venture company in the United States to develop and market pharmaceutical products developed by Sanofi's research operations.

headline: DIGEST'S ELECTRONICS VENTURE
abstract: In its first year and a half of existence, the Source has infuriated its customers, run up millions of dollars in debts to hundreds of creditors, watched its two founders sue each other and hovered continuously on the brink of bankruptcy.   All that, however, did not stop the Reader's Digest Association Inc. from jumping at the chance to buy 51 percent of the Source for $3 million last September and increasing its holdings to 80 percent for an additional $1 million in December.   Now Reader's Digest has embarked on an ambitious program - one that faces many obstacles - to turn the ailing Source around.  The Source is a service that offers news, airline schedules, classified ads and other information that can be read on home computer screens. Reader's Digest thinks the Source's dismal performance can be cured with a dose of careful management and new money.

headline: BUSINESS STILL BACKS REAGAN BILL
abstract: President Reagan's economic plan appears to be holding its own in the business community, despite the unexpected allure of an acrossthe-board reduction in corporate income taxes proposed by the Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee.   Even efforts last week by the Democratic leadership, including Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski and Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., to persuade business to back their version of business tax relief do not appear to have won many converts. Big business has lined up solidly with the Reagan plan, which centers on depreciating plant and equipment.   Representatives of small business, though more interested in the new proposal, did not seem to be fighting for it although they said the plan would probably benefit them.

headline: SWISS REJECT PLAN TO ENHANCE FOREIGN WORKERS' STATUS
abstract: Swiss voters rejected by a ratio of 5 to 1 today a proposed constitutional amendment that would have removed virtually all constraints on foreign workers here.   A relatively heavy turnout of nearly 40 percent of the four million registered voters assured the measure's defeat in each of the 26 cantons that form the Swiss Confederation.   The amendment would have assured the foreign worker the right to remain in Switzerland even if no longer needed unless expelled by a court order after being found guilty of a crime.

headline: Your Money; REAGAN'S PLAN FOR BOAT FEES; Â¸
abstract: IF the Reagan Administration has its way, owners of yachts and lesser recreational boats will soon have to reach down into their oilskins and come up with annual fees set forth in a complicated schedule that could bring the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in years to come.   President Reagan proposed the levies, which are called users' fees, and said they would pay for part of the services of the Coast Guard, whose duties include looking after boaters. The proposal has met some heavy opposition.   Darrell Trent, Deputy Secretary of Transportation, told a House subcommittee hearing last month: ''The reasons for this policy are twofold, equity and efficiency. Those who obtain valuable services from the Government or use Government-funded facilities should pay for them. Those who do not should not be asked to share the cost.''

headline: LYON METAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Preservation Of Capital
abstract: STOCK prices have been soaring for some time now and, as often happens in bull markets, Wall Street is beginning to soft-pedal the idea of preservation of capital to worship at the altar of performance.   This state of affairs is reminiscent of the frothy days of the late 1960's leading up to the debacle of the early 1970's when the stock market experienced its worst setback since the crash.   Investors would do well to reaffirm the twin goals of money management: preserve purchasing power, that is, seek gains equal to or in excess of inflation, but not if safety of principal must be sacrificed.   A money management firm in Boston called Atlantic Financial Management feels so strongly about the capital preservation aspect of the equation that the company's assets have twice been withdrawn from the market completely and placed in money market instruments to ride out an anticipated storm.

headline: THE 'CHUNNELERS' ARE PUSHING A EUROPE LINK- AGAIN
abstract: LONDON EVER since Napoleon in 1802 proposed a tunnel under the English Channel for military reasons, politicians and engineers on both sides of the water have refused to let the idea die. This year the planners are dreaming again.   Previous schemes have suffered false starts, delays and frustrations culminating in 1974, when the Labor Government then in power canceled the project for financial reasons. More than 300 yards of a double-bore tunnel had already been dug.   In 1978, William Rodgers, who was British Transport Minister, met his French counterpart, Joel le Theule, in Paris and reopened discussions on a fixed link - a term that covers the options of a bridge or tunnel.

headline: G.M. PRICES ITS 'J' CARS TO COMPETE WITH JAPAN
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced prices today of $6,966 to $8,452 for the new subcompact ''J'' cars that the auto manufacturer hopes will challenge Japanese imports.   In that range, the new subcompacts - Chevrolet Cavalier and the Pontiac J2000 - are priced just below comparably equipped models of G.M.'s larger ''X'' cars, although a stripped-down ''X'' car would cost less than the new ''J'' cars.   Cavalier and J2000, which go on sale next Thursday, represent a new market strategy for General Motors. Instead of offering a stripped-down base model and allowing customers to add options, G.M.  is providing all the ''J'' cars with relatively high equipment and trim levels - similar to the Japanese subcompacts against which they will compete.

headline: Sugar Price Rises Spur Meeting
abstract: The executive committee of the International Sugar Organization held a short emergency meeting today to consider rising world sugar prices, but it deferred major decisions until June 23.   Rising prices could result in producers placing another one million metric tons of sugar on the world's free market within the next 14 days.

headline: FRENCH SOCIALIST, ON BONN VISIT, SAYS MOSCOW MUST TRIM ARSENAL
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France, making his first foreign trip on behalf of President Francois Mitterrand's new Government, met with West German leaders today and said the Soviet Union must reduce its arsenal of middle-range nuclear missiles aimed at Western Europe.   Referring to the buildup of Soviet SS-20 missiles, Mr. Cheysson said it was ''necessary to reduce this very distressing development.''   That statement, coming from a representitive of the new Socialist leadership in France, seemed certain to please the Government here as well as the Reagan Administration. Mr. Cheysson will visit Washington on Thursday.

headline: Soviet Sharply Cuts Back On Exit Visas for Jews
abstract: The number of exit visas granted to Jews seeking to emigrate from the Soviet Union fell by nearly 50 percent in March after a sudden surge in February, figures obtained today show.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The State Department announced today that the United States and Pakistan had agreed on a $3 billion military and economic aid program to strengthen Pakistani defenses against a ''serious threat'' from Soviet troops in Afghanistan.   The agreement calls for the rapid restoration of United States military aid, including the sale of F-16 aircraft. American aid has been suspended since April 1979, when the Carter Administration, seeking to curb the spread of nuclear arms, halted assistance because Pakistan refused to submit its nuclear development program to international inspection.   The Reagan Administration, aware of Pakistan's concerns about the 85,000 Soviet troops in neighboring Afghanistan, has argued that resumption of American assistance is the best way to restrain the Pakistani move toward nuclear arms.

headline: Conoco-Mitsubishi
abstract: The Conoco Corporation's Conoco Chemicals Company said it had signed a letter of intent to form a joint venture with Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company to sell and manufacture cresylic acids in the Far East.

headline: ROTHMANS OF PALL MALL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Gerber's Net Up by 18.5%
abstract: Gerber Products, the world's largest producer of baby foods, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter ended March 31 rose 18.5 percent, to $10.9 million, or $1.22 a share, from $9.2 million, or $1.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales slipped two-tenths of 1 percent, to $172.4 million, from $172.8 million.

headline: Business People; COLUSSY IS FORMING A REGIONAL AIRLINE
abstract: Dan A. Colussy, the 50-year-old former president of Pan American World Airways, who left the giant international air carrier last November because he wanted to become chief of an airline, intends to do so with a small regional airline, Columbia Air, that he is now forming.   Mr. Colussy, who filed his intentions with the Civil Aeronautics Board on Monday, is chairman of Columbia Air, which will be based at the Baltimore-Washington International Airport. David Hall, 38, who spent 13 years at Pan Am and rose to vice president, planning and scheduling, before leaving in January, is president.

headline: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Taiwanese Donate to Buy Tanks
abstract: Taiwan will buy 14 tanks abroad with public donations, the Defense Ministry said today. A spokesman, Col. Wang Miao, said donations for the ''tank squadron'' from the public in the past six months amounted to $2.6 million.

headline: Peugeot-Honda Pact Expected
abstract: Cycles Peugeot, part of the Peugeot Auto Group, is expected to announce tomorrow an accord with Japan's Honda Motor Company to produce motorcycle engines in France under license, industry sources said today.   A Peugeot spokesman said that Cycles Peugeot would announce an outline agreement with ''a foreign manufacturer'' but declined to give details.

headline: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan Given Ovation On Returning to Offices
abstract: President Reagan returned to his White House offices today for the first time since he was shot on March 30, and he received a standing ovation from his Cabinet members.   ''I should be applauding you,'' the President said in the Cabinet Room.

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. AND I.B.M. IN TALKS TO END LONG ANTITRUST SUIT
abstract: The Reagan Administration and the International Business Machines Corporation have begun talks that could lead to reduced charges in the Government's 12-year-old antitrust suit against the computer giant.   Judge David N. Edelstein of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, who conducted a six-year nonjury trial of the case that rested June 1, disclosed yesterday that the two sides were talking of ways to narrow the case and possibly to settle it. It was the first time an official for the Justice Department was acknowledged to be discussing a compromise with lawyers from I.B.M.   No details were available yesterday on the scope and timing of a possible compromise. However, William F. Baxter, an Assistant Attorney General, and Thomas Barr, lead attorney for I.B.M., are to discuss ways in which charges in the suit could be reduced before Judge Edelstein on June 18.

headline: UNICORP FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Quick Adds Kelly
abstract: Quick & Reilly Inc., the second-largest firm in the discount brokerage business, said it had acquired Kelly Associates, a discount broker in Texas, for about $3 million.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN GOLD BOOM HAS DIVERSE IMPLICATIONS
abstract: After a year in which it earned its most spectacular profits, South Africa's gold mining industry has reclaimed a position of dominance in the nation's economy and embarked on a multibillion dollar expansion program.   Even though the price of gold has eased in recent months - it closed in London Friday at $461.50 an ounce, compared with an average of $614 in 1980 - new investment in the South African industry, the world's leading gold producer, still seems likely to approach $1.5 billion this year. That would be roughly double what it was two years ago.   The expansion is due to continue at that rate for the next five years at least, even if no additional projects are undertaken. In prospect are the sinking of new shafts and the deepening of existing mines that are already the deepest in the world, reaching down in some cases more than two miles.

headline: Algeria Foreign Minister Suffers Injuries in a Plane Crash in Mali
abstract: Foreign Minister Mohammed Ben Yahia of Algeria, a key figure in winning the release by Iran of the 52 United States hostages, suffered multiple fractures in a plane crash near here today.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The New York City Fire Department to Smith/Greenland as its volunteer agency.

headline: Ponderosa Parts From Ad Agency
abstract: Doyle Dane Bernbach, which just said goodbye to American Airlines and hello to Pan Am, is next going to bid farewell to the Ponderosa System, the Dayton, Ohio, chain of steak restaurants with a current ad budget of $14.1 million.

headline: 'Ambitious' Campaign Set For Gordon's Dry Gin
abstract: In an effort to get a bigger piece of the imported gin market, Renfield Importers is about to run what it describes as ''one of the most exciting and ambitious advertising campaigns ever embarked upon by a manufacturer of spirits'' for its Gordon's Dry Gin. Grey Advertising is the font of the excitement.

headline: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GERMANY'S ECONOMY STUMBLES
abstract: West Germany, ''the engine of Europe,'' is in the midst of recession, and its entrenched economic problems have raised nagging questions about whether the country will ever regain its role as Western Europe's financial leader.   Few bankers or economists doubt that there will be a rebound in German business activity in the first half of 1982. But they say there are indications that the nation's business foundations have been severely damaged, bringing a sense of fragility to Germany's image as a resourceful, resilient economic power.   The country's current economic problems are the result, at least in part, of higher oil prices. But there are other, more troubling, aspects that portend longer-term ills. They include declining exports, fewer technological advances, higher labor costs, a lack of skilled workers and increased investment abroad rather than at home.

headline: How Mitterrand Sees The Issues
abstract: Francois Mitterrand's campaign program is a milder version of a more radical Socialist program approved by the party two years ago. During the campaign, Mr. Mitterrand was attacked by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on some of the points in the original program. Mr. Mitterrand says that he is committed only to his campaign platform.   FOREIGN AFFAIRS - He supports the Atlantic alliance and has criticized Mr. Giscard d'Estaing for being too easy on the Soviet Union. He has called for a re-examination of the ways the alliance handles its consultations and differences with the United States. He expresses more sympathy for Israel and more support of the Camp David accords than his predecessor. He opposes the sale of French uranium to Iraq. He is critical of the evolving United States policy toward the third world.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Ladies' Home Journal to Grey Direct for subscription acquistion.

headline: QUEBEC NATIONALISTS UNEXPECTEDLY SEEM TO BE LEADING IN PROVINCIAL RACE
abstract: Parti Quebecois, fighting to hold power despite the defeat in a referendum last year of its goal of independence, showed a surprising lead over the weekend in two polls.  And from the underdog position it has generally been thought to occupy, it has now suddenly begun to look like a possible winner in the provincial election April 13.   But in the district of Mercier, a densely populated, lower-middle-class area of eastern Montreal, the Parti Quebecois candidate says he is "a little worried." Gerald Godin, appointed Minister of Immigration five months ago, has the same problem that other candidates of the party in the Montreal region must contend with - a large proportion of immigrants who tend to side with the native English-speaking minority against the French-speaking majority.

headline: COURT BACKS PENSION DEDUCTION
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law allowed private pension plans to reduce a member's pension benefits by the amount of any compensation award received for a jobrelated disability.   The 8-to-0 opinion was a setback for retired workers. It affirmed a decision by a Federal appeals court that rejected challenges to two private pension plans by employees whose workmen's compensation awards were deducted from their pensions under the terms of the pension plans of the General Motors Corporation and Raybestos-Manhattan Inc.   Regulations issued by the Treasury Department provide that such ''offsets'' are permitted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which covered both pension plans. However, a New Jersey state law, enacted in 1977, prohibits the offsets. The plaintiffs worked at New Jersey plants of the two companies.

headline: NCNBProposes Merger
abstract: The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., a bank holding company whose principal subsidiary is the North Carolina National Bank, said that it had proposed a merger with Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., Florida's fourth-largest bank holding company, in a stock transaction worth $210 million.   Under the proposal, NCNB said, Florida National shareholders would receive voting convertible preferred stock of NCNB Corporation with a liquidating value of $28 a share in exchange for each share of Flordia National's common stock.   The conversion price and the dividend rate for the convertible preferred will be established before the effective date of the merger to create a security that will trade at market value on a fully distributed basis of about $28 a share, NCNB said.

headline: Around the World; English-Language Paper To Start in Peking on June 1
abstract: The China Daily, an English-language paper, will start publication here on June 1.

headline: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Affairs; TO AID SAVINGS, KEEP THE TAX LAW SIMPLE
abstract: HERBERT HOOVER allegedly promised ''a chicken in every pot.'' According to William Safire of The New York Times, the promise came from King Henry IV of France. In that it was the 16th century, the chicken was promised only on Sundays.   Whatever the century, the promise epitomizes the desire for a high consumption economy. But currently, the emphasis has shifted away from consumption and toward savings and investment. The nation is now more interested in producing chicken coops than in producing chickens.

headline: Patents; Diagnostic Device For Motor Vehicles
abstract: A diagnostic and monitoring device for motor vehicles, with a memory for any faults, has been invented for the General Motors Corporation. The equipment is in 1981 G.M. gasoline vehicles.

headline: Polish Cardinal Has a Relapse
abstract: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the ailing Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has taken a turn for the worse, the press agency P.A.P. said today. Quoting a church communique, the agency said that he was in ''very serious'' condition and that his health had deteriorated since the last official statement, on May 14.  Earlier this week, church sources reported an improvement in his condition.

headline: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STORMY LABOR SCENE LAYS WASTE BERMUDA'S SEASON
abstract: At the Southampton Princess Hotel, the flowers have been taken off the tables, the candles put away, the tablecloths folded and placed in storage. The disco is dark and silent, the swimming pool and tennis courts empty. The $220-a-day rooms with their views of turquoise ocean and pink sands hold no tourists nursing rum punches and sunburns. The carpeted corridors of Bermuda's largest hotel, which had expected to be filled with 1,200 visitors by now, are ghostly and deserted.   But in the streets outside the post office, in front of the hospital, at the airport and elsewhere, striking workers move silently in picket lines under the watchful eyes of the police. ''No law is going to make economic slaves out of us,'' proclaimed a sign carried by a striking telephone company worker. ''If a man has to work three jobs just to survive, he's a slave,'' said the man grimly.    The strike, which Bermuda's Prime Minister, David Gibbons, has denounced as ''illegal, irresponsible and reprehensible,'' began more than three weeks ago when several groups of government employees were unable to reach agreement with the Government on a wage increase.

headline: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; CHEAPER SPACE ORBIT LAUNCHINGS
abstract: WASHINGTON AEROSPACE technologists at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., have devised a new launching system for orbiting vehicles that is described as much less costly than the method used to launch the space shuttle. Patent 4,265,416, assigned to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was granted this week to Liam R. Jackson, John P.  Weidner, William J. Small and James A. Martin.

headline: SENATE PANEL BACKS 3-TAX RELIEF MOVES
abstract: Without a single dissenting vote, the Senate Finance Committee today approved three major provisions of a taxrelief bill, including a cut to 50 percent from 70 percent in the maximum tax rate individuals pay on investment income.   Driving hard toward the complete drafting of a tax bill this week, ahead of the House Ways and Means Committee, the Senators also voted for a major easing of inheritance taxes and for the creation of a new tax-exempt savings certificate that banks and thrift institutions would be allowed to sell for one year.   The committee's Republican chairman, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, called   The Senate, responding to criticism that its budget bill contained extraneous legislation, deleted dozens of measures from the package of $39.6 billion in cuts. Page A17. the inheritance tax provision a step toward complete repeal, perhaps within two years. ''We'd like to repeal it,'' he said, noting that President Reagan had long been on record as favoring repeal of the inheritance tax.

headline: NICARAGUA AND HONDURAS CLOSE BORDER AFTER CLASHES
abstract: Honduras and Nicaragua have closed their common border and sent troop reinforcements to the area after a number of minor clashes that the Managua Government says have been provoked by Nicaraguan exiles operating from inside Honduran territory. But after an exchange of gunfire across the border last night, Honduran and Nicaraguan military commanders reportedly met today in the hope of reducing tensions and reopening the frontier.   The two Governments have nevertheless charged each other with creating a climate of war by sending thousands of troops to the mountainous border regions.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Alcoa Aluminio S.A. said it would add a $16 million power production plant to its integrated aluminum complex in Brazil.   * Bank of America has been authorized by Pemex, Mexico's stateowned petroleum agency, to renew and raise a revolving credit facility to $3.5 billion from $2.5 billion.   * Centex Corp. said its two primary general construction subsidiaries, J. W. Bateson Co. and Frank J. Rooney Inc., had received two new contracts worth approximately $170 million.

headline: WELFARE
abstract: To the Business Editor: I was disappointed in Rudolph Penner's "How Fair is Welfare?" (March 29). The issues are not "how much?" or "for whom?" The issue is what are we expecting this system to accomplish.

headline: New Roles at Time
abstract: Kelso Sutton, the new group vice president for magazines at Time Inc., has created a Financial and Development Group to handle various functions of the magazine division that had been taken care of by the corporate comptroller's department. And he has put Lawrence M.  Crutcher, 38-year-old corporate circulation director in charge, with the title vice president-magazines, replacing him with S.  Christo@pher Meigher 3d, 34, who was president of Time Distribution Services. Stepping into that vacancy will be Donald M. El@liman Jr., 36, who was circulation director of Time International.

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The way was paved for passage of the President's budget cuts.  Handing President Reagan a stunning victory, a coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats foiled the attempt by the House Democratic leadership to split into six separate votes the President's request for $5.2 billion in additional budget cuts.  Instead, the House will vote on the cuts as a package, thus increasing the likelihood they will not be changed. (Page A1.)   The Administration's tax-cut proposals also advanced in Congress.  The Senate Finance Committee approved a tax relief bill for individuals and business faithful to the Administration principles.  It is expected to win on the Republican-controlled Senate floor without major changes. (D1.)

headline: TRANS-CANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Doctors Say Pope Improves And Seems Less Fatigued
abstract: Doctors treating Pope John Paul II said today that his condition had clearly improved further and that he appeared less fatigued.

headline: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DENTALLOY INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPECTRA-PHYSICS HITS A SNAG IN PROFITS FROM LASER SYSTEMS
abstract: During the 1960's, few technological advances captured the imagination like the laser beam. Here was a device that would send messages into space, pierce diamonds, and - one might have thought - strongly affect American industry.   Yet the promise was greater than the reality - at least initially.  ''We suffered from overblown expectations,'' recalled Herbert M.  Dwight Jr., the chairman of Spectra-Physics Inc., the company that produced the first commercial laser in 1962. ''This is a technology with great potential, but it has not created overnight revolutions.''

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Britain is striving with reduced resources both to widen its military responsibilities to include a naval presence in the Persian Gulf area and to reshape nuclear and conventional forces to meet what is officially called ''a new sense of risk.''   A military white paper outlining objectives for 1981 forecasts a shift to spending for new weapons and away from the large amounts now tied up in maintaining old ships, aircraft, army vehicles and weapons.   The military budget for 1981-82 is set at about $26.8 billion at present prices, compared with about $23 billion last year. Of the new total, 44 percent will be spent on equipment. The Ministry of Defense says these figures strike a balance between the high priority that the Government gives to military spending and the need to restrict public expenditure in a struggling economy.

headline: Big Bank Plans Variable Rate Note
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the holding company for New York's third-largest bank of the same name, announced yesterday plans to issue $100 million of variable rate notes with a minimum denomination of $1,000 that makes the issue affordable for small, individual investors.   ''The issue was designed to be competitive with money market mutual funds,'' a spokesman for the holding company said.

headline: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BROCK TO VISIT JAPAN FOR AUTO TALKS
abstract: The Foreign Ministry, in a surprise announcement, said today that Bill Brock, the chief United States trade negotiator, would visit Japan later this week to discuss limiting Japanese auto exports to America.   The announcement that Mr. Brock would arrive in Tokyo on Wednesday came as Naohiro Amaya, a top official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, left for Washington to discuss the auto issue with United States officials.   Washington and Tokyo are trying to reach agreement on limiting Japanese auto shipments to the United States before talks between President Reagan and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki in Washington on May 7-8.   Meanwhile, Prime Minister Suzuki is to meet tomorrow with Trade Minister Rokusuke Tanaka, Japanese Ambassador to Washington Yoshio Okawara, Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito and other ministers here to consider the results of Mr. Tanaka's discussions with the Japanese auto industry's top executives Saturday on restraint of shipments to the United States.

headline: VALIDITY OF MARCOS'S '73 CONSTITUTION IS CHALLENGED
abstract: The validity of the 1973 Philippine Constitution under which the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ruled was challenged today by 130 of the 311 members of the body that drafted it.   The challenge came a week before the nation is to hold a national plebiscite on proposed amendments that would provide for a strong president with a six-year term and no bar against re-election. Mr.  Marcos has announced that he intends to end his transitional status as President-Prime Minister and run for the new post of chief of state.   Former President Diosdado Macapagal, an opponent of Mr. Marcos and chairman of the convention that drafted the 1973 charter, said in a telephone interview that the body had ''resumed'' its sessions and adopted a declaration that the Constitution had been improperly ratified and therefore had no legal force.

headline: LEBANON FEARS ARAB-ISRAELI WAR FOUGHT ON ITS LAND
abstract: This once rich little country, ripped apart by a half dozen years of violence, again stands at the brink of war.   Its seemingly ceaseless internal troubles, worsened by international meddling, have festered and become an international crisis with Israel and Syria rattling fighter planes and missiles at each other in possibly the most dangerous situation in the Middle East since the 1973 Arab-Israeli war.   Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, is rushing from capital to capital hoping to talk the principals out of their belligerent stances.   As Mr. Habib met with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria yesterday, Syria's Soviet-built MIG fighters flew low over Damascus in a show of strength. Israel's American-built Phantom jets flew low over Beirut at about the same time, rattling windows with their sonic booms, as they do when they want to make sure their presence is felt.

headline: Conference Services Names President
abstract: Thomas A. Silvestri, 40 years old, has been named president of Harrison Conference Services, which, through a subsidiary, owns or manages eight conference and corporate education centers. He succeeds Walter A. Green, 41, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, which is based in Glen Cove, L.I.   ''I'll be focusing on the expansion of our existing properties and seeking out a new conference center within 45 minutes of the New York area,'' said Mr. Silvestri in a telephone interview.

headline: JOINED THE TOKYO BUREAU IN 1930
abstract: The New York Times honored Junnosuke Ofusa here today for 50 years of service to the newspaper.  A.M. Rosenthal, the executive editor of The Times, and his wife, Ann, were the hosts at a reception at the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan for Mr. Ofusa. The reception was attended by 150 guests, including Ambassador Mike Mansfield.

headline: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Baker Mining Equipment Co., a unit of Baker International Corp., agreed to acquire all of the outstanding stock of Coppinger Machinery Service, in return for an undisclosed number of shares of Baker Mining common stock.   * Baldwin-United Corp. said that the waiting period under a Federal antitrust act had expired with respect to the proposed acquisition by Baldwin-United of the Sperry Hutchinson Co.   * Bristol Brass Co. said it was increasing its strip prices by 4 cents to 6 cents a pound to reflect increased fabricating costs.

headline: Economic Scene; Discord Stirs With Allies
abstract: A STORM is brewing between the incoming Reagan administration and European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over military spending. President-elect Ronald Reagan, stressing the need to counter the Soviet military buildup, has made proposals that would increase military expenditures by an estimated 7 to 9 percent a year in real terms - that is, after allowing for inflation. This represents a sizable increase over President Carter's proposed real increase of 4 1/2 to 5 percent.   Senator John G. Tower, who will become chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has been working with the Reagan transition team to draft a supplemental military budget. The Texas Republican declared this week: ''I don't think we put balancing the budget as the No. 1 priority. We put national security as our No. 1 priority.''

headline: PETRO-CANADA SET TO DRILL 3 WELLS
abstract: Petro-Canada, the federally owned oil company, said it will lead a consortium of eight companies to drill at least three wells off Labrador this year.

headline: BUSINESS TAX ACCORD IS REPORTED
abstract: The Reagan Administration and business representatives were reported today to have worked out a compromise on a sharply criticized element of the Administration's revised tax package dealing with depreciation.   Administration officials said that the compromise on a formula for accelerated depreciation was likely to be announced tomorrow, one day before committees in both the House of Representatives and Senate are scheduled to start drafting their respective bills.   However, aides to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said it was uncertain whether the panel would start ''marking up,'' the process of drafting a bill, on Wednesday. 'Discussion' in Senate   The Senate Finance Committee, evidently to discourage delay in the House, scheduled a ''discussion'' of the tax bill for Wednesday with Treasury officials. The term ''discussion'' meant that no votes would occur, but it was plain that the Senate committee, under a Republican chairman, Bob Dole of Kansas, would be starting its consideration of a tax bill.

headline: K.G.B. BLOCKS EVENT MARKING HOLOCAUST
abstract: The K.G.B. security police have intervened to prevent several hundred Soviet Jews from commemorating the Holocaust today with a traditional gathering in the woods near Moscow, according to organizers of the outing.   The K.G.B., these sources said, has been calling in participants of the project and threatening them with 15 days in jail, irrevocable rejection of applications to emigrate and other penalties if they tried to hold the outdoor meeting as scheduled.   Until a few days ago, the sentiment among most Jewish activists was to go through with their plans.  But a number of activists who scouted the site - a stretch of woods beside the railroad station of Ovrazhki, 25 miles east of Moscow - found it ringed by policemen and K.G.B. agents who said the woods were closed to the public. Asked why, the officers were reported to have said that the area was undergoing ''sanitary cleaning.'' It was reported that a notice to that effect had been hung up in the local suburban train station.

headline: U.S. STEEL TO BUILD SEAMLESS TUBE MILL
abstract: David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, is expected to announce today that the company has decided to build a new seamless tubing mill to supply the boom in oil drilling that began several years ago, according to company sources.   Industry sources said that oil companies would help finance the project and that under the plan the plant would be built by U.S.  Steel and then, in effect, leased to the oil companies.   The site of the new mill, company sources said, will probably be its plant in Fairfield, Ala., which has modern steel-making facilities but lacks modern finishing mills. Company sources said that other sites were still under consideration, however.

headline: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 30 Said to Die as Argentine Plane Crashes Into the Rio de la Plata
abstract: An Argentine jetliner crashed into the Rio de la Plata today after two unsuccessful attempts to land in a thunderstorm. Airline officials said all 30 people aboard were apparently killed.   The wreckage of the Austral Airlines jet was found by Argentine Coast Guard patrol boats and helicopters about 25 miles from the Buenos Aires Metropolitan Airport, where it had been scheduled to land.

headline: Deere's Net Drops 2.4% in Quarter
abstract: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment and a major manufacturer of construction machinery, said yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 slipped 2.4 percent as sales fell 4.5 percent.   ''Operating results for the second quarter were affected adversely by lower physical volumes, particularly of industrial equipment,'' said William A. Hewitt, Deere's chairman.

headline: Caller Says He Shot German Aide
abstract: An anonymous telephone caller, saying that he represented the extreme left-wing Red Army Faction, asserted today that he was responsible for the shooting last week of a West German official. A Justice Ministry official quoted the caller as saying that the Red Army Faction would follow up the murder of Heinz Karry, economics minister in Hesse state, with bomb attacks on airports in Frankfurt and London.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The Soviet military is believed to be concerned about Poland's increasing independence because of the country's central importance to overall Soviet strategy in Europe, according to Western military analysts. The analysts believe that Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces and the former Soviet chief of staff, supported by leaders of the navy and air force, has been leading the campaign to persuade Leonid I. Brezhnev, the party leader and President, to intervene in Poland.   Much has been made of Poland's geographical importance to the Warsaw Pact during a war. The railroads that traverse Poland from east to west and its highways would be vital to resupply and reinforcement of Soviet forces fighting in Germany.

headline: Tax Relief Asked For Work Abroad
abstract: Reagan Administration officials called today for more tax relief for Americans working abroad, but warned that exempting all taxes would give a windfall to motionpicture actors, authors and people living in tax-haven countries.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige; the special trade representative, Bill Brock, and John Chapoton, Assistant Treasury Secretary, said at a Senate finance subcommittee hearing on bills to liberalize tax policy for Americans living overseas that the Administration would not recommend specific legislation until Congress finished work on the Reagan economic package.   They said, however, that a 1978 law liberalizing expatriate taxes had not worked, and that a greater tax break was needed to encourage workers to accept jobs overseas and to spur American exports.

headline: Gavin Is Received in Mexico
abstract: John Gavin presented his credentials today as the new American Ambassador to Mexico to President Jose Lopez Portillo, who is flying to Washington this weekend for talks with President Reagan. The appointment of the 50-year-old actor was not well received in Mexico, where he had gained fame for television spots advertising rum. But Mr. Gavin speaks excellent Spanish and appears to have convinced skeptics in the American business community that he knows Mexico as well as most of them.

headline: G.& W. Lifts Stake In General Tire
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now owns 4.52 million shares, or 18.8 percent, of the common stock of the General Tire and Rubber Company.   The total amount owned includes 583,400 shares purchased on the open market between May 29 and June 5, for approximately $16.1 million, the diversified manufacturing concern said.

headline: HALSTON'S HARD SELL FOR 'PRESTIGE' ACCOUNT
abstract: ''I wanted to formulate a fragrance never experienced before - a totally original fragrance.'' On that note, ''Halston Night,'' a ''strong, direct, alluring'' and, at $125-an-ounce, decidedly expensive perfume, was introduced last month by Halston, the designer, with a little help from his friends: Norton Simon Inc., the conglomerate that acquired his fashion business in 1973; International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., the New York laboratory that formulates scents for some of the most glamorous - and unglamorous - products in the world, and a host of experts in public relations, advertising and other areas involved in the selling of scent.   For the manufacturers of best-selling perfumes, colognes and toilet waters, or what are known in the cosmetics business as straight juice, life can be sweet. Last year, according to William Fitzgerald, an economist specializing in consumer spending, retail sales of fragrances for women totaled $1.6 billion, nearly half from ''prestige'' fragrances sold through department and specialty stores.

headline: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 300 SALVADOR REBELS FAIL IN ATTACK
abstract: Three hundred guerrillas backed by light artillery, bazookas and grenade launchers were repulsed yesterday in one of their largest attacks in the last month, a military commander said today.   There was speculation that the attack might signal the start of the guerrillas' rainy season offensive.

headline: Around the World; Bush, Arriving in Manila, Lauds Filipinos for Support
abstract: Vice President George Bush arrived in Manila today for the inauguration tomorrow of President Ferdinand E.  Marcos, saying the United States would never forget the Philippines for its support.   Opposition leaders, who had boycotted the June 16 election that gave Mr. Marcos a new six-year term, said they disapproved of Mr.  Bush's presence. He was greeted by Imelda R. Marcos, wife of the President, and Foreign Minister Carlos P. Romulo, and was accorded full honors.

headline: G.M. PROFIT UP BY 23% IN QUARTER
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today reported a marginal first-quarter profit of $190.3 million, or 63 cents a share, which the nation's largest auto manufacturer attributed to costcutting rather than any improvement in car and truck sales.   The net income for the quarter was up 23 percent from the $154.7 million, or 52 cents a share, earned in the first quarter of 1980.  Sales totaled $15.72 billion, virtually the same as the $15.71 billion reported in the same period last year.   Sales of cars and trucks in the period declined to 1.69 million units worldwide from 2.03 million, despite a rebate program in the United States that the company said improved auto sales in the final weeks of the quarter.

headline: Company News; DAYTON HUDSON TO OPEN 107 STORES
abstract: Washington, May 1 (AP) - The Federal Trade Commission ordered Montgomery Ward & Company to offer warranty information to its store customer in binders "in a prominent location," a ruling that lessened the impact of a previous F.T.C. decision about keeping buyers informed.  The company said the latest ruling was still unacceptable, and that it would contest it. The case is the first to receive a final F.T.C. decision under its pre-sale warranty regulation, which says all warranties offered on products costing more than $15 must be available to customers before their purchase.

headline: Filipino Priest Slain in Monastery
abstract: Five heavily armed men forced their way into a monastery in the southern Philippines last night and shot and killed a Roman Catholic priest known as a critic of the local military, the authorities said today. The priest,the Rev. Godofredo Alingal, a Jesuit, was a witness last year in a rape case involving the military and was a critic of Government irregularities.

headline: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Yugoslav School Officials Dismissed Over Riots
abstract: Authorities in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province have dismissed the managers of a number of student centers in the capital of Pristina where students and professors were involved in riots last month, officials said today.

headline: Straddle Trade Ban Is Backed
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it favored changing tax law to eliminate benefits from the use of such tax-avoidance schemes as straddle transactions in commodities futures trading.   Taxpayers are currently engaged in a broad variety of transactions whose principal purpose is tax avoidance, involving commodities (such as silver, soybeans and Treasury bills) and futures contracts for commodities, John E. Chapoton, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, told the House Ways and Means Committee.

headline: BANKERS DIVIDED OF IMPACT OF LIFTING RATE CEILING
abstract: Most thrift industry officials said yesterday that they were displeased by the decision of Federal regulators to abolish the ceilings on interest rates they may pay on some deposits, but commercial bankers described the move as ''a step in the right direction.''   The lifting of the interest-rate ceilings, effective Aug. 1, is expected to increase the costs of money for depository institutions, although it is also expected to help them attract, or at least retain, deposits. Many savings institutions have been experiencing net operating losses because the cost of their deposits has been rising more rapidly than the yield on their loans, mainly mortgages.   No one, however, including the Government officials responsible for making the changes, was able to predict with any precision what impact Thursday's decision might have on consumers or on banks and savings institutions. Much will depend on how the regulatory details will be formulated, bankers said.

headline: CHRYSLER FINANCIAL IN CREDIT AGREEMENT
abstract: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, the credit unit of the ailing Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday that it had entered into agreements with the American Motors Financial Corporation and VW Credit Inc., a division of Volkswagen of America, to provide these companies with a broad range of services related to automotive financing.   The agreement gives Americn Motors and Volkswagen something they have wanted for a long time -their own financing subsidiaries to provide credit for car and truck purchases by dealers and consumers.

headline: TIRELESS TROUBLE-SHOOTER FOR THE U.S.
abstract: When Philip C. Habib was selected to try to head off an Israeli-Syrian clash over Syria's missiles in Lebanon, White House and State Department officials were attracted by his past record as a negotiator in one seemingly insoluble problem after another.   The 61-year-old Mr. Habib is described by his friends and colleagues as tireless in his pursuit of a solution. Moreover, they point out, he is also a Lebanese-American, with a heritage that has opened doors for him in the Middle East.   The special Middle East envoy, who began his mission for President Reagan on May 7 and was called home by the President today for consultations, was a career State Department officer whose previous diplomatic challenges included South Korea, Vietnam and Lebanon. At his retirement in 1978 because of a heart condition, Mr. Habib had risen to Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, the highest career position in the Foreign Service.

headline: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: East-West Trade Gets China Tabloid Account
abstract: East-West Trade Publications here in New York has been named to solicit advertising worldwide for International Trade News, a tabloid circulated only in China, according to Louis F. Sharpe, president of East-West Trade. He said the Chinese had ended a 20-year ban on advertising in the country's only official foreign trade newspaper.   According to Mr. Sharpe, the paper has 100,000 subscribers and an advertising page rate of $6,000.

headline: Buses Run Again in The Hague
abstract: Streetcars and buses resumed operation here today after a 21-day strike that left the city without any public transport, union officials said.

headline: Washington Watch; Looking Back At Kennedy Cut
abstract: WASHINGTON 'THE purpose of cutting taxes is not to create a deficit but to increase investment, employment and the prospects for a balanced budget.'' These are words, not of President Reagan, but of an earlier supply-sider, President Kennedy, drawn from his special message to Congress on Jan. 24, 1963 - which laid the foundation for the 1964 general tax cut and investment tax credit.   The Kennedy initiatives produced significant improvements in employment, output, wages, savings, investment and income. As Congress debates the Reagan economic recovery program, the Joint Economic Committee staff has compared predicted effects of the Reagan program with actual experience in the four years following the Kennedy cut.

headline: U.S., FACING QUANDARY, ISSUES LIMITED REBUKE
abstract: In his first policy reaction to Israel's raid on the Iraqi nuclear plant, President Reagan has chosen the cautious course of punishing Israel in a limited way that does not cause the Israelis to worry about his Administration's basic commitment to their security.   What high officials describe as Mr. Reagan's ''very measured response'' reflects Washington's basic political and diplomatic quandary - how to balance American understanding of Israel's anxiety about a potential nuclear threat with Washington's need to protect its own credibility and influence in the Middle East, as well as to control its own arms sales policies.   By suspending the scheduled shipment of four F-16 aircraft to Israel and reporting to Congress that the Israeli raid may have constituted ''substantial violation'' of the 1952 American-Israeli arms agreement, Mr. Reagan has put the Israelis on notice that they cannot expect a blank check when American interests in the region are so vividly at stake. Far Short of '75 Action   But by merely suspending this one arms shipment ''for the time being'' the President has stopped far short of the kind of arms embargo that was invoked by Congress against Turkey in 1975. And he has bought time for the harder question of whether the Administration will later contend that Israel did violate the law.

headline: NEW KODAK COLOR DARKROOM
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced a system that it said would make it easy for darkroom hobbyists to make color enlargements from either negatives or slides.   Company officials and analysts predicted that the system, which adapts instant camera technology to the darkroom, would have widespread appeal among amateur photographers, who have heretofore shied away from color developing because of the complexity involved.   ''This system will appeal to those who are more esthetically oriented than technology oriented,'' said John R. Robertson, vice president and general manager of Kodak's consumer markets division.

headline: Philbro-Cocoa Link
abstract: Phibro Corporation officials said the company was close to acquiring the Cocoa Merchants Group Ltd., a major London-based cocoa trading concern. The officials declined to specify the purchase price beyond saying it would be substantially more than $10 million.  Phibro formerly was the Philipp Brothers unit of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation.

headline: Explosion Kills 5 in South Africa
abstract: A cannister of acetylene gas exploded in a crowded shopping center in suburban Bloemfontein today, killing five people and injuring more than 30 others, the police reported, calling it an accident, not sabotage.

headline: RATES SOAR AS TRADERS SHIFT VIEW
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as traders in the credit markets realized that, contrary to their previous belief, the Federal Reserve did not encourage lower interest levels in March.   The catalyst that set interest rates climbing and bond prices falling resulted from the release Friday of the summary of monetary policy deliberations during February and March, except for the most recent meeting, on March 31. That summary said that the Fed had maintained, without change, its trading range of 15 to 20 percent for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market even though its actions in the last two months seemed to indicate that it was encouraging lower rates.   The stock market dropped broadly in response to the rising rates, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.87 points, to 994.24. (Page D8.)

headline: URUGUAY EDITOR IS TAKING LEAD AS ARMY CRITIC
abstract: "To avoid risk, most newspapers here do not say anything," an opposition spokesman remarked.   "Well," the spokesman, Enrique E. Tarigo, went on, speaking of his weekly newspaper, Opinar, "we tried to say something, then said a little bit more and a lttle bit more, until..."   His voice trailed off.  Mr. Tarigo, who is 53 years old, was recounting his experiences since he emerged as the most popular opposition leader during the constitutional plebiscite of last Nov.  30.  That vote overwhelmingly rejected a proposed charter that would have given the country's armed forces a permanent share of power.   "The plebiscite showed," he said in an interview, "that the majority of the people do not agree with the armed forces and their solutions.  You would think they would move faster now."

headline: Need to Pay Good Salaries Stressed by BBDO Chief
abstract: At the annual meeting of BBDO International yesterday, Bruce Crawford, the chief executive, had some interesting remarks on the need to pay good salaries to make good money.   ''I think it's fair to generalize that, the more limited the resources of an agency are,'' he said, ''the more compromises it must make in the people it hires.

headline: ON AUTONOMY, CATALANS FOLLOW THE QUITE PATH
abstract: For five years, the Catalans have been the well-behaved pupils in the sometimes unruly classroom of Spanish democracy.   Basque nationalists wrested their home-rule statute from Madrid against a backdrop of terrorism. Andalusians staged hunger strikes.  Even Canary Islanders dabbled in plots for independence.

headline: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Letters inflation; HOW DOES YOUR DOLLAR GROM?; IN DEFENSE OF HOUSING'S APPEAL
abstract: To the Business Editor: I was concerned to read ''Homes Losing Appeal'' (June 7), which stated that housing appears to be losing its appeal as a hedge against inflation.   The article is misleading because it only considers realized capital gains on housing.

headline: Technology; Robot's Future As a Servant
abstract: FOR those who can afford to spend several thousand dollars on a somewhat clumsy, dimwitted and near-useless servant, the age of the personal robot is at hand. Industrial robots, which cost from $5,000 to $200,000, are playing a vital role in automating factories, performing such tasks as welding and assembling. Experts envision that robots will eventually move from industry to the home, as the computer is doing.   An affordable robot that can do household chores is at least five and probably 20 years away. But a variety of entrepreneurs and tinkerers are already trying to get into the business and scores of hobbyists are experimenting with their own robots.

headline: Commonwealth Oil Files Plan to End Bankruptcy
abstract: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for more than three years, filed an ammended plan yesterday to bring it out of bankruptcy by the end of July.   The plan is subject to approval by Corco's unsecured creditors, the shareholders and the bankruptcy court.  Edward Doherty, executive vice president of Corco, said he had received no indication whether the Exxon Corporation or the Gulf Oil Company, the two largest unsecured creditors, would agree to the settlement.

headline: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OSR CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BEKINS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AUTO MAKERS VIEW U.S. PLAN AS MODEST
abstract: The Reagan Administration's plan to assist the automobile industry by easing or eliminating no fewer than 35 regulations is apparently being viewed within the industry as a rather modest effort.   ''On the whole, I am greatly encouraged,'' Betsy Ancker-Johnson, vice president for environmental activities at the General Motors Corporation, said. But, she continued, many of the proposals regarding environmental regulations call for futher study rather than action.

headline: Dulcolax Campaign Assigned to Grey
abstract: Dulcolax, a laxative available over the counter in this country for the last decade, is going to get its first consumer advertising - including network and spot television - from Grey Advertising, which just got the assignment. The billings could come to more than $2 million.

headline: Japanese Unconvinced After U.S. Auto Talks
abstract: A United States Government delegation concluded today a mission here to explain President Reagan's relief measures for the American auto industry. But the Japa@nese side remained unconvinced of the effectiveness of the United States program, Japanese officials reported.   Kiichi Miyazawa, Chief Cabinet Secretary and chief aide to Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, was quoted in a newspaper article as saying that the new American measures were a ''disappointment'' and ''not enough'' to persuade Japan to take voluntary action to curb auto exports to the United States.

headline: Foote, Cone & Belding Adding Corporate Unit
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding will join those agencies that have separate units to create corporate advertising. It's becoming quite a specialty and a growth area of advertising spending.

headline: KENYANS LOOK FOR ANSWERS AS THE ECONOMY GOES SOUR
abstract: In East Africa, perhaps in all black Africa except the Ivory Coast, the kindest words have always been reserved for Kenya. It worked, it was full of big game and fine lodges, and so it was fun to visit. It encouraged free enterprise, kept its human rights record fairly clean and, from the Western point of view, won high marks for shunning Soviet influence and retaining a devout commitment to capitalism.   None of this has changed. However, something has gone wrong in Kenya, and it seems to be on the mind of most of the people who live here. Tribalism has a lot to do with it, as well as mismanagement and poor development planning. The trouble has its roots in the presidency of Jomo Kenyatta, who led Kenya to independence in 1963 and who was President from 1964 until his death in 1978.   Mr. Kenyatta was a Kikuyu. The Kikuyu are the most populous of the 13 major tribes in Kenya. The one political party, the Kenya African National Union, over the years essentially became the Kikuyu party.  Although the Vice President was always a non-Kikuyu, it was no secret that the more powerful jobs and the better development projects went mostly to the Kikuyu during the Kenyatta days.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: APPAREL FIELD OFFERS CHALLENGES
abstract: AT least one-third of the apparel and textile companies in business today will fail or disappear through mergers within 10 years, according to Peter Dingeldey, a principal in Thorndike Deland Associates, a management recruiting firm based in New York.   Along with this trend for fewer and larger companies, there will be 250,000 fewer jobs, he estimated. Most job losses will occur at the production level and in administrative functions.   Obviously, a company merged into a larger concern can dispense with some redundant middle managers like treasurers, corporate secretaries and accountants, as well as with production workers displaced by more advanced machinery.

headline: Litton-A.T.&T.  Case Up to Jury
abstract: A $600 million antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company went to the jury yesterday after a five-month trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Litton Systems Inc.  accused A.T.&T. of forcing it out of the office telephone equipment business with monopolistic tactics.

headline: ACTING PRESIDENT IN DACCA PROMISES NEW ELECTIONS
abstract: Abdus Sattar, the acting President, today reiterated his caretaker Government's determination to hold a presidential election on schedule and ''to foil any conspiracy to disturb the democratic process in the country.''   His voice breaking with emotion during a news conference, the 75-year-old former Supreme Court justice also paid tribute to President Ziaur Rahman, who was slain by rebels on Saturday.   ''He was like my son,'' Mr. Sattar said, stopping after almost every word, and sometimes wiping away tears. ''I loved him too much.  I loved him because he was trying to build this small country in a better way.''

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: West Germany, for a decade considered the most powerful European member of NATO, is facing military problems ranging from the high costs of weapons and energy to the growing alienation of the young from the armed forces.   Many of the military problems are common to the Western alliance, but the hostility of the young to the defense concepts on which NATO is based and the inability of the armed forces to establish a role in a democratic society are peculiar to West Germany.   The urgency of the financial problem was emphasized by the recent disclosure that the army is short about a billion marks, approximately $460 million. Erwin Zorn, a member of Parliament in Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party, said that the Government might have to increase taxes to cover higher military costs.

headline: No Headline
abstract: President Reagan discussed African issues today with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa in a meeting described as ''friendly'' by a White House spokesman.   Mr. Botha's meeting with the President was announced late yesterday after talks between the South African and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. apparently made progress on a long-delayed plan to establish an independent nation of Namibia in the territory of South-West Africa, now administered by South Africa.   Mr. Reagan also received an invitation today from President Nicolae Ceaucescu of Rumania to make an official visit to his country . The invitation was delivered to the President during a 10-minute meeting with the Rumanian Foreign Minister, Stefan Andrei. Mr. Reagan told Mr. Andrei that he could not give an immediate answer but that he hoped ''very much'' that he could accept at a later date.

headline: A FOURTH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
abstract: Patrick O'Hara, the fourth of the Irish nationalist hunger strikers, died at the Maze Prison near here last night, after 61 days without food.   His death came less than 24 hours after that of Raymond McCreesh, the third man to die this month in a campaign to gain political prisoner status for imprisoned nationalists.   The British Government announced Mr. O'Hara's death in a terse statement early this morning: ''Patrick O'Hara, a prisoner in Her Majesty's prison Maze, died last night at 11:29. He took his own life by refusing food and medical intervention for 61 days.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Citing sizable increases in interest rates recently, two Federal agencies said today that they would raise the rates under their Government-insured mortgage programs to new high levels.   The Department of Housing and Urban Development's Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration simultaneously announced that they would raise their maximum rates on level mortgage payments for single-family homes one percentage point, to 15 1/2 percent.
