headline: Money Funds Rise By $938.8 Million
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market funds increased by $938.8 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   Though the rise is the 17th consecutive weekly advance, lifting total assets to $118.5 billion, it is a much smaller gain than the average in 1981.

headline: Austrians Report 80% of Those Who Now Seek Asylum Are Poles
abstract: Nearly 80 percent of the refugees seeking asylum in Austria come from Poland, Interior Ministry officials said today.

headline: CHINA'S AIM IN ASIA: TO 'CONTAIN' SOVIET
abstract: China's view of Southeast Asia is dominated by implacable hostility to Vietnam's conquest of Cambodia and a conviction that the event was part of a Soviet quest to encircle China and threaten the rest of the world.   A series of interviews and discussions with senior Chinese officials, professional analysts and responsible journalists in Peking and Shanghai disclosed an attitude that a ranking Southeast Asian diplomat in Peking described as ''a 1950 psychology'' similar to John Foster Dulles's belief that the whole world must unite to defeat a common foe, combined with a faith that ''right will win out'' even if the struggle takes a long time.   A senior Chinese Foreign Ministry official reinforced the comparison by reviving the notion of ''containment,'' a word that had much currency in Mr. Dulles's era. ''We think it is best now to contain the Soviet presence in Afghanistan and Cambodia and not allow it to advance further,'' he declared.

headline: Phillips Petroleum Buys Stake in Salk
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company said that it had purchased a $10 million equity interest in the Salk Institute Biotechnology Corporation, previously a wholly owned subsidiary of the Salk Institute, a private nonprofit biological research concern in La Jolla, Calif.

headline: Hidden Economy
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''No Cuts Here: The Life on the Tab'' (March 29), the claim by the restaurant industry that elimination of the expense account deduction would cause loss of jobs and closing of businesses is, in effect, a request for a Federal subsidy to support establishments that might not succeed on their own merits. While one can sympathize with their plight, it must not be forgotten that such high-priority causes as education, health and mass transportation are about to be cut back.   In the language of the Reagan Administration, there is no reason for the taxes of a citizen of Sioux Falls to be increased so that some businessmen can dine lavishly in New York.  MARVIN P. EPSTEIN    Montclair, N.J., March 29, 1981

headline: U.S. GETS SOUTH AFRICAN RESPONSE TO PLAN FOR NAMIBIA INDEPENDENCE
abstract: The United States and four Western countries today completed a new examination of ways to break the deadlock on talks on independence for South-West Africa.   American officials said South Africa had responded to proposals made to Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha last week by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. suggesting a new framework for the negotiations on South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.   Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, said that ''this is not the moment to make public'' either the content of the South African reply nor the discussions with representatives of Britain, France, West Germany and Canada during a two-day meeting here devoted to ''an extensive examination of ways to move the negotiating process forward.''

headline: Prompter Changes In Certificate Rates
abstract: Effective Tuesday, banks and savings institutions will change the rate they pay on new six-month money market savings certificates on Tuesdays instead of Thursdays. The maximum rate on the certificates will continue to be set one quarter of a percentage point above the average discount rate for six-month Treasury bills, which are sold every Monday.

headline: ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK CAN'T GO IT ALONE
abstract: During the three-day annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank, the Solomon Islands and the director general of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed an agreement for the partial financing of the islands' Lungga Hydropower Project by the OPEC Fund, a lending body for less-developed nations.   It was another example of what the Asian Development Bank calls ''co-financing.'' It will participate in the project, as will the Commonwealth Development Corporation, the Government of Australia, the European Investment Bank and others.   The A.D.B. is encouraging co-financing and welcoming joint venture projects as a way to meet regional demand for financial assistance, particularly in energy projects.

headline: Company News; RENAULT'S EUROPCAR MOVES INTO 3D PLACE AMONG CAR RENTERS
abstract: Europcar, a subsidiary of Renault, the French state-owned auto manufacturer, has emerged in the past nine years as the No.3 car rental company worldwide and No.1 in the fast-growing European market.   The company, the only major car rental concern owned by an auto maker, moved into the No.3 spot last month by acquiring Godfrey Davis, the largest British car rental concern with a fleet of 8,000 cars in 200 locations around Britain, many at airports.   Jean Ordner, Europcar's 55-year-old French president, is proud of his company's successful challenge to the American car rental giants, Hertz and Avis.   ''They were like Coke and Pepsi,'' he said. ''There was no No.3.  Now there is, and it's European.'' Michel Laporte, who studies the car rental business for the French Automobile Manufacturers Association, agrees that Europcar is ''providing a real challenge to Hertz and Avis.''

headline: Expense Accounts
abstract: To the Business Editor: The implication of ''No Cuts Here: The Life on the Tab'' (March 29) is that the expense account is a John Doe taxpayer ripoff. That's curious, because when I had responsibility for approving expense accounts I looked at them as related to the production of income ...  without which, needless to say, a corporation would pay no income taxes.   There's nothing complicated about the proposition that if a company wants a Middle East refinery construction contract it had better send people over there to get it, and should not expect them to swim or take a raft. I suggest that those billions of expense dollars deducted from corporate revenues were contributive to corporate profits.

headline: Marsh & McLennan
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc. said its C.T. Bowring & Company Ltd. subsidiary was seeking a purchaser for some of its shipping interests. A company spokesman would not disclose a target price or the number of vessels to be sold, but said they were all basically bulk carriers. He said Marsh's shipping business accounted for a relatively small percentage of the company's total business.

headline: Sperry-I.C.L. Steps In Venture Cited
abstract: J. Paul Lyet, chairman of the Sperry Corporation, said Sperry had been approached by International Computers Ltd. concerning a possible joint venture, but he said that Sperry had never planned to acquire a majority of I.C.L. Sperry would still be interested in such a deal if it could be resurrected, he added.   Mr. Lyet told a financial writers meeting that I.C.L., Britain's financially troubled computer maker, approached Sperry about two months ago with the joint venture proposal. Yesterday, I.C.L.  replaced its top management and said it was ending talks on joint ventures with foreign companies.

headline: Polish Accord Is Reached In One of Two Labor Cases
abstract: Union and Government negotiators reached an agreement today, forestalling a strike threatened for tomorrow in Bialystok.

headline: 2 BELGIUM STEEL CONCERNS IN MERGER
abstract: Shareholders of Belgium's two main steel concerns approved a merger involving large-scale Government aid in an attempt to stem crippling financial losses.

headline: CHEAP U.S. ALUMINUM HURTS JAPAN
abstract: By MIKE THARP   TOKYO, May 11 - Japanese aluminum refiners, already hurt by high energy costs and sluggish domestic demand, are complaining that cheaper American imports have also damaged their beleaguered industry.   ''In 1978 and 1979 we scrapped a half million tons of capacity and we are now operating (industry-wide) at 60 percent of the 1.1 million ton capacity,'' said Tatsuro Oya of the economic research department of Sumitomo Light Metal Industries. ''This was partly due to depressed demand but mainly due to the flood of imports.''   American producers sent their share of total Japanese aluminum imports to 36.5 percent last year, up from 15 percent in 1979 and only 5.8 percent of total imports by Japan in 1978. In the fiscal year that ended March 31, 1980, Japan imported about 300,000 tons of aluminum ingots and semifabricated products from the U.S., more than three times the volume of the previous year.

headline: AFRICAN POLICY: NEW DIRECTION
abstract: As the State Department tries to put together the jigsaw puzzle that would become a policy on southern Africa, the key officials see nothing but pieces that do not fit: South African politics and strength, the struggle for independence in South-West Africa, the civil war in Angola and American domestic politics.   The officials in charge of finding a new policy for the Reagan Administration say the Carter Administration's approach was not working, so they had to try a new one. The Carter policy was to threaten South Africa with sanctions so it would agree to relinquish its administration of South-West Africa, and then to try to persuade Angola to send home the 20,000 Cuban troops stationed there.   The Reagan approach, outlined in a memorandum that became public this week, essentially would reverse the steps in order to keep movement towards settlement on both issues in parallel. But officials know they are playing a long shot, because of deep-seated problems both here and in Africa.

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP BY 1.6%
abstract: Powered by strength in two basic industries, steel and autos, industrial production surged ahead by 1.6 percent in October, the largest one-month advance in two and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The October report of a ''broadly based'' expansion of factory, mine and utility output appears to support expectations that the economy will ring up in the fourth quarter a stronger advance than in the third, when business picked up by a bare 1 percent at annual rates. There was also good news in the figures for unemployment insurance, where initial claims have been declining.   Nevertheless, there were warnings from economists that the outlook was uncertain and that by early 1981 the recovery from the short 1980 business recession could be decidedly sluggish, as widely forecast.  Citing the upward thrust of interest rates since September, Otto Eckstein, president of Data Resources Inc., a Cambridge, Mass., economic consulting firm, said that the first or second quarter of 1981 ''could easily be a minus.''

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Products and Chemical Inc. filed with the S.E.C. $175 million principal amount of 7 percent debentures due 2011, to be sold through a Lehman Brothers group.   * Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Co., a unit of the American Electric Power Co., filed with the S.E.C. $110 million of first mortgage bonds and 600,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, to be sold through public bidding.

headline: Husky Ends Talks On Conoco Holdings
abstract: Husky Oil Ltd. said that its talks with Conoco Inc. on the possible purchase of Conoco's holdings of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company had ended without agreement.   Husky said in a statement that it ''notified Conoco Inc. this morning that it considers that the discussion phase of the last three weeks on the possible purchase of Conoco shareholdings in Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company has run its course without agreement or understanding on future actions.''   Earlier, Conoco had said it was holding discussions with a number of Canadian companies interested in the possible purchase of Conoco's 53 percent stake in Hudson's Bay Oil.   Conoco is resisting an offer from Dome Petroleum Ltd. in which Dome would buy 14 million shares of Conoco in exchange for the Conoco holdings. Conoco has asked that it be indemnified against any taxes on the transaction.

headline: Shift at St. Jude Medical
abstract: Manuel A. Villafana, the 40-year-old founder, chairman and chief executive officer of St. Jude Medical Inc., a St. Paul manufacturer of prosthetic heart valves, drug delivery systems and other medical devices, will resign his posts, effective Oct. 1. The announcement came after a panel of the Food and Drug Administration accepted the corporation's data on a new heart valve, but requested additional information.   ''You have to know my makeup,'' Mr. Villafana said in a telephone interview. ''I start companies and I bring them to a point where I feel they're on their own two feet and ready to go,'' he added.  ''This product is very well on its way, and my job is done here.  There comes a time when maybe some new blood may do a better job.'' He said he intended to become a consultant to St. Jude under a longterm contract.

headline: THE WIDE OPEN SPACES AT NEWARK
abstract: In Newark International Airport's cavernous North Terminal, where People Express Airlines will originate its service Thursday, the empty seats and frequently closed newsstand and gift shop are testimony to an aviation strategy that never quite got off the ground.   In the 1960's, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the metropolitan airports, forecast growth for the Newark field that has not been approached, much less attained. It estimated that the number of passengers annually would explode to 18 million or 19 million by 1980. To handle the growth it envisioned, the authority built a $400 million complex - Terminals A and B - in the southern part of the field. Today, they easily accommodate passengers using Newark. For while Newark now is growing faster than La Guardia Airport or Kennedy International Airport, last year's passenger traffic at Newark reached only 9.2 million. Terminal C, with its shell completed in 1973, was mothballed. The authority says that construction of that terminal, originally planned as an international arrivals center, is now scheduled to resume in January 1983.

headline: East German-Citroen Deal
abstract: East Germany has ordered 5,000 Citroen GSA-model cars for delivery between June and December this year, Peugeot S.A., a unit of Automobiles Citroen S.A., said today.  Financial details were not disclosed.

headline: U.S. ABLE TO COMBAT NUCLEAR BLACKMAIL
abstract: Government officials said today that they had achieved a sophisticated technological ability to detect, in most cases, whether a terrorist blackmail threat involving nuclear materials was genuine or a bluff.   But the officials also acknowledged to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that it was impossible to provide absolute security against such an incident in the future.   Richard T. Kennedy, the Under Secretary of State for Management, also told the Senate committee that the Soviet Union was ''deeply engaged in support of revolutionary violence'' aimed at weakening and ''destabilizing'' other nations. But he added that Moscow apparently had tried to avoid direct involvement in terrorist incidents and had attempted to channel support to terrorist groups through Soviet ''surrogates.''

headline: LONG-TERM BONDS FIND BUYERS
abstract: New long-term bonds continued to find buyers yesterday even though the market was disrupted by rapid changes in overnight interest rates that made it difficult for securities firms and investors to agree on yields for long-term issues.   Bond prices ended the day down about a point, but many analysts said the decline did not mark the end of the bond market's rally.  Short-term rates rose as much as a quarter of a percentage point.   ''Sentiment is still improving as investors come to expect lower inflation,'' said Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc., ''and the problem of the last few days has been just to find an agreeable yield amid all the uncertainty about the funds rate.''

headline: U.S. SEEKS ANGOLA COMPROMISE AS PRICE FOR ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
abstract: Reagan Administration officials say they have decided on a strategy of tying final agreement on independence for South-West Africa to a withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola and a commitment by the Marxist leaders in Angola to share power with Western-backed guerrillas. The officials say they believe that key black-ruled African countries will have no choice but to go along.   According to documents made available to The New York Times and interviews with Administration officials, the strategy includes these elements:   - South Africa's ''major concerns'' are to be met, including improved relations with Washington, as the only way of inducing that country to give up control of South-West Africa, or Namibia, but actual consummation of the agreement is to be held off.   The prospect of getting South African troops out of Namibia, from which they have been attacking guerrilla forces based in Angola, is to be used as leverage on the Soviet-backed Government of Angola.   Angola is to be asked both to obtain a withdrawal of Cuban forces from its territory and to share power within Angola with Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Western-backed Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

headline: U.S., AT MADRID PARLEY, DEMANDS STRONG RIGHTS STAND
abstract: The Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe started a three-week Easter break today after a strong warning from the United States that the contentious issue of human rights would have to be included in a final document.   ''Our delegation will not settle for language in this vital area that is token or trivial,'' the chief United States delegate, Max M.  Kampelman, said at a session of the 35-nation conference. ''And unfortunately the language that has been provisionally negotiated so far is of that sort.''

headline: Owens-Corning Fiberglas
abstract: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, a leading producer of glass fiber products and other construction and industrial products, announced that net income in the first quarter fell 33.9 percent, to $12.5 million, or 41 cents a share, from $18.9 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first three months of 1980. Sales dropped 6.9 percent, to $539.5 million, from $579.3 million.

headline: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUFFALO WOMAN ON TOUR ALSO WOUNDED
abstract: Ann C. Odre, a 58-year-old retired beautician from Buffalo, was leaning against a barricade and waving an American flag that was the rallying banner of her tour group when she was critically wounded in yesterday's attack on Pope John Paul II.   Msgr. Daniel Szostak, the rector of St. Joseph's Cathedral and a leader of Mrs. Odre's pilgrimage, said that she had maneuvered to the front because she was thrilled at the prospect of receiving a blessing from the Pontiff and planned to celebrate afterward.   ''I heard some shots ring out and I saw the Holy Father slump slightly to his left,'' the 53-year-old monsignor said. ''I started pushing people around me to the ground because I thought there might be more shots. It wasn't until I got closer that someone said that Ann was shot.''

headline: Japanese Act in Loss
abstract: A consortium headed by Mitsubishi will demand $119 million compensation from China to cover losses from a steel plant contract canceled by Peking, company sources said. The $390 million contract, canceled unilaterally by Peking earlier this year, involves the supply of plant and equipment for a hot steel rolling mill for the giant Baoshan steel project near Shanghai.

headline: SHAEFFER BEGINS BREWERY EXPANSION
abstract: The F.&M. Schaeffer Brewing Company said it had begun a $30 million expansion of its Fogelsville, Pa. brewery to produce Stroh's and Schaeffer beer for the Pennsylvania market.

headline: ORIGINATOR OF BRAZIL'S CHICKEN EXPORTS
abstract: There seems to be something about the chicken business that breeds salesmen with a bent for showmanship.  Brazil's answer to Frank Perdue is Nunzio Quraitem, a fast-talking former organ technician in Middle Eastern Catholic cathedrals who struck his first deal by forging a telexed order from Iran for 5,000 tons of frozen poultry five years ago.   It was the beginning of an undertaking that in that short time has made Brazil the world's largest exporter of chicken, with projected sales in 1981 of 260,000 tons, worth $390 million.   The ends of Mr. Quraitem's endeavors have more than forestalled any questions of the means he used to achieve them. ''Fifty percent of Brazil's chicken producers would be bankrupt today if it weren't for what I did,'' said Mr. Quraitem, a 42-year-old naturalized Brazilian, son of a Maltese father and an Italian mother.

headline: MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

headline: WIESENTHAL DENIES SLIGHTING TIMERMAN
abstract: Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of Nazi war criminals, said yesterday that quotations attributed to him in a recent syndicated column by William F. Buckley Jr. questioning the integrity of Jacobo Timerman, the critic of Argentina's rulers, had been partly fabricated.   The quotations were supplied to Mr. Buckley by an aide to Jeane J.  Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate at the United Nations.  In his column for May 31, Mr. Buckley quoted from an interview with Mr. Wiesenthal that appeared April 26 in the newspaper El Pais of Montevideo, Uruguay.   Mr. Wiesenthal was quoted as having suggested that Mr. Timerman had exaggerated the part that anti-Semitism played in his imprisonment in Argentina. Mr. Wiesenthal was also quoted as having suggested that Mr. Timerman was arrested because he had been ''accused of being in favor of terrorism.'' Mr. Wiesenthal purportedly said that Mr. Timerman had ''leftist'' sympathies and that he should ''stick to the truth.''

headline: Coors Adds an Ale To Its Product Line
abstract: The Adolph Coors brewery, which went from 1873 to 1978 with but a single product, Coors Beer, yesterday announced the addition of a fourth label to its line. This time it is an ale, George Gillian's Irish Red, which it will brew under a licensing agreement with the Pelforth Brewery of Lille, France, and from G.H. Lett & Company of County Wexford, Ireland, which licensed Pel@forth but does not brew anything itself.
