abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Company News; Victor Posner Sells Stake in Coachmen
abstract: Victor Posner divested himself of 453,400 shares of Coachmen Industries common stock, at $9.50 a share, representing all his or his companies' holdings in Coachmen.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Development Pro- gram Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Conference on the Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 3 P.M.

headline: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RATE POLICY IS DEFENDED
abstract: A senior Reagan Administration economic official today accused European governments that have criticized high American interest rates, and the resulting strong dollar, of ''flagging'' in their own commitment to fight inflation.   Meyer Rashish, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said that such governments were frequently more concerned about their own short-term political popularity than with the fundamental task of strengthening their economies. ''High unemployment creates very strong pressure to reflate, especially when faced with elections,'' he said.   By contrast the Reagan Administration is in a stronger political position to take unpopular measures. ''President Reagan has bitten that bullet,'' he said.

headline: LUMEX reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Japan and the U.S. agreed on curbing auto exports to the American market. Under the three-year agreement, reached early today in Tokyo, Japanese automakers would limit their sales to the U.S. to 1.68 million units this year. (Page A1.)   Two high officials of the often secretive Federal Reserve debated two of their leading academic critics, both monetarists, at Ohio State University on how best to control monetary growth. (D1.)

headline: SUZUKI IN WASHINGTON FOR ON ARMS SPENDING
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for two days of talks with President Reagan that Administration officials said they hoped would lead to a Japanese commitment to increase military spending.   After landing at Andrews Air Force Base late this afternoon, Mr.  Suzuki traveled to Arlington National Cemetery, where he laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. His official welcome at the White House tomorrow was to be accompanied by an increased display of music and pomp, in keeping with the Administration's desire to restore some festivity to its diplomatic ceremonies.   Mr. Reagan, meanwhile, spent much of the afternoon preparing for his talks with Mr. Suzuki. He used the occasion of a working lunch with State Department officials and others to single out Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. for praise.

headline: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Dominates The Andy Awards Night
abstract: N.W. Ayer Inc., made the finest showing last night at the annual Andy Awards festivities of the Advertising Club of New York held in the Sheraton Center. It picked up seven of the pewter Andy statuettes, far outshining the closest competitors, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Boston's Humphrey Browning MacDougall.

headline: THE SLIPPAGE IN OPEC POWER
abstract: THE meeting of the Organization of Petrolium Exporting Countries in Geneva on May 25 will take place in the midst of a worldwide oil glut that is putting intense pressure on prices.  Spot prices, which exceeded $40 a barrel a year ago, have now fallen as low as $33.  The OPEC ceiling price was set at the last meeting at $41, and the base price at $36.   Saudi Arabia, which has been charging $32 a barrel on contract, has claimed credit for reducing world oil prices by continuing to produce more than 10 million barrels a day.

headline: Newmont Stake
abstract: Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. and its wholly owne United States subsidiary, Amcon Group Inc., held some 2.1 million shares, or 8.1 percent, of Newmont Mining Corporation at the close of business May 29, a Consolidated Gold Fields statement said. In late April, Consolidated said that it had acquired about a 7 percent stake in Newmont and would seek more shares. A Consolidated spokesman added that the company still intended to acquire at least 25 percent of Newmont, but less than 50 percent, if shares were available at appropriate prices.

headline: Talking Businesswith Freeman of First Chicago; Bank Lending And Inflation
abstract: Gaylord Freeman, chairman of the First Chicago Corporation from 1969 until he retired in 1975, is now its honorary chairman and a member of its international advisory committee. He holds a visitor's chair at the Northern Michigan School of Banking.   At the school's winter commencement he raised eyebrows by charging that bankers share the blame for the current round of inflation. He advocated a change in the antitrust laws that would permit bankers to act collectively in regulating bank credit. He elaborated on his plan in a recent interview.

headline: Kuhn's Big K Stores Plans Wal-Mart Tie
abstract: The financially struggling Kuhn's Big K Stores Corporation has agreed to merge with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. of Bentonville, Ark., in a stock transaction worth about $13 million.   The agreement calls for Wal-Mart, which operates 330 discount stores in the Southwest, to acquire all of the 2.58 million shares of Kuhn's common stock for preferred stock based on a valuation of Kuhn's stock at $5 a share.

headline: Japanese Steel Drop Forecast
abstract: Four of Japan's leading steelmakers reported high earnings last year, but Fippon Steel, the world's largest steelmaker, said its profits were cut by a third and next year might be even worse.   Japan's steel industry overtook the United States for the first time last year, but in their annual reports most of the companies saw grim days ahead.

headline: FUN IN THE SUN FOR LESS?
abstract: WESTPORT, Conn.  The cost of fun this spring has gone up again. With the best jogging shoes selling for $75 a pair and indoor tennis court time costing $22 an hour, participation sports are adding to the inflation burden. But the appetite for fun has not abated. Most facilities are close to maximum use and equipment sales are steady.   At the same time, ingenuity in this affluent community that offers an impressive diversity of facilities is playing a role as people contrive to cut costs, or at least share them. Leasing, time-sharing and time planning are becoming increasingly popular and deserve consideration.

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD DOWN 1.8 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 1.8 million shares in the month ended May 15, to 73.1 million.  The short interest for last year totaled 47 million shares.

headline: HAIG REMARK ON CHINA PUZZLES WHITE HOUSE AIDES
abstract: Two White House spokesmen traveling with President Reagan said today that they had no explanation for what Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. meant yesterday when he said that American relations with China had been ''on the decline steadily'' for the last three years.   Mr. Haig made the comment after briefing Mr. Reagan on the Secretary's two-week trip to China and other nations in Asia and the western Pacific.   Asked what Mr. Haig meant, Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said this morning at a briefing for reporters, ''I have no explanation.'' A reporter then suggested that ''maybe'' Richard V. Allen, the President's national security adviser, who was sitting in the back of the room, could provide an explanation.  ''Maybe he could, but he won't,'' Mr. Allen said with a smile.

headline: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; 'The Chase Is On' With a New Theme
abstract: Another new campaign that makes its debut on Monday - and this one is worldwide - will be coming your way from Chase Manhattan with an assist in America and Europe from Wells Rich Greene and in Asia from Bate Advertising in Singapore.   And the new theme is ''The Chase is on.''

headline: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DIVESTITURE URGED FOR I.T.T. UNIT
abstract: A Federal Trade Commission judge ruled today that the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, the world's largest baker of bread, had for nearly 15 years engaged in illegal price discrimination and other anticompetitive practices aimed at monopolizing the wholesale baking business.   As a remedy, the administrative law judge, Miles J. Brown, recommended that the commission consider ordering the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to divest itself of its Continental subsidiary.   I.T.T. said in its 1980 annual report that its food business segment accounted for sales and revenues of about $1.82 billion, which was 7.6 percent of its total for the year of nearly $23.82 billion - which included $5.29 billion in insurance and finance revenues. Net income from the food segment last year amounted to $16 million, 1.7 percent of I.T.T.'s total profits of $894.3 million for 1980.

headline: Leaders of Commons Decide Not to 'Expel' I.R.A. Man
abstract: British parliamentary leaders decided tonight not to try to ''expel'' the imprisoned Irish Republican Army guerrilla Robert Sands from the House of Commons.   Mr. Sands, on a hunger strike in Northern Ireland's Maze Prison, was elected to the Commons last week. He could not take the seat anyway because he is serving a 14-year sentence imposed after a gun battle with the police.

headline: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Producer Price Index jumped 1.3 percent in March, a 16.8 percent annual rate, largely because of soaring oil prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. The first rise in food prices since November contributed to the increase. (Page 1.)   The unemployment rate remained unchanged in March at 7.3 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Economists said that the steadiness indicated that the economy was stronger than many experts believed, in part because of the growth of ''underground'' business.  (11.) New York City's unemployment rate rose to 10.5 percent from 9.4 percent in February. (11.)

headline: WEST BERLINERS TO VOTE TODAY ON A RANGE OF HEATED ISSUES
abstract: In an election that could indicate growing dissatisfaction with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government in Bonn, West Berliners go to the polls tomorrow in a City Council election.   The direct issue is control of this outpost city, run throughout most of its postwar history by the Social Democrats, alone or with a coalition partner. This time the Chancellor's party is expected to suffer heavy losses as a result of widespread discontent over financial scandals, a severe housing shortage and violent youth protests.   According to the latest public opinion polls, the opposition Christian Democrats, in a landslide victory, could get an absolute majority, winning over large segments of disgruntled middle-class voters by promises of a return to law and order.

headline: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Joan Baez Sings to Crowds Despite Ban in Brazil
abstract: The police prevented the American folk singer and activist Joan Baez from doing a show and making guest appearances here last night.   But to the delight of Brazilian audiences, she managed to sing offstage.

headline: SHIP BLAST IN ROTTERDAM
abstract: An explosion and fire on the 72,000-ton Agios Joannes, a Greek ore freighter, killed one person today, injured six people and left five missing, a harbor authority spokesman said. The explosion was in the engine room.

headline: FRAZZLED CANDIDATES WIND UP BITTER FRENCH CAMPAIGN
abstract: The presidential election campaign wound up today in a thoroughly bad temper.  The pressures of a race in which almost precisely half of the electorate seems ready to vote Sunday against the other half have told heavily on the equanimity of both President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist candidate.   Two private polls taken in the last three days showed Mr.  Mitterrand ahead by three to four points but indicated that Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing was narrowing the gap. A third, commissioned by the Giscard d'Estaing organization, gave the President a two-point lead.

headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: OPEC failed to establish a uniform price for oil at its meeting last week in Geneva, and some analysts think that the price of gasoline will fall several cents a gallon as a result. Saudi Arabia refused to raise its $32-a-barrel price or cut production. A majority of the oil nations agreed to reduce output by at least 10 percent and hold their crude oil prices to $36 to $41 a barrel.

headline: U.S. IS RESISTING GREEK DEMANDS SETTING CONDITIONS ON ARMS AID
abstract: Negotiations with the United States over a military and economic cooperation accord are stumbling over Greek demands that Washington appears unwilling to satisfy.   Diplomats on both sides said that, although on a technical level the three-month-old talks had made progress, political questions render almost impossible the signing of the accord by Easter, as originally planned.   American sources said Greece insisted that the United States legally bind itself to a 7-to-10 ratio in military aid between Greece and Turkey as a means of insuring a balance of power.

headline: DOW OFF 2.97 IN CAUTIOUS MARKET
abstract: Energy stocks finally showed some strength yesterday, but the rest of the market finished virtually on an even keel as investors remained sensitive to interest-rate changes and other concerns.  Japanese issues that have constituted one of the market's strongest sectors were hit by profit-taking.   These divergent movements in stock groups typified the conflicting signals given off by the market. Continued uncertainty over the fate of the Administration's tax-cut program was an additional factor dampening any rally attempt.

headline: Frank C. Dougherty
abstract: PRAYING FOR PEACE IN LEBANON: Some of the Christian demonstrators who are staging a sit-in outside the Presidential Palace in Beirut.

headline: U.S. AND JAPAN PLAN CUTS IN SEMICONDUCTOR TARIFFS
abstract: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that the United States and Japan had made a significant breakthrough in liberalizing trade in semiconductors, the tiny memory chips that are at the heart of much advanced technology.   At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Brock disclosed that Japan's Prime Minister, Zenko Suzuki, had agreed ''in principle'' at a meeting with Mr. Brock on Saturday to a mutual reduction in semiconductor tariffs, dropping the duty in both countries to 4.2 percent of import value in the next 12 months.   Japan now has a 10.1 percent tariff, and the United States one of 5.6 percent for the memory chips. The European Economic Community, whose producers are generally acknowledged to be less efficient than those in the United States and Japan, has a 17 percent tariff and is not a party to the agreement.

headline: NOVO INDUSTRI A-S reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Crocker Discusses Namibia With South African Official
abstract: Chester Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for Africa, met Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha today in talks aimed at ending the deadlock on independence for South-West Africa, or Namibia.   Before coming to Pretoria, Mr. Crocker toured the black African countries neighboring South Africa.  The key to all the talks has been the fate of Namibia - a thinly populated territory ruled by South Africa since World War I.  A United Nations plan to guide Namibia to independence has virtually collapsed because of objections from both South Africa and black nationalist guerrillas.

headline: Times Declares Dividend
abstract: The New York Times Company declared its regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share yesterday on its class A and class B common shares, payable June 26 to holders of record June 5. The company also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on its 5 1/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable July 1 to holders of record June 5. The dividends were unchanged from the previous quarter.

headline: Company News; U.S. Insurer Seeks License in Japan
abstract: The Japanese Government is considering a request from the Life Insurance Company of North America to do business in Japan, officials said.

headline: Advertising; Ad Revenues Increased In U.S. Daily Newspapers
abstract: The country's daily newspapers were up an estimated 15.6 percent in ad revenues during the first four months of this year, to $5.36 billion, compared with the same period last year, while magazines belonging to the Publishers Information Bureau were up 6 percent, to $966.1 million.

headline: American Air's Earnings Up
abstract: American Airlines Inc., reversing a $41.9 million loss in the 1980 first quarter, said today that it earned $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in the first three months of the year despite a decline in passenger traffic. Revenues rose 9.4 percent, to $952.5 million, from $871 million in the comparable 1980 period.

headline: Notes on the U.N.
abstract: James Grant, the chief of the United Nations Children's Fund, wants to enlarge his staff by 384 over the next two years. He would take on three new $85,864-a-year assistant secretary generals, increase his payroll by $26.8 million and expand the agency's 1,872 jobs by slightly more than 20 percent.   All this comes as Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, the United States and others are working for ''zero growth'' at the United Nations by holding budgets at their present level. To be sure, this rule applies to agencies that are supported by assessments, and Unicef relies on contributions. But Mr. Grant expects gifts to increase, and this is one reason for his proposals.

headline: No Headline
abstract: IRANIAN OFFICIAL ASSERTS BANI-SADR HAS VANISHED AND MAY HAVE FLED   TEHERAN, Iran, June 18 (By Reuters) - Teheran's revolutionary prosecutor said today that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr had dropped out of sight and might have fled Iran to escape Islamic fundamentalists who want to force his dismissal and place him on trial.   The official, Assadollah Lajverdi, said over the state radio that the President was last known to be in Teheran at 4 P.M. Tuesday.  Asked if the authorities had made any moves to intercept the President, against whom an impeachment debate is to begin in Parliament on Saturday, the prosecutor said the frontier police had been notified. ''But all our frontiers are not under police control,'' he said, ''and it is possible to leave.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has named John W. Dansby vice president for strategic planning.   * Batus Retail Division has appointed Stephen A. Quintin vice president and director of real estate.

headline: U.S. OFICIALS INVESTIGATING POSSIBLITY OF FRAUD IN IMMIGRATION OF KHOMEIMI IRANIANS
abstract: Federal officials are reviewing immigration records for hundreds of Iranians on the suspicion that many got immigration benefits, including status as permanent residents of the United States, through fraud or bribery.   The investigation focuses on the period after the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran, which led President Carter to impose severe restrictions on the issuance of visas and permanent resident alien identification cards, commonly known as green cards, to Iranians.   Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week that Federal agents were reviewing the records and interviewing Iranians to find out how hundreds had obtained visas and green cards despite the restrictions.    Although the United States and Iran have no formal diplomatic relations, Iranians streaming out of the Middle East through Europe continue to seek a haven here. They include supporters of the late Shah, opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and members of many religious and ethnic minority groups.

headline: Union Underwear
abstract: The Woodward Manufacturing Company, a unit of the Union Underwear Company, said it would close its underwear plant here because it could attract only 250 workers to this northwestern Oklahoma area.

headline: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Canon U.S.A. Inc. has appointed Haruo Murase vice president and general manager of the copier division.   * Drew Chemical Corporation, Boonton, N.J., has appointed Robert G. O'@Brien vice president and general counsel.

headline: Missing Priest Turns Up At Embassy in Salvador
abstract: An American Roman Catholic priest who had been missing and feared dead for 10 days walked into the United States Embassy this afternoon in apparent good health, an embassy spokesman said.   The Rev. Roy Bourgeois, a 42-year-old Maryknoll priest based in Chicago, vanished April 26.

headline: FOR S.E.C. CHIEF, BIG DECISIONS
abstract: John S.R. Shad, after little more than a month as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is facing two key decisions that Wall Street and businessmen feel could well set the tone for the future direction of the commission's crucial enforcement division.   In the first place, Mr. Shad must replace Stanley Sporkin, who as head of the division was its most visible symbol until his appointment last month to the post of general counsel for the Central Intelligence Agency.   Mr. Shad, though he has not yet made a final decision on Mr.  Sporkin's replacement, is apparently going to break with recent S.E.C. tradition and appoint as enforcement director an outside lawyer who has never worked for the commission, according to sources familiar with the selection process.   These sources say the leading contenders for Mr. Sporkin's post are three private lawyers: John M. Fedders, a partner in the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter; Jed S. Rakoff, a partner in the New York firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander, and Peter R. Taft, a partner in the Los Angeles firm of Munger, Tolles & Rickershauser.

headline: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: E.E.C.-Japan Talks Snagged
abstract: The European Economic Community's top trade negotiator said today that talks with Japanese officials had amounted to ''pretty much near zero,'' and urged the 10 Common Market countries to take new action to put pressure on Japan to moderate exports.   The Common Market's external affairs director, Roy Denman, said that discussions yesterday and today with the Japanese Deputy Foreign Minister, Kiyaoki Kikuchi, had resulted in virtually ''no progress across the board.''

headline: DOW UP 1.11 AFTER A LATE RALLY
abstract: A late rally rescued a lethargic stock market yesterday, although energy-related issues remained under selling pressure. While the performance lacked the dynamic gains of Tuesday and Wednesday, it marked the third straight session when prices turned notably stronger in the final hour.   Brokerage, airline, precious-metal and selected bank stocks advanced.After rising 21 points in the two previous sessions, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.11 points yesterday, to 994.25. Down most of the day, this indicator was off 3.80 at 3 P.M.

headline: BENEFICIAL PLANS TO SELL SPIEGEL
abstract: The Beneficial Corporation, the nation's largest consumer loan company, said that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its subsidiary, Spiegel, the big Chicago catalogue house, for more than $52 million.   Beneficial refused to disclose the name of the buyer, in accordance with requirements of the prospective buyer, a spokesman for the financial services company said.

headline: U.N. DISPUTE LOOMS ON INFANT FORMULA
abstract: A dispute over the sale of artificial milk to third-world countries is likely to break out next week when the United States casts what may be the sole vote against a code outlawing the promotion of infant formula.   Reagan Administration officials confirmed today that the White House had directly ordered the ''no'' vote, overriding the Departments of State and Health and Human Services. The two departments had recommended an abstention, officials said, to narrow the gap between the United States and the 156 other nations at the United Nations' World Health Assembly.   The leading American makers of powdered milk, Abbott Laboratories, the American Home Products Corporation and the Bristol-Myers Company, have waged a campaign for the ''no'' vote. Administration aides agreed with the manufacturers that there was no persuasive evidence of a connection between the promotion of powdered milk and a drop in breast-feeding and that the code infringes on free speech and restrains trade. In addition, Administration officials oppose any precedent for economic regulation by United Nations agencies.

headline: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: FED PURCHASES HELP PRICES A BIT; KEY U.S. BOND STILL AT 13% LEVEL By MICHAEL QUINT   Purchases of Treasury notes and bonds by the Federal Reserve yesterday helped raise prices in the credit markets, although not by much.   The Fed's buying did not dispel the widespread uncertainty about future changes in interest rates. Traders are troubled by fluctuations in overnight interest rates, and many investors are not buying many long-term bonds until they are more confident that inflation and interest rates will subside.   ''With no such thing as a trading range for Federal funds anymore, the market is on edge,'' one Government securities dealer explained.  This lack of indication about how high or how low the rate may go increases greatly the risks of doing business because financing costs can change so rapidly, he observed. The result: less liquidity in the long-term market and wider price swings resulting from relatively few trades.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Aztec Energy Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an intial offering of five million common shares to be sold through underwriters headed by Rocky Mountain Securities and Investment.   * Bank of Montreal is offering $200.1 million in convertible subordinated debentures through a Wood Gundy group.   * Beehive International announced an offering of 551,000 common shares at a price of $14.875 a share, through a Shearson Loeb Rhoades group.

headline: S.& P. Reduces Kraft Bond Rating
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the financial services publisher and debt-rating agency, said it had reduced the bond ratings of Kraft Inc., a major dairy products and food processor, to Double-A from Triple-A.   S.& P. also announced that it had raised bond ratings to Double-A from Single-A for Dart Industries Inc., a producer of glassware and other products, and of the Hobart Corporation, a major producer of food industry equipment and home appliances.

headline: Portuguese Banking Bill
abstract: The Portuguese Parliament approved a bill to allow the opening of private banks and insurance companies for the first time since both sectors were nationalized in 1975.

headline: HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Rapid-American Reports Gain
abstract: The Rapid-American Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net income of $939,000 in the first fiscal quarter of 1981, which ended in April, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales increased 6 percent, to $604.5 million, from $570.3 million.   Rapid-American, a diversified retailer and distiller, said that the earnings improvement was primarily attributable to better results from retail operations and an increase in Schenley earnings, offset in part by increased interest expense, principally on the 10 percent subordinated debentures issued upon the merger of Rapid-American and the Kenton Corporation.

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP 0.3% IN MAY
abstract: The nation's industrial production rose a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in May, with most of the small gain a result of auto dealers' building up inventories, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The seasonally adjusted May rise in production followed a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in April - small changes compared with increases of 1 percent or more for each of the last five months of 1980 as the economy recovered from a recession.   Industrial production dropped slightly in February from the January level and rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March. Analysts said the slight monthly increases were indicative of slowing economic growth.

headline: DIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reorganization Proceeds At Wells, Rich, Greene
abstract: The four members of the board of directors of Wells, Rich, Greene will be voting on a broad reorganization plan when they meet April 20 to plan ahead to 1982 when the agency cracks through the $500 million-in-billings mark.   According to Mary Wells Lawrence, the chairman, they will create a holding company called Wells, Rich, Gr eene Worldwide.

headline: Counts Against Sears Dismissed
abstract: A Federal judge has dismissed a 13-count indictment against Sears, Roebuck & Company after accusing a Government prosecutor of misconduct.   Government attorneys, however, said that they intended to proceed with the prosecution of Sears for allegedly concealing $1.1 million in rebates from Japanese manufacturers of television sets.

headline: DOUBLE TAX BREAKS ON LEASES
abstract: It goes by an odd name - double dip - and, as interest rates remain near record levels, it is one of the more creative new ways to finance plant and equipment.   Double dip is a tax leasing arrangement that provides such lucrative benefits that few tax leasing experts are willing to talk about it. The fear, they say, is that public disclosure may cause the tax authorities in the United States and in Britain, the two countries where it is practiced, to halt its use.   ''It's a sensitive issue,'' said an international tax expert with a major accounting firm. ''It is marketed by institutions that are very sensitive about publicity. The more people know about it, the less of a likelihood of it standing up. The banks consider this a hot potato.''

headline: Small Party in Italy Gains In Attempt to Form Cabinet
abstract: Senator Giovanni Spadolini, the head of the small Republican Party who is trying to become Italy's first non-Christian Democratic Prime Minister in 35 years, got off to a better-thanexpected start today in his first consultations with other parties.   He won the immediate support of the Socialists and the tentative endorsement of the Social Democrats.

headline: PUTTING VIDEO ADS AT THE SUPERMARKET CHECKOUT
abstract: Commercial-haters beware. On-Line Media Inc. wants to flash ads at you while you stand in the mindless peace of the checkout line at the supermarket.   It seems like the springboard for a shoppers' revolt. But perhaps there aren't as many commercial-haters out there after all. A pilot study in New Jersey supermarkets showed that only 6 percent of the shoppers found the commercials irritating or distracting, while 52 percent said the ads helped relieve the boredom of waiting in line.   On first impression, the advertisers didn't exactly love the concept. ''I didn't think it made sense,'' said Isabel Torbert, advertising manager for The Nestle Company. ''I said, 'So what, so someone is trying to take advantage of a situation, but it won't fit in.' ''

headline: VICTIMIZED INDIANS HOLD KEY TO GUATEMALAN CONFLICT
abstract: When the fighters show up and ask for some beans, some corn or some tortillas in this highland area, the Indian inhabitants have two choices.   One is to give food to the callers, who are dressed in rollbrimmed straw sombreros, rude leather sandals and tattered trousers, discover that they are army troops in guerrilla disguise and be killed for helping the wrong side. The other choice is to not give food to them, discover that they really are guerrillas and be killed for helping the wrong side.   The Indians who make up more than half of Guatemala's population of about seven million are caught in the middle of the violent conflict here. How they decide to get out of it could be the deciding factor in the outcome.

headline: Indonesia Coal Mining
abstract: The Indonesian Government will allow open coal mining to be opened to private companies, including joint ventures with foreign partners, the Mines and Energy Ministry said today.

headline: PLOTTERS ARRESTED, BANGLADESH ASSERTS
abstract: The Bangladesh Government announced tonight that it had arrested 20 army officers involved in the plot last weekend to overthrow the Government and that three of them, including the leader, had been killed shortly after being taken into custody.   President Ziaur Rahman, who was killed in the attempted coup Saturday morning, was buried in Dacca after a long, solemn funeral procession attended by hundreds of thousands of grieving people, many of them in tears and shouting slogans.   The Government announcement left unclear the exact circumstances in which the three officers - Maj. Gen. Mohammed Abdul Manzur and two lieutenant colonels - had died.   According to the Government announcement, reports from Chittagong, where the rebellion took place, said that with the help of local people, the three rebellious officers had been tracked to a ''hideout in the jungle,'' in the southeast corner of the country.

headline: Lawmaker Ends Pakistan Visit
abstract: Representative Joel Pritchard, Republican of Washington, ended a three-day visit to Pakistan promising to advocate continued assistance for Afghan refugees, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. The United States has provided about a quarter of the $400 million being spent on refugee relief.

headline: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEST GERMAN PARLIAMENT SUPPORTS NATO PLAN ON MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt reported to Parliament today on his recent trip to Washington and afterward his governing coalition won legislative approval for a NATO decision to deploy new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.   The coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats adopted a resolution on the issue by a vote of 254 to 236.  The vote was the most recent in a series both within Mr. Schmidt's Social Democratic Party and in Parliament that have supported deployment of the new weapons. These votes, however, have not succeeded in ending discontent among Social Democrats.

headline: I.R.A.'s at Home
abstract: To the Business Editor ''An I.R.A. in Every Portfolio'' (June 14) was interesting reading as far as it went. While it mentioned legislation on Capitol Hill, it omitted one very important bill sponsored by three Republican Senators - David F. Durenberger of Minnesota and Mark O. Hatfield and Bob Packwood of Oregon.

headline: SAVIN TO ACQUIRE U.S. OLIVETTI
abstract: The Savin Corporation and the Olivetti Group, two companies that have had financial difficulties and trouble gaining solid footholds in America's office automation business, announced yesterday that they would merge their efforts in that market.   Under a proposed agreement, Savin will acquire the Olivetti Corporation, the American arm of the Italian company, for about $63 million in common and preferred stock.   The new company, the Savin Olivetti Corporation, will be owned 70 percent by shareholders of Savin and 30 percent by Olivetti. It will be controlled by the top executives of Savin.

headline: SENATE PANEL SOFTENS BAN ON AID TO REBELS IN ANGOLA
abstract: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to lift a legislative ban on assistance to pro-Western rebel forces in Angola, provided that future aid is tied to ''substantial progress'' toward resolving the conflict in neighboring South-West Africa.   The complicated measure, adopted after a morning of parliamentary maneuvering, was a compromise between committee Republicans who favored lifting the ban entirely and Democrats who opposed removing it at this time.   The measure, approved by a 10-to-2 vote, would remove the ban on military aid to rebels opposed to the Marxist Government in Angola.  However, it would prohibit such assistance unless the President privately informed the committee in advance why aid was necessary.

headline: WEST BERLIN GOVERNMENT FORMED
abstract: The West Berlin Parliament today elected a Christian Democrat, Richard von Weizsacker, the city's Mayor, moving the Social Democrats into the opposition for the first time in the postwar period.   Mr. von Weizsacker, who won a majority of 69 votes in the 132-member Parliament with the help of rebel Free Democrats, presented a minority administration made up entirely of Christian Democrats.   In parliamentary elections last month, the Christian Democratic Union won 65 seats, two short of a majority. The Social Democrats obtained 51 seats, while nine seats went to a new left-wing group, the Alternative List, and seven seats were won by the Free Democrats. The Free Democratic Party, which is the Social Democrats' coalition partner in the West German Government in Bonn, was also their partner in the outgoing West Berlin administration.

headline: Emigres Say Czechs Now Hold 19 Who Support Rights Movement
abstract: A police roundup in which supporters of the Charter 77 human rights movement in Czechoslovakia have been arrested continued today, bringing the number of arrests to 19, emigre sources said.

headline: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to march 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PARTIES IN ISRAEL FOCUS APPEALS ON SEPHARDIM
abstract: Israel has never been much of a melting pot, nor has it tried to be. Its population has been gathered over the decades from the scattered shtetls of eastern Europe and the villages of North Africa, the urban centers of the United States and the Arab countries of the Middle East.   Fragmented into diverse religious styles and ethnic groupings, the 3.2 million Jews of Israel have yet to coalesce into a cultural whole, and the ethnic divisions among them have become an issue in the campaign for national elections next Tuesday.   More vividly than in most previous elections, the major political parties are appealing to the Sephardim, the Jews of non-European and non-American background, who make up about 44 percent of the eligible voters. Mostly from North African and Arab countries, they are represented with disproportionate strength among the less-educated, the blue-collar work force and the politically hawkish. After suffering years of discrimination, many are experiencing a surge of pride in their identity, and their old party loyalties have shaken loose, giving them the potent role of swing vote in what is expected to be a close race next Tuesday.

headline: Iraqi Office in Beirut Attacked
abstract: A small rocket damaged the Iraqi Airways office here overnight, Iraqi sources said today. They said gunmen later exchanged fire with the office's guards, but that no one was hurt in either incident.

headline: AFGHAN REBELS BRISTLE WITH NEW ARMS
abstract: Islamic rebels, apparently armed with new supplies, are moving openly and confidently in two widely separated provinces of Afghanistan, according to Westerners back from secret trips into the country.   In southeast Afghanistan, in arid Helmand Province, rebel bands were described as driving jeeps obtained from Iran, according to Steven McCurry, a Philadelphia-based photographer who just returned from his eighth visit with various Afghan rebel groups. In the eight days he spent in the region, which is largely populated by Baluch tribesmen, he said he saw no sign of central government authority.   ''The guerrillas moved around very openly in daytime,'' he said.  ''Some had little plastic badges identifying their particular group.'' Most of them, he went on, had Soviet AK-47 assault rifles and ''no shortage of ammunition.''

headline: PEARCE URSTADT MAYER & GREER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CLASHES IN NORTHERN IRELAND WORSEN AS 51-DAY HUNGER STRIKE GOES ON
abstract: As an imprisoned Irish republican guerrilla began the 51st day of a hunger strike in Belfast, Roman Catholic youths in Londonderry today battled soldiers and the police with stones and bottles.   It was the sixth day of violence that has continued to escalate as the condition of the guerrilla, Robert Sands, has deteriorated.

headline: Excerpts From President's Talk
abstract: Following is a partial transcription of remarks by President Reagan to a group of supporters in the East Room of the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: I came to pay tribute to you - the new superstars of American grass-roots politics. You represent a cross section of Americans from all backgrounds, different regions across this country. In fact you remind me very much of that one special-interest group that I mentioned on Inauguration Day, the one special-interest group that has been neglected and needs help - that is, we, the people.

headline: SEARCH CONTINUES FOR QUAKE VICTIMS
abstract: Residents of Golbaf, Iran, lifting a body from the rubble left by Thursday's earthquake.  Officials estimate that more than 3,000 people have been killed but fear that 5,000 may be found in the southeastern province of Kerman.  More than 1,600 people have already been buried in that region.

headline: DAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NIGERIA, EQUADOR SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
abstract: World oil prices apparently slipped again yesterday.  Industry officials reported that Nigeria was offering discounts of about $2 a barrel on noncontract sales of its oil and that Ecuador was cutting its crude price by $3.80 a barrel, to $35.50.   In London, the Government-owned British National Oil Corporation opened talks with North Sea oil producers and indicated a willingness to cut its price by $2 a barrel, to $37.75. But the producers demanded a $5 price cut.

headline: Textron Sells 3 Units
abstract: Textron Inc. said it had completed the sale of three of its units to Nucon Holdings Inc. for $66 million. Included in the sale were the Burkart polyurethane and foam unit of the Burkart Randall division and the conglomerate's Talon and Willco divisions, which make zippers and hearing-aids, respectively.

headline: NORTHWEST ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ivac Plant Planned
abstract: The Ivac Corporation, a unit of Eli Lilly & Company, the pharmaceutical, chemicals and cosmetics producer, said it planned to build a $10 million manufacturing plant on a 39-acre site in Creedmoor, N.C. Ivac said the 90,000-square-foot plant, scheduled for completion in the summer of 1982, would make plastic sterile intravenous fluid-infusion sets and other medical plastics.

headline: Assets Decline At Money Funds
abstract: The total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $104.6 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   This was the fourth straight week of decline, following 17 weeks of advances.

headline: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES DROP SHARPLY
abstract: Interest rates dropped sharply yesterday, and the Treasury was able to sell new 13 7/8 percent, five-year, five-month notes at an average rate of 13.95 percent, well below the 14.6 percent yield that was estimated earlier in the week.   Although the decline in rates was steep - many short-term issues fell move than half a percentage point -analysts continued to describe the credit markets as nervous, volatile and uncertain.   ''We are in a period of transition from bearish psychology to bullish psychology,'' commented Richard B. Hoey, an economist at Bache Halsey Stuart. This changing period has helped make the markets erratic, he said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BANK SUSPENDS PLAN FOR LONDON ACCOUNT
abstract: Only two days after the introduction, the Bank of California said yesterday that it was suspending a new form of bank account that allowed depositors to collect interest rates as high as 17.25 percent.   The plan, called Money Market Plus, drew the immediate attention of Federal banking regulators and was suspended after a meeting with Federal Reserve Board officials, the bank said.

headline: GEO: LIME GREEN EDSEL OF A MAGAZINE SEARCHES FOR AN IMAGE THAT WORKS
abstract: T HE dream was that it would become a Cadillac among magazines. Many bags of gold were laid aside to insure success. The West Germans promised to pump $20 million into it, a lot of money in any man's language, and it was clear they were not kidding. The sumptuous penthouse offices at 450 Park Avenue alone were testimony to that.   ''In the beginning, the sense of promise was unbelievable,'' recalls an original staffer. ''We thought we were going to do something really unique and important.''

headline: Union Carbide Plans Silicon Factory
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation confirmed that it planned to build a plant in the Pacific Northwest to produce 1,000 metric tons of polycrystalline silicon yearly, with production to begin in late 1984. The silicon ingots would be sold to the semiconductor industry.    The company also announced it had signed a technology agreement with Komatsu Electronic Metals Ltd., Tokyo, covering some processes for high-quality silicon.

headline: CASTRO DECLARES NO INVADER 'CAN GRAB OUR COUNTRY'
abstract: On the 20th anniversary of his victory at the Bay of Pigs, President Fidel Castro of Cuba made an emotional plea for world peace, reaffirmed his nation's solidarity with the Soviet Union and warned that no invader ''can grab our country with its guard down.''   In a 90-minute speech, which he characterized as ''moderate,'' Mr.  Castro tonight made his first public response to accusations by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Cuba was behind a ''terrorist network'' aimed at the ''ultimate takeover of Central America.'' He spoke at the Karl Marx Theater in Havana.   It is the United States, Mr. Castro declared, that is sabotaging the economy of Nicaragua and suspending credit to the regime there, that is conducting a propaganda campaign against Nicaragua and that is allowing the training of Nicaraguan mercenaries at camps in America.

headline: Egypt Charges Anti-Sadat Plot
abstract: An Egyptian Government prosecutor charged today that a former Egyptian Armed Forces Chief of Staff, Lieut.  Gen. Saad Eddin el-Shazli, and 18 other Government opponents living in exile had plotted to overthrow President Anwar el-Sadat. The group allegedly received $2.8 million from Libya at Syria's urging. A statement issued by the prosecutor's office said the members of the group would be tried in abstenia.

headline: Belgian Official Is Asked To Form a New Regime
abstract: King Baudouin of Belgium today accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and asked Finance Minister Marc Eyskens, a Flemish Social Christian, to form a new government, an official statement said.   A communique from the Royal Palace said that Mr. Eyskens, who comes from the same party as Mr. Martens, had accepted the task, which the King urged him to complete as quickly as possible.

headline: TURNER CONSTRUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mauritania Sentences 3 in Plot
abstract: A Mauritanian military court sentenced three men to death in absentia today on charges of taking part in an attempted coup last month, the Algerian press agency reported from the Mauritanian capital.

headline: Company News; Macmillan in Talks To Sell More Units
abstract: Macmillan Inc., which reported a first-quarter loss of $1.7 million, is negotiating the sale of two more operating units, including the nationwide Brentano's Inc. bookstore chain, Edward P.  Evans, Macmillan chairman, told stockholders.   He said the publishing company has sold or phased out 12 operating units since 1979 and concluded ''reluctantly'' that Alco-Gravure Inc., a printing company, and Brentano's did not fit into the parent's plans.

headline: Provident Life Sale
abstract: The Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company of Chattanooga, Tenn., said that it planned to sell its interest in three investment properties it owns in partnership with the MaceRich Company of Santa Monica, Calif. Provident said that the properties -three regional shopping malls in Mississippi and Virginia - are worth about $45 million. Provident said its share in each property ranged between one-third and one-half ownership.

headline: END TO WEEKLY MONEY REPORT STUDIED
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it was considering ending the practice of reporting money supply data each Friday. The move could reduce pressure on the Fed to adjust interest rates weekly in response to short-term changes in the money supply.   The announcement appears to run counter to the views of Beryl W.  Sprin@kel, one of the country's leading monetarists, who is Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs.   Monetarists believe that inflation is primarily a monetary phenomenon and that a constant hand on the control mechanisms for growth of the money supply is the most effective way to check inflation.

headline: CANADIAN JAVELIN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Â¸
abstract: THE beleaguered thrift industry has a lot riding on a meeting this Thursday between bank regulators and Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan. It's still an open question what will be decided, with chances only 50-50 that the savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks will be allowed to pay a quarter of a percentage point more interest than commercial banks do on six-month money market certificates.   Commercial bankers are lobbying hard against the proposal, which is being pushed by Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the savings and loan institutions. Lee Gunderson, president of the American Bankers Association, argues that his members' operations are on the line. The A.B.A. says its computer runs show that restoring the differential may cause a loss in deposits at some banks of 18 to 20 percent.

headline: Nissan Denies Report
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company, which produces the Datsun automobile, today denied published reports that it was reconsidering its plans to build a car assembly plant in Britain. A spokesman for Japan's No.2 auto producer said he had no knowledge of a report published in The London Daily Mail that Nissan was now considering building the plant in Belgium.

headline: TEXT OF REPORT ON IRAQI REACTOR
abstract: Following is the text of a statement made June 12 by Sigvard Eklund of Sweden, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to the agency's Board of Governors in Vienna:   I have received the following report from the Department of Safeguards: The task of the agency in the implementation of safeguards is to verify that no safeguarded nuclear material is diverted from peaceful purposes. In a research reactor of the Osiris type this means, in the first place, to insure that fuel elements supplied from abroad are checked on arrival and that from that moment on continuity of knowledge is maintained on their location and integrity. The primary measures used for this purpose are item accounting, identification and containment and surveillance. The design of the facility and of the fuel elements is such that they provide assurance that the diversion of fuel elements would be detected with very high probability.1

headline: THE DRUG BUSINESS SEES A GOLDEN ERA AHEAD
abstract: THE Warner-Lambert Company, a major pharmaceutical concern, earned a respectable 13.3 percent on shareholder investment last year, just a shade below the national average for manufacturers of all stripes.  But in the exceptionally profitable pharmaceutical industry, it was an also-ran.   Warner-Lambert and its fellow also-rans now have a chance to recoup. With the expectation of increasing demand for a host of new drugs for an aging population, with early signals that the Reagan Administration will relax regulatory requirements, and with such dramatic advances as interferon research in the biological sciences, the drug industry may be on the brink of even greater profitability.   ''These factors will make the 1980's a golden age of drug research,'' Ronald M. Nordmann, senior drug analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, said. ''You will see more interesting new drugs in the 1980's than any decade within memory.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Avatar Holdings Inc., Coral Gables, Fla., has appointed Thomas E. Lewis president and chief operating officer, succeeding Peter Charp, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.   * Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, has named Mark B. Logan senior vice president and president of the Soflens Group.   * Chrysler Corporation, Detroit, has nominated for election to its board Joseph A. Califano, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and Robert C. Wilson, retired chairman of the Memorex Corporation.
