abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: METHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Extending Safe Storage Of Spent Nuclear Fuel
abstract: Radioactive spent fuel from nuclear reactors can now be stored safely for a century. A method for such storage, developed for the Energy Department, was patented this week by Donald G. Schweitzer, Cesar Sastre and Warren Winsche of the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.

headline: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Purported Royal Transcripts Published in West Germany
abstract: Despite a court ban, a West German magazine today distributed 950,000 copies of what were said to be transcripts of talks between Prince Charles of Britain and his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer.   Patrick Engel, production manager for the Munich-based magazine Die Aktuelle, said the material had been published because the court order obtained by the British Embassy in Bonn on behalf of the Prince late yesterday had reached the presses at Nuremberg too late.

headline: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Foundation President Is Chosen
abstract: MICHAEL J. NAPLES, whose background includes experience with most major facets of marketing research, was named president yesterday of the Advertising Research Foundation by its board.   The 43-year-old executive will be giving up the unpaid post of chairman of the foundation to take on this salaried assignment on May 18. Theodore F. Dunn, the Benton & Bowles senior vice president, will then step up from vice chairman to chairman.

headline: Skilled Workers
abstract: To the Business Editor: Lester Thurow's ''Wanted: More Skilled Workers'' (May 3) should make us mindful of ''Rosie the Riveter,'' the award-winning movie about the millions of women who became highly skilled workers making planes, ships and munitions during World War II. They adored their work and being paid decently for it, and expected their skills to provide them with lifetime careers.

headline: Mortgage-Aid Bonds Cleared
abstract: The Treasury Department today cleared the way for new tax-exempt mortgage subsidy bonds but excluded mobile home buyers from the subsidy.   The department announced new regulations allowing state housing authorities to authorize mortgage subsidy bonds under last year's revised Mortgage Subsidy Act for single-family houses and owneroccupied four-unit apartments.

headline: IRANIAN EX-AIDE ON TRIAL SAID TO CLASH WITH JUDGE
abstract: A former Deputy Prime Minister accused of collaborating with the United States was reported today to have clashed repeatedly with the judge at the reopening of his trial in a special prison courtroom.   Former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam, who appeared again without a defense lawyer, insisted, despite many warnings from the judge, on conducting his own defense. The judge, Hojatolislam Mohammed Gilani, accused the defendant of interfering with the court's proceedings, which resumed yesterday after a two-week break.

headline: Communique by OPEC
abstract: Following is the text of the communique issued in English tonight by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the end of a two-day meeting of OPEC oil ministers:   The 60th meeting of the conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was held in Geneva, Switzerland, from 25th to 26th May 1981. H.E. Dr. Subroto, Minister of Mines and Energy of Indonesia and president of the 59th meeting of the conference, formally opened the conference by expressing, on behalf of their excellencies the heads of delegation and all delegates, the profound grief and shock felt on the sad occasion of the tragic death of H.E.  Dr. Jaime Roldos-Aguilera, president of Ecuador, his wife, and a number of high-ranking officers of his Cabinet.   The conference unanimously re-elected as its president H.E. Dr.  Subroto. H.E. Mallam Yahaya Dikko, presidential adviser on petroleum and energy of Nigeria and head of its delegation, was unanimously elected alternate president.   The conference decided to entrust the Long-Term Strategy Committee, under the chairmanship of H.E. Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources of Saudi Arabia, with the further review of OPEC's long-term strategy and present a report to the conference as soon as possible.

headline: Credit Markets; NEW 20-YEAR BOND SETS RECORD
abstract: The Treasury sold 20-year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 13.45 percent, a record for a new issue of that maturity, and one that demonstrated the reluctance of many investors to buy additional long-term bonds.   Elsewhere in the credit markets, short-term rates were mixed with Treasury bills declining while some other rates increased. Long-term rates were unchanged to slightly higher.   ''The dealers expected to be the biggest buyers of the 20-year Treasury bond,'' one Government securities specialist said, ''so they have been pushing prices down in the hope of attracting more buyers.'' He added that so far investors had been slow to buy or show interest in $1.75 billion of new 13 3/8 percent 20-year Treasury bonds, $3.25 billion of 14 percent four-year notes sold Tuesday, and $3 billion of seven-year notes to be sold next Tuesday.

headline: Company News; Textron Plans to Sell 2 Units With Losses
abstract: Textron Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell two subsidiaries for about $66 million to Nucon Holding Inc., a recently formed private company.

headline: DELOREAN
abstract: To the Business Editor: Engineers should run the auto business? Everyone knows that engineers run trains not on time, not cost effectively and not for their employers' profit. Once it was preaching ''production wisdom,'' then, economists' expertise and, now, Mr. DeLorean, how many years late in producing his cars, thinks engineers are the answer.

headline: U.S. CITES PAKISTANI PLEDGE NOT TO MAKE ATOM ARMS
abstract: Pakistan has given the Reagan Administration ''absolute assurances'' that it is neither developing nor planning to develop nuclear weapons, Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley said today.   ''I was assured by the ministers and by the President himself that it was not the intention of the Pakistan Government to develop nuclear weapons,'' he told a Senate Government Affairs subcommittee.   Mr. Buckley added that Pakistan, which has not signed a 1968 treaty to curb the spread of nuclear weapons technology, had made no promise not to seek a weapons-making ability or nuclear explosions such as one by India in 1974.   ''One has to make a distinction between the nuclear option and nuclear weapon,'' he told the Senate panel.

headline: PENNEY STORE CLOSES IN FOUNDER'S TOWN
abstract: Here, where James Cash Penney was born and reared, his memory is very much alive. But after 57 years the town's J.C.  Penney store isn't.   The store's manager, Mike McKay, locked its doors for the last time late Saturday. Penney Store No. 0500-9 has gone out of business because it was no longer profitable.

headline: I.B.M. Reduces Computer Prices
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation cut its prices on a line of small business computers by 20 to 25 percent.  The company said the price of the two least expensive models of its system 34 computers was being reduced by $5,000, from original prices of $20,310 and $22,090, respectively.

headline: Burroughs Reducing Computer Facilities
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation said it will close its computer-systems plant at Goleta, Calif., on Friday and will reduce employment at three Michigan plants and at Carlsbad, Calif.

headline: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRENCH MARKETS SEE VICTORY FOR GISCARD
abstract: If financial markets can foretell the future, one thing is certain about France's two-ballot Presidential election, which begins this Sunday: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is going to emerge victorious, giving France another seven years of moderate conservative governance.   The last time the French went to the polls, to elect a new Parliament in March 1978, the markets feared that the opposition alliance of Communists and Socialists would defeat the ruling Gaullist coalition and form the next government.   The stock market plunged, with the all-share index falling to 50, its lowest level ever. And the franc came under sustained pressure as private money sought refuge in Geneva, Zurich and New York.

headline: Business Conditions; ALL-ENCOMPASSING TV
abstract: Further evidence of television's pervasive reach into American life comes from the A.C. Nielsen Company in estimates based on recently released 1980 census figures on housing. The data showed that more than 80 million American homes now have TV sets - a 2.7 percent increase from figures compiled as recently as last September, when Nielsen's latest annual survey was taken.

headline: G.&W. Buys 5% Of National Steel
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has purchased 980,200 shares of the National Steel Corporation, or 5.17 percent of the common stock, for $25.7 million.   G.&W. said it had acquired the shares, at $23 to $30 each, for ''investment purposes.''

headline: Auto Layoffs Decline
abstract: The number of American auto workers on long-term layoffs fell to 168,650 this week, down 2,300 from 170,950 last week, as auto production climbed to its highest level in more than a year, according to industry reports today.

headline: Fujitsu Presents 2 New Computers
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's leading computer manufacturer, announced the development of two computers it says have the world's largest memory capacity and fastest data-processing speed.   It said the Facom M382, a dual-processor system, has a memory capacity equal to about 128 million letters -twice that of existing models.

headline: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Apr 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 40 Killed in Persian Gulf Storm
abstract: A rainstorm that moved across the Persian Gulf this week killed 40 people, including 33 in Oman, the Government said today. The 48-hour storm, which struck the United Arab Emirates, the southern Arabian Peninsula, the Horn of Africa and part of Iran, was described as ''the worst in living memory'' by the emirates' meteorological office.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Adage Inc. said it planned a public offering of 500,000 common shares, of which 400,000 would be offered by the company and the rest by shareholders.   * Canon Inc., a Japanese camera manufacturer, said it would issue $50 million worth of private-placement convertible debentures in the United States to raise funds for equipment investment.

headline: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE AT CHUBB NOW CHAIRMAN, TOO
abstract: Henry U. Harder, 56, president and chief executive officer of the Chubb Corporation, has been named to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds William M. Rees, who retired from the New Yorkbased insurance holding company at the mandatory retirement age of 65.

headline: SACRED SERBIAN SITE DAMAGED BY BLAZE
abstract: Before daybreak on March 16, the Patriarchate of Pec, which had survived invasion and occupation by the Ottoman Turks, was heavily damaged by fire.   A whole wing of the complex was demolished, including the living quarters of the Patriarch, the nun's refectory, a sick ward, a workshop and priceless icons and books. There were no injuries.   Officially, no cause has been given for the fire. The director of the Institute for the Protection of Monuments declined today to provide any information on the possible causes, merely saying that the case was under investigation.

headline: Company News; American Financial
abstract: The American Financial Corporation, which on March 4 disclosed that it owned 7.8 percent of the stock of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, reported in another Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it now owned about 530,000 shares of the steel company, or a 13.6 percent interest. It stated in the past that the purchase was for investment.

headline: Around the World; Barbados Judge Rules Biggs Must Be Returned to Britain
abstract: A Barbados judge ruled today that Ronald Biggs should be extradited to Britain to serve the rest of a 30-year-sentence for his role in the $7.3 million Great Train Robbery.   Civil Court Judge Frank King sent Mr. Biggs back to prison and said he had 15 days to file an appeal or a writ of habeas corpus.

headline: REQUEST CALLED ROUTINE
abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that, acting on a request by the Israeli Government, it had advised Israeli scientists last Oct. 9 about the amount of damage that would be inflicted on a nuclear reactor by 1,000-kilogram (2,200-pound) bombs.   Bombs of that size were apparently used by Israeli planes June 7 to destroy an Iraqi nuclear reactor that was nearing completion near Baghdad. Tonight, a spokesman at the Israeli Embassy said the visit in October had nothing to do with the attack on the Iraqi installation.

headline: Iran Reports 7 Persons Executed On Charges of Narcotics Dealing
abstract: Seven persons were executed today, six of them in public, on charges of narcotics dealing, the offical Pars press agency reported.   Pars said that the seven, one a woman, had been found guilty by a special court of smuggling heroin and distibuting heroin and other narcotics.   One of those executed was said to be an internationally known drug dealer.

headline: INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Raising Money For Oil and Gas
abstract: WALL STREET has been devising new ways to raise money for oil and natural gas programs at a time when drilling needs have outpaced capital development. The latest approach is a novel one that permits individual investors to convert unmarketable oil and gas interests into a new company's marketable common shares.   Integrated Energy Inc. has just obtained Securities and Exchange Commission approval for the plan. Under the financing, investors who have participated in oil and gas plans with other companies can pledge their holdings for Integrated's common shares.

headline: Hungary Plans 5-Day Workweek, Joining All in Bloc but Rumania
abstract: The Government of Hungary, evidently seeking to avert labor unrest, has taken its first step toward instituting a five-day workweek.

headline: DOW JUMPS 12.88 ON RATE HOPES
abstract: Hopes that interest rates are near their peak touched off a rousing rally in the stock market yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.88 points, to 985.95. Advancing groups on the New York Stock Exchange ranged from brokerage, airline and electronic issues to the aerospace, aluminum and energy sectors.   Volume widened to 45.5 million shares from 42.8 million on Thursday, when the Dow rose 5.31 points.  ''Stocks are climbing because of signs that the interest rate cycle is close to peaking,'' said Raymond F. DeVoe Jr., market strategist at Bruns, Nordeman, Rea & Company. ''Another source of strength comes from conjecture that the Reagan Administration may compromise on its tax-cut proposals that many people regard as inflationary.''

headline: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN EL SALVADOR, NO ESCAPE FROM THE HORRORS OF WAR
abstract: A resident was talking about what it's like to live in El Salvador these days.  ''A secretary who works here was with her mother when a truck backfired,'' he said. ''She instantly pushed her to the ground and threw herself on top of her. They were in Detroit.''   A tailor in the poor industrial suburb of Soyapango complained that on several occasions killers had dumped bodies on the doorstep of his home. ''I just tried to look straight ahead and step over them,'' he said. He arched his leg and resolutely demonstrated the maneuver.   ''When I'm going into the city,'' a lawyer's wife said, ''I usually call up first and find out if there's any violent activity going on.  It's like people in the States asking how the traffic is. If it's bad, I rearrange my schedule and show up later.''

headline: Saudis Cut LPG Price
abstract: The Saudi Arabian state-run oil company, Petromin, has cut its export price for liquefied petroleum gas to Japan by $40 a ton, to $255, effective immediately, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today. Japan imported 10 million tons of LPG in the fiscal year 1980, 3 percent more than in the previous year, with half of it supplied by Petromin, the ministry said.

headline: POLISH COMMUNISTS ASSURE THEIR ALLIES THEY WILL END CRISIS
abstract: The Polish Communists, facing mounting pressure from their allies for speedy action, pledged here today to seek a ''political solution'' of the Polish crisis by mobilizing the party for a struggle against enemies of Communism and ''counterrevolutionaries.''   Speaking at the East German party congress in the presence of Warsaw Pact allies and delegates from Communist parties all over the world, Kazimierz Barcikowski, a member of the Polish Politburo, said the party was determined to assert its authority and ''find a way to settle the complicated and difficult problems that have arisen in Poland as a result of the severe social and economic crisis.''   Mr. Barcikowski's indirect request for more time to resolve Poland's difficulties came after rank-and-file East German delegates had bluntly urged a crackdown on dissidents, saying party action was ''overdue.''

headline: Penn Central's Profit Up 75.1%
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation, which emerged from bankruptcy in 1978 as the successor to the Penn Central Transportation Company, yesterday reported that first-quarter earnings rose 75.1 percent on a 47 percent increase in revenues.

headline: Venezuela Gets U.S. Support For Latin Economic Plan
abstract: Venezuelan officials said today that they had found support in the Reagan Administration for a multinational economic development program to enhance the stability of democratic governments in the Caribbean and Central America.   The first test of this economic cooperation will be in El Salvador, said Rafael Montes de Oca, Venezuela's Interior Minister.

headline: COUP BID HASN'T DETERRED SPAIN'S FOREIGN INVESTORS
abstract: The mood of political uncertainty that has enveloped Spain since February's attempted military coup d'etat so far seems to have had relatively little impact on the flow of foreign investment into the country.   In the wake of the attempted rightist takeover, which was aimed at overturning the country's five-year-old democracy, representatives from multinational companies have trooped to Spain to take its weak economic and political pulse. The influx of capital is below the 1979 peak, but the decline does not seem to have been aggravated by the coup attempt.   Multinational companies that expect to use Spain as a springboard into the European Common Market appear to regard the country still as a good bet: Without democracy, Spain would be rejected by the European Economic Community. But some potential foreign investors also seem to have come to the distinct conclusion that a lurch back to more authoritarian rule would not be altogether bad for business.

headline: HOME REPAIR GAINS SPUR EXPANSION AT HECHINGER CO.
abstract: ''If you can't find it at Hechinger, either it doesn't exist or it isn't worth owning,'' said Philip J.  Mansfield, the company's executive vice president.   Mr. Mansfield was referring to the Hechinger Company's promise to its customers that each of its stores, with 60,000 square feet of sales space, displays the widest assortment of merchandise ''stored under one roof.''   Each store stocks more than seven million feet of board lumber and approximately 40,000 other building materials, and an inventory of hardware and home improvement brand name products - primarily nationally advertised. The company calls this comprehensive sales concept ''category dominance.''

headline: SHELL'S SUCCESS IN OIL BIDDING
abstract: This is a story of high-stakes corporate gambling by tight-lipped men in well-tailored suits.  The stakes run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Promising ''playing cards'' are given the names of women, cocktails or automobile parts to mask their identities. Bagmen with access to very big money roam the city.   ''We have all kinds of weapons in our arsenal for all kinds of purposes,'' one player averred, with the slightest of smiles.For all its romance, however, the game being played here is unlikely to arouse the suspicion of the authorities. Indeed, it has been openly endorsed by the Secretary of Interior, who has even suggested that it should be expanded tenfold over the next five years. Wagering Began 17 Years Ago   The game is the auctioning of Federal real estate off the coast of the United States to oil and gas companies. Since the wagering began 17 years ago, companies have bet more than $30 billion to win a chance at spending billions more in search of underground riches.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Down the Slippery Slope
abstract: Soviet officials from Ambassador Dobrynin on down are buttonholing other foreign diplomats to ask: ''Do you think the Americans will talk?'' The Russians seem desperate to arrange a forum for the discussion of disarmament.   Why? Because the Soviet Union, at the moment, needs to launch a new ''peace offensive.'' After its aggression in Afghanistan and its temptation to use force in Poland, the Soviet Union is once again seen by many Europeans to be a genuine threat. To lull the West back into a false sense of security - and in particular, to prevent the Europeans from letting the U.S. deploy theater nuclear weapons to counter the SS-20 missile threatening Europe - the Russians need a propaganda forum.

headline: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRACKING FAMILY INCOME
abstract: To get a clearer picture of earnings among working families, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has developed a new demographically based survey of wages and salaries that is gaining popularity among economists.   Changes in the composition of the workforce-more women, more households with a single parent and more families with more than one wage earner-prompted the need for the new data, which established B.L.S. earnings surveys could not measure.

headline: 11 DIE AS SOUTH LEBANON FIGHTING WORSENS
abstract: Fighting between Israeli-backed Christian forces and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon intensified today, and the Lebanese authorities reported that at least 11 people were killed and 40 wounded.   Christian militiamen shelled the ports of Tyre and Sidon. The Sidon Governor's office reported tonight that one shell, allegedly fired by Christians, landed on a police barracks housing refugees.  Four people died in the attack, the Governor's office said, including two children, and 12 people were injured. On Sunday, 22 people died in shelling of Sidon by Christian forces.

headline: GREAT BASINS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GLASROCK MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Britain Says Hunger Striker Briefly Considered Eating
abstract: The British Government said today that a jailed Irish Republican Army member, reported close to death after a 58-day-old hunger strike, had asked for food over the weekend but later changed his mind.   Sinn Fein, the political wing of the outlawed I.R.A., said the report about Raymond McCreesh was without foundation.

headline: Salvador Denies Rebel Claim Of Killing 140 Soldiers
abstract: Guerrillas asserted in clandestine broadcasts yesterday that they had overrun the northern town of Arcatao near the Honduran border and killed 140 soldiers.

headline: Letters; MEMTO TO THE FED: DISREGARD PREVIOUS MEMO
abstract: To the Business Editor: Mr. Wright expresses the wish that the Federal Reserve Board be re-educated, assuming that a re-educated Fed would lower interest rates. In that, he is typical of many sensible men who have listened too much to economists.

headline: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PITNEY-BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-Soviet Grain Pact Sought
abstract: Efforts to reach a new long-term agreement to supply the Soviet Union with American grain has been given ''very high priority'' within the Reagan Administration, but no deadline has been set, a senior Agriculture Department official said today.   ''We'll pursue this just as rapidly as we can,'' Under Secretary Seeley G. Lodwick said.

headline: 2 Pitching Sensations At White House Lunch
abstract: President Reagan, a Hall of Fame pitcher in the movies, today met Fernando Valenzuela, a rookie pitching sensation from Mexico who has Los Angeles Dodger fans predicting that he, too, will make it to Cooperstown.   Mr. Valenzuela, a 20-year-old lefthander with a baffling screwball and a bulging waistline, attended a White House state luncheon in honor of President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico.

headline: Jersey Asks to Void Caesars Stock Sale
abstract: The Attorney General of New Jersey asked a state court today to nullify the sale of more than $5 million in Caesars World Inc. stock to the gambling company's founders.   Attorney General James R. Zazzali said the action was a new facet in a case before the Appellate Division of Superior Court, in which the state is trying to force the company's founder to get out or have Caesars give up operation of its Boardwalk Regency casino hotel in Atlantic City.   The state's lawsuit claims that the proposed sale of 450,000 Caesars World shares by William McElnea Jr., of Bel Air, Calif., who resigned as president last month, to Clifford and Stewart Perlman, the company's founders, would further complicate an existing court case.

headline: Lion in Zimbabwe Kills Mother and 3 Children
abstract: A lion killed a woman and her three children in a village in northeastern Zimbabwe, a national parks spokesman said today.

headline: HOLDERS CRITICIZE AMAX CHIEF
abstract: The management of Amax Inc. was strongly criticized by stockholders at the company's annual meeting in New York yesterday for its rejection of a $4 billion takeover bid by the Standard Oil Company of California.   Walter Hochschild, Amax's retired 80-year-old chairman and a major Amax shareholder, was roundly applauded when he told more than 1,000 shareholders at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel: ''In my opinion, a merger with Socal would make a great deal of sense, provided terms are satisfactory.''   The pronouncement is understood to have taken many Amax executives by surprise. It also established that at least two directors of Amax, other than the three Socal directors on the Amax board, favored the proposed merger.

headline: Coca Cola Prediction
abstract: First-quarter operating and net income for the Coca-Cola Company will likely be 6 percent to 10 percent above 1980 levels, the company said.   The projected rise is the result of higher profits per unit and better management, the Atlanta-based company said in a release.

headline: ENVIROTECH'S SUDDEN STUMBLE
abstract: The Envirotech Corporation, a pollution control equipment manufacturer that grew rich on the environmental fervor of the 1970's, finds itself facing a huge debt, slow sales and heavy losses.   The Menlo Park, Calif., company has moved to disengage itself from operations in air pollution control products, but it says that it still has the largest line of waste water equipment in the country.   Envirotech, blaming the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for a large share of its problems, has said that it is now focusing its operations on the production of equipment for mining and other industrial processes. The company asserts that the E.P.A. is taking steps to make changes in its procedures, as it was asked to do by Envirotech and several other leading companies in the industry.

headline: F.C.C. Weighs Appeal by RKO
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today took under advisement a request by lawyers for RKO General Inc. that the agency reconsider its decision to strip the company of valuable television stations in Boston, New York and Los Angeles.   The disciplinary move made last year by the F.C.C. has been appealed by RKO lawyers in the United States Court of Appeals here.

headline: A REAGAN NOTE TO BREZHNEV TELLS OF CONCERN ON POLAND
abstract: President Reagan, using what an American official called ''strong language,'' has sent Leonid I. Brezhnev a message expressing the Administration's extreme concern over the situation in Poland.   Defense Department officials said the letter, which was sent Friday night, underscored the gravity with which the Reagan Administration viewed the Soviet military buildup in and around Poland. An official said that Mr. Reagan told Mr. Brezhnev, the Soviet President and party leader, that an incursion into Poland would ''totally disrupt'' the possibility of negotiations to limit arms.   State Department and White House officials stressed that the message was not a warning or threat by Mr. Reagan.  William J. Dyess, a State Department spokesman, declined to characterize Mr. Reagan's message and he said that ''the message should not be considered out of the ordinary in a tense situation like this.'' He said it was to be expected, under the circumstances, that Mr. Reagan would communicate with Mr. Brezhnev.

headline: Prospects
abstract: Mr. Reagan's Tax Problem   As the May 15 deadline for a joint budget resolution nears, support for the Administration's tax and budget cutting programs appears strong. However, many Congress-watchers remain convinced that compromise is inevitable when individual committees begin to pare their own budgets next month.   Although last week's vote on the House budget proposal gave the White House a stunning victory, some economists say the Administration needs even more firepower. In light of recent indications of unexpectedly fast growth and rapidly decelerating inflation the President's program could use signs of renewed economic weakness in order to convince Congress the nation needs the Reagan tax cut program.

headline: SUZUKI SAYS HE WILL PRESS REAGAN ON SHIP SINKING DURING U.S. VISIT
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki told Parliament today that he would ask President Reagan about the collision between an American submarine and a Japanese freighter at their meeting in Washington next month.   Mr. Suzuki described the accident last Thursday, which resulted in the sinking of the freighter and the deaths of two of its crew, as ''very regrettable and a big shock to me.''   The Japanese have said that the nuclear submarine, the George Washington, failed to pick up the 13 survivors of the collision and that the United States Navy did not report the incident promptly. The dispute over the collision comes at a time when the United States is trying hard to obtain an increased Japanese military commitment.

headline: Around the World; Manila Seizes Eight It Says Plotted Widespread Terror
abstract: The office of President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that eight people had been arrested in what it said was a terrorist plot prepared by a fugitive opposition leader with aid from Libyan-based Moslem rebels.   A statement issued by the presidential palace said that the plot included assassinations and bombings to be carried out nationwide in an effort to disrupt presidential elections June 16.   The statement said the plot was an outgrowth of a recent meeting in the Middle East between a former opposition Senator, Benigno S.  Aquino Jr., who is now living in Boston, and Nur Misuari, the Libyabased chairman of the Moro National Liberation Front, which has waged an eight-year guerrilla campaign for Moslem rule in the southern Philippines.

headline: INSURER OF TROUBLED THRIFT UNITS
abstract: The discotheque in the basement of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board building a block from the White House is named, appropriately enough, the Buck Stops Here.   Upstairs in the offices of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the subsidiary of the bank board that is the main insurer of deposits, computer simulations are being run on the 4,700 federally chartered savings and loan associations.   Fed by the monthly financial data generated by the institutions - numbers on income, net worth, deposits, withdrawals, mortgage portfolio yields and average cost of deposits - the computer spews out the names of ''problem'' institutions that could face insolvency within two years if corrective steps are not taken.   The insurer's computers are where the buck really stops, and they are now running overtime, having already identified 263 problem institutions, up from 246 in March and 120 at the end of 1980.

headline: Washington Watch; A Challenge To Canada
abstract: THE St. Joe Minerals Corporation has started what could be another altercation with Canada. This time it involves a little-known provision of the Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920, which the big mineral extraction corporation wants to use to fend off any new bid by the Seagram Company Ltd.   The Fluor Corporation's recent $60-a-share cash and stock package for St. Joe was hastily put together in a merger proposal designed to keep St. Joe out of Seagram's grasp.   But fearing a new offer by the huge Canadian distiller, St. Joe has now petitioned Interior Secretary James G. Watt to get Canada stricken from a list of so-called reciprocal countries that may control leases on Federal lands if, under the terms of the statute, they grant the United States ''similar or like privileges.''

headline: MEAD SAYS IMPACT OF SUIT IS EXAGGERATED
abstract: The Mead Corporation said yesterday that the potential effect of the Supreme Court's recent announcement in the long-running corrugated-container antitrust case had been misrepresented in news reports.   The diversified forest products company contended that the amounts of possible damages cited came solely from ''inflated and irresponsible speculative reports'' that followed a civil trial in Houston last summer. Those reports have estimated Mead's liability between $350 million and $1 billion.

headline: McGraw-Hill Net Up
abstract: McGraw-Hill Inc., one of the nation's biggest publishing companies, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 15.4 percent, to $17.2 million, or 69 cents a share, from $14.9 million, or 60 cents a share, in the same period of 1980 as the performance of the company's information services operations and the sale of a publication helped increase profits. Revenues for the latest quarter were $234.6 million, up 9.7 percent from $213.8 million a year earlier. Sharply lower borrowing costs and a gain from the sale of Medical World News in early March also contributed to improved earnings, McGraw said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1981
abstract: The Economy   The Senate Finance Committee approved President Reagan's proposal to reduce individual tax rates 25 percent across-the-board over 33 months, starting Oct. 1, 1981. Meanwhile, the House Ways and Means Committee approved $3.3 billion of special tax relief to six basic industries in the next four years. (D1.)   The Treasury Department is investigating Norman B. Ture's role earlier this year in arranging a $223,000 noncompetitive Treasury contract for an economic forecasting model that Mr. Ture, Under Secretary of Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs, had developed and partially owned. Earlier Mr. Ture had been cleared by the Treasury's general counsel's office of any violation of Federal conflict-ofinterest laws. (A1.)

headline: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 MISSING IN TANKER FIRE IN RIO
abstract: A 13,000-ton oil tanker, the Jari, exploded and caught fire while at anchor in Rio's Guanabara Bay last night, severely burning one man on a nearby barge, authorities said.  Two deckhands from the barge were reported missing today. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

headline: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cablevision Merger Waiting Period Ends
abstract: Columbia Cablevision Inc., Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. and Dow Jones & Company said they had been advised by the Federal Trade Commission that the antitrust waiting period with respect to the merger of UA-Columbia into a joint company owned by Knight-Ridder and Dow Jones ended last Friday.   UA-Columbia has agreed to a merger with a joint-venture company of Dow Jones and Knight-Ridder at a price of $80 a share, or $265.2 million, for all the 3.3 million shares outstanding.   The move is being bitterly contested by the United Artists Theatre Circuit, which has made a conditional offer for 735,000 UA-Columbia shares at $90 a share conditioned on 735,000 UA-Columbia shares being tendered.

headline: Turkey Hints It Won't Help If U.S. Acts Alone in Gulf
abstract: Turkish officials indicated today that their country would not be available for bases to support an American rapid deployment force if the United States took unilateral action in the Persian Gulf area.   Defense Minister Haluk Bayulken said that ''the people in the area say the question of defending that area is a question for them.''

headline: HOME SALES UP BY 0.6% FOR MARCH
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses rose six-tenths of 1 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 511,000, despite continued high mortgage interest rates, the Government reported today.   Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said the slight increase in March was hardly encouraging because ''the sales level is so low now that it's kind of academic.'' He blamed continuing high interest rates for the low sales, which he said have not picked up much in April, if at all.

headline: EQUAL RIGHTS PROVISION ADDED TO CONSTITUTION IN SWISS REFERENDUM
abstract: Swiss voters approved an amendment to the Constitution today strengthening guarantees of equality between the sexes in education, industry and in the home.   The amendment also appears to provide a basis for efforts to end discrimination in the last few regions of Switzerland in which women are denied even the right to vote in local elections.   Expanding an article in the Constitution that proclaims that ''all Swiss are equal under the law,'' the amendment makes explicit that women as well as men are entitled to ''equal rights.''   The amendment was approved by a vote of 797,679 to 525,950, with all but 9 of the 26 cantons that form the Swiss confederation recording a majority for the measure.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Enhancing Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Law of the Sea Conference Special Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dutch Journalist Ousted by China After Forming Ties to Dissidents
abstract: A Dutch newspaper correspondent, Willem E.C.  Van Kemenade, departed today for Taiwan, complying with the Chinese Government's request that he leave because of ''inappropriate'' behavior.   Mr. Van Kemenade, accredited since September as a correspondent for the newspaper NRC Handelsblad, said that although the Chinese authorities had protested his presence, his newspaper had not ''recalled'' him.   Mr. Van Kemenade, who speaks Chinese, and his Chinese-born wife, a writer whose family fled to Taiwan after the 1949 Communist takeover, had cultivated relationships with Chinese dissidents.

headline: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL TO SELL ROTHESAY
abstract: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest-products company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its subsidiary, Mac-Millan Rothesay Ltd., to the Irving Interests, a diversified company with interests in energy and pulp and paper. The company said that the total price is $145 million (Canadian).

headline: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Blacks in South Africa Town Riot Over Increase in Rent
abstract: Blacks in Tembisa township rioted today over a rent increase and the police broke up the disturbance with tear gas, authorities said.

headline: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 28, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Differences over a tax-relief bill have been narrowed, said Bob Dole, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. They indicated the next concession had to come from President Reagan. Mr. Rostenkowski said disagreements remained over such issues as the across-the-board rate cuts favored by the Administration. (Page A1.)   United States business productivity rose 4.3 percent during the first quarter, its largest gain in three and a half years, the Labor Department reported. The gain, revised from an earlier estimate of 3.9 percent, was said to reflect the economy's overall strength.  (D1.)

headline: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Banks Seek Plan on Polish Debt
abstract: International banks will try to reach a compromise here tomorrow to ease Poland's crushing burden of foreign debt, on which repayments are becoming increasingly difficult for Warsaw.   A group of 19 banks, representing Poland's 460 creditor banks, will seek an agreement on extending repayments on an estimated $2.37 billion in commercial loans due this year, banking sources said.

headline: Fox Film Falls 61.5% in Quarter
abstract: A drop in earnings from the licensing of feature films to television and poor snow conditions at its Colorado ski resort reduced the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation's first-quarter profits by 61.5 percent, to $11.5 million, from $29.9 million a year earlier, the company said today.   Fox Film's earnings amounted to $1 a share, down from $2.74 a share in the comparable 1980 period. Revenues for the latest quarter rose to $244.1 million, from $210.3 million a year ago.

headline: Reagan Aide, in Salisbury, Rules Out 'Tilt' on Apartheid
abstract: Chester A. Crocker, President Reagan's Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, said today that there would be no ''tilt or endorsement of apartheid'' in South Africa by the Reagan Administration.   Mr. Crocker spoke to reporters at the airport on his arrival here on his fourth stop in a 10-nation tour of Africa.

headline: Company News; Shell-Saudi Oil Pact
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said that it had concluded an agreement with Saudi Arabia giving it access to about 1.33 billion barrels of Saudi crude oil over the next 15 years. Dirk de Bruyne, group president, said in his annual report that the supply stemmed from an agreement to build a petrochemicals complex and refinery at Jubail. The refinery would be a joint venture with the Saudi state concern, Petromin, and the petrochemicals complex would be a joint venture between the Shell Oil Company of the United States and the Saudi Basic Resources Corporation, he said.

headline: Arab Emirates' Oil Net Up
abstract: The United Arab Emirates earned $18.5 billion in 1980 from oil exports, nearly 50 percent more than 1979's $12.5 billion, central bank figures show. A bank report quoted by the official Emirates news agency said revenues rose despite a fall in oil exports to 1.71 million barrels a day in 1980, from 1.82 million in 1979, presumably as a result of crude oil price increases. The United Arab Emirates' current-account surplus at the end of 1980 totaled $5 billion, up from $2.5 billion at the end of 1979, the report said.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Intelligence analysts here and in other NATO capitals say they expect a revival, and perhaps an intensification, of the war between Iran and Iraq.   A gradual increase in the number of Iranian air attacks is expected to be followed by an offensive against strong Iraqi positions in the oil province of Khuzistan. One interpretation of Iranian preparations is that the Teheran Government has lost hope in mediation efforts by the Islamic League and the United Nations.   Recent reports from Teheran, confirmed by reconnaissance photographs, disclosed a significant buildup of military supplies in depots in and around the capital. They included large quantities of plasma and other medical supplies, a sign, analysts said, that Iran is preparing for heavy fighting later in the spring.

headline: Advertising; Kurtz & Tarlow Resigns Tyco Toy Account
abstract: Kurtz & Tarlow announced yesterday that it had resigned the Tyco Industries toy account. The agency also noted that the client had already decided on its new agency, but the client reported that at the request of the new shop it was withholding for the moment the name.   The measured media billings are in the $3 million to $3.5 million range, it is understood, and Tyco says that its total promotion budget is $8.7 million

headline: 10 San Remo Croupiers Accused Of Vast Roulette Fraud at Casino
abstract: Ten croupiers from the San Remo casino on the Italian Riviera were arrested today and accused of taking part in a multimillion-dollar bet-fixing swindle, the police reported.   The arrests brought to 60 the number of casino employees and customers implicated in the case, which the police began investigating last January.

headline: ROOTS OF YUGOSLAV RIOTS: VAGUE 'ENEMY' BLAMED
abstract: Even in the cold, dreary rain, women of Albanian ancestry with white headscarfs and long floral print skirts or baggy trousers strolled along the main street pausing to admire the window displays of modern dress shops, furniture stores and supermarkets.   There was little evidence that this provincial capital had been the scene two weeks ago of the worst riots in Yugoslavia since World War II. The only signs were a few remaining smashed windows, police on patrol, army guards at public buildings and the nervousness of people when asked about the events.   A state of emergency remains in force but has been relaxed in Kosovo Province, which borders on Albania and has one and a half million inhabitants, most of Albanian ancestry.   A curfew has been lifted, grade school students have gone back to classes, and the university, where the troubles began, is to open tomorrow.
