abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ST PAUL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLLOCK PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VOTING IS HEAVY IN IRELAND'S PARLIAMENTARY ELECTION
abstract: Irish voters turned out in substantial numbers today for a parliamentary election in which Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey was seeking a five-year mandate for his program of ''providing better living standards for all'' and of trying to negotiate with the British some constitutional initiative in Northern Ireland.   ''We have the opportunity to choose the kind of Ireland in which we wish to live,'' Prime Minister Haughey, who took office 18 months ago without an election, said in his final appeal to the voters on behalf of the governing Fianna Fail Party.   The voting, which was heavy in many places despite constant rain, took place at a time of increased tension and uncertainty caused by the continuing hunger strike by nationalist inmates of a British prison in Northern Ireland. Four men have starved themselves to death there in the last six weeks, and four other hunger strikers are among nine prisoners running for Parliament in this election.

headline: Hong Kong Banking Bills
abstract: The Hong Kong Government has introduced legislation to strengthen ''prudential supervision'' of banks and deposit-taking companies.

headline: S.E.C. SET TO ORDER STOCK TRADING LINK
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to issue an order on Tuesday that an automated computerized trading link be established between the nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market, agency and industry sources said.   The issuance of such an order, which would come just days before the swearing-in of the next agency chairman, John S.R. Shad, has been strongly opposed by the New York Stock Exchange and key Congressional Republicans. Mr. Shad, the sources said, has nonetheless given his approval for the commission's expected action.   The S.E.C. will be taking the action, sources said, because it concluded that a computerized trading link is needed to implement the 1975 law requiring the agency to ''facilitate'' development of a national market system for stock trading. Such a market, Congress had said, should employ advanced technology to link trading markets to insure that investors receive the best price on stock trades regardless of location.

headline: STEELMAKERS OPTIMISTIC DESPITE SOFTENING ORDERS
abstract: Some steel executives who gathered at their annual convention here said yesterday that orders for steel have begun to soften, but they do not yet foresee a repetition of the sharp drop that occurred last May.   David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel company, told a reporter at the American Iron and Steel Institute meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that unlike last year, there was still a general mood of optimism.   ''We've seen some softening,'' he said, but he added that July orders still looked good.  William J. De Lancey, the chairman and chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation, made a similar assessment at a news conference. He said there was some evidence of softening, due mostly to seasonal factors such as model change-over by the auto industry and anticipated summer shutdowns by some industrial plants.

headline: ANDERSON, GREENWOOD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 13 Men Reported Executed In Liberia for Plotting Coup
abstract: Thirteen army men accused of trying to overthrow the Liberian regime of Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe have been executed,well-placed diplomatic sources said today.   J. Kringa Kahnchea-Harris, the Liberian Assistant Minister of Foreign Affairs, said in a brief interview here this afternoon that the 13 men had been arrested while plotting to take over the Government while Sergeant Doe was in neighboring Sierra Leone recently on a diplomatic mission.

headline: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MASTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BONN OFFICIAL SEES WELFARE CUTS AHEAD
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, addressing the national convention of his Free Democratic Party, asserted today that cuts in West Germany's social welfare budget were unavoidable, a position that could lead to conflict with his Social Democratic partners in the governing coalition.   Budget deficits have made reductions in public spending a necessity, Mr. Genscher, the Free Democrats' leader, told an enthusiastic crowd at the party congress in Cologne. ''Cosmetic operations are not enough,'' he added.

headline: TRUDEAU SAYS HE WILL STEER SUMMIT MEETING IN JULY TO BASIC ISSUES
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who will preside over the summit meeting here next month of seven leading industrial nations, said today that he would seek to force a choice between ''papering over differences'' or seeking basic agreements that would allow the West to ''manage'' political and economic crises in the world.   ''I think it will be a difficult summit without assurance of success,'' Mr. Trudeau said at a news conference. He added that it would be ''the first real summit'' because it would deal with basic subjects.

headline: U.S. House Panel Votes To Honor Wallenberg
abstract: A special subcommittee of the House of Representatives voted today to confer honorary United States citizenship on Raoul Wallenberg, a Swede credited with saving the lives of 100,000 Hungarian Jews at the end of World War II.

headline: Morocco Holds Elections
abstract: Morocco held parliamentary elections today in the southern part of the former Spanish Sahara that it annexed in 1979. Morocco took over the area after Mauritania withdrew under a peace agreement with Algerian-backed guerrillas who have been fighting for the independence of the area since 1976. The inhabitants of the sparsely populated territory were due to elect three deputies to the Moroccan Parliament for the first time since they came under Moroccan rule.

headline: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: President of Texaco Unit
abstract: C. Robert Black, 45, has been named president of Texaco International Trader Inc., a major subsidiary of Texaco Inc. based in Harrison, N.Y. He succeeds Willis R. Buck, who died last month at the age of 53.   The subsidiary acquires crude oil and petroleum products as needed by the corporation and sells crudes and products when they are not needed by the Texaco organization.

headline: AARQUE UNIT TO BUY SUBSIDIARY OF GAF
abstract: The GAF Corporation, undergoing a major realignment, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its graphic reproductions business to a unit of the Aarque Companies for about $80 million.   Robert Button, GAF spokesman, said the transaction was ''the last major piece, but not the last piece'' of a sweeping restructuring plan the diversified company disclosed last December.   The New York-based company said on Dec. 30 that it sought to reduce its debt and strengthen its basic chemicals and building materials operations with proceeds from the sale of eight of its other businesses that accounted for 49 percent of its sales in 1979.

headline: Deltona Net Up 60%
abstract: The Deltona Corporation, a land and housing developer, said first-quarter profits rose 60 percent, to $1.44 million, or 36 cents a share, from $901,000, or 23 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1980. The company said sales climbed 82 percent in the period, to $66.1 million, from $36.3 million. The company said land sales rose 12 percent while housing revenues more than tripled.

headline: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YUGOSLAV OFFICIAL CALLS RIOTS A SURPRISE
abstract: Yugoslavia's leaders were caught off guard by the extent and the intensity of last week's rioting by ethnic Albanians in which 11 people were killed and 57 wounded, it was acknowledged today.   This admission was made by a senior Communist Party official who gave the first detailed official account of the incidents that forced the Government to proclaim a state of emergency in Kosovo Province.   Stane Dolanc, a member of the party's Presidium, attributed the incidents to Albanian nationalists with links to Yugoslavs abroad who he said were either ''pro-Fascist'' or ''pro-Cominform.'' He said the emigre groups were in Stuttgart, West Germany, as well as Brussels, other European nations and the United States.

headline: Company News; Ontario to Consider Massey Stock Bill
abstract: The Ontario government has introduced a bill in the provincial legislature to authorize the purchase of up to $78 million in Massey-Ferguson preferred shares under terms of a $700 million refinancing program worked out for the ailing farm-equipment maker.

headline: Commodities; Limiting Contracts On Futures
abstract: ONE of the oldest controversies in the commodity market began in 1938, when Congress imposed limits on the number of futures contracts that a speculator may hold. Even then it was considered a strange law because it covered domestic farm products, while exempting so-called '' foreign commodities'' such as sugar, copper and other metals.   Actually, the law was a sop to farm groups who blamed the futures markets for the low prices they received during the Depression years. As far as the trade was then concerned, they were more upset by the principle, than by the law's effect. Few speculators at the time ever dreamed of holding three million bushels of corn, wheat or soybeans, or 30,000 bales of cotton, which are still the position limits on these items, for example.

headline: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Beehive International is offering 551,000 shares of common stock at $14.875 a share today through a Shearson Loeb Rhoades group.   * Bell Telephone Co. of Pennsylvania's pending offering of $150 million of new 40-year debentures has been put on a delayed day-today-sales basis.

headline: TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The U.S. gross national product rose at a brisk 6.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, a surprisingly strong advance and the biggest since 1978's second quarter. G.N.P. statistics also indicated that inflation was easing. But Administration officials asserted that despite G.N.P. first quarter growth, the economy is now weakening, and therefore Congress should approve the Administration's program for tax cuts to stimulate growth. (Page A1.)   The Supreme Court said a union could not be forced to share an employer's financial liability for illegal employment discrimination. The 8-to-0 ruling in a case involving Northwest Airlines was considered a victory for organized labor. In other actions, the court let stand a judgment against the General Atomic Company growing out of uranium price rises, and it refused to hear the Justice Department's challenge to an F.C.C. action that allowed A.T.&T. to abandon its bulk discount rates for private line service. (D1.)

headline: Bonn Criticizes Steel Subsidies
abstract: A compromise agreement reached by the European Economic Community last week on ending official subsidies to Common Market steelmakers by 1985 is most likely to be approved by the West German Cabinet even though it considers the accord ''disappointing and unsatisfactory,'' a Government spokesman, Kurt Becker, said today.   He said that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany would raise the issue at the two-day Common Market meeting that opened today. Mr. Schmidt discussed the steel problem with key ministers in Bonn before his departure for Luxembourg.

headline: CASTRO ACCUSES U.S. OF BUILDING TENSION
abstract: President Fidel Castro said today that the threatening language and the military maneuvers of the Reagan Administration are turning Central America and the Caribbean ''into a hotbed of tension similar to that of the Persian Gulf, the Indian Ocean, the Middle East and Europe.''   The United States, he said, is trying to ''attack, to isolate and to impose a policy of pressure and blackmail against Cuba.'' ''Cuba is not threatening the United States,'' he said. ''In the face of threats, Cuba maintains a calm but responsible and firm attitude.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW FOCUS ON POWER-SHARING: MONEY
abstract: The door is kept locked on the new complex of offices that Prof. Jan Lombard occupies here, and there is no sign to identify them. Inside, the professor toils at finding the ways and means - especially the means - to give content to a slogan that has been presented as a main plank in the platform the governing National Party is offering to the all-white electorate, which goes to the polls in two weeks.   The slogan is ''Constellation of States.'' Supposedly it has something to do with the just economic and political order that Prime Minister P.W. Botha says he wishes to create in southern Africa. But the precise nature of that order, the questions of who will belong to it and on what terms, of how it can be expected to satisfy the aspirations of the various population groups in this white-dominated country, all remain a blur.   Sometimes ''constellation'' is used to describe the proposed political and military grouping that would be created to withstand the ''Marxist threat'' that southern Africa is supposed to be facing - not just South Africa and the tiny black states it has created within its borders, which were formerly known as homelands, but neighboring nations as well.

headline: SPOTLIGHT REMAKING THE GIBBS MYSTIQUE
abstract: When Lynn D. Salvage became president of the Katharine Gibbs School last January, many speculated that she had taken the post at the tradition-steeped secretarial school merely as a haven from the challenges of feminism and high finance that beset her during her tumultuous stewardship as president of the First Women's Bank.   But the 34-year-old Miss Salvage insists she is still blazing new trails, making her latest cause that of forging a new role for the Katharine Gibbs graduate - one that will transform the traditional symbol of fast-typing, white-gloved gentility into a major figure in the electronic offices of the 1980's.   ''We are fast moving toward the paperless office,'' Miss Salvage said, sipping white wine over an elegant French dinner at a Manhattan restaurant. ''We have a wealth of technology, but we do not have a wealth of people who know how to use it. Here at Gibbs, we aim to be the leader in developing the staff that will manage the office of the future. We are shedding our white gloves and progressing beyond our typewriters and steno pads to enter the arena of the tabletop computer and the word processor.''

headline: GERMANY FINDS NO EVIDENCE ACCUSED TURK LIVED THERE
abstract: West German officials said today that there was no evidence that Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of shooting Pope John Paul II, had entered West Germany between the time of his escape from an Istanbul prison in 1979 and his entry into Italy.   A spokesman for the Interior Ministry, Hendrik Vygen, said that the passport Mr. Agca carried in Italy contained no German entry stamps and that there was no record that he had entered or left West Germany under his own name or any of his known aliases.   But Mr. Vygen added that there was no way to exclude the possibility that Mr. Agna might have entered the country clandestinely, although there was no evidence that he had.

headline: Mexican Gas Rise Cleared
abstract: American importers have been authorized to pay $4.94 per 1,000 cubic feet for Mexican natural gas, a price the Mexican state oil company demanded to match the latest Canadian price increase, the Energy Department said today.   The agency's Economic Regulatory Administration approved an application from Border Gas Inc. to pay the Mexican increase after finding the new price was still competitive with fuel oil in American markets.

headline: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Weekly Vehicle Output Up 41%
abstract: Car and truck production for the year will break the 4-million mark this week, an industry publication reported today.   Car and truck output for the week ending Saturday will be 211,503, or 41 percent ahead of the level of 149,944 a year ago.

headline: Zimbabwe to Control Press Unit
abstract: Zimbabwe is gaining control of its national press agency from South Africa.  The South African Press Association said today that it would transfer ownership of the press agency to the Salisbury authorities by June 30 because its directors "decided it would be right for the ownership of Zimbabwe's domestic news agency to be in Zimbabwean hands."

headline: BURROUGHS EXPANDS PRODUCT LINE FOR USE IN AUTOMATED OFFICES
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation moved more aggressively into the market for the automated office yesterday with the introduction of an information processing system that can be used by managers and other professionals with no computer training.   The Burroughs system competes head-on with similar easy-to-use automated office equipment introduced in recent months by the International Business Machines Corporation, the Datapoint Corporation and Xerox, and will be compatible with electronic equipment made by other manufacturers.   One shortcoming, according to some analysts, is that the new system will not be able to generate and display graphics. But the analysts were unable to provide detailed comparisons with the competitors' systems.

headline: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAVINGS OUTFLOW IN MARCH A RECORD
abstract: Savers withdrew $1.7 billion more than they deposited at the nation's 4,400 savings and loan associations last month, the largest monthly outflow ever recorded, the United States League of Savings Associations reported today.   A record outflow is also expected to be reported for March by the 460 mutual savings banks. A preliminary estimate by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks places the figure between $500 million and $600 million of their more than $170 billion on deposit.

headline: Geneve Seeks Board Seat
abstract: The Geneve Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was seeking representation on the board of directors of the E.F. MacDonald Company. If a corporate relationship acceptable to Geneve was not achieved by July 1, Geneve said, it would seek either to dispose of its shares of MacDonald stock or seek control of the company. Currently Geneve owns 886,610 shares of MacDonald, or 23.6 percent.

headline: Regan May Not Go to Europe
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan may cancel his scheduled Friday appearance in Switzerland for a meeting of the International Monetary Conference, a Treasury Department spokesman said today.   Mr. Regan will wait ''to see what happens'' on negotiations to create a compromise tax cut bill later this week before deciding whether to leave Thursday night, according to the spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.   Mr. Regan was scheduled to deliver a speech in Lausanne, Switzerland, Friday before delegates to the International Monetary Conference, but, said Mr. Fitzwater, ''We're not sure he's going.''

headline: WESTERN EXPERTS SAY SOVIET TROOPS ARE BUILDING RADIO TOWERS IN POLAND
abstract: Western military sources said today that Soviet troops were active in southeastern Poland and had built important communications facilities there.   The sources said the troops are apparently constructing an extensive network of microwave radio towers for military communications and are also upgrading private communications channels and equipment around military bases elsewhere in the country.   Western military attaches were directed to the site, in a forest near a village close to Jaroslaw, by an unusual disclosure last Wednesday in the daily bulletin of the Warsaw chapter of the independent labor union Solidarity.   The bulletin said there had been a ''landing'' of Soviet troops on the night of April 22 near Rozwienica and three other towns. It said that farmers had complained to the local union chapter that Soviet troops were making spring planting ''difficult'' by cutting down trees ''to make clearings or construct observation towers.''

headline: Alaska's Oil Reserves
abstract: The Alaska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission said today that the state's eight oilfields contained an estimated 8 billion barrels of oil on Jan. 1, with 92.5 percent of these reserves in the Prudhoe Bay field. Alaska's 24 natural gas fields were estimated to contain 32.85 billion cubic feet.

headline: Consumers' Confidence Up
abstract: Consumer confidence in the American economy continued to improve in May for the third consecutive month, the Conference Board, a business research organization, said yesterday in New York.   But consumers' purchasing plans continued to decline, the group's survey found.

headline: OIL-BASED EXPORTS LAG
abstract: The earlier-than-scheduled decontrol of domestic petroleum prices, which took place two months ago, and the rising value of the dollar are hurting American exports of petrochemicals.   The price advantage that American producers enjoyed over European manufacturers of petroleum-based products like benzene, propylene and para-xylene had helped overseas sales to nearly double in the past four years, to $20.7 billion in 1980.

headline: Western Decalta
abstract: Western Decalta Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said that it was considering the sale of its 65 percent interest in the Petrol Oil and Gas Company, which has interests in oil and gas properties in western Canada, the Canadian Arctic and the United States. Based on current securities market values, Western Decalta's holding in Petrol would be worth about $23.4 million (Canadian). Western Decalta is a private company owned by the Mannix family of Alberta.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Many French voters were taken by surprise yesterday when they elected Francois Mitterrand as their President. Many events of magnitude are surprises, even when they are expected or half-expected.   For example, several important opinion polls had been predicting right along that Mr. Mitterrand held an advantage. The law prevented their publication, but they were circulated in restricted fashion and the restriction quite naturally bred skepticism. Those who knew about them doubted them.

headline: UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2.9% G.N.P. Rise Seen in Canada
abstract: Canadian real gross national product is expected to grow by 2.9 percent this year, compared with a onetenth of 1 percent rise in 1980, the Conference Board of Canada said today.   In its latest quarterly Canadian forecast, the business and economic research organization said inflation was expected to be 11.6 percent in 1981, compared with 10.2 percent last year.

headline: People
abstract: * Charles A. Humm has been appointed vice president-marketing for the United States Rent A Car division of the Avis Rent A Car System.   * Nancy Ryan has been named to the new position of operating vice president-advertising for Abraham & Straus.

headline: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHRISTIAN OFFICER VOWS LEBANON CURB
abstract: The commander of the Israeli-supported Lebanese Christian militia force in southern Lebanon met here today with Israeli leaders and agreed to restrain his men from clashing with United Nations peacekeeping forces.   At the same time, the commander, Maj. Saad Haddad, was believed to have obtained assurances of Israeli support.The meeting followed demands from the United Nations and several countries, presumably including the United States, that Israel restrain its Lebanese allies.   Some Israeli participants said, however, that the meeting had been held at Major Haddad's request. He was thought to have been worried by international pressure and wanted to make sure that Israeli support would continue.

headline: THE GREAT OIL PLAY'S MORNING AFTER
abstract: c15.3T HE Great Oil Spill of 1981 occurred not on the high seas but on Wall Street. ''Since mid-December, the stock price of the typical large oil company has dropped 25 to 35 percent,'' noted the Argus Research Corporation, an investment advisory service.   For some issues, such as the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), the plunge has been even sharper. Sohio, which hit a peak price of 91 1/2 last November, closed Thursday at 48 5/8. But in early 1979, it traded at 20, meaning that in less than two years, the price surged 4 1/2 times.

headline: OKC Mailing Out Liquidation Details
abstract: Stockholders of the OKC Corporation, Dallas, have been mailed final details of the company's liquidation plan, which involves distribution to the shareholders of money received from the sale of most of its oil and natural gas properties to the GMW Oil Company, Midland, Tex.   OKC said that, on April 1, directors had approved a liquidating trust for ultimate distribution of an additional $71 million in proceeds.

headline: Business Digest; TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1981; Companies
abstract: RCA will announce today the resignation of Fred Silverman as president of NBC, high-ranking sources at the network say. Grant Tinker, president of MTM Productions and a former NBC executive, is expected to succeed Mr. Silverman. (Page A1.)   Litton Systems was awarded $92.3 million after a five-month civil trial on antitrust charges against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The Federal court jury found that A.T.& T. had used monopolistic tactics to force Litton out of the office telephone equipment market. A.T.& T. said it would appeal. (D1.)

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 23, 1981; Companies
abstract: Nabisco and Standard Brands announced a $2 billion merger plan that would create a new company to be known as Nabisco Brands Inc. Robert M. Schaeberle, Nabisco's 58-year-old chairman, would head the new company, which would rank as the nation's third-largest producer of processed foods. (Page A1.)   Philip Morris, elbowing aside R.J. Reynolds Industries, agreed to buy a $350 million stake in Rothmans International Ltd. The purchase would strengthen Philip Morris's No. 2 ranking in the international tobacco market. Anton Rupert, the South African entrepreneur who controls Rothmans and who ended acquisition talks with Reynolds, would retain a 22 percent stake in the company. (D1.)

headline: LEE IACOCCA'S HEIR APPARENT
abstract: IN the spring of 1979, Gerald Greenwald was Ford's man in Caracas. He was president of Ford de Venezuela, which earned $100 million for the parent company in the United States. His wife was an art critic and feature writer for the Caracas Daily Journal, an English-language paper, and their children enjoyed life abroad.   One evening when the Greenwalds came home, they found a telephone message waiting. The caller was Lee A. Iacocca. Mrs. Greenwald recalls asking: ''Are you really sure you want to call him back?''   Precisely what Gerry Greenwald replied is lost in memory, but the call was made to the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation. In a matter of a few months it propelled Mr. Greenwald to a top financial post at Chrysler and into the swirl of events that made up the desperate attempts to save the No. 3 United States auto maker from bankruptcy.

headline: Your Money; Higher Yields From Banks
abstract: IN an effort to fight back against money market mutual funds, banks are suddenly offering a host of new products to the consumer. None of the new products quite match the liquidity of money market funds, where cash can usually be withdrawn at any time simply by writing a check. Like the money funds, however, some of the new instruments do pay higher interest rates and provide greater liquidity than traditional savings vehicles: passbook accounts or certificates of deposit.   And some may be particularly intriguing if interest rates turn down, since they allow the investor to lock in an interest rate for a period of time, but still provide the freedom to pull funds out.

headline: Grey Subsidiary Wins Huffman-Koos Account
abstract: Grey, Conahy & Lyon, which began last week winning the Velcro account, ended it announcing the landing of the Huffman-Koos business.

headline: INSURER'S STOCK AND MUIR ROLE
abstract: THE Security America Corporation, one of the many new issues marketed by John Muir & Company of late, appears to have fizzled only months after the shares were sold to the public.   Before the public offering, Security America was a mutual company.  But the casualty insurer was reorganized as a holding company and converted to stock company status in November of last year. On the 20th of that month, an underwriting group led by Muir offered the public 2.75 million shares of the holding company at $6 a share.  Muir customers accounted for about 1.5 million of the shares offered.

headline: CHILTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; E.F. HUTTON'S REGAL REPORT
abstract: When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen. When E.F. Hutton poses, people are riveted to the page. The investment giant's latest offering is a slick collection of portrait photography, almost $400,000 in the making, that immortalizes in museum-quality black and white E.F. Hutton's executive elite and their photogenic clientele.

headline: UNITOG CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Company News; BL Ltd. May Close If Deficit Persists
abstract: Sir Michael Edwardes, chairman of BL Ltd., Britain's state-owned auto maker, said that he would shut down the company by 1984 if it continued to operate in the red.   He told the corporation's annual meeting that Britain's only motor company, formerly known as British Leyland, is losing more than $2 million a day and its loss for 1981 is expected to be roughly the same as last year - $793 million.

headline: Commonwealth Oil's Settlement Backed
abstract: The Commonwealth Oil Company said that Judge Joseph Elliott of the United States Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio had confirmed an earlier creditors' vote approving the company's plan to settle the claims against it.   The company has operated under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act for more than three years.

headline: AUSTRALIAN MAGAZINES SOLD BY TIMES CO.
abstract: The New York Times Company announced the sale of its Australian and New Zealand magazine group to the Advertiser Group of Adelaide, Australia, a communications, printing and packaging company. The Advertiser Group will publish the magazines involved under license agreements.   Total value of the transaction, paid in cash and notes, was not disclosed, but the Times Company said it anticipated a tax-free gain on the sale of about $11 million.   The magazine group includes the Australian Family Circle, Better Meredith Corporation and the Times Company) and Modern Medicine of Australia and New Zealand, published under license from Modern Medicine Publications in the United States.  new York times company

headline: 12.46 SURGE SENDS DOW TO 1,006.66
abstract: A late buying surge yesterday sent the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 12.46 points, to 1,006.66, its first finish above the 1,000 hurdle since last Wednesday.   Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced losers by a 9-to-5 ratio, thus reversing the ragged market breadth of the three previous sessions.   Trading volume of 51.8 million shares was up sharply from Monday's 41.8 million shares. As a result, the commission-oriented brokerage stocks shared honors with selected energy, computer, transportation and photography issues.

headline: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEINBERGER, ON EUROPE TRIP, IS WARY OVER BREZHNEV ROLE
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he viewed as a welcome sign the arrival of Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for the Czechoslovak Communist Party meeting in Prague.   Mr. Weinberger, meeting with reporters accompanying him on his first trip to Europe as Secretary of Defense, said that the presence of Mr. Brezhnev at the Prague meeting was unusual because the Soviet leader had not attended such conferences for several years.   Mr. Brezhnev's presence, the Secretary said, ''emphasizes the seriousness that the Soviets attach to the situation in Poland.'' But Mr. Weinberger also cautioned that the Soviet Union might be lining up support in Prague for stronger action against Poland. He said that Soviet leaders ''prefer to use troops other than their own.''

headline: NEW NAMIBIA PLAN BACKED IN PRETORIA
abstract: South Africa can be expected to embrace the Reagan Administration's effort to revise a Western proposal for settlement of the dispute over the territory of South-West Africa, a senior official indicated today.   The main point of the revision would be to seek agreement on a constitution for the territory, also known as Namibia, before an election held under international supervision that would pave the way to independence.   Under the existing proposal put forward by five Western nations, including the United States, the election under international supervision would be for a constituent assembly that would then draft the constitution. Thus the losers of the election would run the risk of also losing their opportunity to make sure their rights were constitutionally protected.

headline: A DIP IN U.S. EXPORTS
abstract: While American's decline in world markets has been well chronicled, The United States nonetheless remains the world's most important exporter.   Figures from the most recent United Nations Statistical Yearbook show that in 1979 American exporters accounted for 10.9 percent of the $1.6 trillion worth of goods exported by all nations during that year.

headline: Italian Party Leader Says He Has Accord on Coalition
abstract: Senator Giovanni Spadolini, who is trying to form the first government not headed by a Christian Democrat in the 35-year history of the Italian Republic, said today that he had reached agreement with the other parties in a prospective coalition.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 30, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on Namibia at 5 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: RELIABLE INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bani-Sadr Loses Appeal Against Foreign Ministry
abstract: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr has lost an appeal against what he has denounced as the Foreign Ministry's encroachment on his responsibities.   At issue was a recent statement by the ministry accusing Habib Chatti of Tunisia, Secretary General of the Islamic Conference Organization and spokesman for a nine-member Islamic peace mission, of being pro-Iraqi.

headline: Advertising; Premium Incentive Exhibition
abstract: REPRESENTATIVES from big companies, such as the RCA Corporation, which would like to get its electronic entertainment equipment used as incentive material for a dealer organization, to small operations, such as Sinrod Studios, a one-man show that would be pleased to put a company's logo onto stained glass, jammed into the New York Coliseum yesterday for the start of the 43d annual four-day Premium Incentive Show.   Even before the official opening at 9 A.M., the died-in-the-wool salespeople manning the 1,100 exhibits had on their sunny-day smiles and were singing happy ''Good mornings,'' as their eyes jumped to name tags looking for potential customers.   ''They come to look, not to buy,'' said Irving Jompole, president of the Jompole Company, his hand busily working a nonelectric automatic razor, ''They exchange cards, and then after that it's a follow-up.''   His neighbor, Kim Sinrod of Long Beach, L.I., added: ''People at this show are looking for ideas. It's very unusual at this show to hit people at the moment they need a product.''

headline: Article 159797 -- No Title
abstract: United Artists, a unit of the TransAmerica Corporation, acknowledged that it would lose at least $29 million on its investment in the box office disaster ''Heaven's Gate.''   A spokesman for TransAmerica said that United Artists had established a $29 million pretax reserve to cover losses from the film, which was savaged by critics from the moment of its introduction.

headline: IN CALIFORNIA, SHARING REACHES THE WORKPLACE
abstract: As always in California, the name of the game is share the experience. The state has a novel program that allows workers, in effect, to double up on unemployment protection, and the littleknown plan is itself getting an unexpected workout.

headline: Stake in Newmont Grows
abstract: Amcon Group Inc. and Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., its corporate parent, said they had increased their stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to a little more than 2.1 million shares, or 8.1 percent. Their latest purchases, they told the Securities and Exchange Commission, totaled 266,000 shares in April and May for $16.9 million. They said they ''desire to develop working relationships with Newmont management.''

headline: Magma Bids Holders Reject Natomas
abstract: The Magma Power Company, a California energy concern with interests in producing geothermal wells, said it had recommended to shareholders that they reject a $42-ashare tender offer from the Natomas Company for the 9.3 million shares of Magma that it does not already own.   In a letter to shareholders, Magma's chairman, B.C. McCabe, said that the offer was ''grossly inadequate'' even though it was not possible to assign specific dollar values to Magma's assets, other than its geysers.

headline: Rates Soar on Action by the Fed; 6-Month Bills Yield 15.10%
abstract: Interest rates soared yesterday as the Federal Reserve continued its efforts to make credit scarce in the banking system and thereby encourage slower growth of the nation's money supply.   Yields for securities due in more than two years, which were already at record levels, rose sharply late in the day after the Fed announced a one-point increase in the basic discount rate, to 14 percent, and a one-point increase in the discount rate surcharge, to 4 percent.   Before the discount-rate announcement, the Treasury sold new three-and six-month bills at average rates of 15.96 percent and 15.10 percent, respectively. New Certificate Rates   Consequently, banks and savings institutions may sell new money market certificates at 15.35 percent, up from 14.29 percent last week.

headline: General Dynamics Drops
abstract: Citing the effects of a slow economy here and abroad, David S.  Lewis, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, a diversifed maker of aircraft, submarines and building materials, told shareholders that the company's earnings declined 15.2 percent, to $30.8 million, or 56 cents a share, in the first quarter from $36.3 million, or 67 cents a share, earned in the first quarter of 1980.   Sales for the first quarter rose 18.6 percent, to $1.27 billion, from $1.07 billion in the 1980 period.  Mr. Lewis also told the group that while ''the economy will probably continue to be soft in the near term, we believe the excellent mixture of government and commercial business will soon see us back on our long-term growth schedule.'' The current backlog of orders is about $11.2 billion, he said, but he gave no comparison with a year ago.

headline: SANDS ASSERTS HE EXPECTS TO DIE SOON
abstract: Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army member on a hunger strike in prison, told a friend today that he expected to die soon, ''maybe tonight, maybe tomorrow morning.''   As night fell over Maze Prison near Belfast, Northern Ireland, where the 27-year-old Mr. Sands has refused all food for the last 62 days, he clung to life. Ulster braced for an explosion if he dies.  The public was told last night by Britain's Minister for Northern Ireland, Humphrey Atkins, that the I.R.A. plans a campaign of arson and violence.

headline: WEST EUROPEANS TO SEEK SOVIET PULLOUT IN AFGHANISTAN
abstract: West European leaders will open a diplomatic initiative to obtain the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from Afghanistan, European officials said today.   The European initiative calls for the convening later this year of a two-stage international conference that would seek a formula acceptable to the Soviet Union for making Afghanistan a genuinely independent and nonaligned country.   Officials said that Lord Carrington, Britain's Foreign Secretary, would visit Moscow next week to seek Soviet support for the plan.  The plan, which was discussed by foreign ministers of the 10-nation European Economic Community last week, will be formally endorsed by the government leaders in the final communique of their annual meeting, which ends tomorrow.

headline: ISRAELI AND IRAQI STATEMENTS ON RAID ON NUCLEAR PLANT
abstract: Following is an unofficial translation of the text of a statement issued today by the Israeli Government describing its attack on an Iraqi atomic reactor:   The Israeli Air Force yesterday attacked and destroyed completely the Osirak nuclear reactor, which is near Baghdad. All our planes returned home safely.   The Government finds itself obligated to explain to enlighten public opinion why it decided on this special operation.  For a long time, we have followed with grave concern the construction of the Osirak nuclear reactor. Sources of unquestioned reliability told us that it was intended, despite statements to the contrary, for the production of atomic bombs.

headline: NERVOUS BANKS IN FRANCE AGAIN LIFT INTEREST RATES
abstract: French banks raised interest rates sharply today in an effort to stem the export of capital that has been caused by last Sunday's Socialist victory in the Presidential elections. The outflow has been aggravated by the pull of the strong dollar.   The French central bank said it would raise its seven-day Treasury bill discount rate, which it uses to set the pattern of interest rates on the Paris money market, by two percentage points tomorrow, to 18 percent. On Monday the rate was raised to 16 percent from 13 1/2 percent.

headline: HUGE DAM SUBDUES YANGTZE AND GIVES CHINESE A LIFT
abstract: After centuries of flowing freely and often recklessly through China's heartland, the Yangtze River is about to begin earning its passage.   The Gezhou Dam, a giant $2.2 billion tribute to Chinese selfreliance, is expected to begin producing electricity from the Yangtze's surging coffee-colored currents in July, in time to add needed pride to celebrations marking the 60th anniversary of the Communist Party.   Some 30,000 laborers are working in three shifts around the clock to meet accelerated construction schedules on the dam site just north of here. The first 7 of 21 water-driven generators are in place, and the first set of navigation locks is ready to reopen riverboat traffic after a six-month hiatus.

headline: Letters; MEMO TO THE FED: DISREGARD PREVIOUS MEMO
abstract: To the Business Editor: Mr. Wright's article is a pro-inflation hustle.

headline: B.P. Denies Reports Of Kuwait Oil Cutoff
abstract: The British Petroleum Company denied news reports that Kuwait had cut off its crude shipments because of a pricing dispute and said the company was still buying oil from the OPEC nation.   It was reported earlier this week that Kuwait had suspended loadings of about 650,000 barrels of oil daily to many of its key customers that were unwilling to pay surcharges of up to $5.50 a barrel.

headline: TRIBUNE NET FALLS 25.8%
abstract: The Tribune Company, a privately held communications company that owns The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 25.8 percent from the first three months last year, to $13.8 million from $18.6 million. Revenues rose 13.2 percent, to $325 million, from $287 million.

headline: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GRAFT IS SUGGESTED
abstract: A former Polish Prime Minister is under investigation by the state prosecutor for decisions made while in office, and a similar case may be prepared against the former party leader, Edward Gierek, a newspaper reported today.   The paper, Zycie Warzawy, did not disclose the details of the investigation against Piotr Jaroszewicz, the former head of Government. However, many rank-and-file members of the Polish Communist Party have demanded that Mr. Jaroszewicz and other top party leaders be tried for mismanaging the country's economy.   Mr. Jaroszewicz, who was dropped as Prime Minister at a party congress in February 1980 and was expelled from the party several months ago, is widely reported to have enriched himself during his 10 years in office. In addition, his son was given a lucrative job heading an automobile importing agency while Mr. Jaroszewicz was Prime Minister.

headline: Corco Expects End Of Chapter 11 Status
abstract: Judge Joseph C. Elliott of the United States Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio authorized the Commonwealth Oil Company to solicit creditor and shareholder acceptances of its plan for emergence from bankruptcy.   Commonwealth, known as Corco, said it expected to begin the solicitation by the first week of May and hopes to emerge from Chapter 11 protection by mid-July.

headline: MAY, ALLIED, DAYTON ALSO GAIN
abstract: Federated Department Stores, the nationwide chain that is the parent of Abraham & Straus and Bloomingdale's, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 surged 53.6 percent as sales increased 14.4 percent.   Federated's gains parallel those made by most of the big retail chain companies, which are showing an excellent first quarter, primarily because of a strong April, good Easter sales and a turnaround from depressed levels of a year ago when credit controls went into effect in mid-March.   The Cincinnati-based company said that net income in the three months ended May 2 rose to $40.7 million, or 84 cents a share, from $26.5 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.51 billion from $1.32 billion.

headline: Fading Film
abstract: To the Business Editor: I was really caught by surprise when I read ''Hollywood's Old Movies Are Fading Fast'' (April 5).  The article omitted the one major factor in extending the life of the moving image on celluloid: All film requires hand inspection, total wet immersion in cleaning solution, chemical impregnation of both the emulsion (picture) side and cell side, foot by foot, on a regularly scheduled basis.

headline: KILLINGS BY GUARD TEST SPANISH REGIME
abstract: An investigation into the deaths of three young men at the hands of the Civil Guard is turning into a major test of the independence of the Spanish judiciary and the credibility of the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.   The Almeria case, as it has become known, has also raised questions about the ability of the Government to control its security forces in the edgy political atmosphere that has taken hold since February's unsuccessful military coup.   On May 7, Luis Cobos, Luis Montero and Juan Manas arrived in Almeria in southern Spain from Santander, the northern city where they lived, to take a vacation and attend a relative's first communion.   On the night of May 9 they were arrested by Civil Guardsmen, who took them for Basque terrorists. The next morning they were dead.  Their charred, bullet-ridden bodies were found in a burned rented car on a lonely road.

headline: Hecla's Bid for Day
abstract: The Hecla Mining Company announced that a bid by Day Mines Inc. for a temporary restraining order to halt Hecla's exchange offer for all outstanding Day shares had been denied by the Federal District Court in Spokane, Wash. The Hecla offer began June 9. Both companies are major silver producers based in Wallace, Idaho.

headline: Your Money; Selecting A Credit Card
abstract: WHAT'S the best credit card deal for the average American? The answer lies in the use made of the card. Each type - the bank card, the retail charge card, oil company card and travel-and-entertainment card - offers a specific use and thus a distinct advantage. But trying to substitute one for the other can be troublesome, if not unproductive.   For purposes of the most direct comparisons, the evaluation might best be made between the two major bank cards, Visa and MasterCard, on the one hand, and the three major travel-and-entertainment cards, American Express, Diner's Club and Carte Blanche, on the other. The biggest differences and advantages are the following:   - The bank cards offer revolving credit and a smaller credit line, usually from $500 to $2,000, with the limit rarely exceeded.

headline: GRUEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN AUTO MAKERS VIE ON EXPORTS
abstract: Japanese auto makers will vigorously debate their allocations for exports to the United States, Japanese Government and auto industry officials said today, although the quotas will be based mainly on previous export volume for each auto maker.   Members of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry began meeting today with representatives of the seven auto companies that exported passenger cars and vans to the United States last year.  Specific figures for each company will not be determined until later this month, Trade Ministry officials said.

headline: G.E. Plans Layoffs
abstract: The General Electric Company will lay off an undetermined number of employees at its Schenectady consumer products plant by the end of the month because of declines in new orders, the company said. The company, which employs about 23,000 people at various plants in Schenectady County, has reduced its production levels lately in the face of declining orders.

headline: Soviet Relents on Hess, Permitting Visit by Son
abstract: Soviet authorities relented today and allowed the son of the former Nazi leader Rudolf Hess to visit his sick father in the British military hospital in West Berlin, an allied spokesman reported.

headline: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Angola Urges a New Conference To Seek a Solution on Namibia
abstract: Angola has called for a new conference to seek a peaceful solution to the problem of South-West Africa, or Namibia, the Angolan press agency Angop said today.   Interior Minister Alexandre Rodrigues told the agency that Angola would press for a new international conference on Namibia at this week's meeting of the Organization of African Unity in Nairobi.   Speaking yesterday before leaving to attend the meeting, Colonel Rodrigues said Angola wanted a new conference to discuss the carrying out of United Nations Security Council Resolution 435,

headline: Brunei Cuts Oil Price
abstract: Brunei has told Japanese importers that its crude oil prices for shipment to Japan have been cut by up to $1.40 a barrel, effective today, industry sources said. New prices are $39.60 a barrel for light seria oil, down a dollar, and $37.75 for champion oil, down $1.40, they said. Japan imported 47 million barrels of crude from Brunei in the 1980 fiscal year, ended last March, or 3 percent of its total import needs.

headline: CITIZENSHIP BILL GAINS IN BRITISH PARLIAMENT OVER MINORITY PROTESTS
abstract: Britain's House of Commons tonight passed a nationality bill attacked by immigrant groups as racially discriminatory.   The measure would set up three categories for British subjects - British citizenship, citizenship of British dependent territories and British overseas citizenship.

headline: 2 Seen in Line For Top Post At W.R. Grace
abstract: Charles H. Erhart Jr., 55, who this week took over as vice chairman and chief administrative officer of W.R. Grace & Company, moved into a highly visible position at the New York-based chemicals, natural resources and specialty consumer products corporation. With his promotion and others announced two months ago, Mr. Erhart and Carl N. Graf, 54, the new president and chief operating officer, appear to analysts to be the leading contenders for the top post of chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: Auto Inventory Up for April
abstract: United States auto makers' inventories swelled to a 65-day supply of new cars on April 30, up from a 44-day supply March 31, as auto production increased 12.6 percent from April 1980, an industry journal reported today.   But Ward's Automotive Reports said the stockpiles still were smaller than the 76-day supply the auto makers had on hand at the end of April 1980.

headline: FRANCE, ON ELECTION EVE, ANNOUNCES GRAIN SALE TO SOVIET
abstract: The French Government, in an announcement certain to appeal to farmers on the eve of a presidential election, said today that it would sell 600,000 tons of grain to the Soviet Union.   The announcement was the first to follow President Reagan's lifting of the United States curb on grain sales to the Soviet Union, a move that was welcomed everywhere from Moscow to Kansas with the possible exception of Buenos Aires. Argentina had ignored the American curb, and its farmers wondered what they were going to do with the expected bumber crop they are now harvesting.   The French announcement was contained in a Government statement that was careful to emphasize that French opposition to the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan was ''unchanged'' and that France still ''refuses to accept the 'fait accompli' imposed on that country.''

headline: REPUBLICANS CALL TAX BILL INSUFFICIENT
abstract: The White House and the senior Republican tax writer in the Senate, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, gave qualified praise today to a one-year tax relief bill proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.    But both said that the Illinois Democrat's proposal did not go far enough to reach President Reagan's economic goals.  The White House issued a statement by Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan that struck several conciliatory notes while disagreeing with Mr. Rostenkowski on important aspects of tax policy. Mr. Rostenkowski, who outlined his ''consensus package'' before the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry, sprinkled his speech with praise for the President and other conciliatory language. Views Exchanged by Phone   As a courtesy, Mr. Rostenkowski telephoned the Treasury Secretary this morning to summarize the luncheon speech. Reciprocating, Mr.  Regan called Mr. Rostenkowski this afternoon to tell the chairman what he had said at a White House news briefing.

headline: Teck Oil Venture Talks Under Way
abstract: The Teck Corporation, a Canadian mining and petroleum company, and the Copperfields Mining Corporation, said that negotiations were under way with the Aquitaine Company of Canada to form a joint exploration company that would develop Aquitaine's extensive holdings in the Beaufort Sea, in the Davis Strait and off the east coast of Labrador.

headline: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sugar Contract Changes
abstract: The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said yesterday that it was increasing the margin requirements for world sugar No.11 and domestic sugar No.12 contracts by $500, effective immediately. Contract prices will now range from $2,500 to $4,600, depending on volume purchased, the exchange said.

headline: Canadian Socialist Assails U.S. Aid to Salvador Junta
abstract: Ed Broadbent, the leader of Canada's New Democratic Party, a Socialist organization, said today that American support for the ruling junta in El Salvador ''can only mean the continuation of great suffering'' for the people there.   Mr. Broadbent, who visited Central America on a fact-finding mission for the Socialist International, said that he had found the great bulk of opinion, including that of the Cuban Government, in favor of a negotiated settlement in El Salvador.

headline: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising
abstract: Philip H. Dougherty Cooperative Couponing Is Popular   ONE of the hottest areas of sales promotion these days - as costs soar and more people use cents-off coupons - has got to be co-op couponing, which gives noncompeting manufacturers an opportunity to share the cost of the delivery vehicle.   There are now two new entries and both of their creators say that they are innovative.  John H. Cohill is offering a pop-up insert that will run only in Family Circle and Women's Day, which, he maintains, attract ''especially heavy users of food and health and beauty aids.''

headline: Albertson's Net Rises
abstract: Albertson's Inc., a supermarket chain with units in the West and Southeast, said today that earnings for the 13 weeks ended April 30 rose 15 percent, to $10.2 million, or 66 cents a share, from $8.9 million, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent, to $813.8 million from $714.5 million.

headline: Great Western's Chief Still Has Eye on Merger
abstract: James F. Montgomery, the 46-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Great Western Financial Corporation, which owns the nation's second-largest savings and loan association with $10.3 billion in assets, called off a proposed merger with the $2.4 billion Financial Federation Inc. this week. But he wants to renew the talks as soon as both of the California savings and loan holding companies convert from state to Federal charters. That would permit a merger without state government approval.

headline: Iranian Guerrilla Leader Is Killed in the War Zone
abstract: The head of Iran's guerrilla warfare units in the war with Iraq was killed today, the official Pars press agency reported.   Mostafa Chamran, a former Defense Minister and Deputy Prime Minister and one of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's two representatives on the Supreme Defense Council, was killed in the war zone near Susangird in Khuzistan Province, the press agency said.

headline: Nissan Introduces 3 New Models
abstract: Japan's Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun cars, introduced three new models of front-engine, frontwheel-drive economy models for overseas markets.

headline: BIG BANKS LIFT PRIME TO 20%
abstract: Under pressure from sharp increases in short-term interest rates that have raised their own cost of money, many of the nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent, from 19 1/2 percent.   Yesterday's half-point climb in rates was led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and followed by Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, First National Bank of Chicago and a host of other banks. Several institutions, including the Chase Manhattan Bank, said they would lift their prime to 20 percent effective today.    Nevertheless, in the credit markets both short-and long-term interest rates declined substantially yesterday, a signal to some economists that interest rates may have peaked.

headline: Peoples Jewellers Raises Zale Holdings
abstract: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto, Canada's largest publicly owned jewelry retailer, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the Zale Corporation of Dallas, the United States' largest retail jewelry concern, to 1.2 million common shares, or 17.5 percent of Zale's outstanding stock, through the purchase of 93,000 additional shares.   Peoples said the aggregate purchase price of its interest was $35 million.

headline: Company News; Hunt Energy Begins Drilling in Michigan
abstract: The Hunt Energy Corporation, owned by the Hunt family of Dallas, said that it had begun a major drilling program in Michigan intended to develop the state's deep oil and gas reserves.   The large independent oil company said it had allocated $75 million to the program and expected to drill at least 70 wells.

headline: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Florida Magazine To be Published in July
abstract: New Florida will be that sunny state's first magazine when it begins monthly publication in July, with Arthur R. Murphy, 65-yearold former publisher of McCall's and Sports Illustrated, publisher once again.

headline: Saudis' Loan To World Bank
abstract: Saudi Arabia has lent the World Bank $10 billion, a Kuwaiti newspaper, Al Qabas, today quoted the Saudi Finance Minister, Mohammed Balkhail, as saying.

headline: PATENTS; Self-Contained System To Cool Outboard Motors
abstract: A new cooling system for outboard motors is designed to avoid damage said to be caused to motors by the use of water through which the boat is passing.

headline: SCA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pope's Wounds Termed Worse Than Reagan's
abstract: Dr. Corrado Manni, director of the intensive care unit at the hospital where Pope John Paul II is being treated, said today that the Pope's wounds appeared to be more dangerous than those sustained by President Reagan in the attempt on his life in March.   Avoiding specific comparisons because he said he had not seen the original medical reports on President Reagan's wounds, the physician said the wounds to the Pope's intestine appeared to present greater potential danger because of the lingering possibility of infection from fecal matter.

headline: South Korean Exports Up
abstract: South Korea's exports in May increased 24.9 percent, to $1.76 billion, from the level of a year earlier, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today. Exports in the first five months of this year grew 23.6 percent, to $8.06 billion. The gains were attributed to rising shipments of textiles and other goods to the United States, Japan and Western Europe.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The Military Airlift Command has only about half the ability it needs to move the Rapid Deployment Force to Southwest Asia, according to its commander.   Gen. Robert E. Huyser said that the command is trying to determine whether it is making full use of its present assets and also any changes that might be needed. He added that the airlift command must decide on ''the procurement of new assets, such as the CX transport aircraft.''   On paper, the Military Airlift Command has impressive resources. It has 77 of the largest American transports, the C-5 Galaxy; 271 C-141's, about half of which have been lengthened by 23 feet, and approximately 550 C-130's, a prop-jet designed for regional operations. These include C-130's used by the National Guard and Air Force Reserve units.

headline: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Technology; Photochemistry: Role of Lasers
abstract: IT'S getting to be that time of year when people like to settle down on the lawn or beach and engage in a little photochemistry.  Getting a tan is one of many photochemical processes - that is, light-induced chemical changes - that are a part of everyday life.  Others include photography, in which pictures are produced by lightinduced changes in the chemicals on the film, and photosynthesis, the process by which plants convert sunlight into the sugars they need to survive.   Despite the pervasiveness of a few applications, the controlled use of light to cause chemical reactions is in its infancy, according to most experts. Theoretically the stage was set for dramatic growth in photochemistry when the laser was invented 20 years ago.  Practically speaking, however, so much has remained unknown about the nature of light, the capabilities of lasers and the economics of photochemistry that commercial applications of laser-based chemistry have proved elusive.

headline: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 10 weeks to May 23
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Purina to Relocate Van Camp Division
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company said that it would reorganize its Van Camp sea food division for greater efficiency by moving several departments to St. Louis from San Diego and making Van Camp a part of its grocery products division.

headline: RISING INTEREST RATES SEND STOCKS LOWER
abstract: The stock market, continuing to react to rising interest rates, edged down yesterday in more active trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout most of the session, closed down 0.27 point, to 976.59.  Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outscored advances by 816 to 705.

headline: INDUSTRIAL BONDS USE SOARING
abstract: In what officials said was the first comprehensive tally, the Congressional Budget Office reported today that the volume of tax-exempt industrial revenue bonds sold in the United States soared to $8.4 billion in 1980, from $1.3 billion in 1975.   These totals were several times larger than the figures compiled by trade sources, according to the report.  The report, Congressional sources said, might strengthen the hand of members of the Ways and Means Committee who want to restrict the issuance by states and local authorities of these so-called industrial bonds. Because interest on these state and local bonds is exempt from Federal income tax, the interest rate paid by the bonds is lower than on fully taxable bonds.

headline: EXOTIC VEGETABLES
abstract: Spring is in the air, and the seeds are going in the ground. Early reports from two of America's oldest and largest seed companies say sales are up, in a market estimated at about $2.5 billion a year by the American Seed Trade Association. Commercial planters, of course, account for a lot of the business, but the guy next door is also shelling out more for 45-cent to $1.50 seed packets via the Post Office.

headline: DIVERGENT FORECASTS ON RATES ABOUND
abstract: Rarely have the credit markets been confronted with such varied interest rate forecasts. Last week, yields rose to record high levels for every maturity beyond one year, but that did not mark the end of the disagreements among those who expect interest rates to decline and those who expect rates to rise still further.   In fact, a slight move to lower yields and higher prices last Thursday and Friday only heightened the controversy.  Traders claim that extreme volatility of prices and interest rates will continue to make investors nervous and hide the underlying trends. The Federal Reserve seems willing to let short-term rates move in a wider range that ever before, they explained, while bond market prices and yields are volatile partly because dealers cannot affort to hold inventories when short-term rates are so high.

headline: TAX CUT MOMENTUM EXPECTED
abstract: Fresh from a House of Representatives victory for the Reagan Administration last week on its budget, Treasury Donald T. Regan said today that the White House was counting on popular support to ''give us the victory'' for the Kemp-Roth tax cut of 30 percent over three years.   But two House Democratic leaders expressed doubt today that President Reagan could translate his popularity and momentum from his budget victory into enactment of the tax cut plan.   Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that ''unless commitments have changed,'' the Democrats and some Republicans on the panel would prefer a less extensive one-year tax cut that he has proposed, or some compromise.   Mr. Rostenkowski and Thomas S. Foley, the Democratic majority whip, both called the Reagan-backed Kemp-Roth plan dangerously inflationary.

headline: Lumber Output Off 8.8%
abstract: Lumber production in February, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 32.1 billion board feet, was 8.8 percent under the January rate and 13.4 percent below the rate of February 1980, according to the National Forest Products Association. Shipments were also lower, running at an annual rate of 29.8 billion board feet, down 11.7 percent from January and off 18.1 percent from the February 1980 rate.

headline: Company News; Chrysler Expanding Overtime at 4 Plants
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said four of its domestic car and truck assembly plants will work six days on expanded overtime schedules next week to meet resurgent demand for its vehicles. The No.3 auto maker reported yesterday that sales in the last 10 days of April rose 69.5 percent from the same period in 1980.   The company said that plants to be put on overtime schedules are its two ''K''-car assembly plants in Detroit and Newark, Del., its Belvidere, Ill., plant, which produces Horizon and Omni cars, and its Warren, Mich., truck assembly plant.

headline: POLISH LEADERS SAYS SOVIET-BLOC ALARM IS 'FULLY JUSTIFIED'
abstract: Stanislaw Kania, the Communist Party leader, declared today that Poland's allies were ''fully justified'' in their alarm over developments and said his leadership would seek to tighten control in important areas of national life.   Addressing a plenary meeting of the policy-making Central Committee, which was called to discuss a stern letter of warning from the Soviet party, Mr. Kania confirmed that such a letter had been received by the Polish leaders.   According to Mr. Kania, the letter warned that Poland's independence was in jeopardy if the party did not move against counterrevolution. Threat to Independence Seen   Quoting directly, he said: ''The serious danger that hangs over socialism in Poland constitutes a threat to the very existence of the independent Polish state.''

headline: HIGH PEKING AIDE IS DUE IN INDIA
abstract: The Chinese Foreign Minister arrives here tomorrow on a fence-mending mission that could pave the way for a new phase of friendship between India and China.   The visit by Foreign Minister Huang Hua is the first by a senior Chinese official since Prime Minister Zhou Enlai came here in 1960.  Within months of that visit, the relationship deteriorated over Chinese territorial claims.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Reworking the Budget   President Reagan, who took the financial markets to task last week for lacking faith in his tax and budget proposals, is finding Congress increasingly skittish about following through on budget cuts that had seemed quite likely only a few weeks ago.   As predicted, item-by-item scrutiny of proposed cuts has brought forth the programs' supporters. The possibility that the President will not get the full $36 billion reduction in nondefense spending called for under the current budget resolution has made compromise on taxes increasingly important, some analysts say.   Lawrence Chimerine of Chase Econometrics now expects about $47 billion in tax cuts to survive, about $7 billion less than the current Reagan proposal. While a multi-year reduction in personal taxes seems likely, Mr. Chimerine says a two-year, 8 percent reduction in rates stands the best chance of passing Congress. And investment-oriented proposals to expand exemptions for individual retirement accounts and lower the maximum tax rate on unearned income and capital gains taxes are likely winners, he says, as is a lower ''marriage penalty.'' The more moderate cuts are to offset spending that may run $25 billion higher than Administration estimates for the coming fiscal year.

headline: 12 More Arrested in Philippines In an Alleged Plot to Kill Marcos
abstract: The police arrested 12 more people and charged them with being involved with an alleged plot by Moslem guerrillas to kill President Ferdinand E. Marcos and bomb polling places in the presidential election on June 16, authorities announced today.   The arrests brought to 20 the number of Moslems who are being held. Statements from the presidential palace have said that the ''terrorist plot'' was formulated by Benigno S. Aquino Jr., an opposition leader who lives in Boston, and by Moslem separatist rebels living in the Middle East.

headline: China Is Said to Detain 6 Democracy Advocates
abstract: The police detained at least six dissidents in a crackdown last month on the remnants of China's democracy movement, informed Chinese sources reported today.   The sources said two of the activists, Xu Wenli and Yang Jing, were from Peking, where they were arrested on April 10.

headline: Lewis Sees U.S. Ending Conrail Ownership by '83
abstract: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, providing details of the Reagan Administration's plans for Conrail, said today that he intended to end Federal ownership of the deficit-ridden rail system in the next two years by selling freight operations and turning passenger operations over to local transit systems.   Mr. Lewis, at a news conference, dismissed critics' contentions that profitable railroads would not buy Conrail lines and that local transit operators wanted no ownership of commuter rail lines.  Representatives of major railroads had assured him that, without Conrail's costly overhead, they would be willing to bid on the lines, he said.

headline: UAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Union Oil Plans Sale Of Canadian Unit
abstract: The Union Oil Company of California said yesterday that it was offering to buy all the minority interest of its Canadian subsidiary, the Union Oil Company of Canada Ltd., for about $54 a share (United States), or $108 million cash.   The move is a ''first step toward selling'' the unit to a Canadian group, a spokesman at the company's Los Angeles headquarters said.

headline: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japanese Warned of Car Quotas
abstract: Leading members of the Japanese Parliament were told by members of Congress today that Japan would face legislated quotas on auto shipments to the United States, unless their Government cut back on exports.   The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, told the Japanese politicians that 65 to 70 senators would back a bill that would cut imports to 1.6 million cars annually for three years.   Last year's shipments of 1.8 million cars represented 21 percent of the $70 billion American car market.  Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, one of the sponsors of the quota bill, suggested it might be redrafted at 1.4 million units. He told the Japanese Parliament members that the 1.6-million level now appeared to be too high, following losses of more than $4 billion reported by American auto makers for 1980.

headline: Article 119658 -- No Title
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Horizon Corporation, one of the largest sellers of undeveloped land in the Southwest, to pay $14.5 million to consumers who bought property with virtually no resale value.   Under the terms of the final commission decision, Horizon must also spend, or have another developer spend, $45 million over 20 years for water, sewers, roads and other improvements.   Last March, the company agreed to these terms, pending final commission approval. Today's action ends a case that has been pending since 1975, when the company, based in Tucson, Ariz., was charged with misleading consumers as to the value of the land it sold.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. headline: News Analysis
abstract: For both political and military reasons, Israel has adopted a posture of determination in its desire to see Syrian antiaircraft missiles withdrawn from Lebanon. but it has not been precise about what it is prepared to do if Syria continues to spurn diplomatic appeals.   The Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is described by officials as eager to avoid a war with Syria, which would at the least undermine the peace treaty with Egypt and could spread into a wider conflict. Yet Mr. Begin has also convinced those who have seen him recently that he is serious about taking some form of military action if the missiles are not removed.   The Israeli concern stems from the increase in the Syrian presence in Lebanon that the missiles represent - beyond what the Israelis say was an understanding reached in 1976 - and from the threat the missiles could pose to Israeli planes conducting air strikes and reconnaissance missions against Palestinian guerrilla bases from which terrorist raids into Israel are launched.

headline: MEANS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Letter Bomb Is Mailed To Prince Charles
abstract: A letter bomb addressed to Prince Charles was spotted at a London postal sorting office today and safely defused, Scotland Yard said.

headline: Timerman Criticizes Reagan On Human Rights Policy
abstract: Jacobo Timerman, who credits the Carter Administration's human rights policy with saving his life, said tonight that the policy was being made irrelevant under the Reagan Administration.   Mr. Timerman, the former Argentine newspaper publisher who has written a book detailing his 30 months of imprisonment and torture, said the Reagan Administration's policy would be interpreted by both left-wing and right-wing dictators as ''unlimited license to trample on human rights.''
