abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Fiat Subsidiaries in Bid
abstract: A group of five private companies, including two Fiat subsidiaries, Fidis S.p.A. and Pirelli E.C. S.p.A., said in a joint statement today that they planned to acquire the Italian Government's shareholding in Montedison S.p.A., an industrial holding company. The other companies involved are the Bonomi group holding company, Invest S.p.A., Societa Metallurgica Italiana S.p.A. and Mediobanca, a Fiat spokesman said. Details of the offer, and the participation of each of the five, are yet to be decided.

headline: BEHESHTI WAS SEEN AS NO. 2 FIGURE IN IRAN AFTER THE ISLAMIC REVOLUTION
abstract: Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, who was killed last night with at least 23 other highranking Iranian politicians when a bomb exploded at the Islamic Republican Party headquarters here, was widely regarded as the second most powerful figure in Iran. He was 52 years old.   But the severe, gravel-voiced official, who wore the black turban of a descendant of the Prophet Mohammed, disputed that claim. He once told an interviewer, ''You know, I'm not really as powerful as people say.''

headline: Canadian Grain Prediction
abstract: United Grain Growers, a farmerowned grain company, forecast today that prairie farmers in Canada's western provinces will produce a bumper 1981 crop of 41.8 million tons of grain, significantly above the 34.1 million tons in 1980.

headline: KHOMEINI STRIPS BANI-SADR OF OFFICE, LEAVING IRAN'S CLERGY IN FULL
abstract: CONTROL   TEHERAN, Iran, June 22 (Reuters) -Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today removed President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr from office.  The action by Iran's 81-year-old revolutionary leader left the clergy and their secular supporters in complete control of Iran's post-revolutionary Government.   The 1979 Constitution provides that the President's duties will be performed by a three-man council for 50 days while a new presidential election is arranged.   The members of the council are Prime Minister Mohammad Ali Rajai, Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, who is Chief Justice and Secretary General of the Islamic Republican Party, and Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Parliament.

headline: Fred Meyer Chain To Reconsider Bid
abstract: Fred Meyer Inc., the largest retail chain in the Pacific Northwest, said today that it would reconsider a bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm, to purchase all its outstanding shares of common stock for $310 million.   The same offer of $45 per share was made by the New York firm last year, but was rejected by the Fred Meyer board on Sept. 30.

headline: KENYA ASKS AFRICANS FOR MORE AID TO NAMIBIA REBELS
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya issued a call today to African nations to step up their political, financial and military assistance to the guerrillas who are fighting to free South-West Africa from the control of South Africa.   Addressing delegates at the formal opening of the foreign ministers' meeting of the Organization of African Unity, President Moi also urged African countries to step up efforts to insure the establishment of black majority rule in South Africa itself.   Stating that the white minority regime ''still indulges in slavery,'' Mr. Moi accused ''some countries'' of being motivated by ''hypocrisy or greed'' in continuing their relations with South Africa.

headline: Entrepreneur for China
abstract: Howard S. MacAyeal, 50, has been appointed managing director of New China Investment Services, which packages the financial services required in developing industrial and commercial ventures involving the United States and China. Mr. MacA@yeal will be based at the New York office of the company, a unit of the China Trade Corporation that also has an office in Hong Kong.   ''We're into a pattern where the big companies are muscle-bound,'' Mr. MacAyeal observed.

headline: BANGLADESHI KEEPS EYE ON WEATHER, NOT POLITICS
abstract: "What matters here is the rain," said Mr. Mustaf, a subsistence rice farmer, automatically casting his eyes up to the leaden sky in the traditional June ritual of waiting for the all important monsoon rains to begin falling.   Like most of the 68,000 villages of Bangladesh, Masail has a life that changes very little over the the years or decades except when there is too much rain or not enough.  And on Mr. Mustaf's family plot of just less than half an acre, he uses tools and procedures with which his grandfather would have felt entirely comfortable.

headline: SPANISH LEADER HOPING FOR ENTRY TO NATO IN '81
abstract: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo is hoping to take Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization before the end of this year.   But Spain's new leader wants first to negotiate a fully overhauled military treaty with the United States that will take account of this country's standing as a democratic nation.   The tall 55-year-old Mr. Calvo Sotelo, whose investiture as Prime Minister was violently interrupted by the seizure of Parliament during an unsuccessful coup on Feb. 23, sketched his plans in an interview given on the understanding that he would not be quoted directly.

headline: U.S. SEES NO LETUP IN RUSSIAN ACTIVITIES
abstract: A State Department spokesman said today that although there had been no letup in Soviet military activities in and around Poland, the Administration did not believe that Soviet intervention in Poland was imminent.   At his daily press briefing, William J. Dyess, a State Department spokesman, said that the Administration was reviewing and discussing a broad range of political, diplomatic and economic steps that could be taken if the Soviet Union intervenes, but he added that no military options were under review by the Administration.   ''Political activity continues at a high level with Brezhnev in Prague,'' said Mr. Dyess, referring to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet President and party leader, ''but we do not believe that a Soviet intervention in Poland is likely in the immediate future.'' Mr.  Brezhnev is attending a party congress in the Czechoslovak capital.   Pressed by reporters about what he meant in terms of timing, Mr.  Dyess replied, ''Look down the road for a few days.'' He stressed, however, that the Administration ''did not have a clear idea as to what Soviet intentions are.''

headline: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Comex Reduces Required Margins
abstract: The Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday announced reductions in margin requirements for trading futures contracts in gold, silver, copper, two-year Treasury notes and Government National Mortgage Association certificates.

headline: REAGAN ASSERTS ISRAEL HAD CAUSE TO MISTRUST IRAQ
abstract: President Reagan said today that Israel appeared to have violated its weapons agreement with the United States when it bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor 10 days ago, but that the Israelis ''might have sincerely believed'' their action was defensive in nature.   At his news conference this afternoon, the President went further than any Administration official has before in suggesting that Israel had abused an agreement prohibiting its use of American-made military equipment for offensive military actions. Previously, officials had said only that Israel may have violated the agreement and that the matter was being reviewed.   However, Mr. Reagan went on to endorse at least some of Israel's justifications for the raid, saying: ''I do think that one has to recognize that Israel had reason for concern in view of the past history of Iraq, which has never signed a cease-fire or recognized Israel as a nation, has never joined in any peace effort for that. So in other words it does not even recognize the existence of Israel as a country.''

headline: Typhoon Floods Kill 2 in Taiwan
abstract: A mother and daughter were drowned today when flash floods unleashed by a typhoon swept through a watermelon field where they had been picking fruit, the police said.  The torrential rains in southern and eastern Taiwan forced China Airlines and Far Eastern Airlines to cancel all domestic flights and interrupted highway traffic in many cities.

headline: TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1981; Energy
abstract: Saudi Arabia said it would raise its $32-a-barrel oil price if other OPEC members lowered theirs. But at the cartel's semiannual ministerial meeting in Geneva, the other 12 members, which charge $36 to $41 a barrel, rejected the proposal to unify its pricing structure. Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, said he did not want to discuss production cuts at this meeting, cuts that the other countries contend are the key issue and essential to preventing further downward pressure on the prices of crude oil.  (Page A1.)

headline: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BARGAIN HUNTERS HELP LIFT DOW
abstract: The stock market, which has been under selling pressure in recent weeks because of rising interest rates, yesterday rose moderately as a late rally strengthened many issues.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up 1.71 points at 3 P.M., closed ahead 7.38 points, to 970.82. Since April 27, when the Dow reached an eight-year high of 1,024.05, the blue chip barometer has dropped 53.23 points.   Analysts noted that increased late bargain hunting and shortcovering, especially in some of the blue chips, provided stimulus for the market's late rise yesterday.

headline: A.T.&T. RISES 10.8% IN QUARTER WITH RECORD NET OF $1.62 BILLION
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest corporation, reported yesterday that it had record quarterly net income of $1.62 billion in the three months ended May 31, up 10.8 percent from the same period a year ago.   ''What makes these results significant is that they were accomplished in the face of a still uncertain economy,'' said Charles L. Brown, chairman of A.T.& T.   The earnings of $2.06 a share in the most recent quarter came on revenues of $13.9 billion. They compared with earnings of $1.46 billion, or $1.99 a share, on revenues of $12.4 billion in last year's second quarter. The $1.62 billion profit surpassed the previous record of $1.596 billion by A.T.& T. in the quarter ended last Nov. 30.

headline: POPE, MAKING PROGRESS, PHONES AILING CARDINAL
abstract: Pope John Paul II, who is said to be making further progress, ate a light lunch today and telephoned his ailing mentor, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.   Rose Hall, 21 years old, one of the two American women shot with John Paul, flew today to West Germany, where she and her husband are church workers.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. announced that its proposed exchange offering to acquire its common shares for units of debentures had been made effective by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   * Helio Science Inc. filed with the S.E.C. an initial 1.5 million units with each unit consisting of one common share and one warrant to purchase one-half common share.

headline: HOUSE UNIT BACKS SALE OF SILVER
abstract: The House Armed Services Committee has approved the sale of about 75 percent of the country's stockpile of silver and about 1.5 million carats of diamonds as a budget-cutting measure.   A committee spokesman said today that the committee, in a closed meeting last week, approved the sale of 105.2 million troy ounces of silver over a three-year period and lesser amounts of such other stockpile items as diamonds, mercuric oxide and mercury.   The silver amounts to about 75 percent of the Government's 139.5-million-ounce stockpile. The proceeds of the sale would go to make up $966 million in budget cuts that the committee was ordered to make as part of the continuing budget reconciliation process, brought about by budget cuts requested by President Reagan and ordered by Congress.

headline: PAGE PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BEGIN AGAIN ATTACKS SCHMIDT ON ROLE UNDER HITLER
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel again denounced Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today, saying that, as an officer in the armed forces in World War II, Mr. Schmidt had remained faithful to Hitler until the end.   In an Israeli radio interview to be broadcast tomorrow on Independence Day, Mr. Begin noted that Mr. Schmidt had served on the Soviet front, and said:   ''All I know is that he served in an army that was ordered to surround cities and maintain order while other special units entered to liquidate Jews.   ''He was a good officer, a good fighter, until he was taken prisoner by the British. He never broke his oath of allegiance to the Fuhrer, Adolf Hitler.''

headline: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 29

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 7 PAN AM EXECUTIVES LOSE JOBS
abstract: Pan American World Airways, suffering the severest losses in its history, let go seven of its 42 vice presidents yesterday in a move to improve efficiency, company sources disclosed. Three other vicepresidential slots were vacated by voluntary departures.   The dismissals were ordered at a monthly board of directors meeting here and were expected to be followed in the next few days by other measures to improve the airline's chances of riding out its economic troubles.

headline: CORNELIUS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Earth Tremors Jolt Parts of Italy
abstract: Earth tremors jolted mountainous areas in central and southern Italy today, panicking people but causing no damage, officials reported. The first tremor hit the earthquake-prone province of Macerata, south of the port city of Ancona, before dawn.

headline: Technology; TRADITIONAL LP IS UPGRADED
abstract: IN the late 1940's, CBS introduced the long-playing record, which became the industry standard. Now it is introducing a system that might help save the LP from becoming obsolete.   The traditional grooved record is facing a challenge from the newer digital disks, which represent sound by a series of numbers rather than by oscillations of a stylus in a groove. These new disks and their players are expected to reach the market in two years and are generally expected to replace the LP in the long run because they offer higher-quality, fuller sound with no surface noise.

headline: INFLUENTIAL RESEARCH CENTER
abstract: The Center for the Study of American Business has often been a target of ridicule since its founding six years ago at Washington University here. Some faculty members have questioned the center's objectivity, and a cartoonist has pictured it as an exuberant cheerleader for business with skimpy garb and pompons.   But the snickers have subsided. Since its founding director, Murray L. Weidenbaum, became chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, the center has found its stature increasing and its advice more widely sought.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FAMILY PERSECUTED IN ARGENTINA FOR STAND ON RIGHTS
abstract: A physicist and his wife, a chemist, talk quietly in their apartment as sunlight filters through the white chiffon curtains. The light dapples the hardwood floors and the books stacked on corner tables.   The couple, who sit on worn furniture, speak with a modesty that belies their reading, but because of their ideas on human rights they are being persecuted.   In 1977, several days after receiving an award for his contribution in physics to his country, Jose Federico Westerkamp lost his tenure at the National University of Buenos Aires. Last year, he lost his university position altogether. Last month he was arrested with five others, spent a week in jail and now is under ''provisional release.''

headline: History
abstract: Wars between Moslems and Hindus have been erupting on the subcontinent for centuries. In the 12th century Moslem invaders brought Islam to Bengal, which is now part of Bangladesh, and the Moslem rulers remained until the British arrived in the 18th century. In 1947, predominantly Hindu India won independence from Britain and a separate Moslem state, Pakistan, was created in two parts divided by 1,000 miles of Indian territory. With power centered in West Pakistan, the more populous East Pakistan demanded greater economic benefits and political change. Rioting broke out in the East in 1968. In 1970 the separatists in the East won a majority in the National Assembly and called for more independence, but Assembly sessions were postponed by Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, who was then President.  Rioting in the East erupted into civil war and Bangladesh was declared independent, forcing the resignation of Mr. Yahya Khan.  Sheik Mujibur Rahman, a leader of the Bengali nationalists in the East, became Prime Minister but was killed in a 1975 coup. His successor was also deposed, and Maj. Gen. Ziaur Rahman, who was assassinated yesterday, became the martial law leader in 1976 and President

headline: Around the World; Five Polish Factory Workers Are Reported to Begin a Fast
abstract: Dissident sources said today that five workers had begun a hunger strike at a factory in Sosnowiec in the heavily industrialized south to protest the imprisonment of political prisoners.   The sources said the workers planned to fast until the Government freed the six known political prisoners in Polish jails, including Leszek Moczulski, head of the dissident group Confederation of Independent Poland.

headline: G.&W. Lifts Stake
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified financial services, manufacturing and resources concern based in New York City, said that it had increased its stake in the Mohasco Corporation to 1,320,000 shares, or 20.1 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, G.&W. said that its holdings included 144,100 shares bought on the New York Stock Exchange between June 12 and June 23 for $2,053,601. G.&W. said that its purchases were for investment purposes only.

headline: Wall Street Brokerages Plan Greater TV Spending
abstract: The discovery of television has certainly made big advertising spenders out of those brokerage people.  The Merrill Lynch total budget will be up this year by 10 percent, to $20 million, with 40 percent going to the tube.

headline: TRUDEAU SET BACK ON CONSTITUTION
abstract: The Newfoundland Court of Appeal handed the Federal Government a major judicial defeat today by unanimously declaring illegal Ottawa's proposals to effect constitutional change without overall provincial consent.   The court ruled 3 to 0 that the proposals now before Parliament infringed on the rights of the provinces and should not be carried out without their consent. Parliament is being asked to approve a resolution requesting Britain to transfer its control of the 114-year-old British North America Act, which has served as the Canadian consitution, to Ottawa along with a new bill of rights binding on the provinces.

headline: COMMODITY HOUSE IN BRITAIN PRESSING FOR SUGAR TAKEOVER
abstract: It was not too long ago that S.& W. Berisford Ltd. was a sleepy company making a nice profit importing food and handling the distribution of sugar in Britain. Then, under new management with new ideas, the company threw itself into the highstakes business of commodity trading.   The result was a spectacular period of growth. In the last 10 years, earnings before taxes increased from just $6 million to $79 million last year, while revenues shot up from $334 million to almost $5.4 billion. In 1980, almost 70 percent of the company's profits came from commodity trading and distribution, with the rest spread mostly across food processing and scrap metal recovery.

headline: Italy-Yugoslav Region Jolted
abstract: Two moderate earth tremors jolted an area near the Italy-Yugoslavia border today, the Trieste Seismological Observatory said. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Japan-Canada Auto Talks
abstract: Japan will discuss possible voluntary restraint on car exports to Canada, but it will not accept any retaliatory action by Canada if no agreement is reached, the Japanese Ambassador, Michiaki Suma, said today.

headline: Peugeot Posted Loss for 1980
abstract: Peugeot, Europe's forth-largest automobile company, today reported a $263 million loss for last year compared with a $316 million profit in 1979.   The figures reflected a sharp decline in saled by its domestic subsidiaries, Automobiles Peugeot, which makes Peugeot and Talbot (formerly Chrysler) cars, and Automobiles Citroen.

headline: Exxon Office Unit Plans Price Cuts
abstract: The Exxon Office Systems Company said yesterday that it was cutting prices on two models of its Vydec word processors by $1,500 and offering volume discounts on its complete line of Qyx electronic typewriters.   Analysts saw the reductions as evidence that the oil giant is floundering in the office automation business and is losing out to competitors offering better features or lower prices.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS FEAR ISRAEL-SYRIA CLASH
abstract: Reagan Administration officials expressed concern today that Israel and Syria were moving toward a new confrontation over Lebanon that neither probably wants but that they may not be able to avoid without appearing to give in to each other.   The officials were frustrated by their inability to persuade the Syrians to withdraw antiaircraft missiles recently moved into Lebanon before Israel takes military action to destroy them.   President Reagan sent a message to Prime Minister Menachem Begin today, following up on an earlier one from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. According to American officials, Mr. Reagan praised Israel for showing restraint in the last few days and urged additional time for American diplomatic efforts to bear fruit. The President reportedly acknowledged that the United States had not yet been able to resolve the problem, but said diplomatic moves were often drawn out.

headline: U.S. Pilot Killed in Germany
abstract: A United States Air Force F-15 jet crashed on a training mission 15 miles northeast of Bremen today, killing the pilot, officials announced. A United States Air Force spokesman identified the pilot as Capt.  George T. Hall of Goodlettsville, Tenn.

headline: Italians Arrest a Suspect In 1978 Slaying of Moro
abstract: Mario Moretti, a suspected Red Brigades guerrilla wanted in connection with the kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro in 1978 was arrested in northern Italy today with a group of other guerrilla suspects, the police reported.   Magistrates issued a warrant for Mr. Moretti's arrest in December 1978, seven months after Mr. Moro's bullet-riddled body was found in the trunk of an abandoned car in Rome.   The police said they suspected Mr. Moretti of being a leader of the Rome units of the Red Brigades and one of the earliest members of the group.

headline: Zimbabwe Mine Seizure Doubted
abstract: Zimbabwe's year-old Socialist Government will not nationalize the nation's mines, Mining Minister Maurice Nyamgumbo was quoted as saying today in The Herald, a Salisbury daily. ''Nationalization for the sake of it is a form of racism, and we don't want it,'' he said. The Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions had urged the Government to seize the mines, most of which are owned by British, American and South African companies.

headline: Harvester Advances Debt Restructuring
abstract: Plans of the ailing International Harvester Company to restructure its debts are progressing, with banks representing 95 percent of the refinancing indicating approval of the package, according to Harvester's chief financial officer, James Cotting.   The number of banks indicating agreement is up from 90 percent reported in mid-May, Mr. Cotting said, after meeting yesterday with 400 bankers representing 225 creditor banks.

headline: Company News; G.E. CLIMBED 5% IN 1ST QUARTER; CATERPILLAR TRACTOR DOWN BY 1%
abstract: The General Electric Corporation, the country's largest manufacturer of electrical equipment and a leading producer of consumer goods, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 increased 5 percent while sales rose 3.6 percent.   The Fairfield, Conn., company said that net income in the latest three months rose to $359 million, or $1.57 a share, from $342 million, or $1.50 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Sales increased to $6.09 billion from $5.88 billion.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Edward H. Budd, the 47-year-old president of the Travelers Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Morrison H. Beach, 64, who will continue as chairman of the Hartford-based company, parent of the Travelers Insurance Companies, until reaching the normal retirement age of 65.

headline: Fewer Cattle In Feed Lots
abstract: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of April 1 totaled 9.76 million head, down 4 percent from a year before and 12 percent less than two years before, the Agriculture Department said today.   Analysts have been predicting a gradually tightening beef supply.

headline: 5.1% Growth Seen for Japan
abstract: The Japan Economic Research Center predicted today that Japan's economy would grow at 5.1 percent in real terms in the fiscal year 1981, which began in April. That growth, it said, would be supported by an increase in personal spending, brisk exports and corporate equipment investment.

headline: U.N. FARM AGENCY SCRAPING FOR MONEY
abstract: The prevailing mood of antagonism toward foreign aid, as toward social programs of all kinds, has created serious financial problems for a $1 billion international agency dedicated to agricultural development in poor countries.   Three years ago the United States put up $200 million of the initial three-year, $1 billion budget of the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Contributions to this specialized agency of the United Nations were to be equitably shared by the industrialized countries and the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which pledged $435.5 million, including $163 million from Saudi Arabia.

headline: 2 SOUTH AFRICAN ELECTION RIVALS, 2 VIEWS OF CHANGE
abstract: Pieter Schoeman, the candidate for Parliament of the relatively liberal Progressive Federal Party in a suburban neighborhood here, had just come to the first Afrikaans name on his list on his nightly door-to-door canvass of registered voters. ''This could be interesting,'' he said, bracing himself.   Speaking politely, almost deferentially, in Afrikaans, his own first language, Mr. Schoeman started to introduce himself and declare his mission. The mere mention of his party's name was enough to make Marius Froneman, a towering, thickset man who opened the apartment door, look as if he wanted to step outside and fight. ''Don't argue,'' said Emmerentia Froneman, stepping between her husband and the candidate, a slightly built man. ''Just say that you're a Nationalist.''

headline: Turkish Military Court Sentences A Pro-Albania Editor to 19 Years
abstract: A military court has sentenced the former managing editor of a banned leftist weekly to 19 years in jail on charges of supporting Communism, making separatist propaganda and lowering the prestige of the armed forces, martial law authorities said today.   The court sentenced Mehmet Cerik, former managing editor of the weekly Halkin, a strongly anti-Soviet and anti-Chinese publication that supported the views of the Albanian leader, Enver Hoxha.   The weekly was banned in Turkey's major cities following the declaration of martial law in one-third of the country after sectarian violence in the southeast in December 1978.

headline: U.S. Protests Soviet Charge Of a Role in Gandhi Plot
abstract: The United States has strongly protested a Soviet report accusing an American diplomat of involvement in an Afghan plot to assassinate Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, the State Department said today.   It said the report in the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda was baseless and may have been designed in part to complicate relations between the United States and India. The Pravda article said that George G.B. Griffin, deputy chief of the United States Embassy in Kabul, had coordinated Afghan ''counterrevolutionaries'' in an attempt to kill Mrs. Gandhi.

abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Air Staff Fights Bid
abstract: Employees of Continental Air Lines today announced a plan intended to keep Texas International Airlines from gaining control of Continental. Details of the plan, involving the issuance of new stock, are to be announced tomorrow by the newly formed Continental Employees Association.

headline: SOUTHERN RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RUSSIAN CRITICIZES REAGAN'S 'ZIGZAG' FOREIGN POLICY
abstract: Georgi A. Arbatov, the Soviet Union's top expert on the United States, accused the Reagan Administration today of failing to formulate a coherent foreign policy in its first 100 days, and of generating anti-Soviet talk that was ''fraught with danger.''   In the long run, Mr. Arbatov wrote in the Communist Party daily Pravda, Mr. Reagan is bound to realize that ''there are no acceptable alternatives to peaceful coexistence.''   ''But the important question is how long this zigzag will last and what price will have to be paid for it,'' he said.  The article by the head of the Soviet Institute on the U.S.A. and Canada underscored Moscow's frustration with what Mr. Arbatov called the Reagan Administration's campaign of ''absurd inventions, accusations and threats.'' But it also suggested that Soviet policy makers have not written off Mr. Reagan as a potential partner in critical matters like arms negotiations.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: The Greek Government today rejected a Turkish protest over an anti-Turkish demonstration by Armenians living here.  A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said the contents of the Greek reply would not be made public but that Athens regarded the protest as ''unjustified.''

headline: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ATLANTIC BUYER HALTS PAYMENTS
abstract: Alleging that he was misled about the financial condition of The Atlantic Monthly, which he purchased it last year, Mortimer Zuckerman has refused to pay five outside stockholders the second installment due under terms of the acquisition agreement.   ''Now the courts will have to determine whether or not I owe the money,'' said Mr. Zuckerman, who confirmed statements by some of the stockholders that the payments had been withheld.   One of the five, Garth Hite, who recently resigned as publisher of the 124-year-old literary magazine, denied that Mr. Zuckerman had been misled. ''He spent seven full months studying the company before he purchased it,'' Mr. Hite said. ''He was into our books continuously and he received 10 years of certified audits from Touche, Ross.''

headline: Ford Plant Retooling Set at $36 Million
abstract: BUFFALO June 11 (AP) - The Ford Motor Company plans to spend $36 million at its Hamburg stamping plant, just south of Buffalo, to prepare for new models and retool for existing car lines, the company said.

headline: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILITARY TANGLED IN ITALY'S SCANDAL
abstract: The Italian Defense Ministry announced today that it had asked for the voluntary suspension of all the generals and admirals on active duty whose names were on a list of alleged members of an illegal Masonic lodge.   The ministry also announced that the future of officers below the rank of general on the list would be decided later this week.

headline: MAJOR ISSUES CLEAR TO S.E.C. NOMINEE
abstract: Bevis Longstreth, the 47-year-old New York lawyer who was nominated by President Reagan last week for a seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a clear view of what he considers to be the major issues facing the Federal agency.   But until the completion of the confirmation process for the S.E.C. membership, which expires next June 5, he does not want to disclose his feelings on these issues.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Stock Exchange has elected Frederick B. Whittemore, managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, vice chairman of the board of governors.   * Chemical Bank has named Richard F. Mangogna a senior vice president.

headline: Ambush Reported in Guatemala
abstract: Leftist guerrillas said today that they had killed 34 soldiers and wounded several others in an ambush of a military truck in western Guatemala. The Government declined to comment. The Organization of People in Arms, in a statement sent to newspapers here, said the attack took place last Friday on the Pan American Highway 61 miles west of the capital.

headline: Credit Markets; RATES UP ON INVENTORY WORRIES
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, when a lack of investor demand for securities encouraged some firms to reduce their inventories before the weekend.   Trading in both the short- and long-term markets followed the fluctuations in the cost of short-term bank loans arranged in the Federal funds market, brokers said. As the cost of these short-term loans rose during the day, prices of other securities declined.   ''Market sentiment was dominated by concern about the cost of carrying inventories,'' one experienced dealer explained. As financing costs rose yesterday, dealers were less willing to hold securities in anticipation of future price rises.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Louis Moskowitz, 64, has been elected chairman of the Republic New York Corporation and its subsidiary, the Republic National Bank of New York. Walter H. Weiner, the 50-year-old president and chief exeutive officer of the holding company and chief executive of the bank, has been named to the additional position of president of the bank.   The management changes follow the retirement of John A. Waage, a 67-year-old banking veteran who spent more than two years at Republic, as chairman of the corporation and the bank. Republic New York is controlled by Trade Development Bank Holdings of Luxembourg, which, in turn, is controlled by Edmund J. Safra, a Lebanese-born financier who lives in Switzerland.

headline: A Chief Economist At Commerce Dept.
abstract: Robert G. Dederick, Harvard-trained senior vice president and top economist of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, is the Administration's choice to become chief economist at the Commerce Department.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said yesterday that he was asking Congress to elevate the job to the status of under secretary for economic affairs in line with a broadening of its functions.

headline: Company News; B.C. COAL CHANGE
abstract: Vancouver, Britich Columbia, May 1(Reuters) - The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation said its B.C. Coal Ltd. unit was seeking a buyer to replace a Swedish company that withdrew from an an agreement to purchase 70 percent of B.C. Coal Ltd. interest in the South Brae oilfield in the North Sea.  Svenska Petroleum Exploration orginally arranged the agreement in principle with Kaiser Resources Ltd, The predecessor of B.C. Coal.  The Swedish company agreed to pay up to $45 million (Canadian) for 70 percent of B.C.  Coal's share of the field but said recent changes in British tax laws had made the transaction uneconomic.

headline: Mutual Fund Sales Up
abstract: The Investment Company Institute announced yesterday that sales of mutual funds, other than short-term funds, rose to $949 million in April from $917 million the month before. The institute said that redemptions of these funds in April increased to $737 million from $684 million in March and $543 million the year before.

headline: Patents; A TALKING SIGN GIVES ADVICE IN AN EMERGENCY
abstract: Signs that can talk and tell people how to get out of buildings in case of fire and other emergencies are being manufactured by Exit-Us Inc., Easton, Conn. Tim G. English, president, was granted patent 4,275,274 this week for the monitoring system.

headline: Market Place; Penn Central's Rail Settlement
abstract: EUPHORIA gripped shareholders of the Penn Central Corporation yesterday in the wake of the announcement that the Federal Government would pay the company $2.1 billion for the assets of its bankrupt railroad, most of which were turned over to the Consolidated Rail Corporation in 1976.   Investors clearly recognized that the oil, gas, coal and amusement park conglomerate was about to be reconstituted in a dramatic manner.  In short, Penn Central's balance sheet will be greatly simplified, while this company, which already generates lots of cash, is unlikely to pay income taxes for many years beyond prior estimates.   Until the settlement, Penn Central carried the assets of its bankrupt line as ''discontinued operations'' at $3.1 billion. With the $2.1 billion settlement, those assets will be eliminated along with liabilities estimated at $2 billion.

headline: POLISH PARLIMENT VOTES A STRIKE BAN TO LAST TWO MONTHS
abstract: Acting after Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski threatened to resign if it did not move to prevent new strikes, the Polish Parliament approved a resolution tonight for a two-month suspension of strikes and threats to strike.   The vote was overwhelmingly in favor, with only four abstentions among the 440 members. It came shortly before midnight after almost 14 hours of debate.   Before the vote, leaders of the independent union Solidarity, meeting in Gdansk, issued a statement expressing ''deep anxiety'' over the Prime Minister's virtual ultimatum.   The statement said that the way to avert strikes was ''by eliminating the causes through upholding the law and fulfilling the agreements.''

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: In an At a Glance box accompanying an article on Xerox last Sunday the company's 1980 stockholders' equity and dividend for the first quarter of 1980 were misstated.

headline: Commonwealth Oil Has New Chairman
abstract: Last August, C. Howard Hardesty Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, said: ''I set out to bring the company out of bankruptcy. I'll be disappointed if I don't.

headline: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Zimbabwe Getting Chinese Aid
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe left China today, reportedly with a promise of $1 billion in aid, and flew to Japan, where he hoped to obtain additional economic help for his newly independent nation. In Peking, Mr. Mugabe was promised a package of about $1 billion in agricultural and other aid, African diplomatic sources said. The sources said China hoped the aid would help head off Soviet influence in southern Africa.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 3.25 AS G.M. LEADS WAY
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday as General Motors shared honors with high-technology and brokerage-house issues among the market's better performers.   After gaining 3 3/8 points in the previous three sessions, G.M.  rose 2 1/4 points, to 57 5/8, as the outstanding gainer in the Dow Jones industrial average. It was also the most active issue.   The Dow finished at 1,010.27, up 3.25 points. At 2 P.M., it was ahead more than 9 points.  Volume totaled 64.2 million shares, the highest turnover in a month, compared with Wednesday's 60.7 million.

headline: Lilco Earnings Gained 18% in First Quarter
abstract: The Long Island Lighting Company reported today that its earnings rose 18 percent in the first quarter, to $64.2 million, from $54.4 million in 1980, or 75 cents a share, compared with 74 cents a share last year.

headline: PATENTS; Sensors Monitor Water That Is Hot or Pressurized
abstract: A sensor to measure the acidity or alkalinity of water at extremely high temperatures and pressures was patented this week for the General Electric Company.

headline: Wrath Aroused On Braniff Pay
abstract: The chairman of the Braniff International Corporation, John J. Casey, found himself surrounded by controversy today because the airline decided to raise the pay of 864 management-level employees by an average of 11.4 percent.   The salary increases for supervisory and staff employees were disclosed last week, barely a month after Braniff's 11,500 workers covered by labor union contracts were asked to accept a 10 percent pay cut to help the financially troubled airline survive.   Some of the company's union employees have bitterly criticized Mr.  Casey.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., has named Robert E. Heaton president and chief executive officer of two wholly owned subsidiaries, the Washington Steel Corporation and the Calstrip Steel Corporation.   * CCI Corporation, Tulsa, Okla., has elected Donald M. Hardin to the new position of vice president, finance and corporate development.

headline: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Reagan's Plans In Fiscal Area
abstract: IN case anyone was wondering whether President-elect Ronald Reagan has changed his mind about his pre-election commitments to huge tax reductions and his other economic proposals, he has now renewed his pledge to do ''what I said during the campaign I was going to do.'' George P. Shultz, the chairman of his 13-member economic policy coordination committee, has indicated that Mr. Reagan will stick to the strategy laid out in his major economic-policy statement of Sept. 9.   That plan, labeled ''Ronald Reagan's Strategy for Economic Growth and Stability,'' is therefore very much alive and worth careful reexamination. It represents an effort to marry the growth-oriented tax-cutting strategy of Mr. Reagan's populists - embodied most importantly in the Kemp-Roth bill for cutting personal income taxes by 30 percent in the next three years and thereafter indexing them to the rate of inflation - with the more cautious fiscal strategy of such conservatives as Mr. Shultz, Alan Greenspan and Arthur F. Burns.

headline: 2 BROTHERS OF CHARLES TO SERVE HIM AT RITES INSTEAD OF A BEST MAN
abstract: Prince Charles will have two official ''supporters'' rather than a best man at his wedding on July 29 to Lady Diana Spencer, Buckingham Palace announced today.   Prince Charles, 32 years old, will be supported by his younger brothers, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward.  Andrew, 21, will perform the traditional best man's task of carrying the ring, while Edward, 17, assists. Sharing the duty has a precedent from previous royal weddings, the palace said in giving the first details of the royal wedding.

headline: GOLDBLATT BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CRANSTON SAYS INDIA AND PAKISTAN ARE PREPARING FOR NUCLEAR TESTING
abstract: Senator Alan Cranston, the assistant Democratic leader, asserted today that both India and Pakistan were making ''final preparations'' for nuclear explosions at test sites.   In a speech on the Senate floor, the California Democrat disclosed what he called recent evidence from ''sources within the executive branch'' indicating that Pakistan was building a horizontal tunnel in a hillside in the Baluchistan Mountains 40 miles from the Afghanistan border. United States officials, Mr. Cranston added, believe that the construction is probably for a test site for nuclear weapons.   Mr. Cranston, prime sponsor of the 1978 Nuclear Nonproliferation Act, also said that since February India has been undertaking ''surface excavations for burial of a nuclear warhead for an underground test.''

headline: HABASH BACK IN BEIRUT AFTER SURGERY ON BRAIN
abstract: George Habash, leader of the Marxist-oriented Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, reappeared in public today after several months of treatment abroad following brain surgery.   Dr. Habash, who is 54 years old, was host at a reception apparently given to show he was back in action.

headline: Product Delay By G.M. Seen
abstract: The General Motors Corporation is delaying or suspending some of its planned new car models and engines that were originally to have been part of its huge four-year, $40 billion retooling program, according to trade sources.   Among the projects being delayed are a V-4 engine to be built by Oldsmobile and three-cylinder engines planned by Chevrolet and Buick.

headline: A NEW BATTLE OF SOWETO FLARES: HOUSING VS. IDEOLOGY
abstract: A sharp bureaucratic battle, with major political implications, is being fought among white administrators over the issue of whether to make more housing available in overcrowded Soweto, South Africa's largest black settlement.   Five years ago, a student uprising in Soweto sent tremors through the white political system. The struggle over black housing, which has as much to do with racial ideology as with financing, is a measure of how hard it has been for that system to absorb the meaning of the violence of 1976.   On one side are die-hard apartheid supporters in key civil service positions who see Government control of housing as a weapon to limit the number of blacks. Increasingly this faction has sought to shape South Africa's racial laws so that the right of blacks to be in an urban area would depend on whether they were properly housed. And that, in the existing system, depends almost entirely on the authorities.

headline: U.S. MAY 'DISENGAGE' FROM NAMIBIA TALKS, AIDE SAYS
abstract: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told a House hearing today that the United States would ''disengage'' from negotiations on independence for South-West Africa if South Africa continued to delay on an internationally acceptable settlement.   Mr. Crocker said that after five months of intensive consultations with South African leaders the Reagan Administration was still not sure whether South Africa was prepared to accept independence for the territory as the new nation of Namibia through elections under United Nations supervision.   Mr. Crocker and Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark visited Pretoria last week for the latest round of talks on Namibia and other issues.

headline: Company News; G. & W. LIFTS STAKE IN CLUETT, PEABODY
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified financial and industrial company that often buys large blocks of other companies' and Exchange Commission filing that it had increased its holdings of Clett, Peabody & Company to 726,400 shares, or 8.19 percent.   Late in March the company reported that it owned 592,00 shares, or 8.19 percent.   Late in March the company reported that it owned 592,000 shares, or 6.8 percent of the apparel maker, and that it had purchased the shares as an investment.

headline: Company News; Bank Offering London Accounts
abstract: In a move to offer consumers high interest rates on their checking accounts, the Bank of California announced yesterday that it would open dollar checking accounts at its London branch for residents of the United States.   The interest rate paid on these accounts would be adjusted daily.  The rate quoted yesterday was 17.1 percent, well above any comparable investment available in the United States, including money market mutual funds and domestic interest-bearing checking accounts.

headline: Market Place; The Outlook For A.T.&T.
abstract: A DIVIDEND increase by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company always ranks as something of an event in Wall Street. After all, Ma Bell has nearly three million owners, and they constitute by far the biggest stockholder family of any company.   With the lone exception of 1975, A.T.&T. has announced an increase in its cash payout every year since 1972. The last increase - to $1.25 a share from $1.15 - was voted in February 1979. That put common-stock payments on an annual basis of $5 a share.

headline: Washington Watch; Customs Study Seen as Hint
abstract: WASHINGTON INITIATORS of the study disavow any connection, but the recently undertaken inquiry into import entry procedures is interpreted as another form of subtle pressure being placed on Japan to agree to voluntary export restraints on car shipments to the United States.   At the suggestion of United States Trade Representative Bill Brock, the Government's commercial representatives abroad have been asked to find out how long cars sit on the docks before clearing customs after being unloaded.   The suspicion is that in many European countries and Japan it takes a lot longer than the five to 10 days that is the normal entry time in this country. Delays in clearance amount to an invisible barrier against American exports.

headline: RAPID AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: July Issue of Intro Makes Magazine National
abstract: Suzanne Douglas, who manages to publish her magazine despite almost constant appearances on TV and radio talk shows, will see her magazine Intro reach national distribution with the July issue. Intro is the magazine for singles who want to meet the opposite sex, and an important feature of each monthly issue is the paid personal classified ads - one for boys and one for girls.

headline: Around the World; Air India Aides Dismissed Over 'Plot' on Mrs. Gandhi
abstract: Five senior officials of the Government-owned airline Air India have been dismissed and security around Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has been tightened after the discovery of an alleged attempt to sabotage a plane scheduled to carry Mrs. Gandhi to Geneva next Tuesday.

headline: SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CYPRUS MOVES TOWARD NEW EFFORT AT FEDERAL STATE
abstract: Cyprus is moving slowly toward another attempt to establish a federal state, and the results of last weekend's Greek Cypriots' parliamentary elections are being interpreted as possibly providing some impetus.   Gains were scored in the election by two opposition parties that have called for a more active role by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations in talks between the Greek Cypriots and the Turkish Cypriots.   The opposition groups, the right-wing Democratic Rally and the Communist party, officially known as AKEL, each won 12 seats in the 35-member Parliament. But President Spyros Kyprianou's ruling Democratic Party, which came in a poor third with eight seats, holds the balance of power.

headline: RATE HOPES SEND DOW UP BY 6.21
abstract: Hopes of a crest in interest rates sent stock prices higher yesterday, but the market ran into profit-taking after the Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 1,000. The indicator closed at 997.96, up 6.21 points.   Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 62.2 million shares, up from Friday's 51.6 million.  Stocks were at their high for the day at 12:30 P.M., when the Dow was ahead 11.59 points, at 1,003.34. Although many Wall Street analysts tend to dismiss any economic significance in the 1,000 figure, stocks repeatedly have come under selling pressure in recent years when the Dow rallies to this mark.

headline: JAPAN'S DEFENSE CHIEF RESISTS U.S. PRESSURE
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger insisted today that Japan rapidly increase its military strength to help cope with a threat from the Soviet Union, but Japan's defense minister firmly resisted the request.   United States and Japanese officials said after Mr. Weinberger met with his Japanese counterpart, Joji Omura, in the Pentagon this morning and later over lunch that Washington and Tokyo remained far apart on the question of how much military power Japan should contribute to the common defense in Asia.   The issue appeared to be potentially more irritating and resistant to compromise than the trade issues that have troubled relations between the two nations for more than a decade. At stake is the question of whether the alliance is to have substance or to be a partnership in name only.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: In his first real organizational move since taking over the helm of N.W. Ayer from Neal O'Connor, Louis T. Hagopian, chairman and chief executive, announced seven changes of status at the international agency yesterday.   Included are the creation of four new divisions each with its own president, three of whom are Princeton men.

headline: World Airways Has Profit
abstract: World Airways, one of the nation's largest charter carriers for commercial and military passengers and cargo, yesterday reported net income for the first quarter of $735,000, or 7 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $11.4 million in the first quarter of 1980.  Sales soared to $78.3 million from $27.2 million.

headline: LEVELS STILL TERMED LOW
abstract: The nation's three largest domestic auto producers reported today that new-car sales rose 11.5 percent in the first 10 days of June compared with the depressed selling levels for the same period last year. Analysts said that, despite the rise, sales levels were still unsatisfactory.   ''There is no recovery yet,'' said Peter Zaglio, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate, approximately 6.2 million units based on sales in the June 1-10 reporting period, is still ''very low,'' he added, ''too close to what it was last year at this time.'' Earlier this year, industry officials had forecast total 1981 sales of 12 million vehicles, including imports.

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY BUILDUP NEEDN'T SIGNAL MOVE ON POLAND
abstract: Senior American officials said today that the intensified Soviet military activity in and around Poland did not necessarily mean that an invasion was imminent.   ''The situation remains extremely dangerous, but we have no sign that the Soviets have made a decision to intervene,'' said a senior White House official.   Administration officials said the recent buildup had brought forces to a level where the Russians could quickly respond to any Polish Government request to aid Polish militia and army forces in a crackdown on internal unrest.

headline: U.S. TELLS ALLIES IT WANTS TALKS WITH SOVIET
abstract: A high-ranking State Department official, seeking to allay European concerns about the Reagan Administration's foreign policy, said today that the United States wanted to achieve a dialogue with the Soviet Union rather than its isolation.   Addressing a group of Western European security experts, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, said at the same time that the firmness of the Atlantic alliance in restraining the Soviet Union was a requisite for the pursuit of the dialogue.   The speech, which contained unusually clear statements of United States willingness to talk with the Soviet Union, appeared to be aimed at dispelling some of the impressions created in Europe by the anti-Soviet tone of speeches by President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. This tone has fueled a reluctance to believe that the United States is ready to negotiate seriously about the limitation of middle-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

headline: Around the World; Unemployment Rate Rises To 11.1% in Britain
abstract: British unemployment rose to a 50-year high of 2,680,977 in June, or 11.1 percent of the work force, the government announced today. The figure was double the jobless total when Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in May 1979.

headline: SPENDING ON BUILDING SLIPS AGAIN
abstract: Spending for new construction fell 2.4 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today, the second consecutive decline after after six months' growth.   The report lent weight to the view, held by many economists, that the economy was slowing and this would be evident in the second quarter.

headline: Arco Moves to Sell Montana Property
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said that the Atlantic Richfield Company was seeking permission to divest its Heddleston, Mont., copper properties, with Asarco Inc. getting them.

headline: VANCE ASSAILS POLICY ON CHINA ARMS SALES
abstract: Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, has sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's decision to sell arms to China as ''needlessly provocative.''   Mr. Vance, who was in Moscow just before the new policy was announced, said that the proposed arms deal has ''virtually removed any influence we have left over the Soviet Union.''   ''We played the China card in no-trump,'' he said in an interview Monday, ''and there is not much left.''

headline: Emissions Test Method Approved
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday gave the Armco Steel Corporation approval to begin using the controversial ''bubble'' method to measure emissions from its plant in Middletown, Ohio.   Under the bubble concept, particulate emissions are measured from a plant as a whole rather than from specific parts of the plant, such as smokestacks.

headline: Fed Changing Rule to Foil Coast Bank's Plan to Pay Higher Interest
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that it would change its rules to prevent the Bank of California from establishing highinterest checking accounts at its London branch for residents of the United States.   In an unusual move, the Bank of California had rebuffed an unofficial request made earlier by the board that the bank indefinitely suspend offering the service.

headline: Ford Predicts End of Losses
abstract: After a year and a half of heavy losses, the Ford Motor Company should approach the break-even point in the current quarter, which ends June 30, Philip Caldwell, the company's chairman, told shareholders today.   Mr. Caldwell, however, would not predict whether the nation's No.2 auto maker would show a profit or loss at the end of the year.

headline: Dome Skirts Query In Hudson's Bay Bid
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which is buying 14 million shares of Conoco Inc. to swap for Conoco's 53 percent interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, sidestepped a Conoco challenge that it be indemnified against any taxes on the transaction but said the offer could be structured so that Conoco would not incur capital gains taxes.   John P. Gallagher, chairman of Dome, told Ralph E. Bailey, chairman of Conoco, in a letter Sunday that there were a number of instances in which the swap technique had been successful while a sale for cash, as preferred by Conoco, could involve up to $400 million in taxes.

headline: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTER-CITY GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OUTPUT UP BY 0.4% ON AUTO GAINS
abstract: The nation's industrial production, prodded by a partial recovery in auto assemblies, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.   The increase for March offset the decline in February, a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent. That drop was the first in half a year, following six consecutive monthly gains as the economy recovered from last year's recession.   While the March production figures would appear to indicate a strengthening economy, most analysts said that, upon closer inspection, they did not.

headline: CONTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPERRY SET TO PROPOSE I.C.L. DEAL
abstract: The Sperry Corporation plans to propose next month a joint venture, in which it will have a minority interest, with Britain's financially troubled International Computers Ltd. The Control Data Corporation previously announced talks with the British company.   Sperry said that it had not worked out the details of its offer.  The company decided that an announcement was necessary after being stung by reports in British newspapers that it wanted to take over I.C.L. and close down much of the British company's manufacturing operations. I.C.L. had sales of $1.5 billion in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1980, and shared market leadership in Britain with the International Business Machines Corporation. It is the nation's only major domestically owned computer manufacturer.

headline: HCC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Graphite Order
abstract: China has awarded an order to a Japanese consortium led by Mitsui & Company to build a plant to produce coloid graphite for color picture tubes, Mitsui said today. The order, placed by the National Technical Import Corporation, called for completion of the plant by mid-1983.

headline: TELERENT LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Here Comes the Taxman   With debate swirling in Washington over the merits and demerits of various programs, taxpayers will be forced to cope with current policy this week, as the April 15 deadline nears. The government expects to refund more money this year than a year ago, but bracket creep and stronger economic performance than was initially anticipated are expected to raise revenues even more. According to Treasury Department estimates, individual taxpayers will receive $47.7 billion in refunds this year, 6.4 percent higher than 1980 levels. Average refunds are expected to reach $635 this year, up from $590 in 1980. With promised tax cuts still an unrealized dream, most economists expect the money to raise consumer spending. However, few think the impact will be substantial. In spite of the refunds, the government is expected to take in nearly 13 percent more revenue from individuals in 1981 than last year, an estimated $325 billion, somewhat more than first anticipated. While some analysts think the increase could reduce Government borrowing requirements in the second quarter, others like Lacy H. Hunt of Philadelphia's Fidelity Bank see no slowdown in expenditure growth, and expect Washington's credit needs to remain strong.

headline: HIROHITO AT 80: FOCUS OF EFFORT TO BRIDGE A GAP
abstract: A forest of tiny Rising Sun flags fluttered in the hands of well-wishers who gathered before the Imperial Palace today to greet Emperor Hirohito on his 80th birthday.   On a balcony above the dense throng, the Emperor, flanked by the Empress and members of his family, waved his hand awkwardly, smiled and leaned forward to speak into a microphone.   ''Thank you very much for coming to celebrate my birthday,'' he said. ''I wish you well.'' The brief greeting, the first time the Emperor has spoken on such an occasion in many years, appeared to be part of a general attempt to bridge a gap between the monarchy and the people.

headline: INVESTING; THE REAL MONEY IN PAPER MONEY
abstract: W HILE inflation-obsessed investors have been jamming the exits to get out of currency, a small band of unusual souls has been doing the opposite -investing in paper money. They are not the ultimate contrary opinionists; they are aficionados of antique bills and rare notes. The objects of their affections beguile the eye with elaborate engravings and beautiful colors, odd shapes (hexagonal) and even odder denominations (6 1/4 cents), fascinating adjuncts to history that serve to remind just how multifarious and provisional the notion of money has been. Judging from price trends, collecting currency also represents a new twist on the adage that money makes money. An old $5 bill bought for $6.75 in 1948 recently sold for $1,800, a gain of roughly 267-fold. ''I would say that in the past five years, notes in general have appreciate 2,000 percent,'' says Herbert Melnick.

headline: NICARAGUAN JUNTA MEMBER SAYS ATTITUDE OF U.S. IS 'DISRESPECTFUL'
abstract: The attitude of the Reagan Administration has brought relations between Nicaragua and the United States to a ''very delicate'' point, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a member of the Nicaraguan junta, said in Havana yesterday.   Mr. Ortega, who has been attending a meeting here of the World Council for Peace and who was the guest of President Fidel Castro at celebrations last night marking the 20th anniversary of the Cuban victory at the Bay of Pigs, was particularly critical of the training of Nicaraguan exiles at camps in Florida.   The Nicaraguan Government, he said at a news conference for Cuban and American journalists, had recently sent a note of protest to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and had also discussed the matter with the American Ambassador in Managua.

headline: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NETTLES FOR REAGAN
abstract: The Israeli air attack on Iraq's nuclear installation has presented the Reagan Administration with its first sharp confrontation with Israel and raised new obstacles for the Administration's overall strategy in the Middle East.   With uncertainty about Arab reaction and possible retaliation, Administration and Congressional leaders were cautious about making assessments that went beyond the State Department's strong condemnation of the Israeli raid.   Officials feared, however, that the Israeli strike had not only complicated Philip C. Habib's peacemaking effort in Lebanon but might also handicap broader American efforts to promote Arab-Israeli peace and to encourage a strategic consensus by Israel and moderate Arabs to resist Soviet penetration of the region. Fostering Arab Solidarity   Normally, when tensions rise between Israel and an Arab nation, moderate Arab countries such as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Jordan feel the pull of Arab solidarity and become more reluctant than usual to be drawn into the peace process with Israel. Iraq's call for an Arab meeting seemed to be designed to exploit such tensions.

headline: Company News; NU-WEST BIDS AGAIN FOR CALGARY POWER
abstract: The Nu-West Group Ltd. today renewed a $517 million (Canadian) offer for 48 percent of Calgary Power Ltd., a major utility company that supplied more than 65 percent of the energy requirements in Alberta Province last year.   The offer, which will remain open for 21 days from the mailing date, renews an earlier bid that was dropped shortly after Canada's national energy program was announced last Oct. 28.

headline: IRAQI REPRISAL: FEW OPTIONS
abstract: Iraq's options for effective retaliation to the Israeli raid on its nuclear reactor near Baghdad appear extremely limited. But United States and NATO military analysts, as well as some Arab military sources, believe Iraq is unlikely to accept the humiliation of the attack without attempting some form of reprisal. The possibility that reprisal action might lead to a another Arab-Israeli war is a major concern. A related issue is whether the Israelis intend to establish a nuclear monopoly in the Middle East.

headline: Credit Markets; BONDS FALL IN VOLATILE TRADING
abstract: Institutional investors, who must become heavy buyers of bonds before there can be a sustained drop in long-term interest rates, still have strong doubts about the Reagan Administration's plans to stimulate the economy and reduce inflation.   Their doubts were demonstrated yesterday when bond prices fell as much as 1 1/2 points, and the yield on 30-year Treasury issues again climbed above 13 percent. With few buyers in the market, traders said prices gyrated widely in mostly dealer-to-dealer transactions.   Volatility was also characteristic of the short-term credit markets, where six-month Treasury bills traded in a range of 12.75 to 13.40 percent before closing at about 13.3 percent.

headline: G.M. Joins Units
abstract: The automobile marketing organizations of Vauxhall Motors Ltd. and Adam Opel A.G. in Britain will be combined immediately, Vauxhall announced today.

headline: MEGO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ORBIT INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LEADER HEALTHCARE ORGANIZATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN INDIA, THERE'S A DEMONSTRATION FOR ANY OCCASION
abstract: Just as Eskimos have more than a hundred words for snow and Arabs have dozens of expressions for sand, so it is entirely fitting that people in India have many ways of saying demonstration.   Every day in every city and large town groups of men and women march, chant, sit, fast or mill about to protest or support all sorts of things, ranging from public policies and salary scales to private utterances or religious behavior.   From time to time the demonstrations flare into violence and are treated nationally as front-page news. But mostly they remain highly ritualized local events that barely impinge on the awareness of passers-by.

headline: Needham, Harper & Steers Wins Dorsey Account
abstract: Thanks to expertise in cold remedies acquired while working on Bristol-Myers's Congespirin, a four-way product, Needham, Harper & Steers, New York, has won a $5 million assignment from Dorsey Laboratories, of Lincoln, Neb.

headline: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sharon Debt Ruling
abstract: A spokesman for the Sharon Steel Corporation said yesterday that a Federal District Court judge had ruled that Sharon must redeem, at par value, up to $113 million of public indebtedness that had been incurred by UV Industries Inc., the assets and liabilities of which were assumed by Sharon in November 1979. The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, trustees for some debt holders, had alleged that UV had defaulted on other debt assumed by Sharon, which automatically put the indentures into default, the spokesman said. Sharon said that it would appeal the decision.

headline: PRAGUE DENOUNCES POLISH LABOR UNION
abstract: Soviet and Czechoslovak officials charged the Polish independent labor federation Solidarity today with ''counterrevolution'' and ''anti-socialism.''   The head of Czechoslovakia's official trade unions likened the continuing labor unrest in Poland to the situation in his nation in 1968 just before the Soviet-led Warsaw pact invasion.   A Czechoslovak spokesman said that the Soviet leader Leonid I.  Brezhnev - a special guest at Czechoslovakia's 16th Communist Party Congress here -would address the meeting again before it closes Friday.

headline: 6 Persian Gulf Countries Sign Cooperation Treaty
abstract: The heads of state of six countries in the Persian Gulf area signed an agreement today to form a Gulf Cooperation Council despite differences on defense policy.

headline: ACCORD SET IN CAIRO ON SINAI PEACE UNIT
abstract: Representatives of Egypt, Israel and the United States announced agreement today on a peacekeeping force to patrol Sinai after the scheduled final withdrawal by Israel from the Egyptian territory next April 25.   A terse statement by the three participants said the agreement was ''preliminary'' and subject to ratification by the Egyptian and Israeli parliaments.   But at a news conference, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Michael Sterner, head of the United States team during the months of negotiations, seemed confident a plan for a force had been worked out that would be acceptable to both Israel and Egypt. U.S. Is 'Delighted'   ''The United States is, of course, delighted this agreement has been reached,'' Mr. Sterner said at Mena House, a hotel near the Great Pyramids of Giza. ''It will strengthen peace and the future of the peace process.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Chromalloy American Corp. signed a letter of intent to sell its Los Angeles water treatment division to Erie Manifacturing Inc., a private multinational company based in Milwaukee, for about $10.3 million.

headline: PROMPT GRAIN PRICE RISE SEEN IF SOVIET CURB SUDDENLY ENDS
abstract: If the curtailment of grain sales to the Soviet Union were suddenly ended, as it might be if the Russians showed they would not intervene in Poland, prices for American wheat, corn and soybeans would rise immediately, grain market analysts believe.   But the analysts say that several factors, including the Reagan Administration's willingness to sell more grain to the Soviet Union, would determine how long prices might continue to rise and to what level.   In the face of mounting complaints from farm leaders and from Republicans in Congress who represent farm states, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has been saying he is ''increasingly optimistic'' about an end to the grain curb soon. But there was still no support for such optimism from the White House today.  Administration spokesmen insisted that no decision had been made and that none was likely to be made as long as unrest in Poland continues.

headline: Mrs. Thatcher in Qatar, Last Stop of a Gulf Tour
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain arrived here today on the last stop of her Persian Gulf tour.

headline: SSC&B's Coast Office Gets an Influx of Billings
abstract: The Los Angeles office of SSC&B, formerly Erwin Wasey, dropped considerably in billings when New York headquarters decided to absorb much of the Carnation work it had been doing.   But now it reports a sudden influx of billings and people thanks to the decision by D'Arcy-McManus & Masius to close its Los Angeles office and move the business to San Francisco.

headline: DAMAGED OIL TANKER IS LEAKING OFF SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: A supertanker that was reportedly damaged by a wave Thursday has created a 60-mile-long oil slick in the Indian Ocean about 15 miles off South African resort beaches, the South African Press Association said today.   Another tanker is to meet the damaged vessel, the Liberianregistered Energy Endurance.

headline: More Thrift Units Cited as 'Problems'
abstract: The agency that regulates the nation's 4,700 federally chartered savings and loan associations said today that the list of institutions in financial trouble serious enough to warrant special scrutiny by examiners was continuing to grow.   The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported that 265 of the associations were on the board's ''problem list,'' up from 246 in March and 120 at the end of 1980.

headline: MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1981
abstract: The Economy   House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. sharply criticized the Administration's new tax-relief plan and predicted the House would reject the revised proposals. But the Administration disputed this.  James A. Baker 3d, White House chief of staff, predicted a House victory, saying, ''In the final analysis we will prevail.'' (Page A1.)

headline: Business People; Caesars World And Jersey Unit Pick President
abstract: J. Terrence Lanni has been elected president and chief operating officer of both Caesars World and its Caesars New Jersey subsidiary, it was announced by the two companies.   The companies also said that Mr. Lanni, 38, would act as chief executive officer of the two corporations until a New Jersey court determines whether Clifford S. Perlman, who has been on leave from the posts of chairman and chief executive officer, can return to the positions.

headline: Business People; FIRST PRESIDENT CHOSEN AT GULF AND WESTERN UNIT
abstract: James I. Spiegel, 52, has been named the first president of the apparel and home furnishings group of Gulf and Western Industries, the New York-based conglomerate. The group -which encompasses the Kayser-Roth Corporation, the Simmons Company and Simmons Universal - had sales in the fiscal year ended last July 31 of about $1.4 billion and operating earnings of $83.3 million.

headline: SMALL BUSINESS GETS ITS OWN CONSULTANTS
abstract: When Carl Ernst opened a management consulting concern in Albany in 1973, he did not have to fight for business in a cutthroat market.  ''To find outside expertise at the time, a businessman had to go to New York or Boston,'' he recalls. ''There was no one to speak to in the area.''   The situation has changed dramatically - in Albany and around the nation. At least a dozen management consulting concerns offer a wide array of services to small companies throughout the Albany area, and their growth typifies a nationwide trend.

headline: Vatican Gets First Ambassador From the Islamic Republic of Iran
abstract: The first Iranian Ambassador to be appointed to the Vatican since Iran became an Islamic republic arrived today to take up his post.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Airborne Freight Corporation, Seattle, has named Tom Rooney vice president-Europe.   * American Can Company has appointed William Johnson president of the Fingerhut Corporation, Jack W. Eugster president of the Musicland Group, and James B. Moran president of Pickwick Distribution Companies.   * AMF Inc., White Plains, has named James L. Rine president of its Potter & Brumfield division, succeeding Joseph E. Mulheim, who has been appointed division chairman.   * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., has named Wil Houde general manager of the personal computer systems division.

headline: Credit Markets; RATE SURGE DOMINATES TRADING
abstract: Credit markets were in disarray yesterday, traders said, as shortterm interest rates rose as much as half a percentage point - an unsually sharp increase - and long-term bond yields set new highs.   Aggravating the situation was a perplexing increase in overnight interest rates. Overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market averaged about 19 1/2 percent and rose to 21 percent for much of the afternoon, a sharp increase from the 16.28 percent average for the week ended Wednesday and the range of 15 to 15 1/2 percent that prevailed in the first half of April.   The rising interest rates had a severe impact on other markets, too. Investor confidence in the stock market suffered, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.57 points, to 997.75 -closing below 1,000 for the first time in 11 sessions. (Page D6.) Expectations that higher rates would attract funds to dollar-denominated accounts sent the dollar up sharply in foreign-exchange trading. It reached a 10-year high against the French franc, and set a record against the lira. (Page D11.)

headline: CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for 13 weeks to Apr 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CORN ACREAGE UP 2% BUT GROWERS VOICE CAUTION ABOUT CROP
abstract: American farmers, the Agriculture Department's Reporting Board said today in an eagerly awaited report, are increasing their corn acreage by 2 percent this year, which could raise the harvest of this vitally needed feed grain to 7.6 billion bushels from last year's drought-hampered 6.6 billion bushels.
