But farmers and grain traders cautioned that the actual harvest would undoubtedly not be that high. Today's report, they noted, was based on planting conditions as of June 1 and did not take into consideration recent flooding in Indiana and Ohio, which has prevented some planting in those key states. When the Agriculture Department issues its first production forecast on July 10, they predicted, the outlook will be down sharply. They expect a crop closer to 6.5 billion bushels, which would mean a tight supply for the second straight year.

headline: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Apple Computer Inc. announced that it filed on Friday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the secondary offering of about 2.3 million shares of common stock by about 100 selling shareholders, to be sold through a group of underwriters managed by Morgan Stanley & Company.   * Alpha Microsystems filed with the S.E.C. an issue of 900,000 common shares, to be sold through a Bateman, Eichler, Hill, Richards group.

headline: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as traders continued to worry about the heavy supply of new corporate and Treasury issues and their financing costs.   Even though prices have dropped in recent days, salesmen say that there has been modest buying of bonds. Nevertheless, it is continuing as some buyers follow the old dictum of ''buy on weakness.'' Since June 16, the price of 30-year Treasury bonds has dropped about 4 1/2 points, or $45 per $1,000 bond, as the 13 7/8 percent issue due in 2011 closed yesterday at 105 14/32 offered to yield 13.14 percent.

headline: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW WEEKLY SAYS POLAND'S TRADE UNION WANTS ROLE OF A PARTY
abstract: Literaturnaya Gazeta, the weekly paper of the Soviet writers union, accused Poland's industrial trade union today of becoming a political movement in competition with the Communist Party.   The charge was made in the second of two articles on Poland by Feliks F. Kuznetsov, head of the Moscow branch of the writers' organization.

headline: Black Youths Loot Shops In Southeastern London
abstract: About 500 black youths smashed shop windows in southeastern London tonight, looting stores and hurling debris at motorists.

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Omni magazine to increase its circulation rate base 3.1 percent, to 825,000 from 800,000, and its advertising rates 22.3 percent, effective with the October issue.   * BBDO International acquiring a minority interest in Publiart Ltd., a Santiago, Chile, agency. * Ogilvy & Mather/Los Angeles opening an office in Irvine, Calif.

headline: POLISH COMMUNIST FACTION APPEALS FOR MORE FREEDOM IN PARTY SYSTEM
abstract: Delegates from Communist Party units throughout Poland met here today to demand democratic changes in the party and a system in which power would flow upward from the people, not downward from the central apparatus.   The meeting marked the emergence of a radical group in the rankand-file membership, one with very different ideas of what the Communist Party should be and how it should function.   Most of the 750 delegates to the meeting, which was held in a a modern, wood-paneled lecture hall at Nicholas Copernicus University, were from Torun, the birthplace of Copernicus five centuries ago.Torun is a center of the democratic movement that has been sweeping Poland since strikes virtually paralyzed the country last summer.  Also present were representatives from at least 19 other Communist Party units.

headline: HUBBELL, HARVEY, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SADAT: A MAN OF WAR AND PEACE, NOW MARKING TIME
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat, who won his reputation with grand initiatives involving war and peace, is spending most of his time now on undramatic endeavors at home.   Almost every day his picture is on front pages - inspecting a chicken farm or a land reclamation project, watching a military display in the desert or presiding at some state council.   Mr. Sadat, who will be meeting tomorrow with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., has been seeking to make his Government stronger and to institutionalize his personal power ever since he took over as his own Prime Minister last May, for the second time, and promised to devote his energy to the country's forbidding economic and social problems.   His drive for consolidation has been successful, in the short term at least, according to impartial foreign observers. For the moment there are fewer pressures on him than at many times in the past. But there are dark clouds.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK ASKS 'PRACTICAL' STEPS ON NAMIBIA
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate, warned the Security Council today that it would not win independence for South-West Africa by cutting off trade with South Africa or issuing declarations and resolutions.   Instead, she urged ''practical alternatives to a continuing search for an internationally acceptable solution.'' What these ''practical alternatives'' were she did not say. But her brief address, an unexpected addition at the end of the third day of Council debate over South-West Africa, or Namibia, deeply disappointed African diplomats.

headline: British Strike Delays Liner
abstract: The British cruise ship Canberra, bringing 1,600 passengers back from the Mediterranean, was turned away here today after striking dock workers refused to service the vessel. Passengers shouted insults at union officials and sang ''Rule Britannia'' before being taken ashore later at Portsmouth by tender.

headline: Mergers Up 46% Over '80
abstract: The pace of corporate mergers quickened in the first quarter of 1981, rising to 599, or 46 percent ahead of the 411 in the same quarter a year earlier, W.T. Grimm & Company, a Chicago-based merger specialist said yesterday.   Reflecting several billion-dollar acquisitions under way in the quarter, total dollar volume rose to a record $17.5 billion, more than double the $7.2 billion in the first quarter of 1980, Grimm said.

headline: U.S. FAVORS NEW PROPOSAL FOR THE INDEPENDENCE OF NAMIBIA
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was prepared to discuss a modification of the United Nations plan for South-West African independence that might be acceptable to South Africa and to black African states.   The officials discussed this possibility as the White House, seeking to demonstrate that foreign policy business was going on as usual despite the wounding of President Reagan, announced formally that Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, would lead a mission to southern Africa next month.   The Administration wants to ask the various parties to consider adoption of a ''Zimbabwe formula,'' in which the future laws of the country would be worked out before an election took place. The current United Nations plan for South-West Africa's independence says elections would be held first to set up a constituent assembly that would in turn draft the laws.

headline: Commodities; Interest Takes Toll On Futures
abstract: THE extraordinary rise in interest rates last week weighed heavily on all basic food and industrial commodity futures prices. At a time when there is no shortage of any raw material, it made trade hedgers loath to carry or add to inventories, while speculators eyed the rising yields on Treasury bills, certificates of deposits and other relatively safe short-term money market instruments.   Copper futures prices on New York's Commodity Exchange provided an example of the impact of interest rates, which are the dominant factor in all futures markets today. Prices fell about a cent a pound on the week, despite the fact that were many indications that the sluggish market was due for a rebound.

headline: Company News; Standard of Indiana Encouraged by Find
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the sixth-largest United States oil company, said that natural gas production from the United Arab Emirates sheikdom of Sharja could begin in 1982 if the company's second well there confirms a major find.

headline: 102 New Products Introduced in March
abstract: The New Product News published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample reports that 102 new products were introduced in March, compared with 78 in February.

headline: KEY DEMOCRATS DRAFT TWO-YEAR BILL TO CUT TAXES 5%, THEN 10%
abstract: In a challenge to the Reagan Administration, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began drawing up a new two-year tax relief bill today that the committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, said he hoped ''all Democrats'' would support on the House floor.   This statement by Mr. Rostenkowski, at the end of a two-hour, closed-door caucus of Ways and Means Democrats, indicated that the Democrats were preparing for a test of strength with the Administration on the House floor over the tax cuts.   One Democratic member of the committee reported that there was an informal committee agreement on a first-year cut of 5 percent and a further 10 percent reduction in 1982. Reagan Backs Three-Year Bill   President Reagan has insisted on a three-year bill with 10 percent annual cuts, although he said yesterday that he would accept a 5 percent cut in the first year.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * William S. David named advertising director of Rolling Stone magazine.   * Charles T. Lanktree appointed vice president in charge of marketing services for Grand Union.

headline: G.P.U. GETS RATE RISE
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation, facing possible bankruptcy because of the Three Mile Island accident, won permission yesterday to increase substantially rates charged by its two Pennsylvania subsidiaries.   Analysts said the increase, which would generate additional annual revenues of $106.7 million, could give the utility more time to solve its financial problems, although the amount was less than G.P.U. had requested. 'Needs Money to Survive'   ''The company needs this money to survive,'' a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission said. The commission unanimously voted to approve the rate increases, the first the two subsidiaries have received since 1978.

headline: BANKERS NOW FAVORING BRAZIL
abstract: In an abrupt departure from the warning signals it was putting out regularly only months ago, the international banking community is expressing favor with the economy of Brazil and lending the Government money at a rate that is outstripping national leaders' programmed goals.   The development has come at a time when banks in Europe, North America and Japan are already showing more Brazilian credit on their books than they would like, and when the inflation rate is at a record 120 percent and foreign debt has topped $57 billion.   The bankers are responding in part to a beginning-of-the-year tendency toward optimism and to the very high spreads being offered by Brazil. But the representatives of foreign banks here are also acting out of belief that the austerity measures being adopted by Brasilia are the correct ones to combat the soaring inflation and manage the foreign debt that is the largest in the developing world.

headline: Cities Service Cuts Oil Fee
abstract: The Cities Service Company yesterday announced a $1-a-barrel reduction in the amount it will pay for high-quality crude oil produced in the United States.   The move by the large American refiner followed recent United States price reductions by the Husky Oil Company and Conoco Inc. and adds strength to expectations for an across-the-board reduction in domestic oil prices.

headline: International
abstract: The Reagan Administration's strict monetarist policy is causing serious problems for other nations, the Bank for International Settlements said in its annual report. High interest rates in America are contributing to a recession in Europe that threatens international economic cooperation, the bank said. (Page D1.)

headline: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sun Weighs Sale Of Texas Refinery
abstract: The Sun Company said it was considering disposing of its Corpus Christi, Tex., refinery and petrochemical plants for an undisclosed target price.

headline: BRO-DART INDUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Producer prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December for finished goods. At the end of 1980, that index was 11.7 percent higher than at the end of 1979 - a bit better than the 12.6 percent rise in 1979. Food prices fell in December, but advances for energy, capital equipment and other goods more than offset the drop, the Labor Department reported. ''It's not comforting at all,'' commented Arnold Shindler, a senior economist at Bankers Trust. (Page 1.)   Unemployment stood at 7.4 percent of the workforce in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Although the rate was below November's 7.5 percent, the improvement was too slight to suggest any real recovery. Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told Congress's Joint Economic Committee, however, that ''some improvement in the economy occurred as both the number of payroll jobs and the factory workweek continued to rise.'' (15.) In New York City the jobless rate was 7.7 percent in December, an improvement over November's 8.3 percent. (15.)

headline: BANI-SADR ASSOCIATES SAY HE MAY BE LOSING POWER STRUGGLE IN TEHERAN
abstract: Associates of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr appear convinced that he is losing his struggle against political foes and that his ouster may be near. But the President, although increasingly isolated by the Shiite clergy that dominates the Government, vows to ''remain in his post'' no matter what. ''To make an oak fall,'' he said in an interview, ''one must start by sawing it.'' He expressed confidence that the Iranian people, who elected him overwhelmingly in January 1980, were still behind him.  The President's associates, however, believe that the turning point in Mr. Bani-Sadr's feud with the Islamic Republican Party, which dominates the Parliament and the judiciary as well as the Government, came May 27 with an attack upon him by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: THE HIGH COST OF KIDNEY CARE
abstract: Statistically, the number of Americans suffering from serious kidney diseases may not loom large, but certainly for them - and also the nation -their survival is becoming a serious economic problem, and possibly a moral one.   The annual cost of kidney-disease benefits now exceeds $1 billion, up from about $900 million a year ago. In the next few years, the costs can be expected to reach $2 billion to $3 billion annually.   What is known as the ''dialysis population'' in this country is now about 62,000, compared with about 16,000 five years ago. It rose last year by about 7,000 people, despite the fact that 2,000 had kidney transplants, which took them off dialysis for as much as five years. But only about half of kidney transplants are successful.

headline: VOTING ON ABORTION IS LIGHT IN ITALY
abstract: Italians started voting today in a referendum on whether to repeal the nation's abortion law, amid speculation on whether the shooting of Pope John Paul II might affect the outcome.   The polls were open all day today and will be open tomorrow morning. The turnout today, a sunny warm day throughout most of Italy, was light, but it is expected to be heavy tomorrow. Both the opponents of the law and its defenders have been waging a bitter campaign.

headline: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Budd Unit to Make Pollution Equipment
abstract: The Budd Company of Troy, Mich., a unit of Thyssen A.G., the West German heavy-industry concern, announced its entry into the air pollution control business with establishment in New York of Thyssen-CEA Environmental Systems Inc. in partnership with Thyssen Engineering, another Thyssen A.G. unit.

headline: TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dun & Bradstreet Net Up
abstract: Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday that its net income rose 15 percent in the three months ended March 31, to $26.5 million, from $23.1 million a year earlier.

headline: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. MIDEAST ENVOY, HIS MISSION CLOUDED, VISITS SAUDI ARABIA
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, traveled to Saudi Arabia today after five quiet days in Beirut, his Middle East peace efforts cast into doubt by the Israeli bombing of an Iraqi nuclear plant.   Mr. Habib left here at 11 this morning, with American officials refusing to disclose his destination. The Saudi press agency reported his arrival in Jidda late this afternoon.   The United States is pinning much of its hope for defusing the Middle East missile crisis between Israel and Syria on the possibility that the Saudis will be able to exert some form of moderating influence on the Syrians.

headline: Soviet Navy Squadron Winds Up A Monthlong Visit to Cuban Port
abstract: A four-ship Soviet naval squadron has left Cuban waters after a monthlong visit and operations in the Caribbean Sea, the United States Navy reported today.   The squadron, including a guided-missile cruiser, two guidedmissile destroyers and a tanker, arrived in Havana on April 15. It was the first Soviet naval force to visit Cuba in 18 months.

headline: Market Place; Inflation: A Tax That Bites Deep
abstract: THE chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Warren E. Buffett, always reflects on the world of business in his company's annual report.  This year his subject is the impact of inflation on corporate earnings, and he paints a grim picture. As always, his remarks have relevance for the nation's shareholders generally.   In Mr. Buffett's view, it is a mistake to focus on reported earnings in determining how the owners of a business did. Only gains in purchasing power represent real earnings on investment, he says, and he uses this illustration to prove his point:   ''If you (a) forgo 10 hamburgers to purchase an investment, (b) receive dividends which, after tax, buy two hamburgers and (c) receive, upon sale of your holdings, after-tax proceeds that will buy eight hamburgers, then (d) you have had no real income from your investment, no matter how much it appreciated in dollars. You may feel richer, but you won't eat richer.''

headline: 2 AIRLINE ACCOUNTS SHIFTED
abstract: BOZELL & JACOBS won the $45 million American Airlines account yesterday after Doyle Dane Bernbach, the carrier's agency for 20 years, dropped out of the running and came up with the $35 million Pan American World Airways account.   If Madison Avenue was shocked, then N.W. Ayer Inc., Pan Am's agency for the last three years, was distraught.  ''I want to say I'm stunned,'' said Louis T. Hagopian, the agency's chairman, ''and that's all I want to say. It's so absolutely shocking.''

headline: UA CABLE MERGER APPROVED
abstract: As expected, UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc.'s board approved a definitive agreement yesterday providing for a merger with a joint venture of United Artists Theater Circuit Inc. and Rogers Cablesystems Inc.   The cable company's board accepted the $90-a-share offer by a unanimous vote, with the four United Artists Theater Circuit directors who attended abstaining. At the same time, UA-Columbia terminated its definitive agreement to merge with Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., which had earlier bid $80 a share for UA-Columbia.

headline: Japan's Premier Rests in Geneva
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for what was described as a weekend of relaxation between stops on his current European tour. Mr. Suzuki has just spent three days in Italy, and plans to travel to Belgium on Monday.

headline: Mitterrand and Schmidt Call for Military Balance
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany met for three and a half hours today and agreed that the West should work to restore military balance in Europe while pursuing arms control talks with Moscow, West German sources said.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE SUIT SETTLEMENT
abstract: PITTSBURGH June 17 (AP) -The Westinghouse Electric Corportion said it had reached an out-of-court settlement with the last of 29 defendants in a five-year-old uranium antitrust suit.   The terms of the settlement with the Phibro Corporation, formerly known as Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals, were not disclosed.

headline: SPORTS FANS ON THE MOVE
abstract: Nelson Skalbania, an entrepreneur from Vancouver, British Columbia, seems to be close to fulfilling his dream of owning a professional franchise in every major sport in the North America.   Reports indicate that Mr. Sakalbania, who was turned down in January when he proposed to add a team to the National Basketball Association, is now negotiating to purchase the San Diego Clippers, which is already in the league, and move the team to Vancouver.   A flamboyant, bearded 42-year-old, Mr. Skalbania is an avid sports buff who made millions in property development and investment during Vancouver's land boom of the 1960's and 70's.

headline: REGAN BARS MONEY FUND CURBS NOW
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration opposed adopting any specific measures at this time to help ailing savings banks and savings and loan associations, including curbs on high-yielding money market mutual funds.   Savings industry leaders have called for the imposition of reserve requirements that would have the effect of reducing the yield that these funds pay to investors. Banks and thrift institutions have complained that the unregulated money market funds, because they can offer higher interest rates, have drained away billions of dollars of deposits that might otherwise have been used for mortgage and consumer loans.   Commercial banks and savings institutions are required by law to set aside a certain portion of their deposits in special noninterestbearing accounts with the Federal Reserve.

headline: Economic Scene; Energy Supply And Strategies
abstract: WASHINGTON THE winter heating season is behind us, petroleum imports are down sharply, the industry is awash in gasoline and there is now talk of a peace treaty between Iraq and Iran, two major OPEC producers that have been engaged in undeclared war since September.   Perhaps this helps to explain why the Reagan Administration and some members of Congress seem so relaxed about the United States energy situation. Others, however, are appalled by what they regard as dangerous complacency about energy supplies when there is a chance for the first time in several years to do something significant to improve supplies.   Could the Republicans be relying too much on the undoubted virtues of the free market in an area where private enterprise cannot be expected to work so well?

headline: Advertising; Petersen's Segmented Markets
abstract: IF it believes in nothing else, Petersen Publishing certainly believes in a segmented marketplace - and how it loves to cater to it. And it believes the more refined the market, the better.   Other magazine publishers might have magazines that cover all hunting and fishing activities, but Petersen has Hunting magazine and Guns & Ammo. It does not have one boating magazine; it has three regional editions, each with a different name.

headline: CAMFLO MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SANDS DIES IN NORTHERN IRELAND JAIL ON THE 66TH DAY OF HUNGER STRIKE
abstract: Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army hunger striker and Member of Parliament, died early today on his 66th day without food. He had begun his fast in an effort to force the British Government to recognize I.R.A. inmates as political prisoners rather than common criminals.   Death came to Mr. Sands at 1:17 A.M. (8:17 P.M. Monday, New York time) in the hospital wing of the Maze Prison, where members of his family had been conducting an anxious vigil for several days.   ''He just finally starved to death,'' said a Government official.  The I.R.A. said this morning that Mr. Sands would be buried later this week ''with all the ceremony due a republican volunteer.'' Soon after 2 A.M., I.R.A. sympathizers in cars with loudspeakers and sirens began spreading the news of Mr. Sand's death through Roman Catholic neighborhoods of Belfast.

headline: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * House and Garden magazine to Wyse Advertising. People   * Frederick Scheel appointed executive vice president of Wimmershoff & Associates, Westwood, N.J. Addendum   * Ladies' Home Journal increasing its national advertising page rates 4.1 percent, effective with the October issue.

headline: FACTORY USE UP SLIGHTLY IN MAY
abstract: The nation's manufacturers operated at 80.1 percent of capacity in May, the highest level in 13 months but only one-tenth of a percentage point higher than April's factory use, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The nearly unchanged use of manufacturing capacity from April to May was ''really no surprise, given the small change in industrial production'' reported yesterday, said David Ernst, vice president of Evans Economics in Washington.   The Fed reported yesterday that industrial production rose a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in May, to a production index figure of 152.8, or 152.8 percent of production in the base year of 1967.

headline: Jordanian King Visits Moscow
abstract: King Hussein left today for Moscow on the first state visit by the Jordanian ruler to the Soviet Union in more than five years.

headline: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Futures Exchange: Resignation Is Seen
abstract: William M. Smith, 37 years old, the first president and chief executive officer of the New York Futures Exchange, intends to resign, sources close to the exchange said yesterday. The exchange opened last August as the New York Stock Exchange's subsidiary for commodity trading.

headline: Holiday Inns Casino Plan
abstract: Holiday Inns Inc. said today that it wanted to buy out its California partner in the $145 million, 504-room Harrah's Marina, the fourth of Atlantic City's seven casino hotels.

headline: Iran Importing U.S. Wheat
abstract: Iran will buy about 125,000 tons of United States Western white wheat a month during the next year, according to American grain exporters. Before the hostage crisis, Iran regularly imported 100,000 to 125,000 tons of such wheat every month.

headline: energywatch
abstract: APRIL 3 Crude oil stocks jumped to 395.4 million barrels. Experts say the increase reflects a decline in refinery output and a rise in crude oil imports.

headline: Gillette, Scripto To Settle Suit
abstract: The Gillette Company and Scripto Inc. said they had agreed on terms for the dismissal of a civil suit brought by Gillette against Scripto in Federal court in Boston last June.

headline: MRS. GANDHI'S SON FAVORED IN INDIAN VOTING TODAY
abstract: As an airline pilot, Rajiv Gandhi, the 36-year-old son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, has flown over this backward area in Uttar Pradesh many times.   As a candidate seeking election to Parliament from this district, Mr. Gandhi has now traversed the length and breadth of the area by jeep and foot, and he says that what he saw has both baffled and overwhelmed him.   ''I came face to face with people in the villages for the first time,'' he said in an interview at the end of a campaign meeting in this village 250 miles southeast of New Delhi. ''What I saw made me feel humble.''

headline: INLAND EXPANSION
abstract: The Inland Steel Company said that it would build a continuous anneal line at its plant near Chicago that would be capable of processing up to 400,000 tons a year of high-strength, light-weight sheet steel. That steel is used in large amounts by the auto industry. Inland, which ranks seventh in terms of raw steel production, did not disclose the cost of the project which was due to completed in 1983.

headline: DOW DOWN 4.06 ON RATE FEARS
abstract: Concern over interest rates sent the stock market down moderately yesterday for the second consecutive session.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the loss column throughout most of the session, finished down 4.06 points, to 969.10. On Monday, the blue-chip barometer fell 7.11 points.

headline: INTERNATIONAL POWER MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cities Service Sues Canadian Interests
abstract: The Cities Service Company said today that it had begun legal action to block purchases of its stock by Canadian interests that it says are trying to ''strong-arm'' United States companies into selling Canadian oil and gas holdings.   The suit, filed in United States District Court here last week, names Nu-West Group Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, and the Toronto Dominion Bank.

headline: SUZUKI SAYS U.S. DID NOT CONSULT ON ENDING GRAIN BAN
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, who will visit Washington next week, criticized the United States today for not having consulted with Japan before ending the 15-month curb on grain shipments to the Soviet Union.   ''We were informed about this lifting before the action was taken,'' said Mr. Suzuki at a news conference with reporters for American news organizations, ''but we were not consulted sufficiently in advance or asked our views on the timing of the move.''   The Prime Minister also said that Japan was not given ''any explanation as to the reason for the action'' and he added that ''there was no move to coordinate with whatever action Japan may take on our economic sanctions against the Soviet Union.''

headline: MITTERRAND LEADS IN POLLS FOR MAY 10 RUNOFF IN FRANCE
abstract: There is still more than a week to go and nothing is yet decided. But as of today the Socialist candidate, Francois Mitterrand, seems to hold the lead over President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in the presidential election that takes place on May 10.   Several developments over the last few days suggest that as things stand now, there is a slightly more than even chance that the series of right-of-center presidencies that have run the Fifth Republic since Charles de Gaulle set it up 23 years ago will give way to one to the left of center.   Of the two major polls taken since last Sunday's first-round balloting - in which the President finished slightly ahead of his Socialist challenger but did not win a majority - one has 51.5 percent favoring Mr. Mitterrand and 48.5 percent for Mr. Giscard d'Estaing. Taken by the I.F.O.P. organization, which came the closest of any poll here to predicting the first-round results, it will be published tomorrow in the magazine Le Point.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SAUDI URGES U.S. TO CHANGE POLICY   (By United Press International) - Prince Saud al-Faisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, urged the United States yesterday to change its policy toward Israel, which he said could strike anywhere ''without restrictions'' and was trying to block American attempts to maintain peace in the Middle East.   ''What would be the state of world if the United States and the Soviet Union could act as Israel?'' he asked in an interview on the ABC News ''Issues and Answers'' program, taped in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, and televised in the United States a week after Israel's attack on Iraq's nuclear reactor.

headline: U.S. Atheist Leader Is 'Stunned'
abstract: Madalyn Murray O'Hair, president and founder of the American Atheist Center, said today that although she considers Pope John Paul II ''my enemy,'' she would send a telegram wishing him a speedy recovery.

headline: Soviet Moves to Offset End Of U.S. Aid to Nicaragua
abstract: The Soviet Union and its allies are apparently moving quickly to compensate for the suspension of aid to Nicaragua by the Reagan Administration.   The Nicaraguan Government announced yesterday that Moscow had donated 20,000 tons of grain and was lending the Nicaraguans two transport helicopters and crews to ferry food, medical supplies and literacy teams to remote villages. In addition, the Government said that it had received a $100 million loan from Libya and $64 million worth of technical assistance from Cuba.

headline: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Reagan Administration's attempts to improve relations with Argentina come when there are few tangible benefits for the United States. The intangible ones are difficult to measure.   The Administration has asked Congress to lift an arms embargo imposed more than two years ago because of Argentina's human rights policies and has sent a number of generals and admirals on visits here.   James L. Buckley, the Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, Science and Technology, testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the embargo frustrates United States strategic interests, particularly in the South Atlantic.

headline: YOUNG MANAGEMENT OF FRENCH GAUMONT BUILDS MEDIA GIANT
abstract: SUR-SEINE, France, May 26 - As the Cannes Film Festival draws to a close, Gaumont, France's largest entertainment company, has, as usual, the biggest battalion on the Cannes battlefront. Yet the Gaumont name is written in tiny letters on its billboards, and its executives meet in a secluded villa removed from the festival limelight.   This low profile typifies the company's distinctly untheatrical demeanor in an industry sometimes given to histrionics.  From an unremarkable modern building just outside the Paris city limits, a young management team has brought the company from a sleepy family entertainment business with revenues of $31.3 million in 1975 to one of Europe's hottest competitors, with revenues of $82.4 million last year.

headline: LUNG GETS BETTER
abstract: Exhaustive clinical tests have shown that Pope John Paul II is suffering from a mild viral infection that has no direct connection with the wounds he suffered in an assassination attempt in May, his doctors announced today.   In a medical bulletin issued at Gemelli Hospital and the Vatican, the Pope's doctors said that the tests, which were carried out over the last three days, confirmed an earlier finding that the wounds in his abdomen were not infected.   The cause of the infection, which was identified as a cytomegalovirus, is often transmitted through the blood, according to a medical expert. In the emergency operation after the Pope was shot he was given about 10 pints of blood, which means that virtually his entire blood volume was replaced. But today's bulletin made no connection between the virus and the blood transfusion.

headline: NEW RISKS FOR GERMAN BUILDERS
abstract: The Hochtief construction company has built a bridge over the Bosporus to link Europe and Asia and an airport at Jidda, Saudi Arabia, and has moved the tombs of the Pharaohs at Abu Simbel when the waters behind Egypt's Aswan Dam threatened to destroy them.   The big German concern was to a certain extent forced into this heady world of international construction in the early 1970's, when a slumping market in West Germany led it to seek projects abroad.   And at the same time, the company found that engineers fresh from successes in Kuwait or Brazil brought new ideas to building subways or streets in Mainz or Hanover.   Today, however, Hochtief may be facing its biggest challenge: how to engineer continued profits in the face of a renewed building slump in Germany, a worldwide recession, growing political uncertainties and spreading competition from builders in developing countries. Competition Is Broad   ''There is competition from Korea and the Far East, Brazil and Mexico,'' said Harald Peiper, Hochtief's chief financial officer and head of international operations at the company's headquarters here.  ''On the best projects, they're always along. Building is one of the first things these countries want to do themselves. It's part of a profound shift on the market.''

headline: FLUOR'S STOCK FALLS AS TRADERS STUDY BID TO TAKE OVER ST. JOE
abstract: The Fluor Corporation's stock fell $4.50 a share in heavy trading yesterday as sharp differences developed over whether the huge engineering and construction company's $2.9 billion offer to acquire the St. Joe Minerals Corporation was really a good deal for Fluor.   Fluor shares, which closed at 46, were the sixth most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. Some traders forecast further declines, while others expressed optimism about the multibilliondollar takeover proposal.   Only a day earlier, the two companies reached a preliminary merger agreement that calls for Fluor to pay $60 a share for 45 percent of St. Joe's stock and to swap 1.2 shares of Fluor stock for each of the remaining St. Joe shares.

headline: SHUTTLE PLAQUE GIVEN TO SPANISH KING
abstract: John W. Young, at right, commander of the first orbital shuttle flight, presenting commemorative plaque to King Juan Carlos in Madrid.

headline: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Wins A Seat in India's Parliament
abstract: Rajiv Gandhi, the 36-year-old son of the Prime Minister, was elected to Parliament today, capturing the seat that became vacant last June when his younger brother, Sanjay, was killed in the crash of a stunt airplane. Since the accident, it has widely been expected that Mr. Gandhi would succeed his brother as his mother's closest adviser.

headline: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; WOMEN'S OUTERWEAR CAMPAIGN
abstract: LONDON TOWN, a subsidiary of Interco, already knows the effectiveness of brand names in rainwear, thanks to its London Fog division. Now it is going to test the concept with women's coats and outerwear. Its Clipper Mist division, with a licensing agreement from Wolverine Wide World, will be marketing them under the Hush Puppies label.

headline: Business People; Dave DeBusschere Finds Business Is a Pleasure
abstract: Dave DeBusschere, 40, the former star basketball player for the New York Knicks, is deeply involved in the world of business these days - more so than most athletes after their retirement from competitive athletics. But to Mr. DeBusschere, his corporations, partnerships and salaried positions are all involvements that he enjoys as much as he enjoyed his playing days.   ''I like business and I like to be creative,'' he said yesterday.  ''But it's a matter of total application. You have to do it yourself. I don't believe somebody's going to come to you.''

headline: ISRAEL EXPRESSES 'PROFOUND REGRET' OVER PLAN TO SELL AWACS TO SAUDIS
abstract: Israel today protested the Reagan Administration's decision to supply sophisticated weapons, including Awacs electronic surveillance aircraft, to Saudi Arabia.   Prime Minister Menachem Begin read an official protest to Ambassador Samuel Lewis, who had requested a meeting this morning to exchange views on the increased fighting in Lebanon. Mr. Begin then amplified on the Government's prepared statement and called on the United States to reconsider its decision.

headline: PENNSYLVANIA FARM LAG SEEN
abstract: Agriculture in the United States has evolved into a large-scale, specialized, highly mechanized system, heavily dependent upon petroleum and relying upon certain regions to provide the bulk of the nation's food needs - California, the produce; the Great Plains, the hogs, and the Corn Belt, the corn, for example.   Now, with the rising cost of energy, critics increasingly are suggesting that this agriculture pattern may be costing consumers dearly, both in dollars and in food security.   A new study, released last week, details what the American food system means for Pennsylvania, the most important agricultural state in the Northeastern region. Pennsylvania, according to the report, imported $8.4 billion worth of food - almost 70 percent of its total food needs - in 1980. That figure includes $400 million for transportation costs alone.

headline: Iranian Jurist Questions Legality Of Ex-Deputy Premier's Spy Trial
abstract: A leading Iranian jurist today questioned the legality of the trial of former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam on charges of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.   In a message published in two Teheran newspapers, Sheik Ali Teherani, widely considered the most eminent Islamic legal expert in Iran, urged President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr to intervene in the trial, saying, ''It is, as you know, in some aspects illegal.''

headline: Blast Kills 4 on Italian Tanker
abstract: An explosion aboard an Italian tanker off Naples last night killed four crew members, officials said today. The 12,000-ton tanker Umiltas was sailing without a cargo at the time of the explosion.

headline: HARVESTER LOSS SEEN UNTIL EARLY IN 1982
abstract: The best that the International Harvester Company can hope for this fiscal year is to break even, according to a report by the consulting firm of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.   The analysis, prepared at Harvester's request, said the big farmmachinery maker is unlikely to turn a profit before the first quarter of the 1982 calendar year.

headline: MR. MOORE'S NEW GAUGE OF JOBS
abstract: In spite of unpredictable economic performance thus far this year, the unemployment rate has remained relatively steady at around 7.5 percent, far above acceptable levels but below what some economists had feared might occur. According to a new index, which is designed to anticipate changes in employment, conditions may even be a bit better than they already appear.

headline: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Florida Systems will redeem all of its issued and outstanding $2.40 series B cumulative convertible preferred stock on June 29.   * Detroit Edison is offering 1.25 million shares of common stock at $11.62 each, and 250,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock 15.68 series at $100 a share plus accrued dividends, to be sold through a Morgan Stanley group.

headline: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FABRI-TEK INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: By Leoanard Sloane
abstract: BUSINESS PEOPLE Tiffany Heir Resigns As Company's Chief   Henry B. Platt, the 56-year-old descendant of Charles L. Tiffany, who founded Tiffany & Company in 1837, has given up the titles of chairman and chief executive officer of the jewelry and silverware retailer and producer after only five months. He will, however, remain as vice chairman.   Mr. Platt's successor as both chairman and chief executive officer is David W. Mitchell, chairman of Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics and fragrances producer that acquired Tiffany in April 1979 for $104 million in stock. In response to a question, Mr. Mitchell said yesterday that he would continue in both roles indefinitely.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Florida System plans to offer 2 million common shares.   * American Agronomics Corporation offered 1 million common shares through underwriters led by Shearson Loeb Rhodes.

headline: Briton Accused of 13 Killings Will Be Tried in London
abstract: The trial of a man accused of murdering 13 women during the last five years will be held in London, lawyers agreed today.   The jury trial for Peter Sutcliffe, a 35-year-old truck driver accused of the murders, will begin April 29.

headline: Kenyon & Eckhardt Wins All of Turtle Wax Back
abstract: After the briefest of flings as a two-agency company, Turtle Wax Inc. of Chicago has consolidated back to one again.

headline: WEINBERGER URGES JAPAN TO TAKE MORE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ITS DEFENSE
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that ''Japan would find it exceedingly difficult to defend itself with current forces'' and should ''provide much more for its own self-defense.''   In a speech in San Francisco, Mr. Weinberger reviewed the first 100 days of the Reagan Administration's military policy but focused on the Soviet threat in Asia and what the United States expected of its Asian allies, particularly Japan. His text was made available here.

headline: Wartime Shell Kills 3 in Soviet
abstract: Three boys, all about 12 years old, were killed and two others were injured when a World War II shell exploded at their school in the Ukraine, a Soviet newspaper said today.

headline: Prices on Bourse Rebound a Bit After Vote Shock
abstract: Stock prices today recovered some of the sharp losses they had suffered earlier in the week following the election of Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, as President.   After a deluge of buy orders, some shares were suspended with limit rises, following the limit declines of the two previous sessions, dealers said. A maximum movement of 10 percent is allowed in any one day.

headline: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHB FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LESLIE FAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW IS PUBLICIZING A HARD-LINE POLISH STATEMENT
abstract: The Soviet press, in giving prominent attention to a document drawn up by Polish Communists in Katowice, has suggested Kremlin support for the thesis that the Polish party is in the grips of ''revisionism and opportunism'' and incapable of controlling events.   A summary by Tass, the Soviet press agency, of statements made at a party forum last week in Katowice was read on the evening television news yesterday and was printed today in Pravda, the principal Soviet newspaper.   The Katowice statement said that the last 10 months had done more damage to the Polish party than the entire decade before that, suggesting that the concessions made to the independent industrial trade union were a greater ideological evil than the damaging economic policies pursued by the Polish party until the worker revolt last August.

headline: SYSTEMS PLANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Britain Consents To Observer's Sale
abstract: Britain's trade secretary, John Biffen, told Parliament today that he had consented to the Atlantic Richfield Company's proposed sale of The Sunday Observer newspaper to Lonrho Ltd, the British conglomerate.   Mr. Biffen said he would support a report published by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission recommending approval of the sale to Lonrho, which is headed by Roland Rowland.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A 14-member tribunal, patterned on the Bertrand Russell inquiry in 1967 into American involvement in Vietnam, began hearing testimony yesterday about alleged Soviet violations of international law in Afghanistan. The tribunal includes former Foreign Minister Ernesto Melo Antunes of Portugal, Eduardo Galeano, the Uruguayan author, and George Wald, the Nobel Prize-winning American biologist.

headline: No Headline
abstract: ''It's like running a small town or like a county board of commissioners,'' said John M. McCabe, legislative director of the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws in Chicago, as he tried to describe how condominium communities are governed.   But the specialized relationships that develop in the homeownercontrolled buildings and complexes that are spreading across the country lack the guidance of centuries of legal precedent to protect the interests of the various parties concerned. All states have some sort of condominium legislation, but much of it is said to be copied after a 1961 Puerto Rico act. That law is now considered primitive and obsolete.

headline: HUSSEIN CONDEMNS ISRAEL, SLIGHTS SYRIA
abstract: Denouncing Israel for its part in the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon, King Hussein of Jordan assessed the situation today as ''very delicate, disturbingly dangerous and explosive.''   But when asked if his Government would directly aid Syria should Israel carry out its threat to use military force to remove the missiles, King Hussein said: ''Jordan already has its hands full on the longest confrontation line with Israel. One cannot see what may or may not happen in the future. Jordan is already exposed. Jordan is equally in danger.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Iranian jet fighters struck today at four airbases deep inside Iraqi territory in what was described by Teheran Radio as a major effort to destroy the enemy's air force.   The attack marked the first time since the war began more than six months ago that Iranian planes had penetrated so deeply inside Iraqi territory.

headline: MASSEY-FERGUSON TO SHUT IOWA PLANT
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. of Toronto has announced the closing of its four-wheel-drive tractor plant at Des Moines as the company seeks greater efficiency to reduce costs.   After the plant is closed on July 31, four-wheel-drive tractors will be made at Massey's plant in Detroit, where two-wheel-drive tractors now are made, and at factories in Toronto and Brantford, Ontario. Some 292 hourly paid workers will be laid off in Des Moines, along with 100 salaried employees, but the company said that 200 people will be added to the work force in Detroit, where 1,150 now are employed.

headline: Divesting Move By Swarthmore
abstract: The Swarthmore College Board of Managers announced today that it had divested itself of nearly $2.4 million worth of stock in corporations that deal with South Africa.   The college board voted to divest itself of its stock in Citicorp, the Newmont Mining Corporation and the Timken Company.

headline: California Auto Dealer Nominated To Be Ambassador to Australia
abstract: President Reagan today nominated Robert Dean Nesen, an aeronautical engineer and owner of a car sales and leasing concern, to be ambassador to Australia.

headline: Posner Units Raise Stake in 2 Concerns
abstract: The Sharon Steel Corporation, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, said it had increased its stake in the Evans Products Company to 2,232,900 shares, or 18.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sharon Steel said that its holdings included purchases between May 19 and June 2 of 130,000 shares of Evans common for an aggregate purchase price of $4.1 million.

headline: U.S SAYS IT IS ENCOURAGED BY HABIB'S MIDEAST MISSION
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it was encouraged by statements from Israeli and Syrian leaders that they wanted the mission of the special American envoy, Philip C.  Habib, to continue, thus allowing more time to avert a conflict.   Taking note of remarks by Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, the State Department spokesman, Dean Fischer, said, ''We welcome this and other indications that the parties concerned are willing to have Ambassador Habib's mission continue.''   Larry Speakes, the acting White House spokesman, said that the situation in the Middle East was ''still very dangerous,'' but that, in being able to extend Mr. Habib's mission, the Administration hoped to produce ''a calmer environment in which the longer-term problems of the area can be addressed.''

headline: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: European Steel Jobs Decline
abstract: The steel industry in the European Economic Community employed 636,400 workers last year, down 155,700, or 19.7 percent, from 792,100 in 1974, Eurostat, the Common Market's statistics agency, reported today.   It said that British steelmakers registered the biggest drop, 32.4 percent, with employment going to 133,600 last year from 197,700 workers in 1974.

headline: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLES PUT OFF SPECIAL SESSION OF PARLIAMENT
abstract: A special session of Parliament that was scheduled for Monday has been postponed until Friday because the Prime Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, is ''indisposed,'' the Polish press agency said today.   The news of the postponement added to tensions that have been mounting in response to Western concern over a possible Soviet invasion.   The alarm raised in Washington was not mentioned in any Polish publications today, but most Poles listen to Radio Free Europe, the Voice of America or the British Broadcasting Corporation, and those who do not listen to the Western broadcasts learn about them through Warsaw's gossip network.   The press agency, P.A.P., gave no details about the Prime Minister's indisposition, saying only that it was temporary. He had been scheduled to deliver a major address before Parliament on the country's crisis.

headline: EX-INSPECTOR ASSERTS IRAQ PLANNED TO USE REACTOR TO BUILD A-BOMBS
abstract: A former inspector for the International Atomic Energy Agency said here today that Iraq had been planning to develop atomic bombs using the nuclear reactor destroyed by Israel and that international safeguards would not have detected secret production of plutonium in the reactor for weapons.   The former inspector, Roger Richter, was one of three people familiar with nuclear reactors to testify this morning that Iraq was capable of using the reactor bombed on June 7 to produce plutonium, which can be used to make atomic weapons.  But neither of the other witnesses, Robert Seldon, head of the applied theoretical physics division at Los Alamos Laboratory, nor Herbert J.C. Kouts, chairman of the department of nuclear energy at Brookhaven National Laboratory, would say under questioning if he believed that Iraq was in fact planning to use the reactor to produce fissionable material for weapons.   Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr.  Richter said his concern over agency constraints in inspecting the Iraqi reactor led him to report his misgivings to the State Department last year. He said that he had never personally inspected the reactor, explaining that checks of the Iraqi plant had been conducted only by Soviet or Eastern European members of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Benton & Bowles Names A Second Vice President
abstract: Meanwhile at Benton & Bowles, which has only one president - John S. Bowen - the executive vice president population was doubled with the naming of a second one.

headline: LEBANESE SOLDIER IS KILLED IN A CLASH WITH ISRAELIS
abstract: United Nations forces and Lebanese troop clashed with Israeli forces in southern Lebanon last night.  One Lebanese soldier was killed and another wounded, according to accounts by the Lebanese radio and a spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping force.

headline: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; U.S. Is Advocating Freeze in U.N. Budgets
abstract: Elliott Abrams, President Reagan's choice for Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, said today that the United States had called on the United Nations and its agencies to hold budgets for 1984 and 1985 to the same dollar level as those being set for 1982 and 1983.   There is ''much too much fat'' in the budgets of international organizations, he told a news conference, adding that the Reagan Administration could not accept any further budgetary expansion.

headline: IN SOVIET, MAY DAY REMAINS FESTIVE HOLIDAY BUT THE SPONTANEITY IS GONE
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev and his colleagues in the Communist Party leadership, sporting red ribbons on their heavy overcoats, mounted the Lenin Mausoleum just before the Kremlin chimes began to ring. At the stroke of 10 o'clock, a recorded voice boomed out across Red Square:   ''Hail the First of May - the Day of International Solidarity of Workers in the struggle against imperialism, for peace, democracy and socialism!''   Thus began the Communist rite of spring in the Soviet capital, a demonstration as carefully orchestrated and controlled as the Chicago event it commemorates was chaotic and unforeseen.   Ninety-five years ago, a strike by workers in Chicago demanding an eight-hour workday led to the Haymarket Square bombing and a battle between workers and policemen. Three years later, the Second International proclaimed May Day as International Workers' Day.

headline: DESOLATE BLACK AREA MUST GIVE ITS SONS TO THE MINES
abstract: For about 1,500 blacks a year, the route to South Africa's gold mines starts in a desolate rural area near here that is inside one of the seven fragments of an officially independent black state called Bophuthatswana.   Rural blacks who cannot find employment in this small frontier town in the western Transvaal have no real alternative to working in the mines, for there is no prospect of a job or productive farming in the crowded countryside where they live. But now, with job hunger growing in the rural black areas of southern Africa, work in the mines is hard to come by even though the industry is in a period of expansion.    In the first two weeks of May there were hundreds of job-seekers in the rural area of Bophuthatswana known as Lehurutshe. But there were only 38 new jobs to be filled at the office of the Employment Bureau of Africa, which serves as the recruiting arm for the six major South African mining houses.

headline: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Marcos Opponents Decide Not to Contest Election
abstract: The main political opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos decided today against entering a candidate in the June 16 presidential elections, thus virtually assuring Mr.  Marcos a new six-year term.

headline: Futures Trading Jumps 130%
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday announced a record 130 percent increase in its first-quarter trading volume.  The exchange said that in the three months ended March 31 a record 450,322 commodity futures contracts were traded, compared with 196,006 in the similar period last year.

headline: Heavy Rains Flood Uzbekistan
abstract: The Republic of Uzbekistan has had as much rain in two days as sometimes falls in a whole year and floods have killed three people, the newspaper Izvestia said today.

headline: Genscher Urges Soviet To Withdraw SS-20's
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany today urged the Soviet Union to agree to a gradual withdrawal of SS-20 nuclear missiles in Europe so that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could review plans to deploy new missiles itself.   In a radio interview, Mr. Genscher accused Moscow of partially going back on Leonid I. Brezhnev's offer that all of Europe, from the Atlantic to the Urals, should be included in East-West agreements to monitor each other's military activities.

headline: Soviet Parliament to Convene
abstract: The Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, will convene in regular session on June 23, the Government announced today.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Hal D. Sieling has joined R. Biederman and Associates, Mission, Kan., as senior vice president of marketing.   * Eddie Kalish appointed vice president-domestic marketing for United Artists.   * Robert G. Lurie named director of advertising and communications for Tyco Industries, Moorestown, N.J.   * Paulette S. Barrett named executive vice president of the Rowland Company.

headline: International
abstract: Britain's two-year economic slide shows signs of having bottomed out, and the nation may even be poised for a modest recovery, according to public and private economists. The latest quarterly report by the Confederation of British Industries was the least gloomy in two years. (Page D1.)

headline: USING BOOKS AS SALES PREMIUMS
abstract: Buy some Kraft cheese and get a free copy of ''The Complete Cheese Cookbook.'' Pick up five packages of Viva towels, send in 50 cents and get the ''Better Homes and Gardens Cookbook.'' Scoop up three packages of Nabisco snack crackers, mail in 35 cents and get James Beard's ''Hors d'Oeuvre and Appetizers.''   These are just some of the offers dangled before consumers in the world of premium books. Marketers, of course, have long offered premiums with their goods or services - whether they be ballpoint pens, cameras, cigarette lighters or television sets.

headline: IRAN STEPS UP HUNT FOR BANI-SADR AND ARRESTS SOME OF HIS AIDES
abstract: Iranian authorities, asserting that former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was still in the country as recently as last night, stepped up their hunt for him today, arresting and questioning some of his closest friends and aides.   The revolutionary prosecutor of Teheran, Assadollah Lajverdi, said at a news conference that Mr. Bani-Sadr, who was removed from the presidency yesterday by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was known to be in Iran at the time.   Mr. Lajverdi did not explain how this was known, but added, ''He has probably not yet gone out of the country.'' Nevertheless, reports persisted that Mr. Bani-Sadr had fled to Egypt or was about to arrive there.  (In Cairo, Egypt's Information Minister, Mansour Hassan, said the Government would neither confirm nor deny reports of Mr. Bani-Sadr's presence there.  Another Egyptian source said that Egypt had granted a request from Mr. Bani-Sadr's aides that he be allowed to enter the country and that the former President was expected to arrive in 48 hours.

headline: Amcon Increases Newmont Holding
abstract: Amcon Group Inc. and Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., its parent, said they had increased their stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to 2.11 million shares, or 8.1 percent.

headline: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.R.S. WITHDRAWS DISPUTED BANK RULE
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service today withdrew a controversial ruling that could have increased borrowing costs for state and local governments while subjecting banks to millions of dollars of liability for back taxes.   The issue was whether banks could deduct on their tax returns interest paid on deposits by state and local governments if the banks used tax-exempt securities as collateral against these deposits.In general, the law forbids deducting interest payments when tax-exempt securities are used. However, the application of this doctrine late last year by the Carter Administration prompted a storm of criticism from banks, localities and others.

headline: A Proxy Battle Likely at SCM
abstract: Willard F. Rockwell Jr., retired Rockwell International Corporation chairman and a dissatisfied major stockholder of the SCM Corporation, said that he would again try to gain control of SCM's board - the third such challenge the diversified manufacturing company would face in as many years.   Mr. Rockwell complained, among other things, that the market price of SCM's stock has continued to remain below its book value - what the company's assets theoretically might fetch if sold - of about $49 a share since his previously unsucccessful battle for control of SCM.

headline: Other Business; A ZOO IN EVERY DRAWER
abstract: Men are beasts.  What feminism hasn't conclusively proven, sport shirts have. The alligator, Izod Lacoste's logo, began creeping across knit shirts 50 years ago when French tennis pro Rene Lacoste was nicknamed ''the croc'' for his speed.  Now, it's a veritable bestiary of the chest. Ralph Lauren's polo horse, Giorgio Armani's eagle, the tiger of Sweden. These atavistic insigniae mean the sports shirt involved sells for $30 to $40. And the designer shirts are sans the $25 Izod's extralong back flap so practical in a vigorous game.

headline: SQUEEZE ON MAGAZINES
abstract: After a period of unprecedented growth between 1975 and 1979, when revenues more than doubled, to $2.7 billion, and the number of pages increased more than 45 percent, a sagging economy made 1980 a disappointing year for magazine advertising.  Revenues rose by 4 percent, to $2.8 billion, a negative rate after inflation is taken into account.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Enhancing Non- Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BUCKLEY, OUTLINING REAGAN POLICY, CALLS ARMS SALES ABROAD 'VITAL' TOOL
abstract: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley declared today that sales of American weapons abroad ''complement and supplement our own defense efforts and serve as a vital and constructive instrument of American foreign policy.''   Speaking before the Aerospace Industries Association in Williamsburg, Va., Mr. Buckley presented a general framework for President Reagan's new policy on arms sales. Specific guidelines will be made public early next week, according to Administration officials.

headline: CANADIANS ARE PURSUING FOREIGN OIL COMPANIES
abstract: Foreign oil companies in Canada today find themselves increasingly the targets of a corporate big game hunt with billions of dollars at stake.   The immediate cause is Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's new nationalistic energy policy, which uses discriminatory taxing and exploration grant guidelines to favor oil companies defined as Canadian-owned. The goal is to raise domestic ownership of Canada's petroleum industry to 50 percent by 1990 from 28 percent today.   Government planners hope that many huge foreign energy companies, such as Exxon, Gulf, Texaco, Acquitaine, Chevron and British Petroleum, will sell all or part of their Canadian subsidiaries to Canadian companies, including Petro-Canada, the state oil company.  The federal Government is using Petro-Canada to gain its own substantial share of the oil business.

headline: SCHMIDT, IN PARLIAMENT, SILENT ON ATTACKS BY BEGIN
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in a report to Parliament today on his recent Middle East trip, declined to respond to personal attacks by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and called on Israel and the Arabs to live together ''in a just and all-embracing peace.''   Mr. Schmidt said he had nothing to add to comments made earlier this week by a West German Government spokesman, who said Mr. Begin was making campaign speeches that were ''not to the point and insulting.''   The Chancellor, who has made every effort not to strain relations further, said he chose silence ''precisely because I am conscious of the moral and historical quality of German-Israeli relations.''

headline: Black Stars Magazine Ends
abstract: Johnson Publications, the nation's largest black-owned publishing company, has ceased publication of its monthly Black Stars magazine and dismissed 51 employees in a cost-cutting move, company officials said today.   June A. Rhinehart, vice president and general counsel of the company, said the company had cut 3 percent of its employees, including many senior staff members of its nationally distributed Ebony magazine.

headline: OREGON METALLURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Fuel Additives Made From Vegetable Oils
abstract: Fuel and lubricant additives derived from vegetable oils were patented this week for the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla.

headline: NEW OIL FUTURES MARKET BOOMS
abstract: Since the first price for heating oil futures contracts was shouted on the floor of the International Petroleum Exchange's headquarters in Cereal House, Mark Lane, in the heart of London's financial district, business has been better than the most optimistic forcasts.   ''I've been involved in commodity trading for 25 years and I can't recall any other commodity market starting out as constructively as this one,'' said Brian Edgeley, managing director of the London subsidiary of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., which is a member of the new exchange.   The exchange reported trading amounting to some 6,919 contracts during its first two weeks ending last Thursday. Each contract calls for the future delivery of 100 metric tons of heating oil, or 31,000 gallons.

headline: SON'S JAILING RACKS SOUTH AFRICAN M.P.
abstract: On his way to Parliament this morning, Alex Boraine stopped by the security police headquarters to ask about his son. Even before he put the question about where his son was being held he knew what the answer would be.   As he later recalled it, the major who received him replied, ''I'm afraid I can't tell you that.'' Then Mr. Boraine asked an even more futile question about whether he and his wife could be allowed to see their son, Andrew. That would not be possible, he was told.

headline: HOUSE PANEL OPPOSES REACTOR
abstract: A House committee dealt a major blow today to the Administration's plans to make greater use of nuclear energy by narrowly voting to ''de-authorize'' the Clinch River breeder reactor and to spend an initial $20 million to terminate the project.   About $1 billion has already been spent in design and other work for the long-delayed facility at Oak Ridge, Tenn., whose purpose has been to demonstrate breeder technology, in which more fuel is produced than consumed. Construction has been scheduled to begin in 1982.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 4, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Trusthouse Forte-Savoy
abstract: S.G. Warburg Ltd. said today that it had purchased on behalf of Trusthouse Forte Ltd. 9.59 million 'A' ordinary shares of Savoy Hotel Ltd. at 190 pence and 95,584 'B' ordinary shares at 1,122.5 pence from the Kuwait Investment Office, indicating a value on the transaction of about $18.76 million. The purchases raise Trusthouse Forte's stake in the Savoy to 60.16 percent of total equity and 37.47 percent of total votes. The Trusthouse offer for the Savoy closes tomorrow.

headline: Advertising; U.S. News Appoints Head
abstract: After less than one year with U.S. News & World Report, James H.  McIlhenny has become the boss.  Yesterday, John H. Sweet, the 73-year-old chairman, president and chief executive, turned those last two titles over to his 53-yearold associate, who joined the company last August as an executive vice president and chief operating officer. He so quickly adapted to the business that by mid-October he was poolside in Palm Springs, Calif., enjoying the Magazine Publishers Association annual meeting with all the rest of the mighties.

headline: F.T.C. KILLS A RULE FOR USED CARS
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission today effectively rejected its long-awaited rule that would make used-car dealers disclose defects in their vehicles and state plainly what warranty protection is provided.   The rejection came when none of the four other commissioners seconded a motion made by Commissioner Michael Pertschuk, former F.T.C. chairman, to vote on the measure. The rule, which had been five years in the making, was tentatively approved by the commissioners last May.

headline: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Seoul General Gets 5-Year Term For Taking Money From Students
abstract: A South Korean court today sentenced a retired three-star general and war hero to five years in prison for embezzlement.

headline: SEAGRAM TELLS OF BID FOR CONOCO
abstract: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons dislosed yesterday that it was the mystery suitor whose $2 billion bid for 25 percent of Conoco was rejected last week by the oil company. Despite the rebuke, Seagram said that it might proceed anyway, and notified the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission that it may purchase shares of Conoco on the open market.   ''We have no reaction because at this time we do not know Seagram's intentions,'' said Samuel Schwartz, senior vice president of Conoco. He added that Conoco, based in Stamford, Conn., was still holding preliminary merger talks with a major American corporation, but declined to name that company.

headline: Indonesia Oil Position
abstract: Indonesia has no intentions of shifting its oil sales from contract deals to a spot market system, Subroto, the Mining and Energy Minister, said today. He said Pertamina, the state-run oil company, would maintain the contract sales system in dealing with its traditional buyers. ''If there is a surplus of production over the contract amount agreement, Pertamina will first of all offer it to its traditional buyers,'' he said.

headline: FORD SAYS IT REJECTED CHRYSLER TIE
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had rejected a proposal to merge with the Chrysler Corporation, a course of action that some Government officials and others consider necessary to insure Chrysler's long-term survival.   Chrysler, however, said the proposal was just one of several that it had made to other automobile makers to satisfy the terms of its most recent $400 million grant in Federally guaranteed loans.   It is an indication of the changed state of the domestic auto industry that merger talks involving any of the Big Three auto companies, however tentative, have taken place at all. No Antitrust Action Seen   With imported cars now taking over a quarter of the American market, and the General Motors Corporation, the leading company, holding on to about half, a combination of Ford and Chrysler, in the opinion of many analysts, no longer seems likely to invite the Government antitrust moves that would have been inevitable a decade ago.

headline: WAGE RISES MODERATED IN QUARTER
abstract: Wage increases reached in major collective bargaining moderated in the first quarter and worker productivity improved substantially, the Labor Department reported today. But Government and business experts warned that the improvement might be short-lived.   If both these trends were to continue, they would be likely to relieve inflationary pressures, but experts from the Labor Department and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said that wages were likely to rise in the second quarter and productivity to decline.   Major collective bargaining settlements in the first three months of 1981 produced average wage increases of 9 percent in the first year of the new contracts compared with average first-year increases of 9.5 percent in 1980 settlements, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

headline: SALE OF UNITS, INVESTMENTS CITED
abstract: The Bendix Corporation, a leading producer of high-technology, automotive and aerospace products, reported yesterday that income from the sale of discontinued operations caused earnings to soar in the second fiscal quarter of 1981, as sales increased 23.1 percent.   The Detroit-based concern said that net income in the three months ended March 31 rose more than fivefold to $268.1 million, or $10.55 a share, from $50.2 million, or $2.14 a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year. Revenues increased to $1.16 billion from $943 million.   Net income in the latest quarter included $217.4 million, or $8.55 a share, in net gains on the disposition of Bendix's forest products business and on the first phase of Bendix's investment in Asarco.

headline: Spanish General Shot, Apparently a Suicide
abstract: A general involved in legislation designed to force Spanish officers to retire at an earlier age than usual died today when his gun went off in his office at army headquarters in central Madrid.   Military sources said that Gen. Marcelo Aramendi Garcia, 63 years old, director-general of military education, had apparently taken his own life.   General Aramendi's death coincided with a right-wing furor following parliamentary approval yesterday of a draft law designed to make Spanish military officers retire early and clear the way for younger men to be promoted.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Amax Stock Sinks After Socal Move
abstract: Amax Inc. stock plummeted in value yesterday in the wake of the withdrawal by the Standard Oil Company of California of a $4.3 billion takeover offer that could have been the largest acquisition in American corporate history.   Amax stock, which traded at $38.25 a share just before the offer was made March 5 and rose to a high of $69 despite Amax's rejection of it, plunged $9.125, to $48.50 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.
