headline: No Headline
abstract: U.S. Said to Lag On Oil Cases   WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) - The Reagan Administration lacks interest in recovering billions of dollars in overcharges allegedly imposed on consumers while oil prices were controlled, a House committee has concluded.   The committee's report, scheduled for release tomorrow, says the Administration proposed actions, mainly reductions in enforcement budgets, that were ''suggestive of a grant of amnesty'' for alleged pricing violations by oil companies.

headline: Pitney Bowes Names President And Chief Operating Officer
abstract: George B. Harvey, 50, has been named president and chief operating officer of Pitney Bowes Inc., the big business and retail equipment and services manufacturer. He succeeds Fred T. Allen, 64, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: DOW SLIPS BY 1.99 IN REDUCED VOLUME
abstract: Mining and hospital-management issues ranked among the stock market's best performing groups yesterday, as prices over all showed slight gains. Energy issues, the market's strongest group in recent sessions, generally posted fractional price changes.   Although the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.99 points, to 976.40, the general market fared better, as advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by a 4-to-3 ratio.   Trading volume of 41.9 million shares was down from Thursday's 42.6 million.  Dome Mines rose 3 5/8 points, to 91 3/8, after the Toronto-based company announced plans for a 4-for-1 stock split. Dome has no longterm debt, and last autumn, when precious-metal issues were setting new highs, it sold at a peak price of 132 5/8.

headline: NAZI HORROR HAUNTS SECOND GENERATION
abstract: ''It's like there's a rock inside of me.'' The young woman, Charlene Bradin, leaned forward intently as she spoke.  And the other children of Holocaust survivors, sitting in a circle, were suspended on her words.   ''My father was from Poland,'' she said. ''Between the time I was 10 and 15, I had a picture of myself in my father's position, because when he was 10 to 15 he went through everything.'' She nodded to a young man who had spoken just before her. ''What you said about waking up with the same dreams that your mother has - I wake up with the same dreams that my father has.''

headline: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEWCOURT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Conrail Seeks Surcharges
abstract: Conrail said today that it wanted to impose $2.7 million in surcharges to cut losses on freight lines in six states scheduled to be abandoned.

headline: Business Conditions; A POOR YEAR FOR POOLS
abstract: Last year was disappointing for swimming pool builders as high interest rates and shortages of water prompted consumers to spend leisure-time dollars in other ways.   According to data gathered by Swimming Pool Weekly, a trade publication, more than 106,000 new residential pools were built last year, a 6.6 percent increase from 1979 levels that brought the total number of pools in place to 1.6 million. The publication estimates, however, that the rate of growth fell about 15 percent last year. (A 16- by 32-foot pool, hardly oceanic in size, fetches from $9,000 to $11,000.)

headline: MASONRY DREW MOZART AND WASHINGTON
abstract: As a quasi-religious society whose members swear fealty to the lodge and each other, Freemasonry has often attracted the wrath of governments and churches.   The largest worldwide secret society, the Freemasons may have as many as six million members, although the exact numbers are among the society's secrets. Most, however, are in the United States and Britain, where the society was founded as a fraternal order.

headline: CHINA PLANS TO POSTPONE OIL SEARCH
abstract: China has postponed until next year plans to solicit bids from foreign oil companies to search for oil in the South China Sea, Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, disclosed here today.   Mr. Butcher said officials of China's Ministry of Petroleum told him that unresolved problems, including questions of double taxation and contract arbitration, had forced another delay until early next year.

headline: BRIGHTER OUTLOOK FOR AIRLINE STOCKS
abstract: Over the years, the airlines, with their, if you'll pardon the expression, repeated downdrafts and altitude gains, have shown themselves to be a classic example of a cyclical industry - much as the retail industry, which tracks the economy, is considered cyclical, while the food industry, which is needed in good times and bad, is not. Both business and pleasure travel rise in good economic times, while they are fall off during recessions.   Yet in the last 12 months, airline stocks have shown in interesting ways how stock prices in a cyclical industry sometimes surge en masse, sometimes come in for individual scrutiny by investors, and sometimes are affected by special external considerations, such as the recent drop in fuel prices.   Over the last year, the basic movement among the airline stocks has been strongly upward, despite the widespread operating losses during 1980. As a group, the stocks of the 13 airlines, which include the 10 major airlines, known as ''trunk carriers,'' and three regional airlines - Frontier, Texas Air and USAir - soared by 113 percent between late April 1980 and the close of trading last Wednesday. In the same period the Standard & Poor's 500 industrial index rose by a relatively modest 37 percent.

headline: JAILED I.R.A. MEMBER WINS COMMONS SEAT
abstract: In a stunning blow to the Protestant establishment in Northern Ireland, Robert Sands, an imprisoned member of the Irish Republican Army, has been elected to the British Parliament.   The 27-year-old prisoner is serving a 14-year sentence for firearms violations and is nearing the end of the sixth week of a hunger strike as well.   Mr. Sands, who is called Bobby, was declared the winner today in yesterday's by-election in a constituency in the southwest corner of the province, along the border with Ireland. He defeated Harold West, a 63-year-old Protestant Unionist.

headline: 2.5 Million Registered To Vote Today in Israel
abstract: About 2,490,000 Israelis will be eligible to vote in tomorrow's parliamentary elections.

headline: Belgian Talks Snagged
abstract: Belgian employers walked out on economic talks with the unions and the Government today, saying recent state measures to reduce their production costs were insufficient.

headline: Company News; AVNET IN AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE SERTECH
abstract: Avnet Inc. the electronics manufactorer, has an agreement in pinciple to acquire all shares of the Sertech Corporation of Salem, Mass. for an undisclosed sum of cash, according to Anthony R.  Hamilton, chairman of Avnet.

headline: HAJOCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: C.I.A. Says Terrorism Is on Rise, With 760 Acts Counted Last Year
abstract: A new report by the Central Intelligence Agency says that the number of terrorist activities around the world have risen dramatically and that American businessmen and diplomats are the terrorists' favorite targets.   The 22-page report, prepared by the agency's National Foreign Assessment Center and made public yesterday, said that 6,714 international terrorist acts had been counted from 1968 through 1980, including 760 last year.

headline: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bond Prices Ease Moderately; Short-Term Bill Rates Rise
abstract: Several long-term bond issues met with good buyer reception yesterday, while short-term rates for Treasury bills moved briskly higher.   Bond prices eased moderately after plunging Monday in response to a half-point increase in the prime rate, to 19 1/2 percent, by major banks.   A busy calendar of new issues is scheduled for today.  In the tax-exempt area, Oregon's $240 million of veterans welfare bonds reached the market yesterday at slightly higher yields than expected earlier. A group headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank won the double-A rated issue with a bid that set the interest cost to the borrower at 11.11 percent.

headline: A.T.&T. FILES DETAILS ON HIGHER RATES
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today filed with the Federal Communications Commission new phone rates it hopes to charge for long-distance calls. The changes, which would generally raise the rates 16 percent, follow the commission's authorization Monday of new profit margins for the company.   A.T.& T. asked that the new rates go into effect five days after the F.C.C. approves the changes, which could be done in a matter of weeks.

headline: Ford Set to Offer Liquid Gas Option
abstract: The Ford Motor Company will offer an optional liquid petroleum gas fuel system on all its medium and heavy trucks and will offer a similar system on certain 1982-model Canadian-built cars, Ford said yesterday.   ''This is a Ford first and the growth potential for its use is substantial,'' said James A. Capolongo, Ford vice president and general manager of truck operations.

headline: OKLAHOMA ENERGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1981; Markets
abstract: The U.S. Treasury was forced to pay the highest price ever for long-term borrowing when it sold $2 billion of new 13 7/8 percent, 30-year bonds at an average yield of 13.95 percent. The higher rates were attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to reduce money supply growth. (Page D1.) The nation's money market funds grew slightly, by $72.6 million, in the week ended Wednesday, to reach $118.5 billion. (D9.)   The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 978.39, up 5.05 on a pattern of small but persistent gains in energy issues. Retail, precious metal and technology issues also advanced. (D7.) The dollar continued its upward climb, following American interest rates up.  Gold was unchanged in London at $480 an ounce, but rose $2.60 to $481.90 on the Comex. (D10.) A ''bewildering'' day was reported in the commodity markets, as livestock and pork belly futures prices rebounded and heating oil futures soared. (D10.)

headline: Indian Officials Send Out a Plane To Hunt for 401 Lost Fishermen
abstract: A Government aircraft took off today from the South Indian coast to search for 401 fishermen missing for three days, a Fisheries Department official said.

headline: U.S. ECONOMY AIDED BY WORLD OIL GLUT
abstract: The current worldwide abundance of crude oil, coupled with improved conservation of petroleum in the industrialized nations, is strengthening the American economy, according to economists and business leaders. This is in sharp contrast to the problems that oil brought to Western economies after the Iranian revolution two and a half years ago.   Bulging worldwide oil inventories are 400 million barrels greater than normal, spot prices have slipped by more than $2 a barrel and expectations are rising that oil prices will decline or remain stable for the rest of the year.   Government statistics show that the abundance of oil is already slowing inflation, aiding economic growth and cutting the United States trade deficit to the slimmest total in more than five years.   These economic gains are also strengthening the dollar, which is approaching its record high levels of the early 1970's on the world's foreign exchange markets. (Page 29.)

headline: BANKS SQUARE OFF AGAINST THE FED
abstract: For years, bank-holding companies and their large banks have been quietly obedient to the Federal Reserve Board, which has enjoyed largely unquestioned adherence to regulations through its powerful grip on the banking industry.   Big banks must obtain the Fed's permission for practically any new venture or product - even to open or close a small branch. In addition, the Fed rules with a certain moral authority that it gets from just being the Fed - it commands awe and deference.   Most bankers, therefore, have been understandably reluctant to take on the Federal Reserve. Today, however, the Fed has a rebellion on its hands. The banks are being punished by competition from money market mutual funds, and on Wall Street, such formidable names as American Express and Prudential have formed alliances with leading brokerage firms, further threatening the banks' competitive position.

headline: Dow Off 8.66 in Slow Trading
abstract: The stock market ended broadly lower yesterday in slower trading with some of the energy-related, technology and blue-chip issues registering the biggest losses.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the loss column throughout the session, finished down 8.66 points, to 1,003.33, after rising about 19 points in the previous six trading days because of declining interest rates.   In the overall market yesterday, declining issues outpaced advancing stocks by almost a 5-to-3 ratio. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 57.8 million shares from 63.4 million shares the day before, as institutional participation slackened.

headline: U.S. ENVOY STRESSES COMMITMENT TO SALVADOR JUNTA
abstract: The new United States Ambassador in El Salvador said today that he would urge the ruling junta to improve its human rights record but stressed that President Reagan will not allow an ''armed insurrection supported from Havana'' to topple the Government.   ''The human rights situation is bad and continues to be bad but it's better than it was,'' Ambassador Deane R. Hinton said in his first interview with reporters since arriving in San Salvador in late May.   ''No one would pretend the human rights situation is what it should be, neither the military commanders I have talked to nor the civilian members of the junta, but they are trying,'' the 58-year-old Mr. Hinton said.

headline: Pakistani Air Hijacker Is Hanged
abstract: A man convicted of attempting to hijack a Pakistani airliner three years ago was executed today, the Government said.

headline: 2 Drug Dealers Executed in Iran
abstract: Two narcotics dealers have been executed in the southern Iranian town of Bandar Abbas, the state radio said today. It said the executions, which took place last night, were for buying, selling and distributing heroin.

headline: Suzuki and Trudeau Discuss Economic Summit Meeting
abstract: Canada and Japan today agreed to place a high priority on resolving conflicts between industrialized and developing nations at the economic summit meeting scheduled in July in Ottawa, spokemen for both countries said.   Both Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan said they believed that the matter of relations between industrialized and developing nations would be a key issue at the Ottawa summit meeting.   Mr. Suzuki made a six-hour stopover here on his way to Tokyo after ending his visit to Washington.

headline: Economic Scene; Clash Over Gold Standard
abstract: IN seeking to reconcile the main ideas of his two principal groups of economic supporters, the supply-siders and the monetarists, President Reagan set aside one of his own economic beliefs: that the country should go back to the gold standard to end inflation.   His desire to return to gold ran afoul of the convictions of the monetarists, who strongly favor floating exchange rates rather than the fixed exchange rates required by the gold standard. The answer to inflation, the monetarists say, is a slow and steady rate of increase in the money supply. The gold standard's history, they note, was one of turbulence, crises and ultimately great depressions when wartime inflation clashed with a fixed relationship of gold and currencies.

headline: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Company News; Du Pont Sues Toray
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it had filed suit in London against Toray Industries of Japan for patent infringement. The company said the suit charged that Toray had violated Du Pont patents in Britain for texturing polyester yarn. Du Pont said it had patent applications for the process in other countries, but did not name them.

headline: Soviet Union Is Establishing An Embassy in Zimbabwe
abstract: A Soviet diplomatic team has arrived in Zimbabwe to set up an embassy and formalize relations with the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, whom the Kremlin refused to support during the seven-year civil war.

headline: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: British Civil Servants Press Demands on Pay
abstract: More than 500,000 British civil servants struck for several hours today to press demands for a 15 percent pay increase, disrupting international air service and shutting down government offices, computers and museums.

headline: SOCIALIST CABINET IN FRANCE RAISES MINIMUM PAY AND SOCIAL BENEFITS
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government today raised France's minimum wage by 10 percent, increased social security benefits and told banks, oil companies and the rich that they face higher taxes.   The Cabinet, in its second session of the new Administration, also abolished some of the practices of the Gaullist administration that have been criticized in the past. It agreed to ask Parliament to disband the State Security Court, which tries suspected spies and terrorists in secret without right of appeal. Rights Protection Bolstered   The Government also said citizens could now sue it for breaches of human rights by using the machinery set up under the Council of Europe. This Strasbourg-based organization, now numbering 20 member countries, was founded in 1949 to promote European unity and uphold parliamentary democracy. Under the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights, signed in 1950, a European Commission investigates alleged rights violations and submits its findings to a European Court of Human Rights, whose jurisdiction has been recognized by 13 countries.

headline: 2 Banks Reduce Broker Loan Rate
abstract: Two large banks lowered their broker loan rate yesterday to 20 percent from 21 percent, reflecting lower costs of funds and competition for loans that have led to widespread discounting of the prime rate from the posted 20 percent level.   Both Chemical Bank and Marine Midland notched down the broker rate that banks charge for overnight loans using securities as collateral.

headline: 3 New Keyboards
abstract: Honeywell Inc. introduced three membrane-type keyboards for wordprocessing machines and electronic data terminals. The keyboards would cost 25 to 65 percent less than current solid-state and electromechanical keyboards and permit faster and more accurate operation of keyboard machines, according to William L. Spivey, marketing director of mechanical products for Honeywell.

headline: MESTA MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. LAWYERS FRUSTRATED IN SAUDI ARABIA
abstract: Burt & Taylor, a small but sophisticated Massachusetts law firm, established a branch practice in Saudi Arabia in 1978. As one of the partners acknowledged, the firm was looking for bigger business.   Dan M. Burt and Frederick W. Taylor were known for good work, and they were paid handsomely for it - as much as $250 an hour. They enjoyed high visibility because they had become experts on antiboycott legislation before large law firms entered the field.

headline: ARMY OVERSEAS CITES PROBLEMS OF FEMALE G.I.'S
abstract: ''The personnel policy of the Army for several years regarding the assignment of women has made their presence throughout the battlefield, with attendant risks, a reality.''   This conclusion to a fact sheet issued by the Third Armored Division in West Germany is one aspect of the Army's attempt to learn how to use the men and women now serving in it.   A support group commander estimated that of the approximately 530 women in his command about 9 percent are pregnant at any given time and that about half of the pregnant women are single.   There are other problems. Many of the soldiers coming to the Seventh Army in West Germany from training in the United States cannot read or write or do simple arithmetic, which means that they cannot understand even the new, simplified training manuals.

headline: Washington Watch; Flexibility On Tax Cuts WASHINGTON
abstract: ''THE door is open and the light is on in the hall.'' That's the White House summation, lifted from a popular country and western song, of President Reagan's attitude toward a tax-cut compromise, with Congress still to be convinced of the wisdom of his three-year, thirty-point reduction in tax rates. Helping to keep that light burning bright is the lead Republican on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, who has sketched some of the elements of a possible accommodation. He thinks there cannot be agreement on a ''clean'' bill without pinning down the second part of the package, at least in terms of its overall cost.

headline: I.B.M., GOVERNMENT REST IN ANTITRUST SUIT
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department rested their cases yesterday in the six-year-old trial and 12-year-old antitrust suit brought against I.B.M. by the department.   Thomas Barr, I.B.M.'s lead lawyer, told Judge David N. Edelstein of the Federal District Court in Manhattan that he had requested a meeting with William F. Baxter, an Assistant Attorney General. The purpose of the meeting, Mr. Barr said, is to discuss narrowing the issues on the basis of two recent appellate decisions - Northeastern Telephone v. A.T.&T. and Berkey v. Kodak.

headline: MOBILE-RADIO 'CELLS' APPROVED BY F.C.C.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to begin licensing a new type of radio system that promises broad changes in mobile communications. At the same time, the F.C.C. also rejected pleas to restrict tightly the entry by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into the new industry.   The Justice Department condemned the commission's action and Bell's rivals promised a court appeal. A.T.& T. applauded the commission for finally ''pulling the regulatory cork on a technological triumph that's going to work wonders for our nation over the years.''   ''This action promotes communication competition benefiting all Americans,'' asserted the F.C.C.'s acting chairman, Robert E. Lee.  ''And this really is the coming of a new era. Dick Tracy comes true,'' a reference to the wrist communications gear worn by the comic-strip character.

headline: Publishers Face the Future
abstract: Representatives of the American Newspaper Publishers Association convene in Chicago this weekend with a chaotic year behind them and major challenges ahead.   Declines in disposable personal income last year tended to flatten circulation growth, while the recession tended to depress advertisers - responsible for more than 75 percent of total revenues.

headline: Swiss Arrest Suspect in Murder Of Aldo Moro, Ex-Italian Premier
abstract: A 41-year-old Italian who is wanted in Italy in connection with the 1978 kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was arrested yesterday in Lucerne, Switzerland.   The Swiss Ministry of Justice and Police said that Giustino de Vuono was arrested as he attempted to sell two knives and a pistol to passers-by.

headline: GARFINCKEL BROOKS BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENT FILINGS BACK UP
abstract: Last year was a busy one for United States patent examiners. A record 105,000 applications were filed for patents on inventions, the first significant yearly increase since 1971.

headline: Investing independent oil companies; OIL STOCKS AT DISTRESS PRICES?
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO I T was a great roller coaster run on Wall Street. Oil stocks, which had doubled, tripled and even quadrupled in price between December 1978 and December 1980, took a nose dive that left investors reeling.   But now, with the dust beginning to settle, some big questions are being raised. Did the oils drop too far, too fast? Could international politics mean a sudden rebound? And most importantly, is it time to buy?

headline: MOST OF WALL STREET BACKS REAGAN PlAN
abstract: Since taking office in January, the Reagan Administration has been saying that the performance of the money and stock markets would be the best indicator of Wall Street's acceptance of the President's economic program.   If the markets are an accurate barometer, however, the President's program is in trouble. Last week Congress passed the heart of the program - the budget. Even so, the bellwether prime interest rate jumped two percentage points, to 19 percent, between April and May.

headline: Business People; PRESIDENT OF CASIO INC. GETS BEHIND THE COUNTER
abstract: John J. McDonald, the 51-year-old president of Casio Inc., the American subsidiary of the Casio Computer Company of Japan, is a person who likes to meet the people who buy his products. And so, for about 15 days a year, he does his own personal market research by working as a salesman at electronic product counters of department stores, such as Macy's in New York and Meier & Frank in Portland, Ore.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK : ON HAIG TRIP A SENSITIVE DISCLOSURE LIGHTS A FUSE
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s 27,643-mile Asian mission is drawing to a close today with the satisfaction that he had felt over the trip somewhat dampened.   Mr. Haig's mood has been hurt by the political uproar over the criticism of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nation, that came from his party and by the growing complaints that the Reagan Administration lacks a coherent foreign policy.   The Secretary arrived in Hawaii two days ago after a grueling overnight flight from New Zealand hoping to spend some time on the beach before meeting with President Reagan in Los Angeles to report on his travels. But suddenly the focus has shifted from the pros and cons of the Administration's China policy to whether Mrs. Kirkpatrick and Mr. Haig were at odds over how she handled herself during the negotiations last week on the resolution condemning Israel.   The information on Mr. Haig's role in the Security Council debate was first provided as a result of questions from reporters on what the Secretary was doing about other parts of the world while he was in Asia. But his staff also wanted to give him public credit for what many of them regarded as extraordinary hours spent on behalf of the country.

headline: WTC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Field & Stream Promotion
abstract: Eugene A. Bay Jr., 47 years old, has been promoted to publisher of Field & Stream and vice president of CBS Publications, Michael J.  O'Neill, his predecessor, and vice president and group publisher of the Men's Magazine Group, announced yesterday. Mr. Bay, associate publisher for three years, was formerly with American Home, Seventeen, Good Food and TV Guide.

headline: United Brands Loan
abstract: The United Brands Company said it had arranged a $250 million, 27-month revolving credit and term loan plan with a group of 11 banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

headline: Advertising
abstract: April at the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Bureaus saw one of those rare cases where the investigative unit of the industry's self-policing body turned a case over to its supreme court, the National Advertising Review Board.   It concerns a challenge by the Schering-Plough Corporation to a claim made by Revlon Inc. in ads by the Leo Burnett Company (no longer Revlon's agency) for Formula 2 Eyecolor (the initiial complaint also included Color Creme Powder Eye Shadow) that the product does not crease, certainly a major concern in many areas of the world.

headline: CONSUMERS DISTRIBUTING CO reports earnings for 13 wks to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: To the Business Editor:   One reason why businessmen hesitate to manifest courtesy and consideration is that our society's popular misconceptions about masculinity discourage them from doing so. Many men and women identify masculinity not with virtues like moral and physical courage, decency, courtesy and kindness but rather with physical strength, aggressiveness, moral and intellectual arrogance and sexual conquests.
