abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ST REGIS PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tsongas Says Levefer Prospects For Rights Post Are Deteriorating
abstract: Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that there was little Administration support for Ernest W. Lefever as President Reagan's chief human rights adviser and that prospects for Mr. Lefever getting the job were deteriorating.   ''I have spoken to no one in this Administration who is strongly supporting this nominee,'' Mr. Tsongas said of Mr. Lefever, whose nomination to be Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights will again be taken up by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday.

headline: PRESIDENT IS NAMED AT AMERICAN STORES
abstract: Thomas W. Field Jr., 47 years old, has been named president of the American Stores Company, which operates supermarket and drug chains under different names throughout the country.   He succeeds L.S. Skaggs, 57, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, which is based in Salt Lake City.

headline: PENSIONS: TAKING IT ALL AT ONCE
abstract: O N March 1, four months after his 55th birthday, an executive at the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation retired. Instead of taking the $14,156 a year for life that he was entitled to under the company's pension plan, he opted for a $104,237 lump sum.   ''There are lots of people like that,'' said Dawn Bates Gaston, director of financial planning at Butcher & Singer, a regional brokerage firm based in Philadelphia.   Indeed, while the number of companies offering the choice of a lump-sum pension payment is small, their ranks are growing. And when they have the choice, employees apparently jump at the chance to receive their full pension at one time.

headline: New Orleans Opening Is Brisk
abstract: The South's only commodity exchange market opened here today with brisk trading in milled rice futures.  Trading in open rough rice and milled rice will begin tomorrow, activity in short staple cotton will start in May, with soybean trading following a few weeks later at the newest of the nation's 12 commodity markets, according to Tom Webber, president of the fledgling New Orleans Commodity Exchange.

headline: Manila Kills Ads In U.S. Magazines
abstract: Philippine Airlines, a Government-owned carrier, canceled advertising schedules in Pacific-area editions of both Time and Newsweek magazines following coverage of a visit by Pope John Paul II that apparently upset the administration of President Ferdinand E.  Marcos, it was learned this week.   The Pope, during his visit from Feb. 17 to 23, was critical of the condition of human rights in the Philippines.

headline: A Nuclear Reactor That Burns Thorium
abstract: An Israeli inventor was granted a patent this week for a nuclear reactor that draws a substantial portion of its power from burning natural thorium, rather than uranium.

headline: MAXIM SHOSTAKOVICH PLAYS OVERTURE TO A NEW LIFE
abstract: At 8 o'clock tonight Maxim Shostakovich gave the downbeat on his father's ''Festive Overture'' at an occasion that that could hardly be more symbolic in spotlighting his defection from the Soviet Union.   The 42-year-old conductor led the National Symphony Orchestra on the west lawn of the Capitol with the Stars and Stripes unfurled on the American Memorial Day and started a new life with the familiar music of his father, Dmitri Shostakovich, whose death, the son says, ultimately left him no longer bound to the Russian homeland.   ''I was so psychologically prepared for this change,'' the conductor said of his defection last month, ''it was like getting on a trolley car at one stop and getting off at the next.''   Mr. Shostakovich said in an interview that he had prepared for the defection for years in suffering the ''isolation of art'' in the Soviet Union. The final decision, he said, was fairly thrust on him and his 19-year-old son, Dmitri, a pianist, by the defection, four days before their own, of the harpist in the maestro's orchestra, the Central Radio and Television Symphony.

headline: LEADER OF EMPLOYEES AT CONTINENTAL AIR
abstract: Paul R. Eckel, the chairman of the Continental Employees Association, a workers group at Continental Airlines that is seeking control of the Los Angeles-based carrier, speaks like a man with a mission.   "If the ownership is going to change, why can't we do it?" asks Mr. Eckel, a 42-year-old Continental pilot.  "We already have sweat equity in our company, and now we'd like to have capital equity."

headline: Pro-West Cyprus Party Cuts Communists' Lead
abstract: A late surge by the pro-Western party of Glafkos Clerides has prevented hard-line Communists from dominating politics in the Greek-Cypriot sector of Cyprus, official election results showed today.   The final tally in Sunday's elections showed that the pro-Moscow party known as AKEL finished ahead of the right-wing Democratic Rally Party of Mr. Clerides by less than one percentage point.

headline: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
Advertising; Ad Revenues Up 12.1%
abstract: According to preliminary estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, revenues in February increased 12.1 percent, to $1.21 billion, from the comparable month of 1980. For the first two months of 1981, revenues totaled $2.4 billion, up 11.5 percent. National advertising led the month's gains, rising 24.3 percent, to $226.6 million, while retail advertising rose 11.9 percent, to $621.2 million, and classified 5.8 percent, to $360.7 million.

headline: Suzuki Starts Talks With Dutch
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived in the Netherlands today and immediately began talks with Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt. Mr. Suzuki arrived from London after a tour of six Western European countries aimed at easing trade tensions. He is expected to face criticism of a growing trade imbalance between the Netherlands and Japan.

headline: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FOREIGNERS FIGHTING IN A UNIT OF SOUTH AFRICAN ARMY
abstract: In response to allegations of atrocities, South Africa has furnished informat on about a battalion made up mainly of foreigners that it has been using for raids into Angola against the guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization.   The battalion, made up of black refugees from Angola and a few Europeans who would normally be described as mercenaries, is a unit of the South African Army, but the only South African citizens in it appear to be its commander and senior noncommissioned officers.   Four South African journalists who visited the unit at its base in the western part of the Caprivi Strip, adjoining Angola, were told that most of the troops were former soldiers in the Front for the Liberation of Angola, a faction that was defeated in the struggle for power after Portugal granted independence to Angola in 1975.  Other blacks in the battalion used to serve in the Portuguese Army.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT AT NATO TALKS
abstract: Following are excerpts from the communique issued here today at the end of a two-day NATO foreign ministers' meeting:   The North Atlantic Council is deeply concerned at the continuing threats to security and international stability. Determined to counter these threats by effective restraints, including firmness in defense and persistence in the search for peaceful solutions, ministers in that spirit agreed on the following: (1)   The strength and cohesion of the alliance remain indispensable to guarantee the security of its members and thereby to foster stable international relations. This stability requires that all nations act with restraint and responsibility. Claims by the Soviet Union that it too subscribes to such policies are not borne out by Soviet deeds.

headline: Italian Car Sales Up
abstract: Italian auto sales rose to 668,600 units in the first four months of 1981 from 629,900 in the same period last year, the national car manufacturers association, Anfia, reported today. Sales in April rose to 189,700 from 152,400 in March and 169,900 in April 1980, Anfia's latest delivery figures showed.  Imports took 40.25 percent of the market in the first four months, compared with 35.9 percent in the same period of 1980.

headline: PACIFIC COAST PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: The special United Nations envoy, Olof Palme of Sweden, arrived in Baghdad from Teheran today with the outline of a comprehensive plan to end the war between Iran and Iraq, the official Iraqi press agency reported. Iran's Supreme Defense Council said it would study the proposal.

headline: SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE IS 'FURIOUS' AT HAIG ABOUT WHEAT SALES ISSUE
abstract: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said he was ''furious'' with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. over a discussion Mr. Haig had with the French Ambassador about a possible wheat sale to the Soviet Union.   Mr. Block was angered when he learned that Mr. Haig had held a discussion with the Ambassador a week ago in which the envoy told him that France was considering selling about 600,000 metric tons of wheat to the Russians.   Mr. Haig did not discuss the conversation with Mr. Block, who found out about it from a ''foreign person'' he met at a reception Wednesday night.   ''I am furious about not being informed and kept up to date on it,'' Mr. Block told a reporter last night.

headline: SECURITY IS STEPPED UP IN ULSTER DURING VISIT BY RELATIVE OF QUEEN
abstract: The police stood guard inside the church and British troops poured into surrounding Catholic sections as Princess Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth, arrived in Ulster today to attend the consecration of a Protestant cathedral.   Princess Alexandra flew to Ulster mainly to attend the consecration today of Belfast's new St. Anne's Church of Ireland Cathedral.

headline: 3 BIG BANKS SOLICITING NATIONWIDE
abstract: In major moves toward nationwide banking, three leading New York banking organizations have begun programs to solicit deposits from consumers across the United States.   Bankers said yesterday that the steps were an attempt to compete against mushrooming money market mutual funds, whose assets have soared by billions, to nearly $120 billion since Jan. 1.   Many analysts believe that much of the money that is going into money funds is coming from banks and savings institutions, which pay lower interest rates. Unlike banks, the money funds are free from federally imposed interest rate ceilings and from the ban on interstate banking.

headline: PRUDENTIAL IS BRANCHING OUT
abstract: Tucked away in the heart of this New Jersey city, the Prudential Insurance Company of America is somewhat removed from the competitive fervor of Wall Street.   But geography has not daunted the Pru's expansion into financial services, and its desire to add new lines of business. Not content to be both the largest life insurer and the largest private money manager in the United States, the mutual company recently made a $385 million bid for the Bache Group, the fifth-largest retail brokerage firm in the country.   For Prudential thinks Bache has the potential to be No.1.  ''Acquiring Bache will be a very significant step in our strategic plan to offer a broad range of financial services,'' said Robert A.  Beck, Prudential's 55-year-old, cigar-chomping chairman. ''From our standpoint, it is an extension of a program we have already been on.''

headline: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN'S FOREIGN MINISTER QUITS IN DISPUTE
abstract: Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito and a key aide unexpectedly resigned last night in a controversy over the degree of Japanese military cooperation with the United States.   Mr. Ito was understood to have resigned to take responsibility for confusion here over the wording of a United States-Japanese communique issued after Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki met with President Reagan in Washington last week. Mr. Ito accompanied the Prime Minister to the United States.   The controversy arose from the use of the word ''alliance'' in the communique. The word was used in the context of United States-Japanese relations to imply, Foreign Ministry officials said later, that a military relationship was developing between the two countries, as hoped for by the Reagan Administration.

headline: ISRAELI AIDES IN U.S. BEMOAN REAGAN LINE
abstract: In intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering to influence American policy, Israeli diplomats are telling their Congressional supporters and American Government officials that the Reagan Administration has put itself and Israel in a quandary over what steps may be necessary to restore suspended deliveries of military planes.   According to Israeli diplomats, Israel fears that President Reagan may have been maneuvered into a position where, against his own instincts, he will have to ask Israel for concessions it will not make. These include opening up its own nuclear reactor for international inspection, dropping its opposition to the sale of radar planes to Saudi Arabia, or moderating its position on removing Syrian missiles from Lebanon.   The Israelis say that the maneuvering is being done by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and that it could result in further Israeli-American tension. Mr. Reagan stopped shipment of four F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel after it used F-16's in the June 7 raid on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

headline: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINESE FARMS AND FACTORIES THRIVE ON INCENTIVES
abstract: With what appears to be a sense of discovery, officials and industrial and farming-commune managers here laud the virtues of a market-oriented economy and of private agriculture. At the same time, they denounce the restrictiveness of the highly centralized and planned economy that prevailed in China through the first three decades of Communism.   The officials interviewed in and around this capital of Sichuan Province defend central planning when asked to do so. But they preferred to concentrate in long discussions on what they described as the important place being given to individual initiative and the need to expand it.

headline: Postal Equipment Contracts Issued
abstract: The United States Postal Service said that it had awarded contracts totaling more than $188 million to Pitney Bowes Inc. and the Burroughs Corporation for the production of new scanning equipment for automated sorting of mail.   The contracts, for production of 252 optical character reading channel sorters, involve ones of $111 million to Pitney Bowes and $71 million to Burroughs.

headline: INDIANAPOLIS POWER & LIGHT reports earnings for Year to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ST. JOE OFFICERS BACK MERGER WITH FLUOR
abstract: Directors of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, one of the nation's leading producers of lead and zinc, yesterday approved a $2.6 billion cash-and-stock merger agreement with the Fluor Corporation.  Meanwhile, directors of Fluor, a California-based construction and engineering concern, scheduled a meeting for today to consider the merger agreement.

headline: Canadians Withdraw From Whaling Commission
abstract: Canada announced last night that it was withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission because of a lack of ''any direct interest in the whaling industry or in the related activities of the commission.'' Canada outlawed commercial whaling in 1972.   The Whale Project, a lobbying coalition representing 30 environmental groups, protested the withdrawal, which it called ''a regrettable abdication of responsibility for the survival of the world's whale population.''

headline: FOR A LIFT IN SPIRIT, CHIRAC GOES BACK TO DEEP FRANCE
abstract: The Limousin is to the Auvergne as the Auvergne is to the rest of France. If the Auvergnat farmer, working his beautiful and stubborn hills, stands for conservative and hardbitten solidity, the Limousin farmer works even more stubborn hills, and is harder bitten.   The French call such places Deep France - like Deep South in the United States - as if character were an aspect of topography. When political candidates come through, they tell the locals that this is where real life is lived, in contrast to the pseudoliving that goes on, 200 miles north of here, in Paris. They hope that such talk will persuade the voters to let them go on living in Paris.   ''I need to come here to breathe a little,'' Jacques Chirac told an assemblage of shopkeepers and notables jammed into a room over the Cafe Union the other day. He was here for an afternoon and evening to touch home base in his strenuous campaign for the French presidency.

headline: U.S. TV Plant Set by Koreans
abstract: The Gold Star Company, a large South Korean electronics manufacturer, will build a $5 million television production plant in Huntsville, Ala. that will eventually produce 400,000 color television sets a year, company officials said in New York on Friday.    The new plant, which would eventually employ 1,000, would be the first South Korean factory in the United States, Shinkoo Huh, president of Gold Star, said.

headline: BANK LENDING RATE SET AT RECORD 14% BY FEDERAL RESERVE
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board, struggling to control the growth of the nation's money supply, today increased its bellwether interest rate on loans to commercial banks to 14 percent from 13 percent, a new high.   The increase in this interest rate, called the discount rate, came late in a day of turbulence in the financial markets.  On the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.48 points to 979.11. Brokers said that stock prices fell sharply from the opening because traders had expected interest rates to rise because of Friday's announcement of a sharp increase in the money supply.   By early afternoon, major banks had raised their prime rate a full percentage point, to 19 percent. The prime, an indication of the direction of most interest rates, is described by banks as the rate charged on short-term loans to their best corporate customers, although these loans are often made at a lower rate. (Page D1.)

headline: Advertising; Product Introductions Set Records in May
abstract: May turned out to be the heaviest month for new product entries in the 18-year history of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, according to Martin Friedman, its founder and publisher, who suggested that part of that record-making was because manufacturers introduced new items at food and tobacco conventions held during the month.   In any event, May saw 149 introductions, compared with 118 in May last year, and that figure pushed the five-month total to 536, another record.   Mr. Friedman wrote that the ''hot'' categories at the food convention were soft snack-bars, liquid soaps, ice cream sandwiches, Mexican foods, dried fruits, prepackaged pork cuts and frozen pudding bars.

headline: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VIDEO SALES MAY PASS PREDICTIONS
abstract: Sales of television sets and other video equipment are expected to set records this year and surpass forecasts made as recently as six months ago, according to industry executives interviewed here today at the start of the summer consumer electronics show.   ''Look at the television set,'' said Ray Gates, executive vice president of the Panasonic Company. ''I don't think anyone thought color television sales would be as good as they are.''   At the beginning of the year, most manufacturers had estimated that TV sales this year would be about the same as last year's total of 10.16-million sets, second only to the 10.24 million sets sold in 1978.

headline: Technology; Computers Learn English
abstract: IT used to be that to use a computer a person had to speak the computer's language. Slowly, however, computers are learning to speak people's language.   In laboratories around the nation, scientists are grappling with making computers understand English so that people can communicate ''naturally'' with them.   Development of such natural language systems is part of an effort to make computers easier to use. At the National Computer Conference in Chicago last week, the feature attraction was the Star work station, a computer terminal developed by the Xerox Corporation, which allows its user to point at little pictures on the screen rather than to type commands. Other vendors demonstrated terminals that could recognize voice commands. These developments are expected to help computers become more widely used by businessmen and eventually by consumers who have had no formal computer training.

headline: European Unemployment
abstract: The number of jobless in the European Economic Community stood at 8.3 million in May, 35 percent higher than a year ago, the Common Market's statistics office said today. The figure is little changed from April, but seasonally adjusted unemployment increased by 2.5 percent in May over April, the office said. The number of jobless represented 7.3 percent of the work force in the Common Market's 10 member countries, against 5.4 percent in May 1980, in the nine-member Community before Greece joined.

headline: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Datsun Model
abstract: Nissan U.S.A., the marketer of Datsun automobiles in the United States, said it had introduced a diesel-powered model of the luxury Maxima into its lineup.

headline: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Polish Cardinal to Visit Rome
abstract: Franciszek Cardinal Macharski, interim head of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland after the death of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, will go to Rome this week and is expected to meet with Pope John Paul II, Western diplomatic sources said today.  Cardinal Macharski visited the Pope in Rome about two weeks ago after Cardinal Wyszynski's condition worsened. Cardinal Wyszynski, the Polish Primate and Archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw, died last Thursday of cancer.

headline: TAIWAN ASSAILS U.S. ARMS POLICY
abstract: Taiwan today criticized the United States decision to lift restrictions on arms sales to China, but it praised President Reagan's pledge to provide the Taipei Government with ''defense equipment.''   ''We are deeply concerned over this unfortunate decision, because it is not in the interest of the peace and stability of East Asia and the Pacific region,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

headline: Ford Unit Wins Big Army Contract
abstract: A Ford Motor Company subsidiary won a $159.2 million contract for the first phase of construction of a new mobile antiaircraft gun, the Pentagon announced.

headline: 3 OFFICERS AND 5 OTHERS HELD IN SPAIN IN POSSIBLE PLOT
abstract: Three military officers and five civilians have been arrested in what might have been another attempt to overthrow the Spanish Government.   The arrests yesterday occurred against a backdrop of a crisis inside the governing party of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.  Some members of the Prime Minister's Union of the Democratic Center have demanded that it be dissolved as a party and converted into a coalition.

headline: 2 PUBLISHERS CABLE BID ADVANCES
abstract: Rebuffing a higher offer for a portion of the shares, the board of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. approved a definitive agreement yesterday that brings the fast-growing cable company a step closer to being acquired by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc.   The board accepted a newly sweetened joint offer from the two big publishers of $80 a share in cash for all UA-Columbia shares, or a total price of $264 million.   At the same time, the cable company's board urged shareholders to spurn last week's tender offer by United Artists Theatre Circuit, its single biggest shareholder, of $85 a share for up to 22 percent of the cable company's stock. That offer represented an attempt by the theater chain to thwart the acquisition by the two publishers, who had originally offered $72 a share, then raised it to $75 before finally advancing it yesterday to $80.

headline: KEYSTONE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YOUTH BATTLE TROOPS IN FIVE CITIES IN NORTHERN IRELAND
abstract: Groups of youths battled British troops and the police in Londonderry, Belfast and three other cities today after an emotional funeral for two teenagers killed in disturbances Sunday in Londonderry.   Hundreds of mourners filled two churches for the separate funerals of James Brown, 18 years old, and Gary English, 19, both killed by a British Army Land-Rover.   In his sermon at Mr. Brown's funeral, the Rev. James Doherty denounced British rule in Northern Ireland. ''Justice must not only be done but must be seen to be done,'' he said, ''especially when people whose occupation it is to uphold the law seem to want only to destroy the law.''

headline: EXCERPT'S FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON HUMAN RIGHTS AND FOREIGN POLICY
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech on human rights delivered by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Trilateral Commission in Washington on March 31:   The controversy over American foreign policy and human rights concerns four questions: Firstly, is our concern for human rights in other countries compatible with the pursuit of America's national interest?  Secondly, how does our foreign policy reflect our concern for human rights?  Thirdly, how should we treat violators of human rights?  And the fourth question, how can we advance human rights in the world today?  Unless we can answer these questions, we cannot speak of a human rights policy. And the way we answer these questions tells us a great deal about how we view ourselves as a people and the problems we face today in international affairs.   Let me deal first with the question of whether a concern for human rights is compatible with the pursuit of America's national interest. My answer to this is a resounding yes.

headline: COMMITTEE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON SALVADOR ISSUE
abstract: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved an amendment to the foreign aid bill establishing conditions for military assistance to El Salvador for the fiscal year 1982: FOR THE AMENDMENT - 26 Democrats - 18 Zablocki, Wis.

headline: The Talk of Warsaw
abstract: Being in Poland these days is like living on a roller coaster. It seems that the entire country swings from peaks of optimism to valleys of despair. Lately the peaks and valleys have been coming at breathtaking speed.   Just when the nation was breathing a collective sigh of relief after the independent labor union, Solidarity, called off a general strike that most people felt would push the crisis beyond the brink, Washington again raised the alarm that Soviet troops were massing on the border and could invade within hours. The news ignited a silent panic.

headline: Yamani Sees Unity
abstract: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was quoted yesterday as saying he expects the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on a unified price structure this year. But in an interview with the Beirut English-language weekly Monday Morning, he said he was not hopeful about getting an accord at an OPEC meeting to take place in Geneva at the end of this month. Asked if Saudi Arabia would press for lower uniform oil prices there, Sheikh Yamani said ''That is our hope; however if it doesn't happen in May, it will happen sometime this year.''

headline: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A U.S.-BRITISH TORPEDO FIGHT
abstract: America's traditional dominance of a small but lucrative part of the world defense market - the manufacture of torpedoes for underwater warfare - has been challenged by a British electronics company that says it has developed a new generation of so-called intelligent torpedoes.   The British development comes at a time when the navies of the non-Communist world are preparing to place orders for a new generation of torpedoes, which defense experts estimate could bring manufacturers as much as $16 billion worth of new business over the next 20 years.   The challenger is the Marconi Company, which after nearly 12 years and $400 million of research, has developed a new generation of torpedoes that ''think'' as they swim, a feat that Marconi executives say is five to 10 years ahead of American technology.   In general, United States makers dispute that claim by Marconi.  Spokesmen for both the Gould Corporation of Cleveland and the Honeywell Corporation of Minneapolis said, however, that they could not provide details about the performance capabilities of their torpedoes because of constraints imposed by their contracts with the Defense Department.

headline: Economic Scene; Free Traders' Defeat on Cars
abstract: UNDER heavy pressure from the Reagan Administration, Japan has agreed to impose quotas on its auto shipments to the United States for three years. This was a sharp defeat for the ''free traders'' in the Administration, led by Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, who thought they had already won the internal battle.   On April 15, Mr. Weidenbaum, when asked in an interview with The New York Times whether the Administration had decided against trying to impose quotas on the Japanese, replied: ''Oh, no question. We've taken a strong, adamant position against quotas. In fact, I must admit I got quite a charge out of a senior representative of the previous Administration who made his mark on public policy by negotiating formal orderly marketing agreements urging us in strong terms not to succumb to protectionist sentiment.''

headline: Market Place; Putting Assets To Better Use
abstract: LAST Wednesday, when the American Can Company disclosed plans to sell its paper and forest-products operations to raise cash for new business ventures, the announcement proved a tonic for the company's long-languishing stock. As the day's most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, American Can jumped 4 7/8 points, to 43 3/4.   In 1971 the company's stock traded as high as 45 7/8, a figure that still stands as its highest price of the last 10 years.  American Can's announcement served to exemplify a development that, in one form or another, is sweeping through corporate board rooms.  Kenneth S. Rolland, chief investment officer of the Chemical Bank's trust division, calls it ''asset deployment.'' Stefan D.  Abrams, chairman of the stock selection committee at Oppenheimer & Company, refers to it as ''enterprise restructuring.''

headline: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHEAPER OIL FROM LIBYA IS REPORTED
abstract: A trade report circulated yesterday that an agent for Libya, which is often aggressive in raising oil prices, had offered to sell Libyan crude for $4 a barrel less than that nation's official prices. Oil buyers, however, responded with skepticism.   Platt's Oil Price Report, which monitors worldwide pricing developments, said the unnamed agent had offered crude at $36 a barrel, compared with official prices ranging from $40.30 to $40.78.  Joan Showstead, executive editor of the publication, said that the move apparently had the approval of the Libyan Government.

headline: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Is 'Closed,' Israeli Aide Says
abstract: A dispute that developed this week after Prime Minister Menachem Begin sharply criticized Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany should be regarded as closed, Foreign Minister @Yitzhak Shamir said today.

headline: Ketchum New York Gets a President
abstract: Here's a bit of this and a bit of that from agency land:   - Ketchum New York has been without a president. But now Walter Kaprielian, 46, a 15-year veteran of Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, has just been promoted from executive vice president.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Associates Corporation of North America, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $150 million of 6 percent 20-year senior debentures, underwritten by a Kidder, Peabody group.   * Clabir Corporation filed with the S.E.C. an offering of 30,000 units with an aggregate price of $30,000, each unit consisting of $1,000 principal amount of subordinated debentures due in 2001 and Clabir common shares, through a Shearson Loeb Rhodes group.

headline: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; 30 Priests in South Korea End 3-Day Hunger Strike
abstract: Thirty Roman Catholic priests ended a three-day hunger strike today after the authorities promised to accept their demands for the release of 23 people jailed for involvement in last year's violent Kwangju uprising, a Catholic official said.   Details of the Government's promise were not known, but the priests from the Kwangju diocese had demanded that it pay ''due homage'' to the victims of the Kwangju riot and release the Rev. Kim Seong Yong and 22 other people still imprisoned for their part in the nine-day uprising.

headline: Company News; Playboy Plans Sale Of Oui Magazine
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said that it was close to selling Oui magazine, the less prosperous companion publication to Playboy.  Magazine sources said that the tentative buyer is Goshen Litho Inc., a printing concern owned by Murray Traub, for a price near $1.5 million.

headline: Belgian Bank Lifts Key Interest Rates
abstract: The Belgian National Bank raised its discount rate by three percentage points today, to an unprecedented 16 percent, in an effort to ease the pressure on the Belgian franc.

headline: Indonesia Gas Sales
abstract: Indonesia will start exporting liquefied petroleum gas to the Philippines in July at the rate of 2,000 metric tons a month, the state oil and gas company announced. The gas will come from North Sumatra, where expansion work on a liquefaction plant is to be completed next month, raising daily capacity to 100 tons. The initial price of $190 a ton will be adjusted after Jan. 1, 1982, according to a formula based on the price of Indonesian crude oil.

headline: FIRST CAROLINA INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRW Inc. Predicts Flat First Quarter
abstract: TRW Inc., a diverse automotive, electronics and energy-systems manufacturer, expects this year's first-quarter results to be about the same as last year's, with sales of $1.2 billion, net earnings of $47.9 million and per share profits of $1.30, its chairman, R.H. Mettler, told analysts today.   Despite a slow first half, however, he said TRW expects another good year of sales and earnings growth.

headline: Harris Corp. Wins Argentina Contract
abstract: The Harris Corporation said that it had won an international competition to design and build in Argentina what it called the world's largest domestic satellite communications system. The initial contract is valued at $30 million.

headline: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TURK IS CALLED A PRODUCT OF VIOLENCE IN HIS NATION
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of wounding Pope John Paul II, is a product of the climate of violence that brought Turkey to the brink of a civil war before last September's military takeover.   A young man from an impoverished family in eastern Turkey, Mr. Agca went west to Istanbul to seek his fortune and fell in with a group of right-wing extremists who had chosen terror as a way of life.   The roots of political violence in Turkey are generally traced to the 1968 student uprisings in Western Europe, which were followed by a wave of leftist talk and student demonstrations in Turkey.   There was no serious violence then, but the radical right took fright and began to organize anti-Communist raiding groups. There were inevitable clashes, a few people were killed and the radical left-right vendetta had set in.

headline: Dutch Fighter Plane Crashes
abstract: A Dutch Air Force single-seater F-16 fighter plane crashed into a lake in the north of the country today but the pilot ejected safely, the Defense Ministry here said. It was the second Dutch F-16 plane to crash since the first supersonic fighter was delivered to the air force in June 1979.

headline: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOOKS ANALYZE JAPAN'S METHODS
abstract: With some of the nation's key industries floundering, Americans are turning for enlightenment to the new Mecca of business success: Japan.   Thanks to the surge of interest in Japanese business practices, authors like William G. Ouchi have fallen into unexpected bonanzas.  A professor at the University of California at Los Angeles management school, Mr. Ouchi has just written a book entitled ''Theory Z: How American Business Can Meet the Japanese Challenge.'' Its publisher is a modest concern in Reading, Mass., the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, which is best known for textbooks and self-help tracts.

headline: TECHNICOLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Soviet Union has promised it will continue to give priority to Argentina as a supplier of grain, Argentine officials said here today.   They said the two countries had agreed, in trade talks here, to postpone until the end of this year any discussion on expanding the minimum levels of Soviet grain purchases set in a five-year agreement signed last year.   Argentina has replaced the United States as Moscow's main source of foreign grain since restrictions on American exports to the Soviet Union were imposed in December 1979.

headline: Around the World; Doctor Says Pope Will Lose Some Movement in Finger
abstract: Pope John Paul II will permanently lose some movement in his left index finger, which was struck by a bullet in the assassination attempt two weeks ago, a doctor treating him said today.   Doctors at the Gemelli Hospital also said that the Pope had begun singing Polish religious hymns as part of breathing exercises to avoid pneumonia and other complications affecting the lungs.

headline: Spot Commodity Index Is Ended
abstract: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, is being discontinued with the figures for the week ended last Tuesday. The decision, announced late last year, resulted from budgetary constraints, the bureau said. It also said that the information in the index was available from private sources.

headline: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: C.I.A. CONCLUDED, EX-AIDE SAYS, THAT ISRAEL MADE NUCLEAR ARMS
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency concluded some years ago that Israel had developed nuclear weapons, aided in part by uranium diverted in the mid-1960's from a plant in Pennsylvania, according to a former Deputy Director of the agency.   In an interview this week, Carl Duckett, Deputy Director for Science and Technology from 1967 to 1976, said there had been a ''clear consensus'' in the agency that the ''most likely case'' was that the Israelis had fabricated nuclear weapons with 200 pounds of enriched uranium diverted from a nuclear processing plant of the Nuclear Materials and Equipment Corporation in Apollo, Pa.   ''I believe that all of my senior analysts who worked on the problem agreed with me fully,'' Mr. Duckett said in an ABC News documentary on nuclear weapons and the Middle East.

headline: DOW GAINS BY 12.24 ON OPEC NEWS
abstract: Stocks rallied sharply late yesterday on news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to freeze oil prices at current levels. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.24 points, with virtually all of the advance occurring in the final hour, to finish at 983.96.   That single hour of trading almost overcame the cumulative decline of 14.23 points last week, when the Dow retreated for five straight sessions amid conflicting reports about the strength of the American economy.   Meanwhile, records levels were reached yesterday for both the American Stock Exchange's market-value index, which rose 1.94, to 375.47, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks, which added 1.01, to 220.24.

headline: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BONN SEEKS CHANGES IN JAPAN TRADE RULES
abstract: West German trade officials, dismayed at Europe's failure to negotiate a restraint of Japanese imports, are mounting a final attempt to convince Japan to moderate its exports and relax its import barriers or face European import restrictions.   Trade officials here said that this message would be communicated to Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan when he arrives in West Germany tomorrow for two days of talks with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt at the start of a 13-day tour of Europe.   On Saturday, Bonn's Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, left for Tokyo for four days of talks with Japanese Government officials and industry leaders. He is seeking a relaxation of Japanese import restrictions and assurances that Japan's recent agreement to restrain car exports to the United States would not increase car sales to Europe.

headline: Soviet Said to Arrest Ukrainian
abstract: Soviet dissident sources said today that a Ukrainian lawyer who monitored Soviet compliance with human rights aspects of the 1975 Helsinki accords had been arrested. The dissident, Ivan Kandyba, was taken into custody March 24 in Pustomyny, a Ukrainian town near Lvov, according to the sources. He was arrested in 1961 for discussing Ukrainian secession from the Soviet Union and served five years.

headline: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The changes in party leadership made at a Central Committee meeting early today fell far short of what party members advocating change had demanded, but their overall cause was advanced in a number of areas, diplomatic analysts said today.   The personnel changes were more of a shuffle than a shakeup. Jozef Pinkowski, who served as Prime Minister during much of the crisis and was replaced in mid-February, was dropped from the Politburo. His dismissal was something of a foregone conclusion, since he was widely viewed as ineffective and associated with the party's old guard, now in disrepute.

headline: Earnings at A.& S.  Highest Since 1977
abstract: Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based store chain, raised its earnings in the last fiscal year to the highest level since 1977 despite low margins and ''substantial inventory shortages,'' some of them resulting from thefts.   The earnings gain and the conditions that prevented it from becoming greater were disclosed yesterday in the annual report of Federated Department Stores Inc., the parent company of A.& S., Bloomingdale's and 20 other store divisions.   Federated reported earlier this month that its net income for its 1980 fiscal year was $220 million, compared with $203 million in the previous year, excluding unusual items, on sales of $6.3 billion, compared with $5.8 billion the previous fiscal year.

headline: Auto Output Up for Year
abstract: United States auto production will break the three-million mark this week with companies planning to build 163,772 vehicles, 30.7 percent above the production level for the comparable week a year ago, an industry publication reported today.   Automotive News said output so far this year has been 3.04 million vehicles, two-tenths of 1 percent more than the 3.03 million vehicles built a year ago.

headline: UNCERTAIN VOTE LEAVES IRELAND IN CONFUSION
abstract: The Irish political scene was plunged into confusion today by a parliamentary election that was so close as to be inconclusive.   The prospect was for a period of several days - or even weeks - of backstage negotiating and political horsetrading to see who could form the next government.   Unofficial returns from the election Thursday showed that Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey's Fianna Fail Party had won the largest number of seats in the Parliament, but its position was several votes short of a majority.

headline: BEGIN WIDENS TERMS FOR SYRIAN PULLOUT OF BORDER MISSILES
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today broadened his public demands on Syria, declaring that its recently deployed antiaircraft missiles must be removed not only from Lebanon but also from Syrian territory adjacent to the Lebanese border.   In addition, he said, Syria must make a commitment not to fire missiles from its own territory at Israeli reconnaissance planes operating over Lebanon.   These demands, made in a television interview with the NBC News program ''Today,'' were expected to complicate diplomatic efforts to resolve the conflict over the missiles. Assad Rejected Earlier Demand   President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has already rejected the earlier, more limited Israeli demands for removal of missiles deployed in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon since April 29, and has strongly criticized the Israeli leader for insisting on their removal.

headline: U.S. Steel to Build With Customer Help
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said that it would finance construction of a 600,000-ton seamless-pipe mill through an arrangement in which part of the money would be put up by customers for the mill, which would be built and operated by the nation's largest steel company.   Long-term contracts for pipe would be the main means for borrowing to construct the mill, a company spokesman said.

headline: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business People; A Rail Chief's Benefits
abstract: Richard M. Bressler, 50, who joined Burlington Northern Inc. as president and chief executive officer last June, was given the right in his employment contract to buy 25,000 shares of company's stock for 10 cents a share, according to the proxy statement for the annual meeting. The stock was worth $40.69 a share at that time and closed yesterday at $62.75.

headline: ASIAN PARLEY URGES CAMBODIAN SOLUTION
abstract: The five non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia ended a conference tonight at which they laid the groundwork for their approach to next month's meeting at the United Nations on Vietnam's continuing occupation of Cambodia.   The Foreign Ministers of the Philippines, Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia declared that a political settlement must be based on three initial steps: the introduction of a United Nations peacekeeping force, the withdrawal of the Vietnamese Army and the disarming of the warring Cambodian factions once the Vietnamese have left.   A senior diplomat from one of the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations said that the five countries' strategy was to convince Vietnam that it was in its interest to reach a political settlement that would make Cambodia neutral and thus satisfy Hanoi's security concerns.   ''This is not directed against the interests of Vietnam but the beginning of a common effort to enhance the longer-term interests of the region,'' said Carlos P. Romulo, Foreign Minister of the Philippines. ''Asean urges Vietnam to see the light of reason,'' he said, referring to the regional organization by its initials.

headline: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; The Outlook For Polaroid
abstract: WALL STREET analysts converged on the Polaroid Corporation at Cambridge, Mass., last week with sugar plums dancing in their heads.  When they emerged, the sugar plums had turned a bit sour.   Their disappointment stemmed from an analysts' tour of facilities.  Unlike so many similar treks during Polaroid annual meetings in years past, this one did not result in the disclosure of a major new product line.

headline: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Conrail Sale Gets Backing
abstract: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that 15 major shippers and groups, including the three largest auto makers, had endorsed the Administration's proposal to sell Conrail to private railroads.   But Mr. Lewis raised the possibility that Conrail could be sold intact to a consortium of profitable railroads, avoiding at least some of the economic dislocation that many states, unions and smaller shippers fear could result from the piecemeal sale of lines envisioned in the Reagan Administration plan.

headline: Albania Denies Role in Bombing
abstract: Albanian newspapers said today that Albania's Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister, Reis Malile, had rejected Yugoslavia's accusation that Albania was involved in the bombing of the Yugoslav Embassy in Tirana last week. Mr. Malile reportedly summoned Yugoslavia's Ambassador in Tirana, Branko Komatina, and told him, ''We have never attacked, nor will we ever attack, the Yugoslav Embassy in Tirana.''

headline: FRINGE BENEFITS ON THE TAX BLOCK
abstract: W ITH inflation pushing more people into higher tax brackets, the Government is finding that a larger number of taxpayers are being attracted to fringe benefits that are beyond the reach of the Internal Revenue Service. Although the law considers all noncash benefits to be taxable income unless they are specifically exempted by the tax code, historically such perquisites as bargain air fares for airline employees and free tuition for children of university professors have not been taxed.   These benefits can be worth thousands of dollars to people who work for the ''right'' employers. Take the hypothetical case of a family of four in which the father is an airline executive, the mother is a college professor and the daughter works as a clerk at a retail store. The entire family travels to Europe every summer, lives in a comfortable house provided by the wife's employer and has free use of the school's recreational facilities. The father's company pays for his chauffeur-driven limousine that takes him to and from the office, and also pays for his city luncheon club. Their teen-age son gets a free education at a neighboring college, and the family buys most of its clothes and furniture at a large discount from the store where the daughter works. Such a family's untaxed fringe benefits would easily surpass $20,000 a year.

headline: A Study of British Drunk-Driving
abstract: One person in 10 breaks the drunk-driving laws each week in Britain, according to a report published today by the Office of Health Economics, a research group financed by the pharmaceutical industry. The report said that Britain has 750,000 or more ''problem drinkers'' in its 56 million population.

headline: SMALL BRITISH JET WINS ITS FIRST ORDER
abstract: British Aerospace Ltd. has obtained a firm order from a United States airline for a new jet plane that is smaller than any commercial jet now made by American aircraft manufacturers.   The purchaser of the BAe 146, a four-engine plane, is Air Wisconsin, a commuter airline that operates short-haul flights in the Middle West. Air Wisconsin announced at its annual meeting yesterday that it had bought four of the newly designed planes for $70 million, with an option to buy another four.   The order for the BAe 146, which started to roll off the British company's production line yesterday, is backed by a 10-year, $45 million loan from the British Export Bank. The interest rate is 8 3/4 percent.

headline: Quake Jolts Western Greece
abstract: A strong earth tremor shook western Greece early today, the Athens Seismological Institute said. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

headline: DOW DECLINES BY 3.06 AFTER A DAY OF SWINGS
abstract: Stock prices fell yesterday in an initial reaction to the shooting of Pope John Paul II and then recovered, only to decline again in late trading. Market analysts linked the late setback to weakness in leading energy issues and other blue chips.   Trading volume held to a moderate pace on the New York Stock Exchange at 42.6 million shares, up slightly from Tuesday's 40.4 million.

headline: Good Friday Closings
abstract: Stock and commodity markets in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. European currency markets were also closed, and American currency markets were open only in the morning

headline: WATS Rates Set to Change
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized changes in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's WATS rates that will mean decreased rates for most customers but substantial increases for the heaviest users.   The F.C.C. granted special permission for the new rates for WATS, or Wide Area Telephone Service, to become effective five days after A.T.& T. files its new tariffs, or no later than June 1.
